headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]And now I would like to turn the conference over to your moderator, Managing Director of
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]
And now I would like to turn the conference over to your moderator, Managing Director of Investor Relations, Mr. Dan Cravens.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us on the call this morning is Doug Parker, our Chairman and CEO; Scott Kirby, President; Derek Kerr, our Chief F
componenttext:
Thanks, Anthony, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us on the call this morning is Doug Parker, our Chairman and CEO; Scott Kirby, President; Derek Kerr, our Chief Financial Officer. Also in the room for our question-and-answer session is Robert Isom, our Chief Operating Officer; Elise Eberwein, our EVP of People and Communications; Maya Leibman, our Chief Information Officer; and Steve Johnson, our EVP of Corporate Affairs. 
As is our normal practice, we're going to start the call today with Doug, and he will provide an overview of our fourth quarter and 2015 financial results. Derek will then walk us through the details on the quarter and provide some details on the -- on our 2016 guidance. Scott will then follow with commentary on the revenue environment and our operational performance. And then after we hear from those comments, we will open the call for analysts' questions and lastly, questions from the media. 
Before we begin, we must state that today's call does contain forward-looking statements, including statements concerning future revenues and costs, forecast of capacity, traffic, load factor, fleet plans and fuel prices. These statements represent our predictions and expectations as to future, but numerous risks and uncertainties could cause actual results to differ from those projected. Information about some of these risks and uncertainties can be found on our earnings press release issued this morning and our Form 10-Q for the quarter ended September 30, 2015.
In addition, we'll be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures this morning, such as net profit and CASM, excluding unusual items. A reconciliation to those numbers to the GAAP financial measures is included in the earnings release, and that can be found on our website at aa.com. A webcast of this will also be archived on our website. The information that we're giving you on the call is as of today's date, and we undertake no obligation to update the information subsequently.
So thanks again for joining us this morning, and at this point, we'll turn the call over to our Chairman and CEO, Doug Parker.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan. Thanks for being on. We're pleased to report our fourth quarter and full year results for 2015. It's hard to imagine that just 2 years ago, this American Airlines was emerging from bankruptcy, but we were. In the first year, the company pr
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan. Thanks for being on. We're pleased to report our fourth quarter and full year results for 2015. It's hard to imagine that just 2 years ago, this American Airlines was emerging from bankruptcy, but we were. In the first year, the company produced record profits of $4.2 billion, including special items that with the record that we set in 2014, which was more than double that American ever made in its past. This year, we've exceeded that with the results we released today of $6.3 billion. So a new record beating last year's record for the quarter, a new record of $1.3 billion exceeding last. This is all the result of incredibly hard work and great work by 100,000 employees doing phenomenal job at taking care of customers while we work through an integration, particularly the integration. Just a year ago, the big concern was whether with -- was how much disruption might put upon its customers as we work through integration everyone's have in the past and had difficulties our team had been barred the park. Accomplishing things like frequent flyer integration single reservation system migration. All of those things done flawlessly and again, great credit to a really phenomenal team who's really doing a great job. We still have a lot to do. We're well aware that -- we are well on our way to restoring American as the greatest airline in the world. Our team is doing a phenomenal job. We should be proud of the results. They've produced and very pleased with our outlook given the positioning we have today. 
So with that said, I will turn over to Derek, who will give you a lot more details on the financials and then Scott will follow with some other details preliminary revenue related.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug. Good morning, everybody. In our earnings release filed this morning, we reported record earnings, as Doug said, for both our fourth quarter and full year 2015, excluding net special credits, our fourth quarter net profit was $1.3 billion or
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug. Good morning, everybody. In our earnings release filed this morning, we reported record earnings, as Doug said, for both our fourth quarter and full year 2015, excluding net special credits, our fourth quarter net profit was $1.3 billion or $2 per diluted share. This represents a $182 million improvement versus our fourth quarter 2014 net profit, excluding net special charges. Our fourth quarter 2015 pretax margin, excluding net special charges, increased 2.8 points year-over-year to a record 13.4%. Our 2015 net earnings, excluding net special credits, were up 50% year-over-year to $6.3 billion or $9.12 per diluted share. And this compares to a 2014 net profit excluding net special charges of $4.2 billion or $5.70 per diluted share. 
Our 2015 pretax margin, excluding net special charges, increased by 5.5 points to a record 15.3%. 
Total capacity for the fourth quarter of 2015 was 65.5 billion ASMs, up 0.6% from the same period in 2014, and mainline capacity for the quarter was 58.1 billion ASMs, up 0.5%. Regional capacity for the quarter was up 1.4% to 7.31 billion ASMs. 
In 2015, we did continue our fleet renewal program by investing more than $5.3 billion in new aircraft, providing the company with the youngest and most modern fleet of the U.S. network airlines. In 2015, the company took delivery of 75 new mainline aircraft while retiring 112 aircraft, and the company also added 52 regional aircraft to its fleet, while we removed 31 regional aircraft from the fleet. This program will continue in 2016 when we take delivery of 55 new mainline aircraft, while adding 49 regional aircraft. We expect to remove 92 mainline aircraft and 29 regional aircraft from our fleet in 2016. With these new deliveries, our mainline average age will drop below 10 years, further widening the age gap between American and our network peers. 
Recently, we reached an agreement with Airbus to defer 2 of the 6 2017 A350 aircraft deliveries to 2020. These deferrals should help us match the pace of wide-body deliveries to our projected needs for international flights. This new schedule still has us taking 4 A350s next year as we remain the North American launch customer. 
Our fourth quarter 2015 revenue was negatively impacted by a large capacity increases in certain domestic segments as well as weaker yields in international markets, due principally to foreign currency devaluation. Lower surcharges and continued economic softness in Latin America also contributed to the decline in revenue. For the quarter, total operating revenues were $9.6 billion, down 5.2% year-over-year. Passenger revenues were $8.3 billion, down 5.4%, driven by 8.9% lower yields on a 0.6% increase in system capacity. Cargo revenues were down 17.3%, due primarily to a 15.5% decline in yields, and other operating revenues were relatively flat at $1.1 billion. 
Total RASM in the fourth quarter was $0.1471[ph], down 5.8%, driven primarily by decline in passenger RASM, which was $0.1269 [ph]. As Doug and Scott will give us more detail on our revenue performance. 
Consistent with the first 9 months of 2015, our fourth quarter financial results continue to reflect a significant savings from our -- the year-over-year decline in fuel prices. Our average mainline fuel price including taxes for the fourth quarter of 2015, was $1.50 per gallon, a 40.6% decline from $2.52 per gallon in the fourth quarter last year. Total operating expenses were $8.6 billion, down 7.9% versus the same period last year, due primarily to the decrease in consolidated fuel expense. Operating expenses, excluding net special charges in the fourth quarter of 2015, were $8.1 billion, down 8% year-over-year. Driven by lower fuel costs, fourth quarter mainline cost per ASM, excluding special charges, was $0.1148[ph], down 8.3% year-over-year. If you exclude net special charges and fuel, our mainline cost per ASM was $0.922[ph], up 6.3%. This increase was due primarily to contractual rate increases for our new labor agreements. Regional operating cost per ASM, excluding net special charges in fuel was $0.161 [ph] for the fourth quarter, an increase of 1.5%. Total consolidated CASM in the quarter was up 5.5%, due principally to the contractual labor increases, I've mentioned earlier, and the increased flyer under capacity purchase agreements. 
We ended the fourth quarter with approximately $8.7 billion in total available liquidity comprised of cash and investments of $6.3 billion and $2.4 billion in undrawn revolver capacity. The company also has a restricted cash position of $695 million. These balances reflect the full write-down of $592 million of Venezuela bolivars. 
During the fourth quarter 2015, we did generate $674 million in cash flow from operations, which is adjusted for the write-down of Venezuela bolivars and paid $332 million in scheduled debt payments. 
In the fourth quarter, the company returned approximately $1.2 billion to its shareholders through the payment of $72 million in quarterly dividends and the repurchase of $1.1 billion of common stock or 25.6 million shares. When combined with the dividends and share repurchases during the first 3 quarters of 2015, the company returned approximately $3.9 billion to its shareholders in 2015 and reduced its shares outstanding by 85.1 million shares. In addition, in 2015, the company elected to pay approximately $306 million to cover employee tax withholding obligations on equity awards, further reducing the share count by 7 million. 
Despite volatility in the capital markets during January 2016, the company was able to secure attractive financing rates to fund a portion of its aircraft deliveries. Earlier this month, the company issued approximately $1.1 billion in enhanced equivalent trust certificates at a blended coupon of just under 4%. The proceeds from this financing were used to fund aircraft deliveries in 2015. 
As we indicated on our third quarter call, we would like to provide you with our views on liquidity and leverage. Looking forward, 2016 and '17 will be a peak period for capital expenditures as we spent approximately $4.5 billion on our fleet renewal program. Beginning in 2018, however, our aircraft CapEx will decline from $4.5 billion to approximately $3 billion each year. Our 2016 and '17 nonaircraft CapEx guidance is $1.2 billion each year, and we expect this to decline to an annual rate of approximately $800 million, starting in 2018, as we complete integration of our internal systems. 
In today's earnings and interest rate environment, liquidity is the first and most important metric we look at. We ended the year with $8.7 billion in available liquidity, which is more than we believe is required to run the airline. But given our leverage, we believe it is important to retain liquidity levels higher than our network peers, so we plan to maintain an industry-leading liquidity level of at least $6.5 billion for the foreseeable future. 
As to leverage, under our current plan, we expect our primary metrics such as net debt to EBITDAR to peak in 2016 and then begin declining each year going forward as our CapEx budget declines. 
Turning now to our 2016 guidance. We're forecasting overall system schedule capacity growth to be up approximately 3%, with full year domestic capacity growth of approximately 2%, while international capacity is expected to be up approximately 6%, primarily growth in the Pacific. 
By quarter, mainline capacity breaks down as follows: 57.4 billion ASMs in the first quarter, 63.4 billion in the second, 65.1 billion in the third, and 58.8 billion in the fourth. Regional capacity each quarter is 7.48 billion in the first, 8.29 billion in the second, 8.69 billion in the third and 8.46 billion in the fourth. For the full year 2016, we are forecasting year-over-year total CASM, x special items and fuel, to be up approximately 0.5% to 2.5%. This does not include the effect of labor deals currently being negotiated, but does include all contracts that have been ratified. Mainline CASM, excluding special items and fuel, is projected to be up approximately 1% to 3%, while regional CASM excluding special items of fuel is projected to be down 4% to 6%. By quarter, mainline CASM should be up 1% to 3% for each of the 4 quarters. Regional CASM, excluding special items and fuel, we believe the first quarter to be approximately flat and the second to fourth quarter down approximately 5% to 7%. 
Based on the fuel curve as of January 27, we expect to see another year with significant fuel savings. While other airlines are just beginning to realize these savings, we have directly benefited from lower fuel prices due to our lack of fuel hedges. We are forecasting our 2016 consolidated fuel price to be in the range of $1.20 to $1.25 per gallon. The first quarter is expected to be $1.15 to $1.20; of the second, $1.16 to $1.21; third, $1.21 to $1.26; and fourth, $1.25 to $1.30. While it's still very early in the year, based on these prices, we expect our 2016 consolidated fuel expense to improve by approximately $2 billion year-over-year. 
Using the midpoints of guidance, we have provided along with the PRASM guidance Scott will give, we expect our first quarter pretax margin, excluding special items, to be between 12% and 14%. 
For taxes, as of December 31, 2015, the company had approximately $8 billion of federal net operating losses and $4 billion in state NOLs. Substantially, all of which are expected to be available in 2016 to reduce future federal and state taxable income. The company expects to recognize a provision for income taxes beginning in 2016 at an effective rate of approximately 38%, which will be substantially noncash as a result of having reversed the valuation allowance at the end of the fourth quarter of 2015. 
In terms of CapEx, talked about a little bit, but we expect total gross aircraft CapEx in '16 to be approximately $4.5 billion, of which $1.2 billion will be in the first quarter. For the full year, we expect to invest $1.2 billion in nonaircraft CapEx, which includes many investments to improve our product and operation. We also expect to make $2.4 billion in debt payments throughout the year. 
In conclusion, thanks to the efforts of our more than 100,000 team members. 2015 was another tremendous year for American Airlines. We successfully completed several integration milestones, made significant investments in our product, our people and our fleet, all while producing record earnings. We look forward to another great year in 2016. 
Thank you for your time, and I'll pass it over to Scott for comments on the revenue side.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Derek. And I'd like to start by thanking all the people of American Airlines for a really fantastic job they've been doing in some unusually difficult weather conditions lately. The people of AA continue to make operational progress in the fourth
componenttext:
Thanks, Derek. And I'd like to start by thanking all the people of American Airlines for a really fantastic job they've been doing in some unusually difficult weather conditions lately. The people of AA continue to make operational progress in the fourth quarter and throughout 2015 with improvement in almost all of our operating metrics. It seems like a long time ago, but it was just during the fourth quarter that we completed the most successful reservation system cut over in airline history, so thanks again to the team. Success with that of her. And now that the rest of the migration is behind us, the team has numerous initiatives underway to further improve our operational performance for our employees and customers. 
On the revenue front, our fourth quarter PRASM was down 5.4%. Domestically, consolidated PRASM was down 3%, and we saw the strongest year-over-year performance in Charlotte and second-strongest domestic performance was in DFW, and that's in spite of all the capacity that's been added here. The weakest performance was in Miami, although that's really a function of declining connecting revenues coming from South America. 
Internationally, the strong U.S. dollar and declining international fuel surcharges account for 2.4 points of our total system PRASM decline. The Atlantic was our best-performing international region, with PRASM down 7%. Across the Pacific, PRASM was down 10%, with weakness in both Japan and China, but positive year-over-year PRASM in South Korea and Hong Kong. Latin PRASM was down 17%, but as it's been for a while now, that weakness is concentrated in Brazil and Venezuela, where PRASM was down 40% and 59%, respectively. 
Looking forward, the factors driving year-over-year PRASM declines remain very similar to the last few quarters. Schedule capacity remains elevated in all regions, and Q1 will actually see higher capacity growth than any quarter we saw last year. 
As we move into the second quarter in the back half of the year, however, we expect capacity growth rates to moderate each quarter. While we're now overlapping some of the moves in the dollar from last year, the dollar does continue to strengthen against many currencies around the world such as the Brazilian real. We project that currency and surcharge declines will impact system PRASM by 1.7 points in Q1, which is down from the 2.4 points in Q4. 
As we experienced throughout 2015, we continue to see significant year-over-year competitive growth in Dallas, and we won't see that moderate until the fourth quarter. And the economy, currencies and revenue environment in Brazil and Venezuela continue to deteriorate. We still don't realistically expect any improvement in South America until the Brazilian economy turns around. Given all this, we expect our system PRASM to decline 6% to 8% year-over-year in the first quarter though, as I said, we expect to see smaller declines in 2Q and beyond. 
In conclusion, we passed a significant integration milestone in the fourth quarter. We American Airlines teams doing a great job running the airline, and we're busy making further improvements to the operation and product now that we're past that integration hurdle. Revenue environment remains challenged for the same factors that we experienced in 2015, but we expect the first quarter to mark the bottom and the rest of the year to see an inflection in revenue results.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Operator, we are ready for questions. Thanks, Derek. Thanks, Scott.
componenttext: All right. Operator, we are ready for questions. Thanks, Derek. Thanks, Scott.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Julie Yates from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Julie Yates from Crédit Suisse.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it looks like in the fourth quarter, you guys retained about 20% of the fuel benefit. How are you thinking about the retention rate in 2016 of that expected $2 billion of incremental savings and whether that changes versus what we saw in Q4 seems like
componenttext: So it looks like in the fourth quarter, you guys retained about 20% of the fuel benefit. How are you thinking about the retention rate in 2016 of that expected $2 billion of incremental savings and whether that changes versus what we saw in Q4 seems like we got to see another letdown in the pricing environment in order to keep pace with the tailwind and from the recent decline in crude.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, we don't really -- I always don't really think about it as retention rate. That's an output, not what we're trying to drive to. We're trying to maximize revenue and maximize earnings in the given environment. And we feel pretty good about 8 strai
componenttext: I guess, we don't really -- I always don't really think about it as retention rate. That's an output, not what we're trying to drive to. We're trying to maximize revenue and maximize earnings in the given environment. And we feel pretty good about 8 straight quarters of record profitability at the airline. We feel good about the trajectory that we're on in terms of getting the integration done. now that we're past the integration, it does give us the opportunity to start realizing more synergies, but also moving the ball forward in terms of our operation and in terms of revenue enhancements, doing things like economy and program all kinds of other programs. So we're focused on maximizing revenue and maximizing earnings environment. It is true that what we have seen and everyone has seen that when oil prices go up, you see supply go up and as a result, that puts pressure on airfares, which puts pressure on RASM. I expect that a reversal will happen as well. But when you see if oil prices go up that you will see airfares go up as well. But we are focused on maximizing earnings as opposed to trying to artificially manage to some retention rate.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Understood. And then Scott is there any more granularity you can offer just on the potential impact of segmenting your further in terms of timing or magnitude to revenues?
componenttext: Okay. Understood. And then Scott is there any more granularity you can offer just on the potential impact of segmenting your further in terms of timing or magnitude to revenues?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're -- we don't -- it does give you a good answer yet because second half of the year before we can roll or the first phase of what we're trying to do with our basic economy product and premium economy product out. And we'll have more to come as we get
componenttext: We're -- we don't -- it does give you a good answer yet because second half of the year before we can roll or the first phase of what we're trying to do with our basic economy product and premium economy product out. And we'll have more to come as we get better details around what the attributes of that product will be and exact timing. But it sometime in the second half of the year. But it is something that we're really excited about. And I think it's transformative maybe too strong of a word, but it at least a significant, I think, as the change to ancillary revenues was back in the 2008 time frame. And so we're really quite excited to move forward on those initiatives. But it will be later this year before they're rolled out. and it'll really be 2017 before you see a meaningful impact on revenues.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jamie Baker of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jamie Baker of JPMorgan.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Follow up, I guess, to Julie. The implication of the Q1 guidance that every single dollar of your fuel savings in the first quarter is going to be handed back to employees and passengers. I suppose the good news is that you've got company if there's equal
componenttext: Follow up, I guess, to Julie. The implication of the Q1 guidance that every single dollar of your fuel savings in the first quarter is going to be handed back to employees and passengers. I suppose the good news is that you've got company if there's equally grim. I'm not debating the significance of your profit production, Scott. You shared your optimism that higher fuel could lead to higher improved PRASM. But shouldn't an integrating network be showing positive relative outperformance to the peer set as opposed to going the opposite way? I mean, that doesn't also imply that integration synergies are just nonexistent?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. And look, in 2015, it's a network carriers we actually had the highest profit margin than any of them, which is a pretty good result second year. And we're going to have less year-over-year benefit in the first quarter from a margin pers
componenttext: I don't think so. And look, in 2015, it's a network carriers we actually had the highest profit margin than any of them, which is a pretty good result second year. And we're going to have less year-over-year benefit in the first quarter from a margin perspective than others because we didn't lose billions of dollars last year hedging fuel so that affects the year-over-year comparison. As we talked about in the last earnings call, we -- you got to look at all the factors going on. So I think we are utilizing synergies and are realizing benefits. But we don't have a new credit card deal some of the others have. We are exposed to what's happened in Dallas huge increases in capacity and, in particular, we're exposed to Brazil. I mean, an amazing statistic in Brazil. The first month after the merger closed, Brazil was 6.1% of the combined airlines revenue. In November, it was 2% of our revenue. Just massive declines in both Brazil and Venezuela. Venezuela was something like 2.5%, and that's 0.5% or something now. So just massive declines. Those things don't have anything to do with integration. But they do affect your relative results. And if you want to try to look at high-level data to figure out our performance on a relative basis, I think you probably have to adjust for those things. But in any of that, having the best margins of any of the network carriers in 2015 2 years into the merger, I think, is a pretty good metric for how we're doing.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question -- second question may be for Doug on operations. And I won't mince words here. I mean, Delta is absolutely crushing it. And they're doing it with a fleet that's older than yours, with hubs that are also prone to nasty meteorological conditions.
componenttext: Question -- second question may be for Doug on operations. And I won't mince words here. I mean, Delta is absolutely crushing it. And they're doing it with a fleet that's older than yours, with hubs that are also prone to nasty meteorological conditions. I don't have any background whatsoever in operations, so pardon the ignorance in my question but is it something about management? Are there technological impediments? Is it stuff that you inherited from standalone AMR, something in the labor contracts? I'm not try to beat you up on reliability. I'm just trying to figure out why if Delta can do it, why can't everybody.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Jamie. The biggest thing is we ran 2 airlines for 2015, which is can't stress it enough how much harder that is been running 1 airline. We're extremely proud of what we did. And if you look at what others did in their second year of post-merg
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Jamie. The biggest thing is we ran 2 airlines for 2015, which is can't stress it enough how much harder that is been running 1 airline. We're extremely proud of what we did. And if you look at what others did in their second year of post-merger, where our performance stands up to anybody's and is better. So we're integrating. And as we get through that, we will do better, but the fact that we were even in this considerations with everybody else, which we were, I think was phenomenal results for our people. Thinks like connecting baggage when so many of your customers are traveling on codeshare is much, much more difficult than when they're all flying on 1 code. So those -- you'll see it get better as we move into 2016. And our goal is to be the best at all -- in all these areas and ways to go. We make great strides for an airline that was running 2 airlines. And you'll see us further improving in 2016. Robert is sitting here as well [indiscernible]

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, the only other thing I'd add is just look, we were disproportionally hit by weather. And the vast majority of the completion factor difference between us and Delta is simply related to that. And of course, with that is resultant disruption as well.
componenttext: Jamie, the only other thing I'd add is just look, we were disproportionally hit by weather. And the vast majority of the completion factor difference between us and Delta is simply related to that. And of course, with that is resultant disruption as well. So we're certainly, as Doug said, improving on all fronts, and we think we've got a great plan going forward no matter what comes our way.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I know you're giving targets, but it is a 2017, 2018 event where we should look for potential parity with liability or something like that?
componenttext: And I know you're giving targets, but it is a 2017, 2018 event where we should look for potential parity with liability or something like that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, I think the right thing to take a look at is departing exactly on time. So departure within 0 [ph]. You'll see that we are very, very close, if not almost right on top of Delta. Even today with all the difficulties that Doug described. That's reall
componenttext: Jamie, I think the right thing to take a look at is departing exactly on time. So departure within 0 [ph]. You'll see that we are very, very close, if not almost right on top of Delta. Even today with all the difficulties that Doug described. That's really incredibly important metric and I think indicative of where we're going to be headed. So we're not far off, and I think we're going to be closing the gap pretty quickly.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Hunter Keay from Wolf research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Hunter Keay from Wolf research.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, last July, you were right and you said that industry PRASM wouldn't be positive at least the second half of -- or I'm sorry, the third quarter of '16. You said that once use the bottom and American specific comment, but assuming sort of a flat fuel
componenttext: Scott, last July, you were right and you said that industry PRASM wouldn't be positive at least the second half of -- or I'm sorry, the third quarter of '16. You said that once use the bottom and American specific comment, but assuming sort of a flat fuel or if fuel stays around here or whatever would you care to make the update at an extended through the end of 2016 absent a material change in fuel prices that we're going to have negative industry PRASM probably through the end of this year too?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would prefer not to, but I will since you asked. Look, 6 months ago, when I made that forecast isn't the right word, but it was just a simple mathematical extrapolation of assuming the demand environment doesn't change look out and see what the capacity
componenttext: I would prefer not to, but I will since you asked. Look, 6 months ago, when I made that forecast isn't the right word, but it was just a simple mathematical extrapolation of assuming the demand environment doesn't change look out and see what the capacity environment looks like and supply was going to be growing faster than demand. And so seems like fairly obvious, if unpopular at the time, statement for me. As you pointed out and as we've said, there is for better or worse, a inverse relationship between fuel prices and revenue. So when fuel prices go down, a lot of that gets passed on as benefit to the consumer and the fares go down. The reverse also happens when fuel prices go up. We see revenue go up. And since I made that original prediction in -- 6 months ago, we've seen a pretty big decline in fuel prices. So I don't have any data to suggest the demand has changed at all. But consistent with the view that you shared and that I agree with that there is a correlation between fuel prices and revenue, if anything, I would say that would push that forecast back a quarter or 2 for when we turn to the point where RASM is positive on a year-over-year basis. All that said, that's not really a forecast. That's not looking at data. I don't have any data that's better than yours. Your forecast or anyone on this call is equally as good as mine. It just assumes that the demand environment stays the same. And in that environment, I think just the move in oil would cause that day to push back. Of course, earnings would've gotten the better because some of that benefit would've flown to the bottom line. If I projecting earnings 6 months ago but just the decline in oil would likely to push that back by a quarter or 2.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good. And then this industry's Scott too or Doug this industry had a track record of truly self-destructive behavior on pricing whether we talk about Americans value pricing the 90s or Delta's fares last decade I think each one of those things were
componenttext: Okay. Good. And then this industry's Scott too or Doug this industry had a track record of truly self-destructive behavior on pricing whether we talk about Americans value pricing the 90s or Delta's fares last decade I think each one of those things were good ideas until they were bad ideas when the operating environment changed. So when I see advantage fares, which is a strategy now that your competitor seems to be adopting to I kind of worry about history repeating itself. So can you help me understand how advantage fares might be different from some of those other things and why we shouldn't view them as may be a pricing cancer that can only be undone through some sort of industry rate restructuring if the fuel prices go up again.

componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I understand the question. But to go to something like basic economy is a complete change to our distribution system. It's not really management issue. It's when you go to aa.com to buy your ticket, you need to be offered a basic economy, a r
componenttext: I'm not sure I understand the question. But to go to something like basic economy is a complete change to our distribution system. It's not really management issue. It's when you go to aa.com to buy your ticket, you need to be offered a basic economy, a regular economy, a premium economy, a first-class fare. We're just not set up to sell that way. So it's more about distribution probably than anything else for us.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Linenberg of Deutsche Bank.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, you talked about Venezuela and Brazil. And I'm just curious things have dramatically moved in Argentina as well. And I think you're one of the carriers that are no longer taking, accepting Argentinian pesos. I can be wrong on that. With the devalua
componenttext: Scott, you talked about Venezuela and Brazil. And I'm just curious things have dramatically moved in Argentina as well. And I think you're one of the carriers that are no longer taking, accepting Argentinian pesos. I can be wrong on that. With the devaluation, one, can you give us some color and that market? Number one. Number two, do you have any cash that's in Argentina that obviously is subject to repatriation where there's been some sort of delay.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We are actually accepting Argentina pesos for ticket payments. There have been times in the past where we stopped when we became unable to repatriate cash. We basically keep an amount of Argentina pesos down there that's working capital. It's in the
componenttext: Sure. We are actually accepting Argentina pesos for ticket payments. There have been times in the past where we stopped when we became unable to repatriate cash. We basically keep an amount of Argentina pesos down there that's working capital. It's in the $15 million to $25 million range. And at the moment, we're able to repatriate. We're also encouraged with the new administration. It won't happen overnight they're making positive changes that's going to set Argentina on the road to recovery.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The PRASM declines that you're seeing down there, I mean, similar magnitude to what you're seeing in Brazil, Venezuela or no?
componenttext: The PRASM declines that you're seeing down there, I mean, similar magnitude to what you're seeing in Brazil, Venezuela or no?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Argentina's actually flattish in terms of PRASM. And in South America, other markets are down a little bit, but it is mostly Brazil and Venezuela. I mean, those 2 markets haven't hit bottom yet and continue to deteriorate. The good news -- that's the
componenttext: No. Argentina's actually flattish in terms of PRASM. And in South America, other markets are down a little bit, but it is mostly Brazil and Venezuela. I mean, those 2 markets haven't hit bottom yet and continue to deteriorate. The good news -- that's the bad news. The good news for as is as I've said the amount of revenue exposure we have because they've deteriorated so much is really declined. It is remarkable to think that was our 6% [ph] of our revenues and it's now down in November it's 2% of our revenues. That's an off-peak month on a full year basis be little more than 2%. But just it can only go to 0 and we've already experienced a lot of it decline.

componenttext: Yes. It's all driven by going to large gauges up about 3.8% stage is up about 2.2%. So a lot of that increase is driven by that.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, this one is probably for Scott and Derek. I mean, just on your synergy targets, can you just provide us an update of what you think the total synergies are on the revenue and cost side now and how much you've achieved and how much you expect to c
componenttext: I guess, this one is probably for Scott and Derek. I mean, just on your synergy targets, can you just provide us an update of what you think the total synergies are on the revenue and cost side now and how much you've achieved and how much you expect to come through in 2016?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think on cost, we're largely there in the numbers already. And you have to come revenue synergies the big ones that we said we would do for better connectivity once we get to single reservation system. And when we first started the merger, we said th
componenttext: So I think on cost, we're largely there in the numbers already. And you have to come revenue synergies the big ones that we said we would do for better connectivity once we get to single reservation system. And when we first started the merger, we said the total of that was $300 million codeshare in place between the 2 so we thought that was kind of $150 million left to come, most of which we expect to realize this year. And then another roughly $300 million of route swaps put the right airplanes in the right market. We are just now starting to do that. That really won't get fully ramped up probably until halfway through 2017. We'll do more each month as each month goes along but we want steady state for a couple of years on that one. I think the more interesting thing, which is not technically a synergy, is getting back to running the business and innovating that we were held up from doing because we all we're all heads down focused on getting integration done. So some of that is just blocking and tackling and whether it's in operations are revenue management or IT. We had people whose spending depending on their job, 10% to 50% of their time working on the integration or more for some of them instead of doing their day jobs getting back to the basics of management for example, will be helpful. Getting things implemented like the new frequent flyer program which will happen next year, will be great. Getting basic economy, premium economy done those are all things that we would've done already, but have had to wait. So those aren't technically synergies, but I think they're areas that create more upside for American Airlines than our competitors because we simply have a larger backlog of projects to get done because we we're focused on integration for so long.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess, just wanted to follow up on some comments around capacity growth in your markets. When I look at the schedule in Dallas, in particular, I mean it looks like you guys were absorbing something like 17%, 18% ASM growth in Dallas for t
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess, just wanted to follow up on some comments around capacity growth in your markets. When I look at the schedule in Dallas, in particular, I mean it looks like you guys were absorbing something like 17%, 18% ASM growth in Dallas for the last few quarters call. And that's died down pretty quickly here are. And when I look at what schedule ASM growth in Dallas is in the kind of the first half of this year Q1 and Q2 that number looks like about 4%. So it looks like about a 15 percentage point slowdown. And so I guess, I just wondered how that you kind of fits within the context of some of the commentary that you made earlier.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the capacity growth rate still elevated in Dallas more than the rest of the system through basically all of this year. And once you get past all coming down. They're not as high as they were at this time last year, but they're still having a capacit
componenttext: Well, the capacity growth rate still elevated in Dallas more than the rest of the system through basically all of this year. And once you get past all coming down. They're not as high as they were at this time last year, but they're still having a capacity growth rate of even if it's 5% in Dallas versus 2% everywhere else, it's going to put incremental pressure on Dallas compared to the rest of the system. It's still higher than everywhere else even if it was double digits last year. But the good news -- that's bad news. The good news is we get the and I think we get to a capacity environment in Dallas that's going to be below industry growth rate because we will overlap all the growth field and it's full so...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I can just one last one in. To what extent does your RASM guidance contemplate things like the -- well, I guess, 2 things really one, weather what we've seen so far and then also, the Zika virus potentially impacting bookings down in the
componenttext: Okay. And then if I can just one last one in. To what extent does your RASM guidance contemplate things like the -- well, I guess, 2 things really one, weather what we've seen so far and then also, the Zika virus potentially impacting bookings down in the Latin America and Caribbean.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neither is the answer. On the first point, we had really bad storm., but we have bad storms last year. So for now are just assuming canceling or being similar on the year-over-year basis. And as to the Zika virus, it's obviously early to tell if it'll hav
componenttext: Neither is the answer. On the first point, we had really bad storm., but we have bad storms last year. So for now are just assuming canceling or being similar on the year-over-year basis. And as to the Zika virus, it's obviously early to tell if it'll have an impact on travel. We certainly can't see anything in our data yet. But other -- unlike some other viruses that have had short-term impact an travel in the past is not airborne so there's not a danger of it being transmitted between passengers. And so as of yet, we haven't seen a material change in bookings. For what it's worth, it's also hard to tell very much when you're looking at a place like Brazil where RASM is already down 40% trying to sort out an incremental decline because of the virus I think would be pretty hard for us to tell. But to date, we don't see that much impact.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we think about your integration and potential synergies, wanted to get your thoughts on the capacity footprint of the combined entity. When we look back at Delta and obviously, that was a tougher backdrop, they were about 2% smaller a couple of years p
componenttext: As we think about your integration and potential synergies, wanted to get your thoughts on the capacity footprint of the combined entity. When we look back at Delta and obviously, that was a tougher backdrop, they were about 2% smaller a couple of years post merger. United, actually, in a pretty strong part of the cycle, was about 7% smaller 2 years post integration, and yet you guys are growing in what feels like a weaker RASM environment for you. So why does that make sense?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one [ph] of the comparisons are not accurate. If you look[Audio Gap]spiked to $145 a barrel followed by the Great Recession and every airline, including consolidated Airlines produced capacity. At American, we feel pretty good about our hubs and
componenttext:
Well, one [ph] of the comparisons are not accurate. If you look
[Audio Gap]
spiked to $145 a barrel followed by the Great Recession and every airline, including consolidated Airlines produced capacity. At American, we feel pretty good about our hubs and the fact that they are complementary. We didn't have the kind of overlapping hubs that some others have. We didn't have Cleveland sandwiched in between, Chicago and New York, for example. And so we feel pretty good about the level of capacity that we have. Those airlines at the time they were reducing capacity weren't producing the highest margins of the network carriers we are that's what we did at least in 2015. They weren't producing 15% margin and in that environment, we don't plan to have a significant change our plan.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. I wanted to follow up on Hunter's question with respect to advantage fares. headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: On the A350 deferrals, is that just fuel related or finance...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not at all, Helane. It's just trying to match up wide-body capacity that we have. And in 2017, we have that 787 deliveries and A350 deliveries. So we just wanted to push out the delivery stream a little bit, but it has nothing to do with the financing or
componenttext: Not at all, Helane. It's just trying to match up wide-body capacity that we have. And in 2017, we have that 787 deliveries and A350 deliveries. So we just wanted to push out the delivery stream a little bit, but it has nothing to do with the financing or anything of the sort. It's just matching capacity to what we believe we can fly in 2017.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also, I think in the note, you talked about repaying the advantage loan. So when we -- so I was looking at that you've got 3 and I wanted to ask about the advantage loan and if that's kind of a prelude to getting a new credit card agreement
componenttext: Okay. And then also, I think in the note, you talked about repaying the advantage loan. So when we -- so I was looking at that you've got 3 and I wanted to ask about the advantage loan and if that's kind of a prelude to getting a new credit card agreement a and b, you look at the balance sheet and in the last year, you've managed to improve debt to equity just on balance sheet from 8 to 3-ish and while still raising $2 billion in debt. And I'm kind of wondering, I know you said that we can expect, I guess, an increase in debt financing going forward for the next 2 years. But can you just kind of put some meat on that bone with respect to how we should think about the balance sheet. Is there a target leverage ratio we should think about? And then on the -- and then using the money from fuel cost savings, I think you said $6 billion in total liquidity. So as you get above that, should we think about that as being share repurchase programs?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll answer the first question and then Doug will be and the second question. But the advantage payback happened early in '15, it really that was a loan on a previous at American Airlines on the previous credit card deal. So it has nothing to do with the
componenttext: I'll answer the first question and then Doug will be and the second question. But the advantage payback happened early in '15, it really that was a loan on a previous at American Airlines on the previous credit card deal. So it has nothing to do with the new credit card deal. We were -- it had a rising interest rate over every month, and it got higher than our 6% target of as we've said earlier that we want to pay off any type of debt that is pre-payable and above 6%. And we just we did that, and we did it in early 2015. So it doesn't have anything to do with anything going forward. It was just that than the books that we were able to prepay any prepaid that early '15. And then Doug you want to...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the broad question kind of how do we look at the balance sheet look, or as bullish as we are, we want very much to make sure that we manage the company in a way that we can withstand any sort of large shocks so we think the best way to do that is
componenttext: Yes, on the broad question kind of how do we look at the balance sheet look, or as bullish as we are, we want very much to make sure that we manage the company in a way that we can withstand any sort of large shocks so we think the best way to do that is to ensure we have a large cash balance on hand. Our minimum cash balance that Derek talked about that we've established some around -- of $6.5 billion as a minimum is higher than any other than our large peers. So we're comfortable. We believe that's an important metric and one that we will continue to manage. We do end up as we're bringing on new airplanes and modernizing fleet. obviously, that results in some capital outlays. The -- in today's environment, we can finance those under 4%. And we don't think in its in our shareholder's best interest to forgo those rates. So we will -- as long as rates, we'll continue to do that in fact, over time with a increase start to paying cash, but it doesn't seem to make any sense to do anything but borrow at those rates. So that's what we've been doing. So I expect we would continued to do what the result of that as Derek said in his comments is the kind of metrics we think makes sense balance sheet, which are metrics such as like net debt to EBITDAR. We expect will peak in 2016 better to go forward because the amount of capital is going to decline. So at any rate that's where we are. We're very comfortable with it. We believe that's the best way to manage this. We don't think the right thing to do is to use our cash to buy airplanes right now when we can borrow at 4%. And we believe the right thing to do is hold a very high level -- a higher level of cash and than our peers to offset the fact that we're going to have less free collateral in terms of aircraft because we're going to be financing those. But put it all together, we feel really good about it. We think that's the best way to manage the balance sheet for our shareholders. The other thing I'd probably should note chance to say yet is that indeed we are, in fact, bullish about the prospects here it. This is that's we've noted that we purchased $1.1 billion of our shares in the quarter. That's because we continue to believe they're really good value. In the almost 30 years now that I run this business, I can't remember a bigger disconnect between what we're seeing in our airline and in our forward prospects and what the markets and how the markets treating our stock. So that we believe provides some opportunity to repurchase. And that's what a lot of our cash is going. We think it's the right thing. So as long as the market provides that opportunity, we'll continue to do that. We'll make sure that we have that we stay well above our minimum cash levels are doing that, but the airlines a lot of cash. The market cap doesn't seem to be anywhere close to what the airlines generating cash. So we'll use the excess cash to repurchase shares you can that'll be a good thing for investors as we move forward.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just was kind of wondering, when you talk to investors or the team goes out and talk to investors and you talk about the disconnect you're seeing relative to what the market is interpreting, what are you hearing back that people like me maybe don't unde
componenttext: I just was kind of wondering, when you talk to investors or the team goes out and talk to investors and you talk about the disconnect you're seeing relative to what the market is interpreting, what are you hearing back that people like me maybe don't understand about your company as we look at it?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helane, I wouldn't suggest you didn't understand it. Look, I think this call so far is indicative of what we're hearing. It's you're given -- your not retaining shares are down because fuel prices are down and you're paying your employees more. And it fee
componenttext: Helane, I wouldn't suggest you didn't understand it. Look, I think this call so far is indicative of what we're hearing. It's you're given -- your not retaining shares are down because fuel prices are down and you're paying your employees more. And it feels a lot to me anyway because trees instead of the forest and the reality is we're producing record profits as Scott said margins that are higher than our peers. And not just record profits, this is record for us. I think it's the highest any airlines ever produced. And if you look -- if you actually just look to the cash flow, instead of wishing they were higher, I can't imagine how you think the stock is undervalued. We certainly don't buying it. So I think that's what's being missed. I think people tend to look to expectations if oil is at $30 last year, it was at whatever, how come therefore earnings aren't much higher? There are a lot of reasons we're happy to explain them. But if you went and built a model that's everything happens fuel price is going to result in higher earnings you, of course, are going to be disappointed. There is a real connection between fuel prices and pricing. And indeed, we've got an industry where people where our employees have gone through incredibly difficult times and pay cuts that were going to be when they only get profitable. And that's a good thing. And we're really happy about that. So that's -- so but look, so those things, again maybe I am if anything, maybe we missed if people don't understand those points. But as Scott said also, what I really think this is a business now that is so much dramatically different than anybody seen before they still can't figure it out. And every time you see things like oh oil prices went down and now wages are going up here you guys go again. And nothing can be further from the truth. This is what's happening is industry that's beginning to act like a real industry. And people who have worked hard in the industry getting their compensation back to where it belongs. And that's natural. But that's a real-time run rate kind of issue as opposed to, I think, what people think's going on. So look, it all feels good to us. Were really, really bullish like us had never seen a bigger disconnect. In some sense that's good because we do -- we are excess cash and we use that to buy back our shares at these low rates. But there are investors who get it. And we think they'll do well.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joseph DeNardi with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joseph DeNardi with Stifel.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, just kind of a follow-on to that question. Is there anything from a leverage or debt payment standpoint this year that would prevent capital returns to shareholders in '16 to look like '15?
componenttext: Doug, just kind of a follow-on to that question. Is there anything from a leverage or debt payment standpoint this year that would prevent capital returns to shareholders in '16 to look like '15?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure I fully understand what you mean returns? You mean share repurchases?
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure I fully understand what you mean returns? You mean share repurchases?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Share buybacks, yes.
componenttext: Share buybacks, yes.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we might of course, there are. Things going to be worse than the stock get much closer to fair value. Please don't look at our at anytime at our share repurchase activity as some programmatic number that you should expect to continue over time. We do
componenttext: Yes, we might of course, there are. Things going to be worse than the stock get much closer to fair value. Please don't look at our at anytime at our share repurchase activity as some programmatic number that you should expect to continue over time. We do this based upon what we view as the prospects for the airline as well as what we believe relative value of the equity. So we're not -- this isn't something we're -- it's the same amount every day. We have Scott and Eric and with the help of some of our board members, look at this on a regular basis and decide where we think we should be purchasing based upon those factors I said. So a lot of things could cause a change including the interest rate environment if indeed we get to a point where it is the comes more expensive to borrow against airplanes. We may decide to start paying cash for aircraft. So any of those things could change it. I don't foresee any of those happening by the way, other than perhaps start getting closer to fair value. But nonetheless, that's -- those are the inputs. Earnings prospects, interest rate the alternatives in terms of aircraft financing and our view of evaluation versus the market.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And then just on the balance sheet strategy longer term, I mean, I think if you look at the 2 other investment-grade airlines, they are both premium to the group and you can debate as to why that is. But I'm just wondering if not pursuing an i
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then just on the balance sheet strategy longer term, I mean, I think if you look at the 2 other investment-grade airlines, they are both premium to the group and you can debate as to why that is. But I'm just wondering if not pursuing an investment-grade rating, do you think that will prevent you from benefiting from an eventual re-rating of the sector or otherwise negatively impact your valuation?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't, of course. Look, no is the answer. I think if we -- as a company, you do the right thing and I can't imagine thinks right thing for us right now would be to forgo 4% of financing on new aircraft. And that's the decision you would make if you wan
componenttext: We don't, of course. Look, no is the answer. I think if we -- as a company, you do the right thing and I can't imagine thinks right thing for us right now would be to forgo 4% of financing on new aircraft. And that's the decision you would make if you want that's what you cared about was driving toward an investment-grade rating. We would not be borrowing at 4%. We have paid down all of the high-cost debt in the company. We are investing into the airline. Everywhere we think makes sense and its billions and billions of dollars, as you know. And we're spending and improving this airline in ways that we think are going to provide really nice returns for our investors going forward. And so and again so that comes first then we go to pay down debt then we look to make sure we have enough cash to go forward. And if we have extra cash that belongs to you guys, then we return it to you. That's what we think the right way to do it. We think that's the best way to do for our shareholders. And I believe the market will, indeed, reward that, whether now or later. But that's the right way to manage the cash generated from the company not to go trying to get to some look, in the other point make on this is I don't know what happened if he got to that point. What I know is right now, we're borrowing at well below investment-grade rates as -- so I'm not sure what benefits we get from that point. So look, we care about the rating, of course. We work well with the rating agencies. We just have a different view, I think, than some of our competitors about what the right way to manage -- what the right leverage amounts are. And it doesn't seem to make any sense. It doesn't make sense to us at this point. And again, it's also worth noting that we are well into a fleet modernization program that the others have not begun and one day will need to begin. But that also comes into play here. So as we bring on this debt, it really becomes an incremental question each time as we bring out these aircraft. How are we going to pay for them? And we continue to believe that at these levels, we should do that through debt financing not by using our cash.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just given all the headlines out there, can you talk about American's playbook in a downturn just given the order book that you have and the impact that we have on capacity and cash flows?
componenttext: Just given all the headlines out there, can you talk about American's playbook in a downturn just given the order book that you have and the impact that we have on capacity and cash flows?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I probably can't talk too specifically about it. But we feel like we would be able to manage through a downturn using a lot of the same tools we have in the past. This is a cyclical business, so we know that there will be ups and downs but we're starting
componenttext: I probably can't talk too specifically about it. But we feel like we would be able to manage through a downturn using a lot of the same tools we have in the past. This is a cyclical business, so we know that there will be ups and downs but we're starting from a much better point, a much higher point in the cycle. And while we will have cyclicality and know that in a recessionary environment, earnings will decline. We're starting from a much better point. We expect to remain profitable throughout the cycle, and we'll use the same kinds of tools that we have in the past to respond just be responding from a much stronger position than we have been able to historically.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, there's a lot of macro noise just following up on some of the previous questions. What do you expect to see from corporate clients and business travel spend in 2016? And how much confidence would you place on that outlook today?
componenttext: Scott, there's a lot of macro noise just following up on some of the previous questions. What do you expect to see from corporate clients and business travel spend in 2016? And how much confidence would you place on that outlook today?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't have a perfectly good crystal ball on it, but we saw pretty sizable increases in volume and corporate traffic in the fourth quarter and expect to see that to continue. Our corporate customers are benefiting from a low-fare environment, so yi
componenttext: Well, I don't have a perfectly good crystal ball on it, but we saw pretty sizable increases in volume and corporate traffic in the fourth quarter and expect to see that to continue. Our corporate customers are benefiting from a low-fare environment, so yields are also down. But at some point, I think the pricing environment will start to recover. But corporate demand seems strong from our perspective. And growing it has been all along like all of our customers they're benefiting from the lower yields right now lower fares, translating to lower yields. But my guess is the volume would remain strong. And like the rest of the system, we will start fares in yields recover as we move sequentially through the quarters throughout the year.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then I appreciate American is reporting record earnings here. But with respect to countries that have no foreseeable recovery, why not take a more aggressive approach to managing the business. And I am seeing American replace 777s with 787
componenttext: Understood. And then I appreciate American is reporting record earnings here. But with respect to countries that have no foreseeable recovery, why not take a more aggressive approach to managing the business. And I am seeing American replace 777s with 787s. And there's both ASM and a margin impact from a more efficient aircraft types. So the implication is that there should be some improvement in margins looking ahead that tells a different story than the PRASM declines. I'm just wondering if you can talk about how you're managing your business to the regions that are just getting hit really hard right now.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you're talking about Brazil and Venezuela. And in Brazil, we've got our capacity 22% in the first quarter of '16 versus '14. We canceled 6 markets entirely during that time period. But a wide margin, we've done more -- we've canceled more capacity t
componenttext: Well, you're talking about Brazil and Venezuela. And in Brazil, we've got our capacity 22% in the first quarter of '16 versus '14. We canceled 6 markets entirely during that time period. But a wide margin, we've done more -- we've canceled more capacity than anyone else. I think probably every other carrier that flies between the U.S. and Brazil actually grown over that time period. So we have been proactive. In Venezuela, I don't remember what our capacity is down exactly, but it's north of 50%. So we have it pretty proactive. It's hard to get ahead of -- it's been hard to get ahead of a market -- 2 markets that have been down so much. When you're seeing 40% declines in Brazil, even with those capacity cuts, that's a little hard to get ahead of. But we'll continue to look at the markets. We've been in Brazil for a long time #1 carrier between the U.S. and Brazil. They're going through a rough patch right now. And we're not just going to abandon the country over a rough patch that we expect a recovery eventually. But it's going to be rough for a while.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: It varies market by market. it depends on how much the man you have in the market. So you can't make a generalization one way or another.

I was looking back and before the merger about the time of the merger guess you guys talking about synergies exceeding $1 billion and then at one point, you added another $400 million through some things that you had founded to get closer look at American. Can you really spell out where you are the answers you gave earlier wasn't really clear to me where you are in terms of the synergies that you expected early in the merger to where you are now?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll do my best from memory. To get all those numbers. We had said roughly $600 million of cost synergies, which we think we've achieved, offset by $600 million of labor cost increases. Those were in net 0. So both of those things happen. We said $1 billi
componenttext: I'll do my best from memory. To get all those numbers. We had said roughly $600 million of cost synergies, which we think we've achieved, offset by $600 million of labor cost increases. Those were in net 0. So both of those things happen. We said $1 billion of revenue synergies. That was $300 million through improved frequent flyer program and bigger network. We think we achieved that. We said call it $333 [ph] million. We said 3 things added up to $1 billion. We said that 1/3 of that was coming from route swaps, which I did talk about and said that those are just now we'll take up other of years phase in. And then the other third was coming from connectivity which we said we've got half of it in 2016 and the other half or 2015 the other half will come this year. The $400 million was re-banking the hubs and off-peak scheduling, which we probably believe we've gotten 3 quarters have done so far.

componenttext: Well, we still think capacity increases that will last on a year-over-year basis through August. It's just the year-over-year comparisons that are different.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In all international locations, we have procedures to keep aircraft clean. There are specified programs and we are in close contact with the CDC on any type of changes that would require adjustments to our programs. And right now, we feel like we're in go
componenttext: In all international locations, we have procedures to keep aircraft clean. There are specified programs and we are in close contact with the CDC on any type of changes that would require adjustments to our programs. And right now, we feel like we're in good shape in terms of addressing any issues, whether it's mosquito-borne issues or any others.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttextpreview: Look, as we said, earlier on the call, it's too early to tell. We haven't seen an effect yet. And I think it's important to point out unlike some other viruses in the past that were airborne, this one is not airborne and can be transmitted from one passen
componenttext: Look, as we said, earlier on the call, it's too early to tell. We haven't seen an effect yet. And I think it's important to point out unlike some other viruses in the past that were airborne, this one is not airborne and can be transmitted from one passenger to another. And as a result, you wouldn't expect it would have as big an impact as something like SARS. But today, we haven't seen a measurable impact on bookings.

componenttext: Well, I don't know. What I know is our right now are making 7% more per hour than theirs are. Because we choose to pay our people higher than to offset the fact of profit-sharing. And the rest of their employees are not union and ours unions that give them better work protection. So I think in a wage business, our numbers are going to look awfully similar to theirs in total compensation. That's serving up the driver of the revenue of the margin overperformance of us versus them. I do to be fair to them, the big driver of our outperformance versus them is the fact that they made a that cost them a couple billion dollars. And if you adjust for that, which is what I would argue if I were them, that indeed their margins are higher than ours and we agree with that. They're 5 years ahead of us. Their merger in 2008 we got ours done 2013 we're going to catch them up, but we will. But that's their margins are higher than ours because our margins this year because they had we didn't that cost them a lot of money caused a lot of profit-sharing. And our -- but if you adjust for that margins are higher. We know that and 5 years ahead, we'll catch them.

componenttext: And again, with that said I'm not sure Delta said anyway but anyway Ted if that's what you want to say look, say which is we have made a decision to compensate our people more per month and not have them be subject to the whims of things like Zika viruses and people's concerns about that whether or not there's going to be travel we think we should we think people should be paid what they earn as they earn it as opposed to waiting for the end of year to see if indeed the airlines profit or not. So we put more in our base wages. Delta actually is with very revamp, cut back their profit-sharing significantly put a lot more base wages in response to again what they read anyway. They said their employees told them they prefer they prefer to have more base wages. We believe our employees prefer it that way. So we have more in base wages and we have more in profit-sharing [indiscernible] it's just a different way of compensation and compensating. But when you add it all up, our total compensation and where our people are compensated is I don't know again a very, very close. That is not the difference. Employee compensation is not the difference in our different in our earnings amounts vis-à-vis each other, the big difference is that we lost a lot of money on that we didn't lose. So if you adjust for that, we agree there are ahead of us.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
