Good morning, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]
And now I would like to turn the conference over to your moderator, Managing Director of Investor Relations, Mr. Dan Cravens.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony. And good morning, everyone, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call.Joining us on the call this morning is Doug Parker, our Chairman and CEO; Scott Kirby, President; Derek Kerr, our Chief
componenttext:
Thanks, Anthony. And good morning, everyone, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call.
Joining us on the call this morning is Doug Parker, our Chairman and CEO; Scott Kirby, President; Derek Kerr, our Chief Financial Officer. Also in the room for our question-and-answer session is Robert Isom, our Chief Operating Officer; Elise Eberwein, our EVP of People and Communications; Maya Leibman, our Chief Information Officer; and Steve Johnson, our EVP of Corporate Affairs. As is our normal practice, we're going to start the call today with Doug, and he will provide an overview of our fourth quarter and 2015 financial results. Derek will then walk us through the details on the quarter and provide some details on the -- on our 2016 guidance. Scott will then follow with commentary on the revenue environment and our operational performance. And then after we hear from those comments, we will open the call for analysts' questions; and lastly, questions from the media.
Before we begin, we must state that today's call does contain forward-looking statements, including statements concerning future revenues and costs, forecasts of capacity, traffic, load factor, fleet plans and fuel prices. These statements represent our predictions and expectations as to future events, but numerous risks and uncertainties could cause actual results to differ from those projected. Information about some of these risks and uncertainties can be found in our earnings press release issued this morning and our Form 10-Q for the quarter ended September 30, 2015.
In addition, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures this morning such as net profit and CASM excluding unusual items. A reconciliation to those numbers to the GAAP financial measures is included in the earnings release, and that can be found on our website at aa.com.
The webcast of this will also be archived on our website. The information that we're giving you on the call is as of today's date, and we undertake no obligation to update the information subsequently.
So thanks again for joining us this morning. And at this point, we'll turn the call over to our Chairman and CEO, Doug Parker.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dan. Thanks for everyone for being on.We're pleased to report our fourth quarter and full year results for 2015. It's hard to imagine that, just 2 years ago, this -- American Airlines was emerging from bankruptcy, but we were. In the first ye
componenttext:
Thank you, Dan. Thanks for everyone for being on.
We're pleased to report our fourth quarter and full year results for 2015. It's hard to imagine that, just 2 years ago, this -- American Airlines was emerging from bankruptcy, but we were. In the first year, the company produced record profits of $4.2 billion, excluding special items. That was the record that we set in 2014, which was more than double that American ever made in its past. This year, we've exceeded that with the results we've released today of $6.3 billion, so a new record beating last year's record for the quarter; a new record of $1.3 billion, exceeding last. This is all the result of incredibly hard work and great work by 100,000 employees who are just doing a phenomenal job at taking care of customers while we work through an integration, particularly the [indiscernible] integration. It was just a year ago the big concern was whether or not -- was how much disruption this airline might put upon its customers as we work through integration. As other airlines have, in the past, had difficulties, our team hit the ball out of the park, accomplishing things like frequent flyer integration, single operating certificate, reservations system migration; all of those things done flawlessly. And again, great credit to a really phenomenal team who is doing a great job. We still have a lot to do. We're well aware of that, but we are well on our way to restoring American as the greatest airline in the world. Our team is doing a phenomenal job. We're actually really proud of the results they've produced and very pleased with our outlook given the positioning we have today.
So with that said, I will turn it over to Derek, who will give you a lot more details on the financials. And then Scott will follow with some other details primarily revenue related. Derek?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Doug. Good morning, everybody.In our earnings release filed this morning, we reported record earnings, as Doug said, for both our fourth quarter and full year 2015. Excluding net special credits, our fourth quarter net profit was $1.3 bil
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Doug. Good morning, everybody.
In our earnings release filed this morning, we reported record earnings, as Doug said, for both our fourth quarter and full year 2015. Excluding net special credits, our fourth quarter net profit was $1.3 billion or $2 per diluted share. This represents a $182 million improvement versus our fourth quarter 2014 net profit excluding net special charges. Our fourth quarter 2015 pretax margin, excluding net special charges, increased 2.8 points year-over-year to a record 13.4%.
Our 2015 net earnings, excluding net special credits, were up 50% year-over-year to $6.3 billion or $9.12 per diluted share. And this compares to a 2014 net profit, excluding net special charges, of $4.2 billion or $5.70 per diluted share. Our 2015 pretax margin, excluding net special charges, increased by 5.5 points to a record 15.3%.
Total capacity for the fourth quarter of 2015 was 65.5 billion ASMs, up 0.6% from the same period in 2014. And mainline capacity for the quarter was 58.1 billion ASMs, up 0.5%. Regional capacity for the quarter was up 1.4% to 7.31 billion ASMs.
In 2015, we did continue our fleet renewal program by investing more than $5.3 billion in new aircraft, providing the company with the youngest and most modern fleet of the U.S. network airlines. In 2015, the company took delivery of 75 new mainline aircraft while retiring 112 aircraft. And the company also added 52 regional aircraft to its fleet, while we removed 31 regional aircraft from the fleet. This program will continue in 2016 when we take delivery of 55 new mainline aircraft while adding 49 regional aircraft. We expect to remove 92 mainline aircraft and 29 regional aircraft from our fleet in 2016. With these new deliveries, our mainline average age will drop below 10 years, further widening the age gap between American and our network peers.
Recently, we reached an agreement with Airbus to defer 2 of the 6 2017 A350 aircraft deliveries to 2020. These deferrals should help us match the pace of widebody deliveries to our projected needs for international flights. This new schedule still has us taking 4 A350s next year, as we remain the North American launch customer.
Our fourth quarter 2015 revenue was negatively impacted by large capacity increases in certain domestic segments as well as weaker yields in international markets due principally to foreign currency devaluation. Lower surcharges and continued economic softness in Latin America also contributed to the decline in revenue. For the quarter, total operating revenues were $9.6 billion, down 5.2% year-over-year. Passenger revenues were $8.3 billion, down 5.4%, driven by 8.9% lower yields on a 0.6% increase in system capacity. Cargo revenues were down 17.3% due primarily to a 15.5% decline in yields. And other operating revenues were relatively flat at $1.1 billion.
Total RASM in the fourth quarter was $0.1471, down 5.8%, driven primarily by a decline in passenger RASM, which was $0.1269. And as Doug said, Scott will give us more detail on our revenue performance.
Consistent with the first 9 months of 2015, our fourth quarter financial results continued to reflect the significant savings from our -- the year-over-year decline in fuel prices. Our average mainline fuel price, including taxes, for the fourth quarter of 2015 was $1.50 per gallon, a 40.6% decline from $2.52 per gallon in the fourth quarter last year.
Total operating expenses were $8.6 billion, down 7.9% versus the same period last year due primarily to the decrease in consolidated fuel expense. Operating expenses, excluding net special charges, in the fourth quarter of 2015 were $8.1 billion, down 8% year-over-year. Driven by lower fuel costs, fourth quarter mainline cost per ASM, excluding special charges, was $0.1148, down 8.3% year-over-year. If you exclude net special charges and fuel, our mainline cost per ASM was $0.0922, up 6.3%. This increase was due primarily to contractual rate increases for our new labor agreements. Regional operating cost per ASM, excluding net special charges and fuel, was $0.161 for the fourth quarter, an increase of 1.5%.
Total consolidated CASM in the fourth quarter was up 5.5% due principally to the contractual labor increases I've mentioned earlier and the increased flying under capacity purchase agreements.
We ended the fourth quarter with approximately $8.7 billion in total available liquidity, comprised of cash and investments of $6.3 billion and $2.4 billion in undrawn revolver capacity. The company also has a restricted cash position of $695 million. These balances reflect the full write-down of $592 million of Venezuela bolivars. During the fourth quarter of 2015, we did generate $674 million in cash flow from operations, which is adjusted for the write-down of Venezuela bolivars; and paid $332 million in scheduled debt payments.
In the fourth quarter, the company returned approximately $1.2 billion to its shareholders through the payment of $72 million in quarterly dividends and the repurchase of $1.1 billion of common stock or 25.6 million shares. When combined with the dividends and share repurchases during the first 3 quarters of 2015, the company returned approximately $3.9 billion to its shareholders in 2015 and reduced its shares outstanding by 85.1 million shares. In addition, in 2015, the company elected to pay approximately $306 million to cover employee tax withholding obligations on equity awards, further reducing the share count by 7 million.
Despite volatility in the capital markets during January 2016, the company was able to secure attractive financing rates to fund a portion of its aircraft deliveries. Earlier this month, the company issued approximately $1.1 billion in enhanced equipment trust certificates at a blended coupon of just under 4%. The proceeds from this financing were used to fund aircraft deliveries in 2015.
As we indicated on our Third Quarter Call, we would like to provide you with our views on liquidity and leverage. Looking forward, 2016 and '17 will be a peak period for capital expenditures as we spend approximately $4.5 billion on our fleet renewal program. Beginning in 2018, however, our aircraft CapEx will decline from $4.5 billion to approximately $3 billion each year. Our 2016 and '17 non-aircraft CapEx guidance is $1.2 billion each year, and we expect this to decline to an annual rate of approximately $800 million, starting in 2018, as we complete integration of our internal systems.
In today's earnings and interest rate environment, liquidity is the first and most important metric we look at. We ended the year with $8.7 billion in available liquidity, which is more than we believe is required to run the airline. But given our leverage, we believe it is important to retain liquidity at levels higher than our network peers', so we plan to maintain an industry-leading liquidity level of at least $6.5 billion for the foreseeable future. As to leverage, under our current plan, we expect our primary metrics such as net debt-to-EBITDAR to peak in 2016 and then begin declining each year going forward as our CapEx budget declines.
Turning now to our 2016 guidance. We're forecasting overall system scheduled capacity growth to be up approximately 3%, with full year domestic capacity growth of approximately 2%, while international capacity is expected to be up approximately 6%, primarily growth in the Pacific. By quarter, mainline capacity breaks down as follows: 57.4 billion ASMs in the first quarter, 63.4 billion in the second, 65.1 billion in the third and 58.8 billion in the fourth. Regional capacity each quarter is 7.48 billion in the first, 8.29 billion in the second, 8.69 billion in the third and 8.46 billion in the fourth.
For the full year 2016, we are forecasting year-over-year total CASM, ex special items and fuel, to be up approximately 0.5% to 2.5%. This does not include the effect of labor deals currently being negotiated but does include all contracts that have been ratified. Mainline CASM, excluding special items and fuel, is projected to be up approximately 1% to 3%; while regional CASM, excluding special items and fuel, is projected to be down 4% to 6%. By quarter, mainline CASM should be up 1% to 3% for each of the 4 quarters. Regional CASM, excluding special items and fuel, we believe the first quarter to be approximately flat and the second to fourth quarter down approximately 5% to 7%.
Based on the fuel curve as of January 27, we expect to see another year with significant fuel savings. While other airlines are just beginning to realize these savings, we have directly benefited from lower fuel prices due to our lack of fuel hedges. We are forecasting our 2016 consolidated fuel price to be in the range of $1.20 to $1.25 per gallon. The first quarter is expected to be $1.15 to $1.20; the second, $1.16 to $1.21; third, $1.21 to $1.26; and fourth, $1.25 to $1.30. While it's still very early in the year, based on these prices, we expect our 2016 consolidated fuel expense to improve by approximately $2 billion year-over-year.
Using the midpoints of guidance we have provided, along with the PRASM guidance that Scott will give, we expect our first quarter pretax margin, excluding special items, to be between 12% and 14%.
For taxes, as of December 31, 2015, the company had approximately $8 billion of federal net operating losses and $4 billion in state NOLs, substantially all of which are expected to be available in 2016 to reduce future federal and state taxable income. The company expects to recognize a provision for income taxes, beginning in 2016, at an effective rate of approximately 38%, which will be substantially noncash as a result of having reversed the valuation allowance at the end of the fourth quarter of 2015.
In terms of CapEx, we've talked about it a little bit, but we expect total gross aircraft CapEx in '16 to be approximately $4.5 billion, of which $1.2 billion will be in the first quarter. For the full year, we expect to invest $1.2 billion in non-aircraft CapEx, which includes many investments to improve our products and operation. We also expect to make $2.4 billion in debt payments throughout the year.
In conclusion, thanks to the efforts of our more than 100,000 team members, 2015 was another tremendous year for American Airlines. We successfully completed several integration milestones; made significant investments in our product, our people and our fleet, all while producing record earnings. We look forward to another great year in 2016.
Thank you for your time. And I'll pass it over to Scott for comments on the revenue side.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Derek.And I'd like to start by thanking all the people of American Airlines for a really fantastic job they've been doing in some unusually difficult weather conditions lately. The people of AA continued to make great operational progress in the
componenttext:
Thanks, Derek.
And I'd like to start by thanking all the people of American Airlines for a really fantastic job they've been doing in some unusually difficult weather conditions lately. The people of AA continued to make great operational progress in the fourth quarter and throughout 2015, with improvement in almost all of our operating metrics. It seems like a long time ago, but it was just during the fourth quarter that we completed the most successful reservation system cutover in airline history, so thanks again to the team for such a smooth cutover. And now that the rest of the migration is behind us, the team has numerous initiatives underway to further improve our operational performance for our employees and customers.
On the revenue front, our fourth quarter PRASM was down 5.4%. Domestically, consolidated PRASM was down 3%. And we saw the strongest year-over-year performance in Charlotte. And the second strongest domestic performance was in DFW, and that's in spite of all the capacity that's been added here. The weakest performance was in Miami, although that's really a function of declining connecting revenues coming from South America. Internationally, the strong U.S. dollar and declining international fuel surcharges account for 2.4 points of our total system PRASM decline.
The Atlantic was our best-performing international region, with PRASM down 7%. Across the Pacific, PRASM was down 10%, with weakness in both Japan and China but positive year-over-year PRASM in South Korea and Hong Kong. Latin PRASM was down 17%, but as it's been for a while now, that weakness is concentrated in Brazil and Venezuela where PRASM was down 40% and 59%, respectively.
Looking forward, the factors driving year-over-year PRASM declines remain very similar to the last few quarters. Scheduled capacity remains elevated in all regions, and Q1 will actually see higher capacity growth than any quarter we saw last year. As we move into the second quarter and the back half of the year, however, we expect capacity growth rates to moderate each quarter. While we're now overlapping some of the moves in the dollar from last year, the dollar does continue to strengthen against many currencies around the world such as the Brazilian real. We project that currency and surcharge declines will impact system PRASM by 1.7 points in Q1, which is down from the 2.4 points in Q4.
As we experienced throughout 2015, we continue to see significant year-over-year competitive growth in Dallas, and we won't see that moderate until the fourth quarter. And the economy, currencies and revenue environment in Brazil and Venezuela continue to deteriorate. We still don't realistically expect any improvement in South America until the Brazilian economy turns around. Given all this, we expect our system PRASM to decline 6% to 8% year-over-year in the first quarter, though as I said, we expect to see smaller declines in 2Q and beyond.
In conclusion. We passed a significant integration milestone in the fourth quarter. The American Airlines team is doing a great job running the airline, and we're busy making further improvements to the operation and products now that we're past that integration hurdle. The revenue environment remains challenged by the same factors that we experienced in 2015, but we expect the first quarter to mark the bottom and the rest of the year to see an inflection in revenue results.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. All right, operator, we are ready for questions. Thanks, Derek. Thanks, Scott.
componenttext: Great. All right, operator, we are ready for questions. Thanks, Derek. Thanks, Scott.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it looks like, in the fourth quarter, you guys retained about 20% of the fuel benefit. How are you thinking about the retention rate in 2016 of that expected $2 billion of incremental savings and whether that changes versus what we saw in Q4? It seems
componenttext: So it looks like, in the fourth quarter, you guys retained about 20% of the fuel benefit. How are you thinking about the retention rate in 2016 of that expected $2 billion of incremental savings and whether that changes versus what we saw in Q4? It seems like we'd have to see another letdown in the pricing environment in order to keep pace with the tailwind and from the recent decline in crude.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess we don't really -- I -- we just don't really think about it as retention rates. That's an output, not what we're trying to drive to. We're trying to maximize revenue and maximize earnings in any given environment. And we feel pretty good about 8 s
componenttext: I guess we don't really -- I -- we just don't really think about it as retention rates. That's an output, not what we're trying to drive to. We're trying to maximize revenue and maximize earnings in any given environment. And we feel pretty good about 8 straight quarters of record profitability at the airline. And we feel good about the trajectory that we're on in terms of getting the integration done. Now that we're past the integration, it does give us the opportunity to start realizing more synergies; but also moving the ball forward in terms of our operation and in terms of revenue enhancements, doing things like basic and premium economy. And we've got prior program, all kinds of other programs, so we're focused on maximizing revenue and maximizing earnings in any environment. It is true that what we have seen and everyone has seen, that when oil prices go up, you see supply go up, and as a result, that puts pressure on airfares and which puts pressure on RASM. I expect that the reverse will happen as well, that when you see -- if oil prices go up, that you will see airfares go up as well. But we are focused on maximizing earnings, as opposed to trying to artificially manage to some retention rate.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then Scott, is there any more granularity you can offer just on the potential impact of segmenting your cabin further in terms of timing or magnitude to revenues?
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then Scott, is there any more granularity you can offer just on the potential impact of segmenting your cabin further in terms of timing or magnitude to revenues?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're -- we don't -- I probably won't give you a really good answer yet because we know it will be the second half of the year before we can roll or -- the first phase of what we're planning to do with our basic economy product and premium economy product
componenttext: We're -- we don't -- I probably won't give you a really good answer yet because we know it will be the second half of the year before we can roll or -- the first phase of what we're planning to do with our basic economy product and premium economy product out. And we'll have more to come as we get better details around what the attributes of that product will be and exact timing, but it's sometime in the second half of the year. But it is something that we're really excited about. And I think it's transformative may be too strong of a word, but it's at least as significant, I think, as the change to ancillary revenues was back in the 2008 time frame. And so we're really quite excited to move forward on those initiatives, but it will be later this year before they're rolled out. And it will really be 2017 before you see the meaningful impacts on revenues.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A follow-up, I guess, to Julie. The implication of the Q1 guide is that every single dollar of year-on-year fuel savings in the first quarter is going to be handed back to employees and passengers. I suppose the good news is that you've got company churn
componenttext: A follow-up, I guess, to Julie. The implication of the Q1 guide is that every single dollar of year-on-year fuel savings in the first quarter is going to be handed back to employees and passengers. I suppose the good news is that you've got company churn there as equally grim. I'm not debating the significance of your profit production, Scott. You shared your optimism that higher fuel could lead to higher, improved RASM, but shouldn't an integrating network be showing positive relative outperformance to the peer set, as opposed to going the opposite way? I mean, doesn't this also imply that integration synergies are just nonexistent?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. And look, in 2015, of the network carriers, we actually had the highest profit margins of any of them, which is a pretty good result in your second year. And we are going to have less year-over-year benefit in the first quarter from a ma
componenttext: I don't think so. And look, in 2015, of the network carriers, we actually had the highest profit margins of any of them, which is a pretty good result in your second year. And we are going to have less year-over-year benefit in the first quarter from a margin perspective than others because we didn't lose billions of dollars last year hedging fuel, so that affects the year-over-year comparisons. As we talked about in our last earnings call, we -- you got to look at all the other factors that are going on. So I think we are realizing synergies and are realizing benefits, but we don't have a new credit card deal that some of the others have. We are exposed to what's happened in Dallas, plus huge increases in capacity. And in particular, we're exposed to Brazil. We need an amazing statistic in Brazil. The first month after the merger closed, Brazil was 6.1% of the combined airlines' revenue. In November, it was 2% of our revenue, just massive declines in both Brazil and Venezuela. Venezuela was something like 2.5%, and that's 0.5% or something now. So just massive declines. Those things don't have anything to do with integration, but they do affect your relative results. And so I think you -- if you want to try to look at high-level data to figure out how we're performing on a relative basis, I think you'd probably have to adjust for those things. But in any event, having the best margins of any of the network carriers in 2015, 2 years into the merger, I think, is a pretty good metric for how we're doing.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Question, second question, maybe for Doug, on operations. And I won't mince words here. I mean Delta is absolutely crushing it. And they're doing it with a fleet that's older than yours, with hubs that are also prone to nasty meteorological condition
componenttext: Yes. Question, second question, maybe for Doug, on operations. And I won't mince words here. I mean Delta is absolutely crushing it. And they're doing it with a fleet that's older than yours, with hubs that are also prone to nasty meteorological conditions. I don't have any background, whatsoever in operations, so pardon the ignorance in my question, but is it something about management? Are there technological impediments? Is it stuff that you inherited from stand-alone AMR, something in the labor contracts? I'm not trying to beat you up on reliability. I'm just trying to figure out that why -- if Delta can do it, why can't everybody?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Jamie. It's the biggest thing is we ran 2 airlines through 2015 [indiscernible], which is I can't stress it enough how much harder that is than running 1 airline. And we are extremely proud, I think [ph], of what we did. And if you go look at
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Jamie. It's the biggest thing is we ran 2 airlines through 2015 [indiscernible], which is I can't stress it enough how much harder that is than running 1 airline. And we are extremely proud, I think [ph], of what we did. And if you go look at what others did in their second year of postmerger, we're -- our performance stands up to anybody's and is better. So we were integrating. And as we get through that, we will do better, but the fact that we were even in this consideration set with everybody else, which we were, I think, was phenomenal results by our people. Look, many things like connecting baggage when so many of your customers are traveling on codeshare is much, much more difficult than when they're all flying on 1 code. So those -- you'll see it get better as we move into 2016. And our goal is to be the best at all -- in all these areas, and we've got -- like I say, we got a ways to go, but we made great strides for an airline that was running 2 airlines. And you'll see us further improve in 2016. Robert is sitting here as well. Got anything to add, Robert?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, the only other thing I'd add is just, look, we were disproportionally hit by weather. And the vast majority of the completion factor difference between us and Delta is simply related to that. And of course, with that is resultant disruption as well
componenttext: Jamie, the only other thing I'd add is just, look, we were disproportionally hit by weather. And the vast majority of the completion factor difference between us and Delta is simply related to that. And of course, with that is resultant disruption as well. So we're certainly, as Doug said, improving on all fronts. And we think we've got a great plan going forward no matter what comes our way.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I know you're shy of giving targets, but is it a 2017, 2018 event where we should look for potential parity with -- on dispatcher liability, something like that?
componenttext: And I know you're shy of giving targets, but is it a 2017, 2018 event where we should look for potential parity with -- on dispatcher liability, something like that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, I think the right thing to take a look at, okay, is departing exactly on time, so departure within 0. You'll see that we are very, very close, if not almost right on top of, Delta even today with all the difficulties that Doug described. That's rea
componenttext: Jamie, I think the right thing to take a look at, okay, is departing exactly on time, so departure within 0. You'll see that we are very, very close, if not almost right on top of, Delta even today with all the difficulties that Doug described. That's really an incredibly important metric and, I think, indicative of where we're going to be headed. So we're not that far off, and I think we're going to be closing the gap pretty quickly.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, last July, you were right, and you said that industry PRASM wouldn't be positive until at least the second half of -- or I'm sorry, the third quarter of '16. You said, one, use the bottom. I think that was an American-specific comment, but assuming
componenttext: Scott, last July, you were right, and you said that industry PRASM wouldn't be positive until at least the second half of -- or I'm sorry, the third quarter of '16. You said, one, use the bottom. I think that was an American-specific comment, but assuming sort of a flat fuel or if fuel stays around here or whatever, would you care to maybe update that and extend it through the end of 2016, absent a material change in fuel prices, that we're going to have negative industry PRASM probably through the end of this year too?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would prefer not to, but I will since you asked. Look, 6 months ago, when I made that -- forecast isn't the right word, but it was just a simple mathematical extrapolation of assuming the demand environment doesn't change and, like, to look out and see
componenttext: I would prefer not to, but I will since you asked. Look, 6 months ago, when I made that -- forecast isn't the right word, but it was just a simple mathematical extrapolation of assuming the demand environment doesn't change and, like, to look out and see what the capacity environment looks like. And supply was going to be growing faster than demand. And so it seemed like a fairly obvious, if unpopular, at the time, statement for me. As you pointed out and as we've said, there is a -- for better or worse, a inverse relationship between fuel prices and revenue, so when fuel prices go down, a lot of that gets passed on as benefit to the consumer and fares go down. The reverse also happens. When fuel prices go up, we see revenue go up. Since I made that original prediction in 6 months ago, we've seen a pretty big decline in fuel prices. So I don't have any data to suggest the demand has changed at all, but consistent with the view that you shared and that I agree with that there is a correlation between fuel prices and revenue, if anything, I would say that I would push that forecast back a quarter or 2 for when we return to the point where RASM is positive on a year-over-year basis. All that said, that's not really a forecast. That's not looking at data. I don't have any data that's any better than yours. Your forecast or, anyone on this call, is equally as good as mine. It's it just assumes that the demand environment stays the same. And in that environment, I think just the move in oil would cause that date to push back. Of course, earnings would have gotten better because some of that benefit would have flown to the bottom line, if I had been projecting earnings 6 months ago. But just the decline in oil is likely to push that back by a quarter or 2.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And then this industry is -- also another one for you, Scott, too, or Doug. This industry has a track record of truly self-destructive behavior on pricing. And whether we talk about American's value pricing in the '90s or Delta's simpler fares
componenttext: Okay, good. And then this industry is -- also another one for you, Scott, too, or Doug. This industry has a track record of truly self-destructive behavior on pricing. And whether we talk about American's value pricing in the '90s or Delta's simpler fares last decade, I think each one of those things were good ideas until they were bad ideas when the operating environment changed. So when I see advantage fares, which is a strategy now that your competitor seems to be adopting too, I kind of worry about history repeating itself. So can you help me understand how advantage fares might be different from some of those other things; and why we shouldn't view them as maybe a pricing cancer that can only be undone through some sort of industry restructuring if, say, fuel prices go up again.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Hunter, look, there's lots of low fares in the market. Consumers are having a field day in this environment, particularly with lower oil prices, when there's low fares. But I usually like to answer all the questions that I get asked on an earnings c
componenttext: Well, Hunter, look, there's lots of low fares in the market. Consumers are having a field day in this environment, particularly with lower oil prices, when there's low fares. But I usually like to answer all the questions that I get asked on an earnings call, but on this one, I'm going to demure and just not make commentary about advantage fares.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Savi Syth with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Savi Syth with Raymond James.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Just one question on the domestic side. And as you said, the kind of unit revenue declines moderated a bit here in the fourth quarter. And I was just wondering if that was just a function of not your own capacity moderation or if you've just seen improvements in either kind of the fare environment or how you're managing through it.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I -- look, I think, broadly, in the third, fourth quarters and again into the first quarter, the environments remained broadly the same. There might be small puts and takes here and differences in storms and holidays, peak, offpeak. But broadly, the envir
componenttext: I -- look, I think, broadly, in the third, fourth quarters and again into the first quarter, the environments remained broadly the same. There might be small puts and takes here and differences in storms and holidays, peak, offpeak. But broadly, the environment has been the same for about the last -- the demand environment has been about the same for the last 6 months and expected to main -- to remain some more in the first quarter.

componenttext: And then just on going to that cabin segmentation, I was just kind of curious what the technology investments would let you do that just kind of current-day revenue management technology doesn't let you do.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I understand the question, but to go to something like basic economy is a complete change to our distribution system. It's not really a management issue. It's, when you go to aa.com to buy your ticket, you need to be offered a basic economy o
componenttext: I'm not sure I understand the question, but to go to something like basic economy is a complete change to our distribution system. It's not really a management issue. It's, when you go to aa.com to buy your ticket, you need to be offered a basic economy or a regular economy, a premium economy and first-class fare. And we're just not set up to sell that way, so it's more about distribution probably than anything else for us.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, you talked about Venezuela and Brazil, and I'm just curious. Things have dramatically moved in Argentina as well. And I think you're one of the carriers that are no longer taking, accepting Argentinian pesos. I could be wrong on that. With the deva
componenttext: Scott, you talked about Venezuela and Brazil, and I'm just curious. Things have dramatically moved in Argentina as well. And I think you're one of the carriers that are no longer taking, accepting Argentinian pesos. I could be wrong on that. With the devaluation, one, can you -- just can you give us some color on that market? Number one. Number two, do you have any cash that's in Argentina that obviously is subject to repatriation where there's been some sort of the delay?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We are actually accepting Argentinian pesos for ticket payments. There have been times in the past where we've stopped when we -- when it became -- when we became unable to repatriate cash. We basically keep an amount of Argentinian pesos down there
componenttext: Sure. We are actually accepting Argentinian pesos for ticket payments. There have been times in the past where we've stopped when we -- when it became -- when we became unable to repatriate cash. We basically keep an amount of Argentinian pesos down there that's working capital. It's in a $15 million to $25 million range. And at the moment, we're able to repatriate. We're also encouraged with the new administration. It won't happen overnight, but they're making positive changes that's going to set Argentina on the road to recovery.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The PRASM declines that you're seeing down there, I mean, are they of a similar magnitude to what you're seeing in Brazil and Venezuela, or no?
componenttext: The PRASM declines that you're seeing down there, I mean, are they of a similar magnitude to what you're seeing in Brazil and Venezuela, or no?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Argentina is actually flattish in terms of PRASM. And in South America, other markets are down a little bit, but it is mostly Brazil and Venezuela. I mean those 2 markets haven't hit bottom yet and continue to deteriorate. The good news -- that's the
componenttext: No. Argentina is actually flattish in terms of PRASM. And in South America, other markets are down a little bit, but it is mostly Brazil and Venezuela. I mean those 2 markets haven't hit bottom yet and continue to deteriorate. The good news -- that's the bad news. The good news for us is, as I said, the amount of revenue exposure we have, because they've deteriorated so much, has really declined. I mean it is remarkable to think that, that was over 6% of our revenues, and it's now down in November. It was 2% of our revenues. That's an offpeak month. On a full year basis, it will be a little more than 2%, but just it can only go to 0. And we've already experienced a lot of it, the decline.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just over to Derek. I -- just a question on your regional costs forecast for the year. I mean it's down a lot. And I'm just curious, is that stage? Is that gauge moving more to just larger regional jets? What's driving that?
componenttext: And then just over to Derek. I -- just a question on your regional costs forecast for the year. I mean it's down a lot. And I'm just curious, is that stage? Is that gauge moving more to just larger regional jets? What's driving that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's all driven by going to large -- gauge is up about 3.8%. Stage is up about 2.2%. So a lot of that increase is driven by that.
componenttext: Yes, it's all driven by going to large -- gauge is up about 3.8%. Stage is up about 2.2%. So a lot of that increase is driven by that.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Darryl Genovesi with UBS.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess this one's probably for Scott and Derek. I mean, just on your synergy targets, can you just provide us an update of what you think the total synergies are on the revenue and cost side now and how much you've achieved and how much you expect to com
componenttext: I guess this one's probably for Scott and Derek. I mean, just on your synergy targets, can you just provide us an update of what you think the total synergies are on the revenue and cost side now and how much you've achieved and how much you expect to come through in 2016?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, on costs, we're largely there in the numbers already and yet to come on revenue synergies. The big ones that we've said we would do were better connectivity once we got to a single reservation system. And when we first started the merger, we s
componenttext: So I think, on costs, we're largely there in the numbers already and yet to come on revenue synergies. The big ones that we've said we would do were better connectivity once we got to a single reservation system. And when we first started the merger, we said the total of that was $300 million. We have the codeshare in place between the two, so we thought that was kind of $150 million left to come, most of which we expect to realize this year. And then another roughly $300 million of route swaps, so being able to put the right airplane in the right market, we are just now starting to do that. That really won't get fully ramped up probably until halfway through 2017. We'll do more each month as each month goes along, but we won't be to steady state for a couple of years on that one. I think the more interesting thing, which is not technically a synergy, is getting back to running the business and innovating that we were held up from doing because we're all heads-down focused on getting the integration done. So some of that is just blocking and tackling and whether it's in operations or revenue management or IT. You have people who's -- who are spending, depending on their job, 10% to 50% of their time working on the integration, or more for some of them, instead of doing their day jobs. And getting back to the basics of management, for example, will be helpful. Getting things implemented like the new frequent flyer program, which will happen next year, will be great; getting basic economy and premium economy done. Those are all things that we would have done already but have had to wait. So those aren't technically synergies, but I think they're areas that create more upside for American Airlines than our competitors because we simply have a larger backlog of projects to get done because we were focused on integration for so long.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I guess just I just wanted to follow up on some of your comments around capacity growth in your markets. When I look at the schedule on Dallas in particular, I mean, it looks like you guys were -- you're absorbing something like 17%, 18% ASM grow
componenttext: And then I guess just I just wanted to follow up on some of your comments around capacity growth in your markets. When I look at the schedule on Dallas in particular, I mean, it looks like you guys were -- you're absorbing something like 17%, 18% ASM growth in Dallas for the last few quarters call. And that's died down pretty quickly here. And when I look at what scheduled ASM growth in Dallas is in the kind of the first half of this year, Q1 and Q2, that number looks like about 4%, so it looks like about a 15 percentage point slowdown. And so I guess I just wondered how that kind of fits within the context of some of the commentary that you made earlier.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the capacity growth rate is still elevated in Dallas more than the rest of the system through basically all months of this year. And once we get past August, they will be coming down. But they're not as high as they were at this time last year, but
componenttext: Well, the capacity growth rate is still elevated in Dallas more than the rest of the system through basically all months of this year. And once we get past August, they will be coming down. But they're not as high as they were at this time last year, but they're still having a capacity growth rate of -- even if it's 5% in Dallas versus 2% everywhere else, it's going to put incremental pressure on Dallas compared to the rest of the system. It's still higher than everywhere else even if it was double digits last year, but the good news -- that's the bad news. The good news is when we get to August and I think we'll get to a capacity environment in Dallas that's going to be below industry growth rate because we will have overlapped all the growth at Love Field and it's full. So...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I can just squeeze one last one in. To what extent does your RASM guidance contemplate things like the -- well, I guess, 2 things really: one, weather, what we've seen so far; and then also the Zika virus potentially impacting bookings d
componenttext: Okay. And then if I can just squeeze one last one in. To what extent does your RASM guidance contemplate things like the -- well, I guess, 2 things really: one, weather, what we've seen so far; and then also the Zika virus potentially impacting bookings down into Latin America and the Caribbean?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neither is the answer. On the first point, we had a  really bad storm a week or 2 ago, but we have bad storms last year, so for now we're just assuming those things lined up canceling or being similar on a year-over-year basis. And as to the Zika virus, i
componenttext: Neither is the answer. On the first point, we had a  really bad storm a week or 2 ago, but we have bad storms last year, so for now we're just assuming those things lined up canceling or being similar on a year-over-year basis. And as to the Zika virus, it's obviously a little early to tell if it'll have any impact on travel. We certainly can't see anything in our data yet. But other -- unlike some other viruses that have had short-term impact on air travel in the past Zika is not airborne so there's not a danger of it being transmitted between passengers. And so as of yet, we haven't seen a material change in bookings. For what it's worth, it'll also be hard to tell very much when you're looking at a place like Brazil where RASM is already down 40% trying to sort out an incremental decline because of the virus. I think it would be pretty hard for us to tell. But to date, we don't see much impact.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we think about your integration and potential synergies, wanted to get your thoughts on the capacity footprint of the combined entity. When we look back at Delta and obviously, that was a tougher backdrop, they were about 2% smaller a couple of years p
componenttext: As we think about your integration and potential synergies, wanted to get your thoughts on the capacity footprint of the combined entity. When we look back at Delta and obviously, that was a tougher backdrop, they were about 2% smaller a couple of years post merger. United, actually, in a pretty strong part of the cycle, was about 7% smaller 2 years post integration, and yet you guys are growing in what feels like a weaker RASM environment for you. So why does that make sense?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, [indiscernible] comparisons are not accurate. If you look it just spiked to $145 a barrel followed by the Great Recession and every airline, including nonconsolidated airlines produced capacity. At American, we feel pretty good about our hubs and th
componenttext: Well, [indiscernible] comparisons are not accurate. If you look it just spiked to $145 a barrel followed by the Great Recession and every airline, including nonconsolidated airlines produced capacity. At American, we feel pretty good about our hubs and the fact that they are complementary. We didn't have the kind of overlapping hubs that some others have. We didn't have Cleveland sandwiched in between Chicago and New York, for example. And so we feel pretty good about the level of capacity that we have. Those airlines at the time they were reducing capacity weren't producing the highest margins of the network carriers, we are, but we did at least in 2015. They weren't producing 15% margins and in that environment, we don't plan to have a significant change to our capacity plan.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I wanted to follow up on Hunter's question with respect to advantage fares. Can you talk about -- and this might be something that you can't, but can you talk about the prevalence of those sort of currently relative to where we were 3 to 6 months ag
componenttext: Okay. I wanted to follow up on Hunter's question with respect to advantage fares. Can you talk about -- and this might be something that you can't, but can you talk about the prevalence of those sort of currently relative to where we were 3 to 6 months ago because actually feels like maybe there's -- they're less prevalent now than they were.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, but no, I can't.
componenttext: I'm sorry, but no, I can't.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the A350 deferrals, is that just fuel related or finance...
componenttext: On the A350 deferrals, is that just fuel related or finance...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh no, not at all, Helane. It's just trying to match up wide-body capacity that we have. And in 2017, we have 787 deliveries and A350 deliveries. So we just wanted to push out the delivery stream a little bit, but it has nothing to do with the financing o
componenttext: Oh no, not at all, Helane. It's just trying to match up wide-body capacity that we have. And in 2017, we have 787 deliveries and A350 deliveries. So we just wanted to push out the delivery stream a little bit, but it has nothing to do with the financing or anything of the sort. It's just matching capacity to what we believe we can fly in 2017.

componenttext: We had 2. We had order book at US Airways and order book at American. You put them together and they're a little heavier. They're a little high and wide-body than that time frame, Helane.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then my next question is on the balance sheet, what is the restricted cash specifically related to?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then my next question is on the balance sheet, what is the restricted cash specifically related to?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of that is workers' compensation.
componenttext: Most of that is workers' compensation.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also I think in the note, you talked about repaying the advantage loan. So when we -- so I was looking at that you've got 3 and I wanted to ask about the advantage loan and if that's kind of a prelude to getting a new credit card agreement
componenttext: Okay. And then also I think in the note, you talked about repaying the advantage loan. So when we -- so I was looking at that you've got 3 and I wanted to ask about the advantage loan and if that's kind of a prelude to getting a new credit card agreement a and b, you look at the balance sheet and in the last year, you've managed to improve debt to equity just on balance sheet from 8 to 3-ish and while still raising $2 billion in debt. And I'm kind of wondering, I know you said that we can expect, I guess, an increase in debt financing going forward for the next 2 years but can you just kind of put some meat on that bone with respect to how we should think about the balance sheet? Is there a target leverage ratio we should think about? And then on the -- and then using the money from fuel cost savings, I think you said $6 billion in total liquidity. So as you get above that, should we think about that as being share repurchase programs?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll answer the first question then Doug will beat in on the second question, but the advantage payback happened early in '15. And really that was a loan on the previous -- at American Airlines on the previous credit card deal. So it has nothing to
componenttext: Well, I'll answer the first question then Doug will beat in on the second question, but the advantage payback happened early in '15. And really that was a loan on the previous -- at American Airlines on the previous credit card deal. So it has nothing to do with the new credit card deal. We were -- it had a rising interest rate over every month and it got higher than our 6% target of as we've said earlier that we want to pay off any type of debt that is pre-payable and above 6%. And we just -- we did that and we did it in early 2015. So it doesn't have anything to do with anything going forward. It was just debt on the books that we were able to prepay any we prepaid that early '15. And then Doug you want to...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. Helane it's Doug. On the -- on your, I guess, broad question kind of how do we look at the balance sheet. Look, we're as bullish as we are, we know we want very much to make sure that we manage the company in a way that we can withstand any sor
componenttext: Sure, yes. Helane it's Doug. On the -- on your, I guess, broad question kind of how do we look at the balance sheet. Look, we're as bullish as we are, we know we want very much to make sure that we manage the company in a way that we can withstand any sort of large shocks. So we think the best way to do that is to ensure we have a large cash balance on hand. Our minimum cash balance that Derek talked about that we've established some around -- of $6.5 billion as a minimum, is higher than any other than our large peers. So we're comfortable. We believe that's an important metric and one that we will continue to manage. We do end up as we're bringing on new airplanes and modernizing fleet. We obviously -- that results in some capital outlays. The -- in today's environment, we can finance those under 4%. And we don't think it's in our shareholders' best interest to forgo those rates. So we will -- as long as those rates stay there, we'll continue to do that, if in fact over time they increase the rates, you're starting to pay cash but it doesn't seem to make any sense to do anything but borrow at those rates. So that's what we've been doing. So I expect we would continue to do, what the result of that is, as Derek said in his comments, is the kind of metrics that we think makes sense for in terms of looking at the balance sheet, which are metrics such as like net debt to EBITDAR. We expect will peak in 2016. It'll be better to go forward because the amount of capital is going to decline. So at any rate that's where we are. We're very comfortable with it. We believe we're -- that's the best way to manage this. We don't think the right thing to do is to use our cash to buy airplanes right now when we can borrow at 4%. And we believe the right thing to do is hold a very high level -- a higher level of cash than our peers to offset the fact that we're going to have less free collateral in terms of aircraft because we're going to be financing those but put it all together, we feel really good about it. We think that's the best way to manage the balance sheet for our shareholders. The other thing I'd probably should note because we don't have the chance to say it yet, is that indeed that we are, in fact, bullish about the prospects here it. This is -- we noted that we purchased $1.1 billion of our shares in the quarter. That's because we continue to believe they're a really good value. In the almost 30 years now that I run this business, I can't remember a bigger disconnect between what we're seeing in our airline and in our forward prospects and what the markets and how the market's treating our stock. So that we believe provide us an opportunity to repurchase. And that's what a lot of our cash is going to. We think it's the right thing. So as long as the market provides that opportunity, we'll continue to do that. We'll make sure that we have, that we stay well above our minimum cash levels are doing that but the airlines are throwing up a lot of cash. The market cap doesn't seem to be anywhere close to what the airlines are generating cash. So we'll use the excess cash to repurchase shares and that'll be a good thing for our investors as we move forward.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just was kind of wondering, when you talk to investors or the team goes out and talk to investors and you talk about the disconnect you're seeing relative to what the market is interpreting, what are you hearing back that people like me maybe don't unde
componenttext: I just was kind of wondering, when you talk to investors or the team goes out and talk to investors and you talk about the disconnect you're seeing relative to what the market is interpreting, what are you hearing back that people like me maybe don't understand about your company as we look at it?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helane, I wouldn't suggest you didn't understand it. Well, look, I think this call so far is indicative of what we're hearing. It's gee, you're given -- you're not retaining it, the fares are down because fuel prices are down and you're paying your employ
componenttext: Helane, I wouldn't suggest you didn't understand it. Well, look, I think this call so far is indicative of what we're hearing. It's gee, you're given -- you're not retaining it, the fares are down because fuel prices are down and you're paying your employees more. And it feels a lot, to me anyway, like focusing on the trees instead of the forest. And the reality is we are producing record profits as Scott said a couple of times now that margins that are higher than our peers and not just record profits, this is record for us I think it's the highest any airline has ever produced. And if you look -- if you actually just look to the cash flow, instead of wishing they were higher, I can't imagine how you think the stock is undervalued. We certainly don't that's why we're buying it. So I think that's what's being missed. I think people tend to look to expectations and say, "Gee if oil is at $30 last year, it was at whatever, how come therefore earnings aren't much higher?" There are a lot of reasons for that, we're happy to explain them. But if you went and build a model that said everything that happens in fuel price is going to result in higher earnings, you, of course, are going to be disappointed. There is a real connection between fuel prices and pricing. And indeed, we've got an industry where people, where our employees have gone through incredibly difficult times and pay cuts that were going to be restored when they only get profitable. And that's a good thing. And we're really happy about that. So that's -- so but look, so those things, again, I guess maybe if anything, maybe we missed it when I explain that, Helane, to people, if people don't understand those points. But as Scott said also, look, what I really think this is a business now that is so much dramatically different than anybody's ever seen before that they can't, they still can't figure it out. And every time you see things like, oh, oil prices went down and now wages are going up, here you guys go again. And nothing can be further from the truth. This is -- what's happening is, it's an industry that's beginning to act like a real industry, and people who have worked hard in the industry getting their compensation back to where it belongs, and that's natural. But that's a real-time run rate kind of issue as opposed to, I think, what people think is going on. So look, it all feels good to us. We are really, really bullish and like I say, I've never seen a bigger disconnect. In some sense that's good because we do -- we are throwing up excess cash and we'll use that to buy back our shares at these low rates but there are investors who get it. And we think they'll do well.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joseph DeNardi with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joseph DeNardi with Stifel.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, just kind of a follow-on to the capital deployment question. Is there anything from a leverage or debt payment standpoint this year that would prevent capital returns to shareholders in '16 to look like '15?
componenttext: Doug, just kind of a follow-on to the capital deployment question. Is there anything from a leverage or debt payment standpoint this year that would prevent capital returns to shareholders in '16 to look like '15?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure I fully understand what you mean by the returns? You mean share repurchases?
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure I fully understand what you mean by the returns? You mean share repurchases?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Share buybacks, yes.
componenttext: Share buybacks, yes.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, of course there are. Things can be worse, the stock can get much closer to fair value. Please don't look at our -- at any time at our share repurchase activity as some programmatic number that you should expect to continue over time. We do this
componenttext: Well, yes, of course there are. Things can be worse, the stock can get much closer to fair value. Please don't look at our -- at any time at our share repurchase activity as some programmatic number that you should expect to continue over time. We do this based upon what we view as the prospects for the airline as well as what we believe is a relative value of the equity. So we're not -- this isn't something we're -- it's the same amount every day. We have Scott and Derek, and with the help of some of our board members, look at this on a regular basis and decide where we think we should be purchasing based upon those factors I said. So a lot of things could cause a change including the interest rate environment if indeed we get to a point where it is -- it becomes more expensive to borrow against airplanes. We may decide to start paying cash for aircraft. So any of those things could change it. I don't foresee any of those happening by the way, other than perhaps it start getting closer to fair value. But nonetheless, that's -- those are the inputs. Earnings prospects, interest rate, the alternatives in terms of aircraft financing and our view of valuation versus the market.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And then just on the balance sheet strategy longer term, I mean, I think if you look at the 2 other investment-grade airlines, they're both -- they've orchestrated their premium to the group and you could debate as to why that is but I'm just
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then just on the balance sheet strategy longer term, I mean, I think if you look at the 2 other investment-grade airlines, they're both -- they've orchestrated their premium to the group and you could debate as to why that is but I'm just wondering if not pursuing an investment-grade rating, do you think that will prevent you from benefiting from an eventual re-rating of the sector or otherwise negatively impact your valuation?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't, of course. Look, no is the answer. I think if we -- as a company, you do the right thing and I can't imagine any one thing is the right -- the right thing for us right now would be to forgo 4% of financing on new aircraft. And that's the decisio
componenttext: We don't, of course. Look, no is the answer. I think if we -- as a company, you do the right thing and I can't imagine any one thing is the right -- the right thing for us right now would be to forgo 4% of financing on new aircraft. And that's the decision you would make if you want to come -- if that's what you cared about was driving toward an investment-grade rating. We would not be borrowing at 4%. We have paid down all the high-cost debt in the company. We are investing into the airline, everywhere we think makes sense and its billions and billions of dollars, as you know. And we're spending and improving this airline in ways that we think are going to provide really nice returns for our investors going forward, so, and again there were -- so that comes first then we go to pay down debt, then we look to make sure we have enough cash to go forward and if we have extra cash that belongs to you guys, then we return it to you. That's what we think the right way to do it is. We think that's the best thing to do for our shareholders. And I believe the market will, indeed, reward that, whether now or later. That's the right way to manage the cash generated from the company not to go trying to get to some -- look, and the other point maybe I should make on this is I don't know what happen if we got to that point. What I know is right now, we're borrowing at well below investment-grade rates as -- so I'm not sure what benefit we get from getting to that point. So look, we care about the rating, of course. We work well with the rating agencies. We just have a different view, I think, than some of our competitors about what the right way to manage -- what the right leverage amounts are. And it doesn't seem to make any sense. It doesn't make sense to us at this point. And again it's also worth noting that we are well into a fleet modernization program that the others have not begun and one day will need to begin. But that also comes into play here. So as we bring on this debt, it really becomes an incremental question each time as we bring on these aircraft. How are we going to pay for them? And we continue to believe at these levels, we should do that through debt financing not by using our cash.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just given all the headlines out there, can you talk about American's playbook in a downturn just given the order book that you have and the impact that we have on capacity and cash flows?
componenttext: Just given all the headlines out there, can you talk about American's playbook in a downturn just given the order book that you have and the impact that we have on capacity and cash flows?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I probably can't talk too specifically about it but we feel like we would be able to manage through a downturn using a lot of the same tools that we have in the past. This is a cyclical business, so we know that there will be ups and downs but we're
componenttext: Look, I probably can't talk too specifically about it but we feel like we would be able to manage through a downturn using a lot of the same tools that we have in the past. This is a cyclical business, so we know that there will be ups and downs but we're starting from a much better point, a much higher point in the cycle. And while we will have cyclicality and know that in a recessionary environment, earnings would decline, we're starting from a much better point. We expect to remain profitable throughout the cycle and we'll use the same kinds of tools that we have in the past to respond about -- we'll just be responding from a much stronger position than we have been able to historically.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just in terms of your updated capacity guide for the year. Did I hear you correctly that, that moved up above the midpoint and if so, why?
componenttext: And just in terms of your updated capacity guide for the year. Did I hear you correctly that, that moved up above the midpoint and if so, why?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moved up above the midpoint of...
componenttext: Moved up above the midpoint of...
