componenttext: Just one question on the domestic side. I noticed that the kind of unit revenue declines moderated a bit here in the fourth quarter. And I was just wondering if that was just a function of not -- your own capacity moderation or if you've seen improvements in either kind of the fare environment or how you're managing through it.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I -- look, I think, broadly, in the third, fourth quarters and again into the first quarter, the environments remained broadly the same. There might be small puts and takes here and differences in storms and holidays, peak, offpeak. But broadly, the envir
componenttext: I -- look, I think, broadly, in the third, fourth quarters and again into the first quarter, the environments remained broadly the same. There might be small puts and takes here and differences in storms and holidays, peak, offpeak. But broadly, the environment has been the same for about the last -- the demand environment has been about the same for the last 6 months and expected to main -- to remain similar in the first quarter.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just on going to that cabin segmentation, I was just kind of curious what the technology investments would let you do that just kind of current-day revenue management technology doesn't let you do.
componenttext: And then just on going to that cabin segmentation, I was just kind of curious what the technology investments would let you do that just kind of current-day revenue management technology doesn't let you do.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I understand the question, but to go to something like basic economy is a complete change to our distribution system. It's not really a yield management issue, it's when you go to aa.com to buy your ticket, you need to be offered a basic econ
componenttext: I'm not sure I understand the question, but to go to something like basic economy is a complete change to our distribution system. It's not really a yield management issue, it's when you go to aa.com to buy your ticket, you need to be offered a basic economy or a regular economy, a premium economy, a first-class fare. I mean, we're just not set up to sell that way. So it's more about distribution, probably, than anything else for us.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, you talked about Venezuela and Brazil, and I'm just curious, things have dramatically moved in Argentina as well. And I think you're one of the carriers that are no longer taking, accepting Argentinian pesos. I could be wrong on that. With the deva
componenttext: Scott, you talked about Venezuela and Brazil, and I'm just curious, things have dramatically moved in Argentina as well. And I think you're one of the carriers that are no longer taking, accepting Argentinian pesos. I could be wrong on that. With the devaluation, one, can you -- just can you give us some color on that market? Number one. Number two, do you have any cash that's in Argentina that obviously is subject to repatriation where there's been some sort of delay?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, we are actually accepting Argentinian pesos for ticket payments. There have been times in the past where we've stopped, when we -- when it became -- when we became unable to repatriate cash. But we basically keep an amount of Argentinian pesos down
componenttext: Sure, we are actually accepting Argentinian pesos for ticket payments. There have been times in the past where we've stopped, when we -- when it became -- when we became unable to repatriate cash. But we basically keep an amount of Argentinian pesos down there that's working capital. It's in the $15 million to $25 million range. And at the moment, we're able to repatriate. We're also encouraged with the new administration. It won't happen overnight, but they're making positive changes that's going to set Argentina on the road to recovery.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The PRASM declines that you're seeing down there, I mean, are they of a similar magnitude to what you're seeing in Brazil and Venezuela, or no?
componenttext: The PRASM declines that you're seeing down there, I mean, are they of a similar magnitude to what you're seeing in Brazil and Venezuela, or no?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Argentina is actually flattish in terms of PRASM. And in South America, other markets are down a little bit, but it is mostly Brazil and Venezuela. I mean, those 2 markets haven't hit bottom yet and continue to deteriorate. The good news -- that's the
componenttext: No. Argentina is actually flattish in terms of PRASM. And in South America, other markets are down a little bit, but it is mostly Brazil and Venezuela. I mean, those 2 markets haven't hit bottom yet and continue to deteriorate. The good news -- that's the bad news. The good news for us is, as I said, the amount of revenue exposure we have, because they've deteriorated so much, has really declined. I mean, it is remarkable to think that, that was over 6% of our revenues, and it's now down, in November, it was 2% of our revenues. That's an offpeak month. On a full year basis, it will be a little more than 2%, but just, it can only go to 0. And we've already experienced a lot of it, the decline.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just over to Derek. I -- just a question on your regional costs forecast for the year. I mean, it's down a lot. And I'm just curious, is that stage? Is that gauge moving more to just larger regional jets? What's driving that?
componenttext: And then just over to Derek. I -- just a question on your regional costs forecast for the year. I mean, it's down a lot. And I'm just curious, is that stage? Is that gauge moving more to just larger regional jets? What's driving that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's all driven by going to large -- gauge is up about 3.8%. Stage is up about 2.2%. So a lot of that increase is driven by that.
componenttext: Yes, it's all driven by going to large -- gauge is up about 3.8%. Stage is up about 2.2%. So a lot of that increase is driven by that.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Darryl Genovesi with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Darryl Genovesi with UBS.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess this one's probably for Scott and Derek. I mean, just on your synergy targets, can you just provide us an update of what you think the total synergies are on the revenue and cost side now and how much you've achieved and how much you expect to com
componenttext: I guess this one's probably for Scott and Derek. I mean, just on your synergy targets, can you just provide us an update of what you think the total synergies are on the revenue and cost side now and how much you've achieved and how much you expect to come through in 2016?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, on costs, we're largely there in the numbers already and yet to come on revenue synergies. The big ones that we've said we would do were better connectivity once we got to a single reservation system. And when we first started the merger, we s
componenttext: So I think, on costs, we're largely there in the numbers already and yet to come on revenue synergies. The big ones that we've said we would do were better connectivity once we got to a single reservation system. And when we first started the merger, we said the total of that was $300 million. We had a codeshare in place between the two, so we thought that was kind of $150 million left to come, most of which we expect to realize this year. And then another roughly $300 million of route swaps, so being able to put the right airplane in the right market, we are just now starting to do that. That really won't get fully ramped up probably until halfway through 2017. We'll do more each month as each month goes along, but we won't be to steady state for a couple of years on that one. I think the more interesting thing, which is not technically a synergy, is getting back to running the business and innovating that we were held up from doing because we were all heads down focused on getting the integration done. So some of that is just blocking and tackling. And whether it's in operations or revenue management or IT, you have people who's -- who are spending, depending on their job, 10% to 50% of their time working on the integration, or more for some of them, instead of doing their day jobs. And getting back to the basics of yield management, for example, will be helpful. Getting things implemented, like the new frequent flyer program, which will happen next year, will be great; getting basic economy and premium economy done. Those are all things that we would have done already but have had to wait. So those aren't technically synergies, but I think they're areas that create more upside for American Airlines than our competitors because we simply have a larger backlog of projects to get done because we were focused on integration for so long.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I guess, just I just wanted to follow up on some of your comments around capacity growth in your markets. When I look at the schedule in Dallas in particular, I mean, it looks like you guys were -- you're absorbing something like 17%, 18% ASM gro
componenttext: And then I guess, just I just wanted to follow up on some of your comments around capacity growth in your markets. When I look at the schedule in Dallas in particular, I mean, it looks like you guys were -- you're absorbing something like 17%, 18% ASM growth in Dallas for the last few quarters, call it. And that's died down pretty quickly here. And when I look at what scheduled ASM growth in Dallas is in the kind of the first half of this year, Q1 and Q2, that number looks like about 4%, so it looks like about a 15 percentage point slowdown. And so I guess I just wondered how that kind of fits within the context of some of the commentary that you made earlier.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the capacity growth rate is still elevated in Dallas more than the rest of the system through basically August of this year. And once we get past August, they will be coming down. They're not as high as they were at this time last year, but they're
componenttext: Well, the capacity growth rate is still elevated in Dallas more than the rest of the system through basically August of this year. And once we get past August, they will be coming down. They're not as high as they were at this time last year, but they're still having a capacity growth rate of -- even if it's 5% in Dallas versus 2% everywhere else, it's going to put incremental pressure on Dallas compared to the rest of the system. It's still higher than everywhere else, even if it was double digits last year, but the good news -- that's the bad news. The good news is when we get to August and I think we get to a capacity environment in Dallas that's going to be below industry growth rate, because we will have overlapped all the growth at Love Field and it's full, so...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I can just squeeze one last one in. To what extent this year does your RASM guidance contemplate things like the -- well, I guess, 2 things really: winter weather, what we've seen so far; and then also the Zika virus potentially impactin
componenttext: Okay. And then if I can just squeeze one last one in. To what extent this year does your RASM guidance contemplate things like the -- well, I guess, 2 things really: winter weather, what we've seen so far; and then also the Zika virus potentially impacting bookings down into Latin America and the Caribbean?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neither, is the answer. On the first point, we had a really bad storm a week or 2 ago, but we had bad storms last year. So for now, we're just assuming those things wind up canceling or being similar on a year-over-year basis. And as to the Zika virus, it
componenttext: Neither, is the answer. On the first point, we had a really bad storm a week or 2 ago, but we had bad storms last year. So for now, we're just assuming those things wind up canceling or being similar on a year-over-year basis. And as to the Zika virus, it's obviously a little early to tell if it'll have any impact on travel. We certainly can't see anything in our data yet. But other -- unlike some other viruses that have had short-term impact on air travel in the past, Zika is not airborne, so there's not a danger of it being transmitted between passengers. And so as of yet, we haven't seen a material change in bookings. For what it's worth, it'll also be hard to tell very much, when you're looking at a place like Brazil, where RASM is already down 40%, trying to sort out an incremental decline because of the virus I think would be pretty hard for us to tell. But to date, we don't see much impact.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we think about your integration and potential synergies, wanted to get your thoughts on the capacity footprint of the combined entity. When we look back at Delta, and obviously, that was a tougher backdrop. They were about 2% smaller a couple of years
componenttext: As we think about your integration and potential synergies, wanted to get your thoughts on the capacity footprint of the combined entity. When we look back at Delta, and obviously, that was a tougher backdrop. They were about 2% smaller a couple of years post-merger. United, actually, in a pretty strong part of the cycle, was about 7% smaller 2 years post-integration. And yet you guys are growing in what feels like a weaker RASM environment, at least for you. So why does that make sense?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one, I think the comparisons are not accurate. If you look at what Delta did on their reduction, it was because oil prices spiked to $145 -- it wasn't really the merger, it was because oil prices spiked to $145 a barrel, followed by the Great Recess
componenttext: Well, one, I think the comparisons are not accurate. If you look at what Delta did on their reduction, it was because oil prices spiked to $145 -- it wasn't really the merger, it was because oil prices spiked to $145 a barrel, followed by the Great Recession, and every airline, including nonconsolidated airlines, reduced capacity. At American, we feel pretty good about our hubs and the fact that they are complementary. We didn't have the kind of overlapping hubs that some others have. We didn't have Cleveland sandwiched in between Chicago and Newark, for example. And so we feel pretty good about the level of capacity that we have. Those airlines at the time they were reducing capacity weren't producing the highest margins of the network carriers. We are, or we did, at least in 2015. They weren't producing 15% margins and in that environment, we don't plan to have a significant change to our capacity plan.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I wanted to follow up on Hunter's question with respect to Advantage Fares. Can you talk about -- and this might be something that you can't, but can you talk about the prevalence of those sort of currently, relative to where we were 3 to 6 months a
componenttext: Okay. I wanted to follow up on Hunter's question with respect to Advantage Fares. Can you talk about -- and this might be something that you can't, but can you talk about the prevalence of those sort of currently, relative to where we were 3 to 6 months ago, because I actually feel like maybe there's -- they are less prevalent now than they were.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, but no, I can't.
componenttext: I'm sorry, but no, I can't.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Helane Becker with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Helane Becker with Cowen and Company.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the A350 deferrals, is that jet fuel-related or finance?
componenttext: On the A350 deferrals, is that jet fuel-related or finance?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh no, not at all, Helane. It's just trying to match up wide-body capacity that we have. And in 2017, we have 787 deliveries and A350 deliveries. So we just wanted to push out the delivery stream a little bit, but it has nothing to do with financing or an
componenttext: Oh no, not at all, Helane. It's just trying to match up wide-body capacity that we have. And in 2017, we have 787 deliveries and A350 deliveries. So we just wanted to push out the delivery stream a little bit, but it has nothing to do with financing or anything of the sort. It's just matching capacity to what we believe we can fly in 2017.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had 2 -- we had an order book at US Airways and an order book at American. You put them together and they were a little heavier -- they were a little high on wide-bodies in that time frame, Helane, so we're just smoothing that out.
componenttext: We had 2 -- we had an order book at US Airways and an order book at American. You put them together and they were a little heavier -- they were a little high on wide-bodies in that time frame, Helane, so we're just smoothing that out.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then my next question is on the balance sheet, what is the restricted cash specifically related to?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then my next question is on the balance sheet, what is the restricted cash specifically related to?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of that is workers' compensation.
componenttext: Most of that is workers' compensation.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also, I think in the note, you talked about repaying the Advantage loan. So when we -- so I was looking at that, you've got 3 -- I wanted to ask about the Advantage loan and if that's kind of a prelude to getting a new credit card agreement
componenttext: Okay. And then also, I think in the note, you talked about repaying the Advantage loan. So when we -- so I was looking at that, you've got 3 -- I wanted to ask about the Advantage loan and if that's kind of a prelude to getting a new credit card agreement, a. And b, you look at the balance sheet and in the last year, you've managed to improve debt to equity just on balance sheet from 8 to 3-ish and while still raising $2 billion in debt. And I'm kind of wondering, I know you said that we can expect, I guess, an increase in debt financing going forward for the next 2 years, but can you just kind of put some meat on that bone with respect to how we should think about the balance sheet? Is there a target leverage ratio we should think about? And then on the -- and then using the money from fuel cost savings, I think you said $6 billion in total liquidity. So as you get above that, should we think about that as being share repurchase programs?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll answer the first question then Doug will feed in on the second question, but the Advantage payback happened early in '15. And really, that was a loan on a previous -- at American Airlines on the previous credit card deal. So it has nothing to d
componenttext: Well, I'll answer the first question then Doug will feed in on the second question, but the Advantage payback happened early in '15. And really, that was a loan on a previous -- at American Airlines on the previous credit card deal. So it has nothing to do with the new credit card deal. We were -- it had a rising interest rate over every month and it got higher than our 6% target of, as we've said earlier that we want to pay off any type of debt that is pre-payable and above 6%. And we just -- we did that and we did it in early 2015. So it doesn't have anything to do with anything going forward. It was just debt on the books that we were able to prepay, and we prepaid that early '15. And then Doug you want to...?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. Helane, it's Doug. On the -- on your, I guess, broad question kind of how do we look at the balance sheet. Look, we're, as bullish as we are, we know we want very much to make sure that we manage the company in a way that we can withstand any s
componenttext: Sure, yes. Helane, it's Doug. On the -- on your, I guess, broad question kind of how do we look at the balance sheet. Look, we're, as bullish as we are, we know we want very much to make sure that we manage the company in a way that we can withstand any sort of large shocks. So we think the best way to do that is to ensure we have a large cash balance on hand, or a minimum cash balance that Derek talked about that we've established of around, of $6.5 billion as a minimum, is higher than any other than our large peers. So we're comfortable. We believe that's an important metric and one that we will continue to manage. We do end up, as we're bringing on new airplanes and modernizing the fleet, we obviously -- that results in some capital outlays. The -- in today's environment, we can finance those at under 4%. And we don't think it's in our shareholders' best interest to forgo those rates. So we will -- as long as those rates stay there, we'll continue to do that. And if in fact over time they increase, you may see us starting to pay cash, but it doesn't seem to make any sense to do anything but borrow at those rates. So that's what we've been doing, and I expect we would continue to do. What the result of that is, as Derek said in his comments, is the kind of metrics that we think makes sense for in terms of looking at the balance sheet, which are metrics such as like net debt to EBITDAR, we expect will peak in 2016, and it's only going to get better as we go forward, because the amount of capital is going to decline. So at any rate, that's where we are. We're very comfortable with it. We believe we're -- that's the best way to manage this. We don't think the right thing to do is to use our cash to buy airplanes right now when we can borrow at 4%. And we believe the right thing to do is hold a very high level of -- a higher level of cash than our peers to offset the fact that we're going to have less free collateral in terms of aircraft because we're going to be financing those. But put it all together, we feel really good about it. We think that's the best way to manage the balance sheet for our shareholders. The other thing I probably should note, because we haven't had a chance to say it yet, is that indeed, that we are in fact bullish about the prospects here. This is -- we noted that we purchased $1.1 billion of our shares in the quarter. That's because we continue to believe they're a really good value. In the almost 30 years now that I've been in this business, I can't remember a bigger disconnect between what we're seeing in our airline and in our forward prospects and what the markets and how the market's treating our stock. So that we believe provides us an opportunity to repurchase. And that's what a lot of our cash is going to. We think it's the right thing. So as long as the market provides that opportunity, we'll continue to do that. We'll make sure that we have, that we stay well above our minimum cash levels as we're doing that, but the airline's throwing off a lot of cash. The market cap doesn't seem to be anywhere close to what the airline is generating in cash. So we'll use the excess cash to repurchase shares and that'll be a good thing for our investors as we move forward.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just was kind of wondering, when you talk to investors or the team goes out and talks to investors and you talk about the disconnect you're seeing relative to what the market is interpreting, what are you hearing back that people like me maybe don't und
componenttext: I just was kind of wondering, when you talk to investors or the team goes out and talks to investors and you talk about the disconnect you're seeing relative to what the market is interpreting, what are you hearing back that people like me maybe don't understand about your company as we look at it?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helane, I wouldn't suggest you didn't understand it. Well, look, I think this call so far is indicative of what we're hearing. It's gee, you're given -- you're not retaining it, the fares are down because fuel prices are down and you're paying your employ
componenttext: Helane, I wouldn't suggest you didn't understand it. Well, look, I think this call so far is indicative of what we're hearing. It's gee, you're given -- you're not retaining it, the fares are down because fuel prices are down and you're paying your employees more. And it feels a lot, to me anyway, like focusing on the trees instead of the forest. And the reality is we are producing record profits, as Scott said a couple of times now, that margins are higher than our peers. And not just record profits, this is record for us, I think it's the highest any airline has ever produced. And if you look -- if you actually just looked through the cash flow, instead of wishing they were higher, I can't imagine how you think the stock is undervalued. We certainly don't, that's why we're buying it. So I think that's what's being missed. I think people tend to look to expectations and say, "Gee, if oil is at $30, last year, it was at whatever, how come therefore earnings aren't much higher?" There are a lot of reasons for that, we're happy to explain them. But if you went and built a model that said everything that happens in fuel price is going to result in higher earnings, you, of course, are going to be disappointed. There is a real connection between fuel prices and pricing. And indeed, we've got an industry where people, where our employees, have gone through incredibly difficult times and pay cuts, that were going to be restored when the airline got profitable. And that's a good thing. And we're really happy about that. So that's -- so but look, so those things, again, I guess maybe if anything, maybe we missed it by not explaining that well to people, if people don't understand those points. But as Scott said also, look, what I really think this is a business now that is so much dramatically different than anybody's ever seen before that they can't, they still can't figure it out. And every time you see things like, oh, oil prices went down and now wages are going up, here you guys go again. And nothing can be further from the truth. This is -- what's happening is, it's an industry that's beginning to act like a real industry, and people who have worked hard in the industry getting their compensation back to where it belongs, and that's natural. But that's a real-time run rate kind of issue, as opposed to, I think what people think is going on. So look, it all feels good to us. We are really, really bullish and like I say, I've never seen a bigger disconnect. In some sense that's good, because we do -- we are throwing off excess cash and we'll use that to buy back our shares at these low rates, but there are investors who get it. And we think they'll do well.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joseph DeNardi with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joseph DeNardi with Stifel.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, just kind of a follow-on to the capital deployment question. Is there anything from a leverage or debt payment standpoint this year that would prevent capital returns to shareholders in '16 to look like '15?
componenttext: Doug, just kind of a follow-on to the capital deployment question. Is there anything from a leverage or debt payment standpoint this year that would prevent capital returns to shareholders in '16 to look like '15?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure I fully understand, what do you mean by the returns? You mean share repurchases?
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure I fully understand, what do you mean by the returns? You mean share repurchases?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Share buybacks, yes.
componenttext: Share buybacks, yes.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, of course there are. Things could be worse, the stock can get much closer to fair value. Please don't look at our -- at any time at our share repurchase activity as some programmatic number that you should expect to continue over time. We do th
componenttext: Well, yes, of course there are. Things could be worse, the stock can get much closer to fair value. Please don't look at our -- at any time at our share repurchase activity as some programmatic number that you should expect to continue over time. We do this based upon what we view as the prospects for the airline as well as what we believe is the relative value of the equity. So we're not -- this isn't something we're -- it's the same amount every day. We have Scott and Derek, and with the help of some of our board members, look at this on a regular basis and decide where we think we should be purchasing based upon those factors I said. So a lot of things could cause it to change, including the interest rate environment. If indeed we get to a point where it is -- it becomes more expensive to borrow against airplanes, we may decide to start paying cash for aircraft. So any of those things could change it. I don't foresee any of those happening, by the way, other than perhaps the stock getting closer to fair value. But nonetheless, that's -- those are the inputs. Earnings prospects, interest rate, the alternatives in terms of aircraft financing and our view of valuation versus the market.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then just on the balance sheet strategy longer term, I mean, I think if you look at the 2 other investment-grade airlines, they're both -- they both trade at a premium to the group and you could debate as to why that is. But I'm just wonde
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then just on the balance sheet strategy longer term, I mean, I think if you look at the 2 other investment-grade airlines, they're both -- they both trade at a premium to the group and you could debate as to why that is. But I'm just wondering if not pursuing an investment-grade rating, do you think that will prevent you from benefiting from an eventual re-rating of the sector or otherwise just negatively impact your valuation?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't, of course. Look, no is the answer. I think if we -- as a company, you do the right thing and I can't imagine anyone thinks the right, the right thing for us right now would be to forgo 4% of financing on new aircraft. And that's the decision you
componenttext: We don't, of course. Look, no is the answer. I think if we -- as a company, you do the right thing and I can't imagine anyone thinks the right, the right thing for us right now would be to forgo 4% of financing on new aircraft. And that's the decision you would make if you wanted to come -- if that's all you cared about, was driving toward an investment-grade rating. We would not be borrowing at 4%. We have paid down all the high-cost debt in the company. We are investing into the airline, everywhere we think makes sense, and its billions and billions of dollars, as you know. And we're spending and improving this airline in ways that we think are going to provide really nice returns for our investors going forward. So, and again, there were -- so that comes first. Then we go to pay down debt, then we look to make sure we have enough cash to go forward and if we have extra cash, that belongs to you guys, and we return it to you. That's what we think the right way to do it is. We think that's the best thing to do for our shareholders. And I believe the market will indeed reward that, whether now or later. That's the right way to manage the cash generated from the company, not to go trying to get to some -- look, and the other point I really should make on this is I don't know what would happen if we got to that point. What I know is right now, we're borrowing at well below investment-grade rates as -- so I'm not sure what benefit we get from getting to that point. So look, we care about the rating, of course. We work well with the rating agencies. We just have a different view, I think, than some of our competitors about what the right way to manage -- what the right leverage amounts are. And it doesn't seem to make any sense, it doesn't make sense to us at this point. And again, it's also worth noting that we are well into a fleet modernization program that the others have not begun and one day will need to begin. But that also comes into play here. So as we bring on this debt, it really becomes an incremental question each time as we bring on these aircraft. How do we want to pay for them? And we continue to believe at these levels, we should do that through debt financing, not by using our cash.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just given all the headlines out there, can you talk about American's playbook in a downturn, just given the order book that you have and the impact that would have on capacity and cash flows?
componenttext: Just given all the headlines out there, can you talk about American's playbook in a downturn, just given the order book that you have and the impact that would have on capacity and cash flows?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I probably can't talk too specifically about it, but we feel like we would be able to manage through a downturn using a lot of the same tools that we have in the past. This is a cyclical business, so we know that there will be ups and downs. But we'
componenttext: Look, I probably can't talk too specifically about it, but we feel like we would be able to manage through a downturn using a lot of the same tools that we have in the past. This is a cyclical business, so we know that there will be ups and downs. But we're starting from a much better point, a much higher point in the cycle, and while we will have cyclicality and know that in a recessionary environment earnings would decline, we're starting from a much better point. And we expect to remain profitable throughout the cycle and we'll use the same kinds of tools that we have in the past to respond, although we'll just be responding from a much stronger position than we have been able to historically.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just in terms of your updated capacity guide for the year, did I hear you correctly that, that moved up above the midpoint, and if so, why?
componenttext: And just in terms of your updated capacity guide for the year, did I hear you correctly that, that moved up above the midpoint, and if so, why?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Moved up above the midpoint of...?
componenttext: Moved up above the midpoint of...?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just where you guided to as far as capacity growth for '16 today versus before.
componenttext: Just where you guided to as far as capacity growth for '16 today versus before.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we had given 1 to 3 and we're just at the high end of the 3 for the whole -- for full year. And it's really driven by the international, that we're adding more international lines than what we had. But no big difference from what I had guided befo
componenttext: I think we had given 1 to 3 and we're just at the high end of the 3 for the whole -- for full year. And it's really driven by the international, that we're adding more international lines than what we had. But no big difference from what I had guided before.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan McKenzie with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan McKenzie with Buckingham Research.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, there's a lot of macro noise, just following up on some of the previous questions. What do you expect to see from corporate clients on business travel spend in 2016? And how much confidence would you place on that outlook today?
componenttext: Scott, there's a lot of macro noise, just following up on some of the previous questions. What do you expect to see from corporate clients on business travel spend in 2016? And how much confidence would you place on that outlook today?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't have a particularly good crystal ball on it, but we saw pretty sizable increases in volume in corporate traffic in the fourth quarter and expect to see that continue. Our corporate customers are benefiting from a low-fare environment, so yie
componenttext: Well, I don't have a particularly good crystal ball on it, but we saw pretty sizable increases in volume in corporate traffic in the fourth quarter and expect to see that continue. Our corporate customers are benefiting from a low-fare environment, so yields are also down. But at some point, I think the pricing environment will start to recover. But corporate demand seems strong from our perspective and growing. It has been all along. Like all of our customers, they're benefiting from lower yields right now, lower fares translating to lower yields. But my guess is that volume would remain strong. And like the rest of the system, we will start to see fares and yields recover as we move sequentially through the quarters throughout the year.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then I appreciate American is reporting record earnings here, but with respect to countries that have no foreseeable recovery, why not take a more aggressive approach to managing the business? And I am seeing American replace 777s with 787
componenttext: Understood. And then I appreciate American is reporting record earnings here, but with respect to countries that have no foreseeable recovery, why not take a more aggressive approach to managing the business? And I am seeing American replace 777s with 787s. And so there's both an ASM and a margin impact from a more efficient aircraft type. So the implication is that there should be some improvement in margins looking ahead that tells a different story than the PRASM declines. I'm just wondering if you can talk about how you're managing your business to the regions that are just getting hit really hard right now.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you're talking about Brazil and Venezuela. And in Brazil, we've cut our capacity 22% in the first quarter of '16 versus '14. We canceled 6 markets entirely during that time period. By a wide margin, we've done more -- we've canceled more capacity th
componenttext: Well, you're talking about Brazil and Venezuela. And in Brazil, we've cut our capacity 22% in the first quarter of '16 versus '14. We canceled 6 markets entirely during that time period. By a wide margin, we've done more -- we've canceled more capacity than anyone else. I think probably every other carrier that flies between the U.S. and Brazil has actually grown over that time period. So we have been proactive. In Venezuela, I don't remember what our capacity is down exactly, but it's north of 50%. So we have been pretty proactive. It's hard to get ahead of -- it's been hard to get ahead of a market, 2 markets that have been down so much. When you're seeing 40% declines in Brazil, even with those capacity cuts, that's a little hard to get ahead of. But we'll continue to look at the markets. We've been in Brazil for a long time as the #1 carrier between the U.S. and Brazil. They're going through a rough patch right now. And we're not just going to abandon the country over a rough patch that we expect to recover eventually, but it's going to be rough for a while.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is the margin differential between the 787 and the 777 different or is it roughly the same?
componenttext: And is the margin differential between the 787 and the 777 different or is it roughly the same?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, it varies market by market. It depends on how much demand you have in the market. So you can't make a generalization one way or another.
componenttext: Look, it varies market by market. It depends on how much demand you have in the market. So you can't make a generalization one way or another.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Hunter.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: And now, we'll take questions from media at this time. [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Mary Schlangenstein with Bloomberg News.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's been corrected, if it hasn't already been. I wanted to ask, Scott, if you can clarify something for me in terms of the synergies. I was looking back and before the merger, about the time of the merger, I guess you guys were talking about synergies
componenttext: That's been corrected, if it hasn't already been. I wanted to ask, Scott, if you can clarify something for me in terms of the synergies. I was looking back and before the merger, about the time of the merger, I guess you guys were talking about synergies exceeding $1 billion and then at one point, you added another $400 million through some things that you had found as you got a closer look at American. Can you really spell out where you are? The answers you gave earlier wasn't really clear to me where you are in terms of the synergies that you expected early in the merger to where you are now.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll do my best from memory, to get to all those numbers. We had said roughly $600 million of cost synergies, which we think we've achieved, offset by $600 million of labor cost increases. So those were net 0. So both of those things can happen. We
componenttext: Okay, I'll do my best from memory, to get to all those numbers. We had said roughly $600 million of cost synergies, which we think we've achieved, offset by $600 million of labor cost increases. So those were net 0. So both of those things can happen. We said $1 billion of revenue synergies. That was $300 million through improved frequent flyer program and bigger network. We think we've achieved that. We said, call it, $333 million. We said 3 things that added up to $1 billion. We said that 1/3 of that was coming from route swaps, which I did talk about, and said that those are just now starting to phase in. It will take a couple of years to fully phase in. And the other 1/3 was coming from connectivity, which we said we've got 1/2 of it in 2016 and the other -- or 2015, and the other 1/2 will come this year. The $400 million was re-banking the hubs and off-peak scheduling, which we probably believe we've gotten 3/4 of done so far.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Andrea Ahles with Fort Worth Star-Telegram.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Andrea Ahles with Fort Worth Star-Telegram.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, I was wondering if you could give me a little bit of an update on how contract talks are going with the TWU at this point. Do you expect to get those contracts, the joint contracts, done sometime this year or you think it's going to be more into nex
componenttext: Doug, I was wondering if you could give me a little bit of an update on how contract talks are going with the TWU at this point. Do you expect to get those contracts, the joint contracts, done sometime this year or you think it's going to be more into next year?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We certainly hope it will get done this year, but I'll let Steve give some more color.
componenttext: We certainly hope it will get done this year, but I'll let Steve give some more color.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrea, we still are optimistic that we'll get the big contracts with the TWU and IAM done this year. But there -- the talks are going fine so far, and I believe the union is also focused on getting these concluded quickly, but they are complicated and th
componenttext: Andrea, we still are optimistic that we'll get the big contracts with the TWU and IAM done this year. But there -- the talks are going fine so far, and I believe the union is also focused on getting these concluded quickly, but they are complicated and they just take time. So sometime this year is still a pretty good prediction, but probably not sometime this quarter.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then a follow-up on, Scott, you talked a lot about the capacity increases here in Dallas, in the Dallas market, DFW. Can you give any more color on this? Are we going to continue to see this sort of competitive, low-fare environment from American as y
componenttext: And then a follow-up on, Scott, you talked a lot about the capacity increases here in Dallas, in the Dallas market, DFW. Can you give any more color on this? Are we going to continue to see this sort of competitive, low-fare environment from American as you compete on the capacity that's been added here through August, I think is what you said? Or is it sort of -- or have we stabilized in terms of the capacity increases that you've been seeing in this market?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we still see capacity increases that will last on a year-over-year basis through August. As it relates to pricing however, American Airlines tends to always compete aggressively on price. And so I don't think anything changes when you go to August,
componenttext: Well, we still see capacity increases that will last on a year-over-year basis through August. As it relates to pricing however, American Airlines tends to always compete aggressively on price. And so I don't think anything changes when you go to August, but the year-over-year numbers in terms of RASM start to change. But I wouldn't expect any meaningful changes to the pricing environment because it'll look the same in September as it did in August sequentially. It's just the year-over-year comparisons that are different.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Susan Carey with Wall Street Journal.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Susan Carey with Wall Street Journal.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, could you just go run through again the RASM outlook for the year? Are you now saying that you don't think the industry or American is going to see positive RASM until 2017? Or are you saying perhaps by the end of '16?
componenttext: Scott, could you just go run through again the RASM outlook for the year? Are you now saying that you don't think the industry or American is going to see positive RASM until 2017? Or are you saying perhaps by the end of '16?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I didn't say either one of those things. I'm not making a forecast.
componenttext: I didn't say either one of those things. I'm not making a forecast.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, say something.
componenttext: Well, say something.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All I'm saying is there is a relationship between fuel price and revenue and oil prices are significantly lower today than when I made the original prediction 6 months ago. And so just the mathematics of lower oil prices would likely move that out a quart
componenttext: All I'm saying is there is a relationship between fuel price and revenue and oil prices are significantly lower today than when I made the original prediction 6 months ago. And so just the mathematics of lower oil prices would likely move that out a quarter or 2, but I haven't tried to -- I haven't done the math to say when exactly that would happen. And so I'm not actually making a prediction but just saying lower oil prices probably pushed back the time frame longer than it otherwise would have been.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: For American or for the industry?
componenttext: For American or for the industry?

componenttextpreview: Both.
componenttext: Both.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeffrey Dastin with Reuters.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roughly how many customers have asked for reservation changes related to the Zika virus? And does that represent a significant increase from the number of travelers that typically request such changes?
componenttext: Roughly how many customers have asked for reservation changes related to the Zika virus? And does that represent a significant increase from the number of travelers that typically request such changes?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know, but I know it has not been a meaningful number. I don't know the exact number, though.
componenttext: I don't know, but I know it has not been a meaningful number. I don't know the exact number, though.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what steps, just to follow up, is American taking to keep its cabin free of mosquitoes and its crew members and passengers safe in the scare of Zika?
componenttext: Okay. And what steps, just to follow up, is American taking to keep its cabin free of mosquitoes and its crew members and passengers safe in the scare of Zika?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In all international locations, we have procedures to keep aircraft clean. There are specified programs and we are in close contact with the CDC on any type of changes that would require adjustments to our programs. And right now, we feel like we're in go
componenttext: In all international locations, we have procedures to keep aircraft clean. There are specified programs and we are in close contact with the CDC on any type of changes that would require adjustments to our programs. And right now, we feel like we're in good shape in terms of addressing any issues, whether it's mosquito-borne issues or any others.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And if I may ask one follow-up related to Zika. Is there any extra concern about the short-term business in Latin America because of Zika and also because of closer ties with Lat Am now that you guys have a joint business?
componenttext: Great. And if I may ask one follow-up related to Zika. Is there any extra concern about the short-term business in Latin America because of Zika and also because of closer ties with Lat Am now that you guys have a joint business?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, as we said earlier on the call, it's too early to tell. We haven't seen an effect yet. And I think it's important to point out unlike some other viruses in the past that were airborne, this one is not airborne and it can't be transmitted from
componenttext: Well, look, as we said earlier on the call, it's too early to tell. We haven't seen an effect yet. And I think it's important to point out unlike some other viruses in the past that were airborne, this one is not airborne and it can't be transmitted from one passenger to another. And as a result, you wouldn't expect it to have as big an impact as something like SARS. But to date, we haven't seen a measurable impact on bookings.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And of course, at this point, anyway, just known to only have an impact on pregnant women. It's not the entire traveling public.
componenttext: And of course, at this point, anyway, just known to only have an impact on pregnant women. It's not the entire traveling public.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could elaborate a bit on your capacity growth plans for 2015. How much is going to come from upgauging and increased seat counts versus new markets? And where you might be looking to grow this year?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could elaborate a bit on your capacity growth plans for 2015. How much is going to come from upgauging and increased seat counts versus new markets? And where you might be looking to grow this year?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if we talk about from the mainline perspective, gauge is up about 1.6%. Stage length is up 4% and the departures are actually down 3% from a mainline perspective. Most of the growth is international, in the Pacific. Domestic is only up about
componenttext: Yes, I think if we talk about from the mainline perspective, gauge is up about 1.6%. Stage length is up 4% and the departures are actually down 3% from a mainline perspective. Most of the growth is international, in the Pacific. Domestic is only up about 2%.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pacific being Australia and New Zealand.
componenttext: Pacific being Australia and New Zealand.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ted Reed with TheStreet.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ted Reed with TheStreet.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 things. First of all, you were talking about Charlotte and saying the PRASM gains there are the best in the system and I think you said the same thing on the last call. What's the reason for the growth in Charlotte, PRASM growth in Charlotte?
componenttext: I have 2 things. First of all, you were talking about Charlotte and saying the PRASM gains there are the best in the system and I think you said the same thing on the last call. What's the reason for the growth in Charlotte, PRASM growth in Charlotte?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charlotte's a great market and strong demand and it's been less impacted by some of the things like what's happening in Dallas with the significant capacity growth. But Charlotte is a great market with strong local demand, strong connecting demand, strong
componenttext: Charlotte's a great market and strong demand and it's been less impacted by some of the things like what's happening in Dallas with the significant capacity growth. But Charlotte is a great market with strong local demand, strong connecting demand, strong business demand and it has held up well through this environment.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: My other thing is, Delta is saying that if they hadn't had $1.5 billion in profit sharing this year, their profit for 2015 would've been $7.4 billion. So they would have had the highest profit of any airline. Do you have a response to that?
componenttext: My other thing is, Delta is saying that if they hadn't had $1.5 billion in profit sharing this year, their profit for 2015 would've been $7.4 billion. So they would have had the highest profit of any airline. Do you have a response to that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know, Ted. What I know is our pilots right now are making 7% more per hour than theirs are, because we choose to pay our people higher than -- to offset the fact of profit-sharing. And the rest of their employees are non-union and ours are i
componenttext: Well, I don't know, Ted. What I know is our pilots right now are making 7% more per hour than theirs are, because we choose to pay our people higher than -- to offset the fact of profit-sharing. And the rest of their employees are non-union and ours are in unions that give them better worker protection. So I think on a wage business, our numbers are going to look awfully similar to theirs in total compensation. That's certainly not the driver of the revenue. Of the margin overperformance of us versus them, I do think, to be fair to them, the big driver of our outperformance versus them is the fact that they made a fuel hedge that cost them a couple billion dollars. And if you adjust for that, which is what I would argue if I were them, that indeed, their margins are higher than ours and we agree with that. They're 5 years ahead of us. They got their merger done in 2008, we got ours done in 2013. We're going to catch them. We're not there yet, but we will. But that's -- their margins are higher than ours because -- our margins are higher this year because they hedged fuel and we didn't, and that cost them a lot of money, and indeed, cost them a lot of profit-sharing. And our -- but if you adjust for that, their margins are higher. We know that, and like I said, they're 5 years ahead, we'll catch them.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: But in terms of profit, because you -- in terms of profit, because they're saying the profit would have been the highest ever for an airline. Just a simple profit number, you're saying theirs is affected by the fuel hedges.
componenttext: But in terms of profit, because you -- in terms of profit, because they're saying the profit would have been the highest ever for an airline. Just a simple profit number, you're saying theirs is affected by the fuel hedges.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ted, this is Steve. I mean, I think that's kind of a silly allegation by Delta, because as you can tell from the way we've built our collective bargaining agreements and the way some of the other airlines have, if Delta wasn't paying $1.5 billion of profi
componenttext: Ted, this is Steve. I mean, I think that's kind of a silly allegation by Delta, because as you can tell from the way we've built our collective bargaining agreements and the way some of the other airlines have, if Delta wasn't paying $1.5 billion of profit-sharing, they'd be paying something like that in wages. So it's...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, Ted said it, I'm not sure if Delta said it anyway, so but anyway, Ted, if that's what you want to say. Look, I think I'll just -- will just say what I said, which is we have made a decision to compensate our people more per month and not have t
componenttext: And again, Ted said it, I'm not sure if Delta said it anyway, so but anyway, Ted, if that's what you want to say. Look, I think I'll just -- will just say what I said, which is we have made a decision to compensate our people more per month and not have them be subject to the whims of things like Zika viruses and people's concerns about that and whether or not there's going to be travel, we think we should pay -- we think people should be paid what they earn as they earn it as opposed to waiting for the end of the year to see if indeed the airline's profitable or not. So we put more in our base wages. Delta, actually, is -- with their revamp, cut back their profit-sharing significantly, put a lot more into base wages in response to their -- again, what I read anyways, is they said their employees told them they prefer it that way. They prefer to have more in the base wages. We believe our employees prefer it that way. So we have more in base wages and they have more in profit-sharing, and if -- like I say, it's just a different way of compensation and compensating. But when you add it all up, our total compensation and where our people are compensated is, I don't know, again, very, very close. That is not the difference. Employee compensation is not the difference in our different -- in our earnings amounts vis-à-vis each other. The big difference is they lost a lot of money on fuel hedges that we didn't lose. So if you adjust for that, we agree they're ahead of us.
