headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the American Airlines Group First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] And now I would like to turn the conference over to your moderator, Managing Director of Investor Re
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the American Airlines Group First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] And now I would like to turn the conference over to your moderator, Managing Director of Investor Relations, Mr. Dan Cravens.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the American Airlines Group First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.Joining us on the call today is Doug Parker, our Chairman and CEO; Scott Kirby, our President; Derek Kerr, our Chief Financial Officer. Also i
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the American Airlines Group First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.
Joining us on the call today is Doug Parker, our Chairman and CEO; Scott Kirby, our President; Derek Kerr, our Chief Financial Officer. Also in the room for the question-and-answer session is Robert Isom, the Chief Operating Officer; Elise Eberwein, our EVP of People and Communications; Maya Leibman, our Chief Information Officer; and Steve Johnson, our EVP of Corporate Affairs.
As is our normal practice, we're going to start the call today with Doug, and he will provide an overview of our first quarter 2016 financial results. Derek will then walk us through the details on the quarter and provide some additional information on our guidance for the remainder of the year.
Scott will then follow with commentary on the revenue environment and our operational performance. And then after we hear from those comments, we'll open the call for analysts' questions and lastly, questions from the media.
Before we begin, we must state that today's call does contain forward-looking statements, including statements concerning future revenues and costs, forecasts of capacity, traffic, load factor, fleet plans and fuel prices. These statements represent our predictions and expectations as to future events, but numerous risks and uncertainties could cause actual results to differ from those projected.
Information about some of these risks and uncertainties can be found in our earnings press release issued this morning and our Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March 31, 2016. 
In addition, we'll be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures this morning such as net profit and CASM excluding unusual items. A reconciliation to those numbers to the GAAP financial measures is included in the earnings release, and that can be found on our website at aa.com.
A webcast of this will also be archived on our website and the information that we're giving you on the call is as of today's date, and we undertake no obligation to update the information subsequently.
So thanks again for joining us this morning. At this point, I'll turn the call over to our Chairman and CEO, Doug Parker.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. Thanks, everyone, for being on the call. This morning we announced 2016 pretax earnings for the first quarter, excluding special items at $1.2 billion and it's slightly down from our all-time record first quarter earnings that were set in 201
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. Thanks, everyone, for being on the call. This morning we announced 2016 pretax earnings for the first quarter, excluding special items at $1.2 billion and it's slightly down from our all-time record first quarter earnings that were set in 2015. But a more relevant to our shareholders on an adjusted earnings per share basis, EPS actually grew 15% versus last year's record. That, of course, because our share count is lower due to the share repurchase program we've had in place.
And absolute earnings would have been slightly higher than last year's record slightly lower except for the company's unilateral decision to institute a profit sharing program for our employees beginning in 2016. And our investors may question that decision, it's a big decision and the fact of the matter is we at American had attempted to transform our industry's compensation structure consistent with our view that our industry been transformed. 
In short, we believe the best way as most industries do to pay our hard-working team is to give them an industry-leading base wages, that have lower wages and give them the share of the profits at the end of the year. But as it became more clear over time that our competitors were not going to do the same. It became a real issue for our team and therefore for our shareholders. And while the team understood the logic, we've couldn't get past a collective view amongst the team that the company didn't appreciate their contributions to the success of the team and that certainly wasn't the intent nor our view. So we implemented a unilateral 5% profit sharing program. The first accrual of which is in these results. The accrual was $73 million were achieved. We're quite pleased with that and we believe the shareholders as well. The fact of the matter is the announcement had the impact that we had hoped. Our team is excited. They're engaged. They are intent upon returning American to be the greatest airline in the world and we're seeing it in the results. You can see it in the great job our team is running around airline, taking care of our customers. So I will begin by thanking them for their continued hard work and everything they're doing to return American to greatness and take care of our customers. 
As for the share repurchase, we returned more than $1.6 billion to our shareholders in the first quarter and our board has authorized a new $2 billion repurchase program that will expire at the end of 2017. Look, we're purchasing our shares because we're bullish on the stock and our prospects at American. We think it's a great investment for a couple of the reasons. 1, we continue to believe that the market does not seem to fully appreciate the transformation that's taken place in this industry. And as a result, we believe the industry is well undervalued. Second, we think American Airlines has more upside than anyone else in the industry. We're not done with the integration. We have -- we are making investments at a rate that no other airlines has done in the past in the product and our people, which will turn into our product. And that gives us upside that others don't have. So we're very bullish. But look because we're bullish, it doesn't mean we are totally pleased with the current performance because we're not. In particular, discipline in our revenue performance on both an absolute level and relative to some of our peers. And Scott will take some time to explain the current situation and the outlook. But just know that we don't view the current revenue trends as either acceptable or long-term. If we did, we wouldn't be as bullish as we are. So with that said, I will turn it over to Derek to give you a lot more details and then Scott will give you some color and I will take questions. Derek?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everybody. In our 10-Q and earnings press release filed this morning, we reported first quarter 2016 net profit, excluding net special charges, of $765 million or $1.25 per diluted share. This compares to 2015 net profit, e
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everybody. In our 10-Q and earnings press release filed this morning, we reported first quarter 2016 net profit, excluding net special charges, of $765 million or $1.25 per diluted share. This compares to 2015 net profit, excluding net special charges, of $1.2 billion or $0.0173 per diluted share. 
As we talked about our last call, in the fourth quarter of 2015, the company concluded that realization of substantially all of the deferred tax assets principally net operating loss carryforwards or NOLs was more likely than that. This was the basis for the company's strong financial performance since the merger and expectations of financial sustain future profitability. Accordingly, the company reversed the valuation allowance on its deferred tax asset as of December 31, 2015. Starting with its first quarter of 2016 results, the company will be recognizing a provision for income tax that has substantially noncash due to its utilization of NOLs. 
For 2016, quarterly net profit will not be comparable to net profit of 2015. As a result, we believe pretax profit, excluding net special items, is a better measure for evaluating year-over-year performance and net income. 
On a net basis, our first quarter pretax profit, excluding net special charges, was $1.22 billion, which resulted in record first quarter pretax margin of 12.9%. This compares to our 2015 first quarter pretax profit, excluding net special charges, of $1.25 billion and a pretax margin of 12.7%. 
As Doug talked about, excluding the effects of our special items and the noncash tax provision, our first quarter 2016 adjusted fully diluted EPS was up 15% to $1.99 per share, reflecting a 15% reduction in our fully diluted average share count. 
Total capacity for the first quarter of 2016 was 65.1 billion ASMs, up 3.6% from the same period in 2015 with mainline capacity up 3.1% and regional capacity was up 8.1%. We continue to make significant investments in our fleet renewal program, which has given the company the youngest and most modern fleet of the U.S. network airlines. By the end of this year, we expect the average age of our mainline fleet to fall below 10 years, well below any of our network competitors. In the first quarter of 2016, the company took delivery of 15 new mainline aircraft, while retiring 19 mainline aircraft. The company also added 13 regional aircraft and removed 3 regional aircraft. This program will continue throughout the year when we expect to take delivery of 55 new mainline aircraft, while adding 49 regional aircraft. And if we could keep our capacity in check, we expect to remove 86 mainline aircraft and 23 regional aircraft from our fleet during the year.
Our first quarter 2016 revenue continue to be negatively impacted by competitive capacity increases principally in certain domestic markets, economic softness in Latin America and the impact of a stronger dollar in foreign markets. For the quarter, total operating revenues were $9.4 billion, down 4% year-over-year. Passenger revenues were $8.1 billion, down 4.2%, driven by 7.1% lower yields on a 3.6% increase in system capacity. 
Cargo revenues were down 16.8% to $162 million due primarily to a 15.3% decline in yields in international freight. Other operating revenues were relatively flat at $1.2 billion. 
Total RASM in the first quarter of 2016 was $0.145, down 7.3% driven principally by a decline in passenger RASM of 7.5%, which Scott will talk about in a minute. 
As Doug mentioned in his remarks, on March 23, we introduced an employee profit sharing program, which will pay out 5% of pretax profit, excluding special items starting with our full year 2016 results. This program was retroactive to January 1 and accordingly, we recognize $73 million of profit sharing expense in the first quarter. The company also accelerated a contractual marked-to-market the rate adjustment for the company's flight attendants and reach agreement with our dispatchers on a new contract in April. Costs associated with these rate adjustments and the profit sharing program will be included in our forward CASM guidance that I'll discussed later.
Our first quarter financial results continue to reflect the significant savings from the year-over-year decline in jet fuel prices. Our average mainline fuel price, including taxes for the first quarter of 2016 was down 34.1% to $1.20 per gallon. Total GAAP operating expenses were $8.1 billion, down 5.9% versus the same period last year due primarily to $607 million decrease in consolidated; fuel expense. Operating expenses, excluding net special charges, for the first quarter of 2016 were $8 billion, down 3.7% year-over-year. 
First quarter mainline CASM, cost per ASM, excluding net special charges, was $0.1141, down 6.9% year-over-year due primarily to lower fuel costs. Excluding special items and fuel, our mainline cost per ASM was $0.0962 in the first quarter, up 1.4% year-over-year. This increase was due primarily to contractual labor rate increases including for our customer service and the introduction of our profit sharing plan. This rate increases were offset in part by maintenance timing and lower selling expenses.
Regional operating cost per ASM, excluding special items and fuel, was $0.1611 for the first quarter of 2016, a decrease of 2.2% and our consolidated first quarter CASM was up 1%. 
We ended the first quarter with approximately $9.4 billion in total available liquidity comprised of cash and investments of $6.9 billion and a $2.4 billion undrawn revolver capacity. 
The company also had $691 million classified in restricted cash. During the first quarter of 2016, we generated $2.6 billion of cash flow from operations and paid $310 million scheduled debt payments. As a reminder, on our fourth quarter earnings call, we provided our view on leverage and liquidity for American going forward. In particular, we stated that in today's earnings and interest rate environment, liquidity was the most important metric we consider. And given our relative leverage, we expect to maintain our liquidity of at least $6.5 billion. We also provided guidance with respect to where we are with our fleet rental program, access to attractive debt in the capital markets, ongoing share repurchase programs and belief that the American will produce sustained earnings. Our liquidity of $9.4 billion for the quarter and was up -- up from $8.7 billion at the end of 2015 and was well in excess of the $6.5 billion liquidity we seek to maintain for the foreseeable future. 
As previously mentioned, we believe it's important to retain liquidity levels higher than our network peers given our own overall leverage and that we have not yet completed our fleet renewal program. 
With respect to leverage, we look to metrics, such as net debt-to-EBITDAR and with our planned aircraft financing this year, we continue to expect that on this matter, we will peak in 2016 and then begin to see this decline each year going forward as our capital spending declines. 
In early January, the company issued $1.1 billion and enhanced equipment trust certificates at a blended rate just below 4%. The proceeds for this financing were used to finance aircraft previously delivered in 2015. The company also raised approximately $4 billion, [ph] $400 million in other low-cost aircraft financing during the quarter. 
For the first quarter, the company returned more than $1.6 billion to its shareholders through the repayment of $61 million in quarterly dividends and the repurchase of $1.56 billion of common stock or 39.3 million shares. Since our capital return program started in mid 2014, the company has returned approximately $6.6 billion to shareholders through share repurchases of $6.1 billion and dividends of $0.5 billion. Including share repurchases, shares withheld to cover taxes associated with employee equity words and shares distributions and the cash extinguishment of convertible debt, our share count has dropped to 23% from 756.1 million at merger close to 585.7 million shares on March 31, 2016. 
At the end of the quarter, the company had approximately $850 million remaining on its current authorization and as a result, the company's Board of Directors authorized a new $2 billion share repurchase program that will expire at the end of 2017. On a program-to-date basis, the company's Board of Directors has authorized a total of $9 billion of share repurchases.
Turning now to our 2016 guidance, we continued to value our capacity and [indiscernible] update 2 weeks ago, we Lauridsen capacity guidance by 0.5 point and are forecasting it to be up approximately 2.5%. Full year domestic capacity growth is expected to be up approximately 2.5% and international has been reduced from 6% down to 2.5%. By quarter, the first quarter is $62.2 billion -- or second quarter $62.6 billion -- excuse me, $64.8 billion in the third, $58.9 million in the fourth. On a regional breakdown, it's $8.01 billion in the second, $8.22 billion in the third and $8.08 billion in the fourth.
On a cost side, we're forecasting year-to-year mainline CASM, excluding special items and fuel, to be up approximately 3% to 5% with the regional CASM, excluding special items and fuel, is projected to be down approximately 3% to 5%. Mainline CASM in the first and second quarter will be up between 4% ang 6% and in the fourth quarter, up 3% to 5%. Regional CASM be down by approximately 4% to 6% in the second quarter and down 3% to 5% in both the third and fourth quarter.
Based on the overall fuel curve of April 18, 2016, we you expect to see another year of significant year-over-year fuel savings. In our second quarter, we expect $1.30 to $1.35; third quarter, $1.36 to $1.41; fourth quarter, $1.40 to $1.45. 
On the regional side, the second quarter we have $1.35 to $1.40; third quarter $1.43 to $1.48; and fourth quarter, $1.47 to $1.52. And based on these prices, we expect our 2016 consolidated fuel expense to decrease the approximately $1.6 billion year-over-year.
Using the midpoints of guidance we provided along with the PRASM guidance that Scott will give, we expect our second quarter pretax margin, excluding special items, to be between 14% and 16%. The capital expenditures, we still expect total gross aircraft CapEx to be approximately $4.5 billion, of which $1.2 billion will occur in the second quarter. For the full year 2016, we expect to invest $1.2 billion for nonaircraft CapEx, which includes investment to improve our product and the operations.
So in conclusion, thanks for the efforts of more than 100,000 team members, we have strong first quarter results, which make an excellent start to 2016. While still have about before to do to complete our integration and our continued financial success, as well positioned for the years ahead. 
And with that, I will turn it over to Scott.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Derek. And I'd like to start by thanking our operations team and 100,000 people of American Airlines continue to make great strides. And in fact, the first quarter was our best operational quarters since the merger closed. Despite the fact that we
componenttext:
Thanks, Derek. And I'd like to start by thanking our operations team and 100,000 people of American Airlines continue to make great strides. And in fact, the first quarter was our best operational quarters since the merger closed. Despite the fact that we're years behind our competitors and starting the merger integration process, we've already gotten to a point where we're neck and neck for first place in departures and [indiscernible], which we view as a primary metric for core operating reliability. And our other operating metrics were showing improvement as well with mishandled baggage rates down over 20% year-over-year and significant improvement in completion factor. 
But we know we can do even better. We have many initiatives and technology projects underway to further improve all of our operating metrics and are well on the path to operating the best airline in the world. Of the revenue front, the first quarter confused challenging revenue environment with PRASM down 7.5%. Domestically, our consolidated PRASM was down 5.3%. We saw the strongest performance year-over-year in Los Angeles, Dallas/Fort Worth and Chicago. That the weakest performance once again was in Miami although that's still really a function of declining connecting revenues from South America. Internationally, the stronger U.S. dollar and declining international fuel surcharges made up 1.7 points of total system PRASM decline. So that is a smaller impact than we saw in fourth quarter as we're beginning to overlap the dollar appreciation from last year. 
The Atlantic was our best-performing international region with PRASM down 2.1%. While we're relatively pleased with that result, we expect capacity growth across the Atlantic this summer to drive some incremental pressure in this region. 
Across the Pacific, PRASM was down 16% on 29% ASM growth. With continued weakness in both Japan and China, but positive year-over-year PRASM in South Korea. 
Latin PRASM was down 17% but as it's been for a while now, that weakness is concentrated in Brazil and Venezuela, where PRASM was down 39% and 48%, respectively. 
Looking forward, while the comes gets easier in 2Q, the revenue environment remains challenging. We expect the revenue environment to remain challenging throughout 2016 but longer term, we feel quite positive about all the initiatives we have in place to drive higher revenues, including basic and premium, a new revenue base frequent flyer program, $3 billion in new product investments, our continued fleet modernization program and the best people in the industry who are focused on delivering the best customer service. 
We also recognize that the market is rightly concerned about getting back to positive PRASM and we're also focused on that as explicit internal goal. I think that time line is unfortunately, we've pushed in the next year and some of the long-term initiatives I described will make a big difference in that regard in 2017. But we'd also like to finalize to accelerate the PRASM positive trends in this year. Doing so will require a fair level of sequential improvement. But one of the areas were focused on in the near term, it include implementing a new demand forecasting system and yield management. This initiative were will know will ultimately produce much better results but as we've implemented this, in the recent past, we've had 1 some step forward, 2 steps back issues with the new system. 
We're cautiously optimistic that we're through some of the tipping pain, and in fact, as we look out into the summer, our PRASM for June and beyond looks much better than April and May. As most of you know, we're also in the middle of negotiations for new credit card deal. 
While I won't predict on this call when or even if we'll ever get a deal done, all of our large players have done new deals in the past couple of years and we expect a similar larger tailwind for American Airlines when we do ultimately get a new deal done. 
Further, we also adjust capacity in a world where we see declining demand. American Airlines was the slowest growing airline in the United States last year. And as you've seen for several quarters in a row, we can continue to reduce our capacity plan in light of declining year-over-year PRASM. 
So while we believe the long-term outlook is bright and even have near-term opportunities that could drive outperformance. I know that many people on this call are a little more focused just on 2Q revenues. So for the second quarter, total scheduled capacity remains elevated in all regions and hilw capacity growth rates were down slightly from the first quarter levels, total capacity still growing faster than the economies in all regions of the world. 
As we move into the back half of the year, however, we still expect capacity growth rates to moderate further from the first of level. As we experienced throughout 2015, we continue to see significant year-over-year competitive growth in Dallas, and we don't expect that to moderate until September. And while the comps gets busier, the economy, currencies and revenue environment in Brazil and Venezuela mobile continued to deteriorate on a sequential basis. Hearing all this, we expect our system PRASM to decline 6% to 8% year-over-year in the second quarter. In conclusion, the near-term revenue environment remains challenging. While we're delivering solid bottom line results, we are getting back to PRASM growth is important to our near and long-term future. So to do that, we are making smart investments in our product and continuing to modernize our fleet dividends focus on improving our operations in starting to see the results and our operating metrics and we're investing in our people, our team members are responsible for delivering great service our customers each and everyday. In the near term, we are focused on better day-to-day execution in revenue management and that in our new yield management system properly time. When you put it altogether, we for the good about the foundation will billion dollars for the long term, which will enable us to run the world's best operations and drive higher revenues.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. Thank you, Derek, thank you, Scott. Operator, we are ready to take any questions.
componenttext: Excellent. Thank you, Derek, thank you, Scott. Operator, we are ready to take any questions.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Joseph DeNardi from stifled.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Joseph DeNardi from stifled.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, just a question kind of on the PRASM environment and the messaging. I feel like it's getting a little bit mixed. And if you guys wanted to get to flat PRASM or positive PRASM, you could probably do it next quarter but you're not because that capaci
componenttext: Scott, just a question kind of on the PRASM environment and the messaging. I feel like it's getting a little bit mixed. And if you guys wanted to get to flat PRASM or positive PRASM, you could probably do it next quarter but you're not because that capacity is earning and cash flow accretive. So can you just talk about in an environment where you did reduce capacity, was would cash flow look like? And what are you doing with incremental cash flow you're getting from the capacity growth?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first, I don't think it's that simple. I think American Airlines unilaterally reducing capacity wouldn't get us to PRASM positive on its own and it's going to require more than that. It's going to require a lot of the kinds of things that I talked a
componenttext: Well, first, I don't think it's that simple. I think American Airlines unilaterally reducing capacity wouldn't get us to PRASM positive on its own and it's going to require more than that. It's going to require a lot of the kinds of things that I talked about in my prepared remarks. There are some near-term things that we're focused, particularly in the yield management area and a lot of the longer term investments and initiatives are the kind of get does not just that the positive PRASM growth but hopefully recovering what we've lost in '15 in '16 and get back to the actual growth PRASM growth. We're not in a world where we're saying heat capacity in place just taking near-term perspective on cash flow or anything else. We are focused on getting to cash flow or PRASM positive. You see us, I don't know how many quarters in a row, 6 or 7 quarters in a row, where we have reduced capacity. But I don't think capacity is a simplistic button to push that will just turn magically turn PRASM positive.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Doug, just on the decision on the profit sharing side of this, have you seen -- are you expecting benefits operationally from improved employee engagement? Is that part of this? Or is it just you have to do this also doing business at this
componenttext: Okay. And then Doug, just on the decision on the profit sharing side of this, have you seen -- are you expecting benefits operationally from improved employee engagement? Is that part of this? Or is it just you have to do this also doing business at this point?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Joe, we're not going to try to point to anything. We're going to see [indiscernible] so the improvement. What I can tell you is this, we've lost part of the team and it's important particularly at this airlines given the future -- given the history
componenttext: Well, Joe, we're not going to try to point to anything. We're going to see [indiscernible] so the improvement. What I can tell you is this, we've lost part of the team and it's important particularly at this airlines given the future -- given the history that the team have gone through and given what we're trying to accomplish to pull everyone together and help them understand that indeed, it's different, much like we're trying to with everyone of our partners help understand the world is different. What had happened is we've lost a part of the team not because they understood analytically the argument we laid out, that we've laid out for you, and that we lay out all the time. And certainly past our looking in the eye test, which is important to us. We will our employees in the area and all the way met the decisions, and we could do that extremely well. We are still since we were getting back on this 1. I mean The employees got it with their brains but they didn't get it in their hearts. And it really felt like -- again, largely because, while our other -- while our competitors kind were moving in our direction, they weren't going to the point that we're in and other airlines have in place this profit-sharing programs, and we did not. And to our team like we -- well, they understood again the logic. Help us we weren't appreciating their contribution to the bottom line, which is the last thing we were trying to accomplish. So what we realized is if we were going to really get our team engaged and excited which is an imperative to accomplishing [indiscernible] accomplishing all of the things Scott talked about that we're working on to get or to compete against the other airlines, particularly for premium travelers. We had Derek, our engaged and excited and this was holding us back. So I firmly belief it's in our shareholders' best interest to do it, and wouldn't have been otherwise. We have indeed seen an uplift in engagement and excitement because of this. Not so much I don't think because of the actual dollars involved just because it proved what our employees want to believe that indeed it is different. And that we will listen and that we will do things even though we've made -- even though we take strong positions if it gets to the point that we think it's not working, we're willing to revisit those decisions. So all those things have had a positive impact on, I think, that's good for -- I know it's good for our shareholders. It's impossible to quantify and it's also early. The real challenge to the team is to not build on it. This is temporary. While the profit-sharing will stay in place, the feeling of instituting profit-sharing is not going to stay in place. It will become just I imagine over time just part of everyone's conversation that -- and the way they do it and our challenge is now to use it to go do these things that we want to go do as an airline and put in place the product with the people that do their job so well. We really want to. So just a long way for me saying, it was not an easy decision but I know it's the right decision for our shareholders.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, we did it -- we had a good quarter. Some of that is true-ups that happened at the end of the year or the previous year. So some of our outperformance this quarter was really -- was true-ups from other quarters, which mean that our other quarter perf
componenttext: Look, we did it -- we had a good quarter. Some of that is true-ups that happened at the end of the year or the previous year. So some of our outperformance this quarter was really -- was true-ups from other quarters, which mean that our other quarter performance had been better. We expect that to get a little bit worse in the second quarter. Demand across the transatlantic though, particularly with the -- in light of the Brussels tragedy, has remained pretty strong and pretty resilient. There's a lot of capacity coming, however, it's expected to take that -- that to take a downturn going forward, but core demand is pretty across the Atlantic.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay, and Scott, can you comment on advanced booking trends in corporate versus leisure and whether you're using the same positive trends in advance summer yields domestically that the delta called out last week?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we hit a -- I'll go back a little bit. We hit a little bit of a rough patch in February and March, where corporate demand in particular seemed a little weak, and I think a lot of airlines -- well, a every airline tended to see that the, I think, I ac
componenttext: Yes, we hit a -- I'll go back a little bit. We hit a little bit of a rough patch in February and March, where corporate demand in particular seemed a little weak, and I think a lot of airlines -- well, a every airline tended to see that the, I think, I actually, I think, there's 2 reasons for that as near as I can hypothesize, both of which have gotten better now so that's good news. The first 1 is we had a stock market that dropped, whatever it dropped, 10% or 12% as we said before, on a headline basis, whether it should or not that does affect travel demand, particularly corporate travel demand, which is easy to go. When you start to get worried when you travel and entertainment budget. As I do think that was one of the factors. It appears that the market has come back, that coast and booking demand has gotten stronger. Another thing that happened, which got talked about a little bit on our earnings call the last time, got asked a question about advantage which I know many people on this call think -- or were worried was problematic and I declined to answer it on the last call. The reason I declined to answer it on the last call. Well, the reason I declined to answer it is because there were no advantage fares in the market at the time. None of the airlines had advantage fares. They have all been canceled. So I don't want to talk about it. We went for about 3 months with no advantage fares in the market. That 3-month period actually coincided with the wealthy decline in revenue expectations across most of the all airlines. So we start to wonder if our decision to cancel advantage fares was really the correct revenue decision. But before we have made a final decision on that 1 of our competitors, I presumably concluded that it was also the wrong decision and put them back. So they've been back in the market now for a couple of weeks and the combination of those 2 things means that the last couple of weeks we've actually seen strengthening posting demand, not just the absolute demand but revenue. So we actually felt better about the revenue environment that we would have say 3 to 4 weeks ago. On the domestic front, I know that some have talked advanced book yields being up. our book to yields domestically for May, June, July and August are up year-over-year for all of those months. But I don't want to mislead anyone because that's been true for the past several months. The issue has not really been about advanced book yields. We've had advanced book yields domestically up. It's been a weak to close in yields. And there's still is weakness in close-in yields although we do have a pretty strong demand environment and bookings are a up a lot year-over-year but the yield is tending to fall as we get closer to departure.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, following up on your last point, you know if we look at the domestic fare structure, it looks pretty sloppy to me. I don't didn't really care how we got here, but the fares that I'm being asked to pay, particularly close in and to your point, they
componenttext: Scott, following up on your last point, you know if we look at the domestic fare structure, it looks pretty sloppy to me. I don't didn't really care how we got here, but the fares that I'm being asked to pay, particularly close in and to your point, they strike me as stupidly low. Notwithstanding airlines recalcitrance to discuss pricing, what is potentially wrong with the structure? Is it multisegment itineraries that are pricing too low? Is it the junk fares have been popping up at markets where discounters don't even exist? Is it something about minimum stay requirements? I mean the reason I ask is not in regards to what you might do differently, it's what we might be looking for, keeping an eye out for in terms of change as opposed to just monitoring for plain vanilla fare increases?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I will use the term wrong because of the connotation that it has. But the fare environment has changed over the last couple of decades, one of the big -- probably I think the biggest change has been the lack of pricing [indiscernible] So historicall
componenttext: Well, I will use the term wrong because of the connotation that it has. But the fare environment has changed over the last couple of decades, one of the big -- probably I think the biggest change has been the lack of pricing [indiscernible] So historically, airlines had 14 day advantage purchases with Saturday night stays and that is an effective way to segment demand and offer business travelers great product, high-frequency, the availability to book last minute but also to be available to offer leisure fares that could fill the empty seats on airplanes that were below the average cost of flying the airplane but could go what would have otherwise been empty seats and it would have effectively segment the demand. Really because of the growth of low-cost carriers, those pricing fences have broken down across the board and lots of zero AP fares, lots of 1 way fares and more than anything, that's what, I think, has driven lower fares for business travel and for close and traffic. Now the ways to combat that are and to drive higher fares, basic and premium economy are 2 of the really, I think big levers for American Airlines in doing that. We're not going to have that really in place until next year. But today, when we -- we wanted to be competitive with others and so we have low fares in the market that have very few restrictions on them and there's no reason for a customer to pay more. And we're going to -- you get the exact same product whether you buy a $41 walk up fare or a $900 walk up fare and we're going to change that and we're going to have different products and the more your paying, the better benefits you're going to get. That's one of the really big things that we can do. Part of that -- part and parcel of that is investing the products and having a great product that customers are actually willing to pay for and pay more for. So that -- for those customers who aren't commodity customers, we have a lot of customers were commoditized. But for those who customers who are not commoditize, we can sell them a better product and be appropriately compensated for that. You also see changes going on in the industry like this stuff about fare combinability, which for the most part has been rollback now. But those are -- the fare combinability is an artifact of history that goes back to the 1960s when GDS were first built, and has had unintended consequences as the pricing environment change. So the fact that those kinds of changes are happening even if they happen in a 1 step forward, 2 steps back kind of process, are actual the long-term encouraging to me because we're moving to a world where we're getting away from just commoditizing the price of the product and getting to we will sell commoditized product for some customers but for other customers, we will be able to decommoditize the product and that's not going to happen overnight, that's got nothing happened this year but we're on a good path to get better and that's a structural change.

componenttext: Benefits from yield management segmentation and credit cards, et cetera. To the extent that you have for those in place today or at some point going forward, what would pricing actually look like? Would it be more flattish? Would be positive? That's the first question. And then the second question, just on the domestic side, what sort of capacity growth does the industry need to see it actually have more stable pricing? Clearly, the numbers we're seeing today aren't cutting it but just your thoughts there at all that would be great.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the second part of the second part of the question, I'm just going to say I can't answer that. [indiscernible] Industry capacity and [indiscernible] , which are to do is best for American Airlines Smith said we have always try to give you guys the b
componenttext: So on the second part of the second part of the question, I'm just going to say I can't answer that. [indiscernible] Industry capacity and [indiscernible] , which are to do is best for American Airlines Smith said we have always try to give you guys the best 50-50 forecast that we can on our outlook for capacity growth. And in a world where we continue to see PRASM declines even though earnings have been growing for many quarters in a row, in a world of negative PRASM, we view that as indicative of supply and demand being misbalanced. And so as a result, we cut capacity historically. Turning to those other items, they're really hard to quantify. A credit card deal, I'm not going to try to quantify. You can look to what other deals have done and make your own guess as to what the American Airlines deal will be. The American Airlines loyalty program and our partnerships with the Citi and Barclays, we have the largest and best loyalty program in the world. And we're very proud of that and we have 2 great partners today and we're looking forward to making that even better for American Airlines, for our customers and for our bank partners. On the other items, some of those things are longer term like basic economy, premium economy, those are really 2017 initiatives for next year, again, hard to quantify. In the yield management area, those are the -- that's the kind of thing when we'll ultimately get everything completed that we're working on. It's probably -- we don't -- again, it's impossible to know for sure but probably worth 2 to 3 points PRASM, which is, I think, it should be worth 2 to 3 points of PRASM. But it's also hard to know when you'll finish that. You put a new yield management system in place, your placing something that's been there for 25 years, you're going to get to a better position in the end but all the patches and the things that have been built into the system for the past 25 years to fix this problem or that problem or this that's been worked well, you wrapup all those Band-Aids. And so you do take a few steps back sometimes before you can really get the system tuned and running. And that's probably a continuous process and never finishes. But we're right in the middle of starting a conversion process so it's probably more challenging for us in the short term than it would be in the normal symptom but they did in previous yield management, ultimately should be worth 2 or 3 points for us.

componenttext: We just use that to make a plug, the reasonable we are not looking for new orders is, as Derek said, we have a large order book, and we brought in a lot of the airplanes. Our team is just -- one of the things we don't talk enough about, I think is the great job our team has done of modernizing this fleet. Robert and his team are inducting a new airplane almost every 4 days or [indiscernible] 4 days then retiring an older 1. The result is the American Airlines fleet now is run right around 10 years on average, which is lower than any of our peers and well lower than some of our peers and shrinking. When we did the merger, we were -- we have the second oldest fleet of the 4 largest airlines now we have the youngest and that's happened because we've lowered our fleet age over time. This is something the others that we're ahead of the others. We're happy about that. It's a product advantage. It's also a future capital allocation advantage.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll do my best. Look, Hunter, you all have to -- you have a customer that care about near-term. You have some that care about long-term. We care about the long-term, I guess, is the only difference. The difference is we -- look, we care like crazy
componenttext: Okay, I'll do my best. Look, Hunter, you all have to -- you have a customer that care about near-term. You have some that care about long-term. We care about the long-term, I guess, is the only difference. The difference is we -- look, we care like crazy about our revenue trends in the near term and what they look like next quarter. We just, I think, I have a sense we don't care as much as some of your investors. But look, if I was an investor who had a short-term horizon on trading, I would care about what next -- what tomorrow's revenue look like. And that's a lot of who you have to deal with and those are shareholders we care about them as well. But our job is to maximize long-term shareholder value and that doesn't mean at all that we ignore the near-term and I'm not -- none of us would suggest that we are. But this is what I try to say in my comments. Just because we're bullish about the future, don't take that to mean that we're entirely pleased with the current environment because we're not. We just -- I just -- we just happen to believe that the long-term prospects for the stock don't -- are not reflected in the current price. And maybe that's because there's too much focus on the near-term or maybe it's just because we're wrong. I don't know. So look, that's for you all to decide. Our job is to run the airline for the long-term. We're very excited about the long-term. We are not pleased with the current term. Again, I should be pleased we're actually making $1.2 billion in the quarter is not something we're unhappy about. But our value -- or our job is to maximize shareholder value, and we know there are things that can be done better and particularly, as Scott has noted, on the revenue environment, we think there are brighter days ahead but we're not pleased with where we are now. It's not what we expect it to be at this point. None of us were looking out a year ago and thinking we'd see these kinds of revenue declines. But I'm also happy it's no the word projected this kind of revenue declines I don't think we would have projected $1.2 billion in earnings. So I don't know . It's a long answer, I'm not sure I can tell you why you what you think, Hunter. But I can tell you what we think and what we think is the near-term is really important but so is the long-term and it seems that times that we focus that you all have to focus more in the near term than we do. And it's -- I don't think that's a good thing that's inconsistent. I don't think that's a disconnect. I just think it's a different perspective of turnaround.

componenttext: It's okay. I want to get more. So this is a question for Scott. So you talk about some of these initiatives to clean up some of the fares and that's good. But they seem like the value add [indiscernible] So this industry, Scott, has a track record of making really good transformational changes when things are really painful and bad. So I'm wondering why we're using a pricing system that dates back to the '80s based on algorithms that might not even apply anymore when the industry structure has completely overhauled. So is it kind of just our thinking transformational stuff here in terms of how you price your ticket, may be to [indiscernible] your initiative, I don't know. But why are you using a pricing system built in the '80s for an industry industry that is now completely different than it used to be when the stuff was designed?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll do my best to answer the question. I'm not 100% sure what you mean transformational. I think we are doing things that maybe they're not big enough to be called transformational. Well, they're certainly evolutionary. Things like basic economy, p
componenttext: Well, I'll do my best to answer the question. I'm not 100% sure what you mean transformational. I think we are doing things that maybe they're not big enough to be called transformational. Well, they're certainly evolutionary. Things like basic economy, premium economy, I'll put in the transformational market. Even things like getting rid of fare -- changing fare combineability and trying to get a better pricing structure to eliminating fare combineability. It has the potential to be transformational. We're stock to some degree with we still sell a huge percentage of our ticket through GDS and through even our own reservation. It's the systems that were built and architected in the 1960s. And this fare combineability is one of those things. It's just built into a hardwiring of the system and when we eliminate it for good reason, we great some unintended consequences with things like multicity ticketing and others. We're running hard  -- we're not the only 1, other airlines too are running hard to change the way we price and to be able to do things to, in particular I think, the commoditized the product and change the way Öland pricing has worked historically, but we're working with these old mainframe systems and it takes us time to get that. It's not just us, it takes our partner's time. It's break time, it takes the squabbled travel time all the changes because we're working these old systems and it's frustrating to us that we can't get these things done quicker because of great ideas about how to sell the product more effectively, about how to be able to at the same airplane compete with Spirit Airlines and at the same time, sell tickets to our premium customers who want a better product then they could ever possibly get on an airline like Spirit. But we're not going to get there tomorrow. We're running in that direction but it's going to take time to get there.

componenttextpreview: Duane, I'll let Steve do the specifics as to where we are because frankly, I'm not certain myself. But the fact of the matter is, we announced the plan that did not record, that did not ask our unions to do anything, in exchange for it. So it's a company
componenttext: Duane, I'll let Steve do the specifics as to where we are because frankly, I'm not certain myself. But the fact of the matter is, we announced the plan that did not record, that did not ask our unions to do anything, in exchange for it. So it's a company profit sharing plan that doesn't require any any negotiations, it simply require any negotiations. It simply requires the unions to agree to put, if they chose to, to put language in their contract basically a side letter that says, we will participate in whatever the company's that plan is and that's what we've asked them to do if I can't imagine a union would not want to put such language in their contracts but that's how it works. This is not a negotiation. The company has a plan, and we are required for, of course, with our collective bargaining groups to -- if we make any changes to the compensation for them to agree to it. But in this case, all they're agreeing to is to accept the profit sharing, not to be asked doing anything else. So Steve, are they all done?

componenttext: Not all done yet. But I expect the bottom line several of the unions have agreed on radio couple of these are reviewing the plan and have internal governance to care of and then 4 of our unions are still in the process of negotiating joint collective-bargaining agreements and that will, I think, obtain the agreement as part of those negotiations.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And certainly we'd be looking you give towards an amount. Thanks for that detail. And then Scott, if you could just talk big picture, I'd love to hear your thoughts on the relationship between fuel prices and revenue. Do you think a higher fuel curve as a
componenttext: And certainly we'd be looking you give towards an amount. Thanks for that detail. And then Scott, if you could just talk big picture, I'd love to hear your thoughts on the relationship between fuel prices and revenue. Do you think a higher fuel curve as accelerates that time line for positive PRASM even if capacity doesn't change?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do think that there is a pretty strong inverse correlation between fuel price and revenue. If you go back and look over the past really going all the way back to, I think, before the financial crisis. And you've seen oil prices go up, you've seen fares
componenttext: I do think that there is a pretty strong inverse correlation between fuel price and revenue. If you go back and look over the past really going all the way back to, I think, before the financial crisis. And you've seen oil prices go up, you've seen fares go up with a lag, with a 3- to 6-month lag. A lot of times that lag, I think part of that is you wind up with less capacity which is completely rationale. You wind up with less capacity, which is completely rational. You wind up with less capacity when oil prices go up and that leads to move this by Croatia leads to higher prices. Disappointed when oil prices fell that link went to the other direction as well, it did. And when oil prices fell, probably went up and fares went down. I think that, that is going to be in place going forward and kind of going back to the earlier question, I think, the investor focus and worry about PRASM is appropriate but essentially it is a worry that link won't exist. It's easy to say oil prices -- earnings are good right now but what if oil prices go up and revenues don't go up along with it? And, I think, that's really I would characterize investor worry about PRASM and I think that it's one of the important points for investing in airlines. If you believe that, it's a pretty investment. If you don't believe that, it's a harder investment. I happen to believe it, we all here believe it pretty strongly. I mean it's only a glamor. But if you look at this quarter, oil prices have gone up. They're still at really low levels. But as they gone up across quarter essentially every airline that I read the transcript for so far, it's something that you talk about reducing capacity. Those 2 things, I think, are correlated. And if it's rational, and so I think that we will see that link if the oil prices go up, that revenues will go up as well and I think that's sort of key to the investment thesis if you're an airline investor. If you believe that it's a pretty sister in the us if you don't believe that, I get the obsession the focus on near-term PRASM and worry about near-term PRASM.

componenttext: And I guess just taking a step back from PRASM, if you're just looking at the sequential revenue trends, just passenger revenue sequentially, with a very low but still modestly higher fuel price, I'd say we're still kind of waiting for that intersection and so and it's just a timing issue would be my guess.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Particularly if you're looking at the second quarter, it will take at the end of the third quarter. It has been 3- to 6-month lag because you start to see oil prices go up you're not going to turn of the schedule tomorrow but the next scheduled change you
componenttext: Particularly if you're looking at the second quarter, it will take at the end of the third quarter. It has been 3- to 6-month lag because you start to see oil prices go up you're not going to turn of the schedule tomorrow but the next scheduled change you're looking out 3 or 4 months in advance is where you start to that marginal flight out that made sense when oil was $35 a barrel but no longer make sense when oil was $50 a barrel.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's take our next question from Helane Becker from Cowen and Company.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, this is my question to you. When you think about the capacity adjustments that you guys has made over the last couple of years in markets in which you reduced capacity, I get the sense that some of the lower-cost guys are coming in and backfilling t
componenttext: Doug, this is my question to you. When you think about the capacity adjustments that you guys has made over the last couple of years in markets in which you reduced capacity, I get the sense that some of the lower-cost guys are coming in and backfilling that. And even in the North Atlantic you're starting to see low-cost providers like Norwegian come in and backfill capacity that you guys have taken out. So don't you run the risk if you shrink too much of giving up traffic share that your traffic share went up falling below your seat share in some of these markets?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for addressing, but Scott to give for answering but from just a larger perspective, of course, no, we don't look to seat sure as our measure of -- as a success factor. We'll look to pass profitable. To the extent you are saved us through we're, et
componenttext: Thanks for addressing, but Scott to give for answering but from just a larger perspective, of course, no, we don't look to seat sure as our measure of -- as a success factor. We'll look to pass profitable. To the extent you are saved us through we're, et cetera we agree with. But to the extent that it was true, we would say that's we're not here to try to have a revenue share or to be the largest. We are here to be the most profitable and the best. So if indeed that's the best, that we are unprofitable, and we therefore, reduce service to a market and it was later replaced by someone else, that's what supposed to happen. We couldn't be profitable there. Someone else wants to give it a shot. That's what competition is. So I wouldn't be particularly concerned for that and that's recently agreed with the premises. anything to add third?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, we are always -- our capacity decisions are always maximizing capacity and when we do that, with about what the consequence in the South overcapacity changes will be an what our competitors will do. And it is naïve not to think of that. For th
componenttext: Yes, look, we are always -- our capacity decisions are always maximizing capacity and when we do that, with about what the consequence in the South overcapacity changes will be an what our competitors will do. And it is naïve not to think of that. For the most part, those 2 things are exactly the same. We assume our competitors are going to be basically doing what they're doing irregardless of us. And therefore, our capacity decisions are just about what is going to happen with our profitability and we're not looking at somebody is going to try to backfill or take market share changes. It's unusual to look at that. That 1 place has become an exception to that but we continue to reduce capacity here, it's been in South America where we could see this disaster, catastrophic numbers coming and started to get ahead or try to get ahead of the curve on reducing capacity pretty significantly. And so of a lot of competitors continue to grow double digits. No the good news is that it appears to have stopped. It's gotten better enough in Brazil in particular that everyone is deciding to shrink. But I was frankly surprised at the competitive reaction in a place where you're having RASM decline to 40% 2 years in a row to see that. But almost everywhere else, we look at the world and just say, whatever it's best for American Airlines is going to be the same no matter what the competitive response is.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a follow-up on some of the comments you made around what you think is investors concern about your the revenue perhaps decoupling from the longer term. I guess just wonder how you sort of apply that logic to today, right? Because if we were to thi
componenttext: So just a follow-up on some of the comments you made around what you think is investors concern about your the revenue perhaps decoupling from the longer term. I guess just wonder how you sort of apply that logic to today, right? Because if we were to think about, for instance, the domestic environment. In the second quarter, you saw about 6.4% revenue decline domestically and I appreciate that probably playing a role but may be you still have a mid-single-digit decline in your unit revenue in Q1. And that's on an industry capacity growth number that's adjusted for leap year and a domestic market of about 5%. And so if I go back and look historically, domestic airline revenue has grown at something like U.S. nominal GDP. So if you have kind of a low to single-digit -- low to mid-single-digit underlying revenue trend as result of just general economic activity and you couple that with a 5% supply growth number then I guess I would have expected something more like low single-digit kind of RASM declined as opposed to mid-single-digit RASM declined. So I guess, sorry for the long-winded question but, I think, the worry here isn't so much that capacity decisions have decoupled from fuel. It's more that pricing seems to have decoupled from what's going on with capacity and, I think, we're all just struggling to understand that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, understand the concern. The first quarter sort of I guess across the industry domestically was weaker than, I think, you would have thought fundamentals would suggest. For us, RASM -- consolidated domestic RASM was down 5.3%. I think you referr
componenttext: Yes, look, understand the concern. The first quarter sort of I guess across the industry domestically was weaker than, I think, you would have thought fundamentals would suggest. For us, RASM -- consolidated domestic RASM was down 5.3%. I think you referred to the mainline my number. But a 5% PRASM decline even a couple of points to that is coming from DPIJ, I think, [indiscernible] better. I really do think it was the first question on the call. I go back to, I think, there were 2 big things that caused the second first quarter to be worse than it would otherwise would have been. One was the temporary change in the pricing structure where advantage fares have gone and now they are back. And second was we had a drop incorporate travel demand mid-quarter that coincided with the decline in the stock market. And we see that happen before and it comes back that's the bad news. The good news is as we move into April, close-in demand as those 2 things have changed, close-in demand actually has picked up pretty well. So fingers are crossed that we are going back to a more normal trendline of the relationship between supply and demand and revenue.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for that. And then I guess, Doug, I know you don't have as much as a crystal ball as maybe we expected you sometimes. But a couple of quarters of all in your Q3 call, was with that can the similar levels that is today maybe $1 or $2 a barrel
componenttext: Okay, thanks for that. And then I guess, Doug, I know you don't have as much as a crystal ball as maybe we expected you sometimes. But a couple of quarters of all in your Q3 call, was with that can the similar levels that is today maybe $1 or $2 a barrel cheap -- sorry, $1 or $2 a barrel more expensive, but generally at same ballpark. At that time, you said you thought there was a reasonable potential impact margins would be down this year but that you would expect pretty good opportunity for margin expansion in 2017. Just wondering if that's still the way you view the world?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what I know I said -- the way you characterize it, I don't want to get into the business of forecasting margins year-over-year. At the time, we were talking about was a real concern among -- on people's part that indeed you might see declines in the
componenttext: Yes, what I know I said -- the way you characterize it, I don't want to get into the business of forecasting margins year-over-year. At the time, we were talking about was a real concern among -- on people's part that indeed you might see declines in the 2016 versus 2015 and at least articulated by some as a concern that we had peaked as an industry. And what I was trying to point out at that time was that was up our review. Indeed, what I said was we believe what I said pretty sure was 2015 has this phenomenon of incredibly quickly falling fuel prices that fell so fast that capacity couldn't catch it. And in a sense, the 2015 results because of that were higher than one would expect them to be the long-term. So well you might see therefore the grants in 2016 and in margins, you shouldn't view that as the industry had peaked rather you should view that as kind of a 1 term, onetime spike in margins in the industry and they would normalize in '16 to a level higher than '14 which by the way it appears they're going to. And therefore, 1 shouldn't assume that they will continue to fall from '16 to '17. So I think all that is still true and that going to try to make a forecast on '17 for you because I don't know. But that's what I was trying to point out that the 2015 -- the fact that 2016 was going to be lower than 2015, which turned out to be, I certainly wouldn't if you asked some sort of cyclical issue as opposed to kind a spike that we had in '15.

componenttext: Second half, we don't have a precise forecast but I think that the trend will continue that all regions will get better in the second half, all 4 regions will continue to progress better because the capacity environment progress better, I think, in the third and fourth quarter. And as result, I expect everyone of what those regions to continue to sequentially improve from the second to the third to the fourth quarter.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Robert Isom. Yes, we've been making considerable investments and seeing payoffs and as Scott noted in his opening remarks, the best indication of that is operating performance in terms of departing and arriving on time and also baggage performance
componenttext: This is Robert Isom. Yes, we've been making considerable investments and seeing payoffs and as Scott noted in his opening remarks, the best indication of that is operating performance in terms of departing and arriving on time and also baggage performance as well to the corresponding impact of that is obviously, fewer disconnected passengers and disconnected and lost bags as well. Inflation adapters are higher. A lot of that is a result of investments we have made that have been put in place in regard to ground equipment, process changes, people. And then as we look forward into the future, you're going to see some benefits from technology changes as well that will really help as we tried to tackle issues when operational disruptions occur. So all positive on that front.

componenttext: You mentioned closing demand ticking up in April question is a really more volumes ticking up or are you seeing improvements in yield? Because our sense is that yields under pressure because winning corporate travel.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're not seeing pickup in yield. It is improvement, it is certainly improvement in volume but the revenue environment, the book revenues were also improving relative to where they were in February and March. In February and March, we had the same yi
componenttext: Yes, we're not seeing pickup in yield. It is improvement, it is certainly improvement in volume but the revenue environment, the book revenues were also improving relative to where they were in February and March. In February and March, we had the same yield issue that we have right now sure that's really with no different but we also had weak volumes. So we still have weak year-over-year yields but unlike February and March where we have weak year-over-year yields an weak year-over-year volumes at least now we have higher year-over-year volumes.

componenttext: On the AAdvantage fare thing, can I just -- can you remind me I thought that was like a proprietary thing that US Airways had, which was sort of a cheaper ticket for flights via connection. But you're talking about it almost like it's a generic thing now. Could you explain that to me?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is a generic thing now. You describe it correctly. It is when a connecting carrier offers a lower price than the nonstop carrier. The rationale being that an inferior product from a customer going to fly nonstop and some offer a lower price and that's
componenttext: It is a generic thing now. You describe it correctly. It is when a connecting carrier offers a lower price than the nonstop carrier. The rationale being that an inferior product from a customer going to fly nonstop and some offer a lower price and that's something that US Airways uniquely did. We brought it had to American Airlines after the merger and when we did that, our large competitors copied us. So now it is superbly is a generic thing but it is a really systematic and accessed virtually everywhere there's nonstop services in the U.S.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would be an incorrect headline, Ted. What I would say is the team at American Airlines is doing an excellent job of running the airline, getting 2 airlines integrated, taking care of other customers and the result of that is profitable. And the resul
componenttext: That would be an incorrect headline, Ted. What I would say is the team at American Airlines is doing an excellent job of running the airline, getting 2 airlines integrated, taking care of other customers and the result of that is profitable. And the result of those profits is primarily being used to invest in its product and its team because it's team is critical to its product and those results are paying of. And the future of America books really bright as a result of for that, the industry has been transformed, the American Airlines has been transformed and you should expect to see more of that in the future. But businesses are supposed to be profitable and ours is. And we expect to continue it to be and to the extent that we can generate profits and use of those to continue to put in product and take care of our team and to the extent we have generate even more than that, that gets returned to shareholders. So it's what business is supposed to do and we're happy to be actually in that position now versus where airlines have been in the past. So the headline I know but whatever.
