componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Joseph DeNardi with Stifel.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, just a question, kind of on the PRASM environment and the messaging. I feel like it's getting a little bit mixed. And if you guys wanted to get to flat PRASM or positive PRASM, you could probably do it next quarter, but you're not because that capa
componenttext: Scott, just a question, kind of on the PRASM environment and the messaging. I feel like it's getting a little bit mixed. And if you guys wanted to get to flat PRASM or positive PRASM, you could probably do it next quarter, but you're not because that capacity is earnings and cash flow-accretive. So can you just talk about, in an environment where you did reduce capacity, what would cash flow look like and what are you doing with incremental cash flow you're getting from the capacity growth?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first, I don't think it's that simple. I think American Airlines unilaterally reducing capacity wouldn't get us to PRASM positive on its own, and it's going to require more than that. It's going to require a lot of the kinds of things that I talked
componenttext:
Well, first, I don't think it's that simple. I think American Airlines unilaterally reducing capacity wouldn't get us to PRASM positive on its own, and it's going to require more than that. It's going to require a lot of the kinds of things that I talked about in my prepared remarks. There are some near-term things that we're focused on, particularly in the yield management area. And a lot of the longer-term investments and initiatives are the kind of things that are going to get us not just back to positive PRASM growth, but hopefully recovering what we've lost in '15 and '16 and get back to actual real PRASM growth. 
We're not in a world where we're saying, keep capacity in place, just taking a near-term perspective on cash flow or anything else. We are focused on getting to cash flow or PRASM-positive. You see us, I don't know how many quarters in a row, 6 or 7 quarters in a row, where we have reduced capacity. But I don't think capacity is a simplistic button to push that will just magically turn PRASM-positive.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Doug, just on the decision on the profit sharing side of this, are -- have you seen -- are you expecting benefits operationally from improved employee engagement? Is that part of this? Or is it just you had to do this so just -- also doing
componenttext: Okay. And then Doug, just on the decision on the profit sharing side of this, are -- have you seen -- are you expecting benefits operationally from improved employee engagement? Is that part of this? Or is it just you had to do this so just -- also doing business at this point?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Joe, we're not going to try and point to anything where you're going to see absolute improvement. What I can tell you is this, we'd lost part of the team, and it's really important, particularly at this airline, given the future -- given the history
componenttext: Well, Joe, we're not going to try and point to anything where you're going to see absolute improvement. What I can tell you is this, we'd lost part of the team, and it's really important, particularly at this airline, given the future -- given the history that the team had gone through. And given what we're trying to accomplish to pull everyone together and help them understand that, indeed, it's different, much like we're trying to, with every one of our partners, help them understand that the world is different. What had happened is we'd lost a part of the team not because -- they understood analytically the argument we laid out, and that we've laid out for you and that we lay out all the time. And it certainly passed our, "look them in the eye test" which was important to us. We all talk about it with the team. We need to look our employees in the eye and tell them why we made the decisions, and we could do that extremely well. We just didn't like the look we were getting back on this one. I mean, the employees got it with their brains but they didn't get it in their hearts. And it really felt like -- again, largely because, while our other -- while our competitors kind of were moving in our direction, they weren't going to the point that we had. And other airlines had in place these profit-sharing programs, and we did not. And it felt to our team like we -- well, they understood, again, the logic -- felt as though we weren't appreciating their contribution to the bottom line, which is the last thing we were trying to accomplish. So what we realized is, if we were going to really get our team engaged and excited, which is an imperative to accomplishing all we want to accomplish and all the things Scott talked about that we're working on, to get -- or to compete against the other airlines, and particularly for premium travelers, we have to have our team engaged and excited, and this was holding us back. So I firmly believe it's in our shareholders' best interest to do it. We wouldn't have done it otherwise. We have indeed seen an uplift in engagement and excitement because of this. Not so much, I don't think, because of the actual dollars involved, just because it proved what our employees wanted to believe, that indeed, it is different. And that we will listen. And that we will do things even though we've made -- even though we've taken strong positions, if it gets to the point that we think it's not working, we're willing to revisit those decisions. So all those things have had a positive impact on the team. I think that's good for -- I know it's good for our shareholders. It's impossible to quantify. And it's also early. The real challenge to the team is to not -- is to now build on it. This is temporary. While the profit sharing is -- will stay in place, the feeling of instituting profit sharing is not going to stay in place. It will become just, I imagine, over time, just part of everyone's compensation that they -- that -- in the way they view it. And our challenge is now to use it to go do the things that we want to go do as an airline and put in place the product with the people that do their job so well. And we want to. So just a long way of me saying, it wasn't an easy decision, but I know it's the right decision for our shareholders.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: And we'll go next to Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: The transatlantic PRASM, down just 2%, was really quite impressive compared to peers. What are the primary factors there? And how do you expect that to trend into Q2?
componenttext: The transatlantic PRASM, down just 2%, was really quite impressive compared to peers. What are the primary factors there? And how do you expect that to trend into Q2?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, we did it -- we had a good quarter. Some of that is true-ups that happened at the end of the year or for the previous year. So some of our outperformance this quarter was really -- it was true-ups from earlier quarters, which means that our earlier
componenttext: Look, we did it -- we had a good quarter. Some of that is true-ups that happened at the end of the year or for the previous year. So some of our outperformance this quarter was really -- it was true-ups from earlier quarters, which means that our earlier quarter performance would have been better. We expect that to get a little bit worse in the second quarter. Demand across the transatlantic, though, particularly with the -- in light of the Brussels tragedy, has remained pretty strong and pretty resilient. There is a lot of capacity coming, however, so I expect to take that -- that to take a downturn going forward. But core demand still seems pretty good across the Atlantic.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Scott, can you comment on advanced booking trends in corporate versus leisure and whether you're using the same positive trends in advance summer yields domestically that Delta called out last week?
componenttext: Okay. And Scott, can you comment on advanced booking trends in corporate versus leisure and whether you're using the same positive trends in advance summer yields domestically that Delta called out last week?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we hit a -- I'll go back a little bit. We hit a little bit of a rough patch in February and March, where corporate demand, in particular, seemed a little weak, and I think a lot of airlines -- well, every airline tended to see that. I think, actually
componenttext:
Yes, we hit a -- I'll go back a little bit. We hit a little bit of a rough patch in February and March, where corporate demand, in particular, seemed a little weak, and I think a lot of airlines -- well, every airline tended to see that. I think, actually, I think, there's 2 reasons for that as near as I can hypothesize, both of which have gotten better now, so that's the good news. The first one is, we had a stock market that dropped, whatever it dropped, 10% or 12% and, as we've said before, on a headline basis, whether it should or not, that does affect travel demand, particularly corporate travel demand, which it's easy to go when you start to get worried, rein in your travel and entertainment budget. 
And so I do think that was one of the factors, it appears that the market has come back. That close-in booking demand has gotten stronger. 
Another thing that happened, which got talked about a little bit on our earnings call the last time, I got asked a question about Advantage fares, which I know many people on this call think -- or were worried was problematic, and I declined to answer it on the last call. The reason I declined to answer it is because there were no Advantage fares on the market at the time. None of the airlines had Advantage fares. They'd all been canceled. And so I didn't want to talk about it. 
We went for about 3 months with no Advantage fares in the market. That 3-month period actually coincided with the relative decline in revenue expectations across mostly all airlines. So we were starting to wonder if our decision to cancel Advantage fares was really the correct revenue decision. But before we had made a final decision on that, one of our competitors, I presumably concluded, that it was also the wrong decision and put them back. So they've been back in the market now for a couple of weeks. And the combination of those 2 things means that in the last couple of weeks, we've actually seen strengthening close-in demand, not just absolute demand, but booked revenue. So we actually feel better about the revenue environment than we would have, say, 3 to 4 weeks ago. 
On the domestic front, I know that some have talked advanced book yields being up. That's true for us, too. Our booked yields domestically for May, June, July and August are up year-over-year for all of those months. But I don't want to mislead anyone because that's been true for the past several months. The issue has not really been about advanced book yields. We've had advanced book yields domestically up. It's been about weak close-in yields. And there still is weakness in close-in yields, although we do have a pretty strong demand environment. And bookings are up a lot year-over-year, but the yield is tending to fall as we get closer to departure.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Jamie Baker with JP Morgan.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jamie Baker with JP Morgan.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, following up on your last point, if we look at the domestic fare structure, it looks pretty sloppy to me. I don't really care how we got here, but the fares that I'm being asked to pay, particularly close-in, and to your point, they strike me as st
componenttext: Scott, following up on your last point, if we look at the domestic fare structure, it looks pretty sloppy to me. I don't really care how we got here, but the fares that I'm being asked to pay, particularly close-in, and to your point, they strike me as stupidly low. Notwithstanding airlines recalcitrance to discuss pricing, what is potentially wrong with the structure? Is it multi-segment itineraries that are pricing too low? Is it the junk fares have been popping up in markets where discounters don't even exist? Is it something about minimum stay requirements? I mean, the reason I ask is not in regards to what you might do differently, it's what we might be looking for, keeping an eye out for in terms of change as opposed to just monitoring for plain vanilla fare increases?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I won't use the term wrong because of the connotations that has. But the fare environment has changed over the last couple of decades. One of the big -- probably, I think the biggest change has been the lack of pricing fences. So historically, airli
componenttext:
Well, I won't use the term wrong because of the connotations that has. But the fare environment has changed over the last couple of decades. One of the big -- probably, I think the biggest change has been the lack of pricing fences. So historically, airlines had a 14-day advance purchases with Saturday night stays, and that was an effective way to segment demand and offer business travelers great product, high-frequency, the availability to book last minute, but also to be able to offer leisure fares that could fill the empty seats on airplanes that were below the average cost of flying the airplanes, but could fill what would have otherwise been empty seats, and it would effectively have segmented demand. Really, because of the growth of low-cost carriers, those pricing fences have broken down across-the-board, and you have lots of 0 AP [ph] fares, lots of one-way fares and more than anything, that's what, I think, has driven lower fares for business travel and for close-in traffic. 
Now the ways to combat that are -- and to drive higher fares, basic and premium economy are 2 of the really, I think, big levers for American Airlines in doing that. We're not going to have that really in place until next year. But today, when we -- we wind up having to be competitive with others, and so we have low fares in the market that have very few restrictions on them, and there's no reason for a customer to pay more. And we're going to -- you get the exact same product, whether you buy a $41 walk-up fare or a $900 walk-up fare. And we're going to change that. And we're going to have different products. And the more you're paying, the better benefits you're going to get. That's one of the really big things that we can do. Part of that -- part and parcel of that is investing in the products and having a great product that customers are actually willing to pay for and pay more for. So that for those customers who aren't commodity customers, we have a lot of our customers who are commoditized. But for those customers who are not commoditized, we can sell them a better product and be appropriately compensated for that. 
You also see changes going on in the industry like this stuff about fare combinability which, for the most part, has been rolled back now. But those are -- the fare combinability is an artifact of history that goes back to the 1960s when GDSs were first built and has had unintended consequences as the pricing environment changed. So the fact that those kinds of changes are happening, even if they happen in fitful "one step forward, two steps back" kind of process are actually long-term encouraging to me because we're moving to a world where we're getting away from just commoditizing the price of the product and getting to we will sell a commoditized product for some customers, but for other customers, we will be able to decommoditize the product, and that's not going to happen overnight. That's not going to happen this year, but we're on a good path to get there. And that's a structural change.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Helpful. And then a quick housekeeping question. Derek, there were reports in the last couple of weeks about stepped-up hedging by airlines. It wasn't even clear that the unnamed airlines were even in the United States, but I do feel compelled
componenttext: All right. Helpful. And then a quick housekeeping question. Derek, there were reports in the last couple of weeks about stepped-up hedging by airlines. It wasn't even clear that the unnamed airlines were even in the United States, but I do feel compelled to ask. Any changes in terms of American's no-hedge policy?

componenttext: No changes at this time.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] benefits from yield management and cabin segmentation, credit cards, et cetera. To the extent that you have those in place today or at some point going forward, what would pricing actually look like? Would you be more flattish? Would be po
componenttext: [indiscernible] benefits from yield management and cabin segmentation, credit cards, et cetera. To the extent that you have those in place today or at some point going forward, what would pricing actually look like? Would you be more flattish? Would be positive? That's the first question. And then the second question, just on the domestic side, what sort of capacity growth does the industry need to see it actually have more stable pricing? Clearly, the numbers we're seeing today aren't cutting it, but just your thoughts there on all of that would be great.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the second part of the second part of the question, I'm just going to say I can't answer that about industry capacity [indiscernible] and just say that, look, we try to do what's best for American Airlines, as I said. We always try to give you guys
componenttext:
So on the second part of the second part of the question, I'm just going to say I can't answer that about industry capacity [indiscernible] and just say that, look, we try to do what's best for American Airlines, as I said. We always try to give you guys the best 50-50 forecast that we can on our outlook for capacity growth. And in a world where we continue to see PRASM declines, even though our earnings have been growing for many quarters in a row, in a world of negative PRASM, we view that as indicative of supply and demand being misbalanced. And so as a result, we've cut capacity historically. 
Turning to those other items, they're really hard to quantify. A credit card deal, I'm not going to try to quantify. You can look to what other deals have done and make your own guess as to what the American Airlines deal will be. The American Airlines loyalty program and our partnerships with Citi and Barclays, we have the largest and best loyalty program in the world, and we're very proud of that. And we have 2 great partners today, and we're looking forward to making that even better for American Airlines, for our customers and for our bank partners. 
On the other items, some of those things are longer-term, like basic economy, premium economy. Those are really 2017 initiatives for next year, again, hard to quantify. In the yield management area, those are the -- that's the kind of thing that when we'll ultimately get everything completed that we're working on. It's probably -- we don't -- it's, again, impossible to know for sure but probably worth 2 to 3 points of PRASM, at least I think it should be worth 2 to 3 points of PRASM. But it's also hard to know when you will finish that. Yes, you put a new yield management system in place. You're replacing something that's been there for 25 years. You're going to get to a better position in the end, but all the patches and things that have been built into the system for the past 25 years to fix this problem or that problem or this place that didn't work worked well -- you rip off all those Band-Aids, and so you do take a few steps back sometimes before you can really get the system tuned and running. And that's, frankly, a continuous process. It never finishes. But we're right in the middle of starting a conversion process, so it's probably more challenging for us in the short term than it would be in a normal state of time. But I think, improvements to yield management, ultimately, should be worth 2 to 3 points for us.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I can squeeze in one quick one for Derek. I think I know the answer to this, but as far as your peers, they've stepped-up some aircraft orders recently, be it because of regional issues or just better pricing from the OEMs. Where are you guys on all of
componenttext: If I can squeeze in one quick one for Derek. I think I know the answer to this, but as far as your peers, they've stepped-up some aircraft orders recently, be it because of regional issues or just better pricing from the OEMs. Where are you guys on all of that? And I know you've have some regional issues, but you also have the big order books. Just some quick color would be great.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's no change to our order book. I think we have a significant amount of aircraft coming in this year, '17, '18, '19. So I think we have the order that's in place that needs to be there. So there's no change to our order book going forward. We'll
componenttext: Yes, there's no change to our order book. I think we have a significant amount of aircraft coming in this year, '17, '18, '19. So I think we have the order that's in place that needs to be there. So there's no change to our order book going forward. We'll always be looking at opportunities. But at this point in time, no change to the order book going forward.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Raj, let me just use that to make a plug. I mean, the reason we're not looking for new orders is, as Derek said, we have a large order book, and we've brought in a lot of new airplanes. Our team is just -- one of the things we don't talk about enough, I t
componenttext: Raj, let me just use that to make a plug. I mean, the reason we're not looking for new orders is, as Derek said, we have a large order book, and we've brought in a lot of new airplanes. Our team is just -- one of the things we don't talk about enough, I think, is the great job our team has done of modernizing this fleet. Robert Isom and his team were inducting a new airplane almost every 4 days or about every 4 days then retiring an older one. The result is the American Airlines fleet now is down right around 10 years on average, which is lower than any of our peers and well lower than some of our peers and shrinking. When we did the merger, we were -- we had the second oldest fleet of the 4 largest airlines. Now we have the youngest. And that's happened -- that's because we've lowered our fleet age over time. This is something the others -- that we're ahead of the others on. We're happy about that. It's a product advantage. It's also a future capital allocation advantage.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: We'll go next to Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. Hey, Doug, or Scott, or anybody, why do you think the...
componenttext: Two questions. Hey, Doug, or Scott, or anybody, why do you think the...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: There's a lot of us here, Hunter. What have you got?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. Well, then, Doug, why do you think we care so much about PRASM? And if you were on the buy-side, how would you think about PRASM when making an investment decision?
componenttext: Okay, good. Well, then, Doug, why do you think we care so much about PRASM? And if you were on the buy-side, how would you think about PRASM when making an investment decision?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're asking me why I think, you think what you think?
componenttext: You're asking me why I think, you think what you think?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. That's exactly what I'm asking.
componenttext: That's right. That's exactly what I'm asking.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll do my best. Look, Hunter, you all have to -- you have customers that care about near term. You have some that care about long term. We care more about the long term. I think it's the only difference. And again, I wouldn't say the difference. We
componenttext: Okay, I'll do my best. Look, Hunter, you all have to -- you have customers that care about near term. You have some that care about long term. We care more about the long term. I think it's the only difference. And again, I wouldn't say the difference. We -- look, we care like crazy about our revenue trends in the near term and what they look like next quarter. We just -- I think, I have a sense we don't care as much as some of your investors. But look, if I was an investor who had a short-term horizon on trading, I would care about what next -- what tomorrow's revenues look like. And that's a lot of who you have to deal with, and those are our shareholders we care about them as well. But our job is to maximize long-term shareholder value, and that doesn't mean at all that we ignore the near term, and I'm not -- none of us would suggest that we are. But this is what I tried to say in my comments. Just because we're bullish about the future don't take that to mean that we're entirely pleased with the current environment because we're not. We just -- I just -- we just happen to believe that the long-term prospects for the stock don't -- are not reflected in the current price. And maybe that's because there's too much focus on the near term or maybe it's just because we're wrong. I don't know. So look, that's for you all to decide. Our job is to run the airline for the long term. We are very excited about the long term. We are not pleased with the current term. Again, I shouldn't say we're not pleased. We're actually making $1.2 billion in the quarter is not something we're unhappy about. But our value -- or our job is to maximize shareholder value, and we know there are things that we -- that can be done better. And particularly, as Scott has noted, on the revenue environment, we think there are brighter days ahead, but we're not pleased with where we are now. It's not where we expected to be at this point. None of us were looking out a year ago and thinking we'd see these kinds of revenue declines. But I'm also happy to report that if we -- if someone were to have projected these kinds of revenue declines, I don't think they would have projected $1.2 billion in earnings. So I don't know. It's a long answer, and I'm not sure I can tell you why you what you think, Hunter. But what I -- I can tell you what we think, and what we think is the near term is really important but so is the long term. And it seems at times that we focus -- that you all have to focus more on the near term than we do. And so I don't think that's inconsistent. I don't think that's a disconnect. I just think it's a different perspective of time horizon.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when your long-term shareholders have their stocks go down 25%, they become near term as well, but...
componenttext: Well, I think when your long-term shareholders have their stocks go down 25%, they become near term as well, but...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No kidding. Absolutely, Hunter -- right.
componenttext: No kidding. Absolutely, Hunter -- right.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's okay. I want to get more in. So this is a question for Scott. So you talk about some of these initiatives to clean up some of the fares, and that's good. But they seem like the value-add -- they're value-add, for sure, but they also seem a little bit
componenttext: It's okay. I want to get more in. So this is a question for Scott. So you talk about some of these initiatives to clean up some of the fares, and that's good. But they seem like the value-add -- they're value-add, for sure, but they also seem a little bit transactional. So this industry, Scott, has a track record of making really good transformational changes when things are really painful and bad. So I'm wondering why we're using a pricing system that dates back to the '80s based on algorithms that might not even apply anymore when the industry structure has completely overhauled. So is it time to start thinking transformational stuff here in terms of how you price your ticket? Maybe it's a 5-year initiative, I don't know. But why are we using a pricing system built in the '80s for an industry that is now completely different than it used to be when this stuff was designed?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll do my best to answer the question. I'm not 100% sure what you mean by transformational. I think we are doing things that maybe they're not big enough to be called transformational but they're certainly evolutionary. Things like basic economy, p
componenttext: Well, I'll do my best to answer the question. I'm not 100% sure what you mean by transformational. I think we are doing things that maybe they're not big enough to be called transformational but they're certainly evolutionary. Things like basic economy, premium economy, I'll put in the transformational bucket. Even things like getting rid of fare -- changing fare combinability and trying to get a better pricing structure through eliminating fare combinability -- has the potential to be transformational. We're stuck to some degree with -- we still sell a huge percentage of our tickets through GDSs and through even our own reservation systems, systems that were built and architected in the 1960s. And this fare combinability is one of those things. It's just built into the hardwiring of the system. And when we eliminate it for good reason, we create some unintended consequences with things like multicity ticketing and others. We're all -- we're running hard, we're not the only one. Other airlines, too, are running hard to change the way we price and to be able to do things to, in particular, I think, decommoditize the product and change the way airline pricing has worked historically. But we're working with these old mainframe systems, and it takes us time to get that done. It's not just us, it takes our partners' time, it takes SABRE time, it takes AmEx GlobalTravel time, all the changes because we're working in these old systems. And it's frustrating to us that we can't get these things done quicker because of great ideas about how to sell the product more effectively, about how to be able to, at the same airplane, compete with Spirit Airlines and at the same time, sell tickets to our premium customers who want a better product than they could ever possibly get on an airline like Spirit. But we're not going to get there tomorrow. We are running in that direction, but it's going to take time to get there.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the profit sharing, you're accruing, and I would assume that for your unionized employees, you would need an approval there. Can you talk about the time line for those approvals? And if there is a chance that after accruing you don't have to pay it?
componenttext: On the profit sharing, you're accruing, and I would assume that for your unionized employees, you would need an approval there. Can you talk about the time line for those approvals? And if there is a chance that after accruing you don't have to pay it?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, I'll let Steve give you the specifics as to where we are because, frankly, I'm not certain myself. But the fact of the matter is we announced the plan that did not ask our unions to do anything in exchange for it. So it's a company profit-sharing p
componenttext: Duane, I'll let Steve give you the specifics as to where we are because, frankly, I'm not certain myself. But the fact of the matter is we announced the plan that did not ask our unions to do anything in exchange for it. So it's a company profit-sharing plan that doesn't require any negotiations. It simply requires the unions to agree to put, if they chose to, to put language in their contract, basically a side letter that says "We will participate in whatever the company's plan is." And that's what we've asked them to do if -- I can't imagine a union would not want to put such language in their contracts, but that's how it works. This is not a negotiation. The company has a plan, and we are required for, of course, with our collective bargaining groups to -- if we make any changes to the compensation for them to agree to it. But in this case, all they're agreeing to, is to accept the profit sharing, not to be asked do anything else. So Steve, are they all done?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not all done yet. But I expect them to fall in line. Several of the unions have agreed already. A couple of unions are reviewing the plan and have internal governance to care of. And then 4 of our unions are still in the process of negotiating joint colle
componenttext: Not all done yet. But I expect them to fall in line. Several of the unions have agreed already. A couple of unions are reviewing the plan and have internal governance to care of. And then 4 of our unions are still in the process of negotiating joint collective bargaining agreements and will, I think, obtain the agreement as part of those negotiations.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it would be a big mistake to assume that we would not pay these. You're more likely to assume that some union officials get tossed out if we don't pay them. So they're going to be paid as they should be.
componenttext: I think it would be a big mistake to assume that we would not pay these. You're more likely to assume that some union officials get tossed out if we don't pay them. So they're going to be paid as they should be.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That certainly would be looking a gift horse in the mouth. And then Scott, if you could just talk big picture, I'd love to hear your thoughts on the relationship between fuel prices and revenue. Do you think a higher fuel curve accelerates that time line
componenttext: That certainly would be looking a gift horse in the mouth. And then Scott, if you could just talk big picture, I'd love to hear your thoughts on the relationship between fuel prices and revenue. Do you think a higher fuel curve accelerates that time line for positive PRASM even if capacity doesn't change?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do think that there's a pretty strong inverse correlation between fuel price and revenue. Look, you go back and look over the past really going all the way back to, I think, before the financial crisis and you've seen oil prices go up, you've seen fares
componenttext: I do think that there's a pretty strong inverse correlation between fuel price and revenue. Look, you go back and look over the past really going all the way back to, I think, before the financial crisis and you've seen oil prices go up, you've seen fares go up with a lag, with a 3- to 6-month lag. A lot of times that lag, I mean, I think part of that is that you wind up with less capacity, which is completely rational. You wind up with less capacity when oil prices go up and that leads to a move in the supply curve, which leads to higher prices. I was disappointed when oil prices fell, but that link went the other direction as well, it did. And when oil prices fell, supply went up and fares went down. I think that, that is going to be in place going forward. And kind of going back to the earlier question, I think, the investor focus and worry about PRASM is appropriate, but essentially it is a worry that, that link won't exist. It's easy to say oil prices -- earnings are good right now, but what if oil prices go up and revenues don't go up along with it? And I think, that's really, I would characterize investor worry about PRASM. And I think it's one of the important points for investing in airlines. If you believe that, it's a pretty easy investment. If you don't believe that, it's a harder investment. I happen to believe it. We all here believe it pretty strongly. I mean, it's only a glimmer, but even if you look at this quarter, oil prices have gone up. They're still at really low levels. But as they've gone up across this quarter, essentially every airline that I've read the transcript for, so far, it's something they talk about reducing capacity. Those 2 things, I think, are correlated. And if it's rational, and so I think that we will see that link. And if oil prices go up, that revenues will go up as well. And I think that's sort of key to the investment thesis if you're an airline investor. If you believe that, it's a pretty easy story to say yes. And if you don't believe that, I get the focus on near-term PRASM and worry about near-term PRASM.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, it's Doug, if I can. All I want to add to that is I should have included that as part of my response to Hunter. I think, to Hunter's question, why is there -- if there's -- to the extent, there's a disconnect, it's that. I didn't -- I think I tried
componenttext: Duane, it's Doug, if I can. All I want to add to that is I should have included that as part of my response to Hunter. I think, to Hunter's question, why is there -- if there's -- to the extent, there's a disconnect, it's that. I didn't -- I think I tried to say that but I didn't articulate that point. The focus on near-term PRASM, I think, we look at -- I think investors look at that and think, "My gosh, if oil prices go up, what's this going to look like?" And we believe if oil prices goes up, it won't look like this. So I think that's as much as anything and I should -- and I should have made that more explicit in my response to Hunter.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, just taking a step back from PRASM, if you're just looking at the sequential revenue trends, just passenger revenue sequentially, with a very low but still modestly higher fuel price, I'd say we're still kind of waiting for that inflection. A
componenttext: And I guess, just taking a step back from PRASM, if you're just looking at the sequential revenue trends, just passenger revenue sequentially, with a very low but still modestly higher fuel price, I'd say we're still kind of waiting for that inflection. And so I think it's just a timing issue would be my guess.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, particularly if you're looking at the second quarter, it will take end of the third quarter. It has been a 3- to 6-month lag because you start to see oil prices go up, you're not going to turn off the schedule tomorrow. But the next schedule change t
componenttext: Yes, particularly if you're looking at the second quarter, it will take end of the third quarter. It has been a 3- to 6-month lag because you start to see oil prices go up, you're not going to turn off the schedule tomorrow. But the next schedule change that you're looking out 3 to 4 months in advance is where you start to prune that marginal flight out. That made sense when oil was $35 a barrel, but no longer makes sense when oil is $50 a barrel.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Helane Becker with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Helane Becker with Cowen and Company.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, this is my question to you. When you think about the capacity adjustments that you guys have made over the last couple of years and markets in which you've reduced capacity, I get the sense that some of the lower-cost guys are coming in and backfill
componenttext: Doug, this is my question to you. When you think about the capacity adjustments that you guys have made over the last couple of years and markets in which you've reduced capacity, I get the sense that some of the lower-cost guys are coming in and backfilling that. And even on the North Atlantic you're starting to see low-cost providers like Norwegian come in and backfill capacity that you guys have taken out. So don't you run the risk if you shrink too much of giving up seat -- traffic share, that your traffic share winds up falling below your seat share in some of these markets?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helane, thanks for addressing that to me, but Scott will probably end up doing most of the answering. But I'll answer from just a larger perspective. Of course not, we don't look to seat share as our measure of -- as a success factor. What we look to is w
componenttext: Helane, thanks for addressing that to me, but Scott will probably end up doing most of the answering. But I'll answer from just a larger perspective. Of course not, we don't look to seat share as our measure of -- as a success factor. What we look to is where we're profitable. So to the extent what you're saying is true, which I'm not certain we'd agree with, but to the extent that was true, we would say, "Well, that's -- we're not here to try and have a revenue share or to be the largest. We're here to be the most profitable and the best." So if indeed that's the case, that we were unprofitable and when we -- and we therefore reduced service to a market, and it was later replaced by someone else, that's what's supposed to happen. We couldn't be profitable there. And someone else wants to give it a shot. That's what competition is. So I wouldn't be particularly concerned by that, but I'm also not certain we agree with the premise as much as stated. Scott, anything to add?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, we were always -- our capacity decisions are about maximizing profitability. And when we're doing that, we do think about what the consequences of our capacity changes will be and what our competitors will do. And it'd be naïve not to think of
componenttext: Yes, look, we were always -- our capacity decisions are about maximizing profitability. And when we're doing that, we do think about what the consequences of our capacity changes will be and what our competitors will do. And it'd be naïve not to think of that. For the most part, those 2 things are exactly the same. We assume our competitors are going to basically be doing what they're doing irregardless of us. And therefore, our capacity decisions are just about what is going to happen with our profitability, and we're not looking at somebody is going to try to backfill it or market share changes. It's unusual to look at that. If there's one place that's become an exception to that, that we continue to reduce capacity here, it's been in South America, where we could see this disaster, catastrophic numbers coming and started to get ahead or tried to get ahead of the curve on reducing capacity pretty significantly. And saw a lot of competitors continue to grow double digits. Now the good news is that appears to have stopped. It's gotten bad enough in Brazil, in particular, that everyone is deciding to shrink. But I was frankly surprised at the competitive reaction in a place where you're having RASM decline to 40% 2 years in a row to see that. But almost everywhere else, we look at the world and just say, here's -- whatever is best for American Airlines is going to be the same no matter what the competitive response is.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on -- just sort of a maintenance-related item on the maintenance cost being down 15%. I'm assuming that's with the new fleet and there's nothing -- and that's like a new run rate of a quarterly spend. Or was there something in the quar
componenttext: Okay. And then just on -- just sort of a maintenance-related item on the maintenance cost being down 15%. I'm assuming that's with the new fleet and there's nothing -- and that's like a new run rate of a quarterly spend. Or was there something in the quarter that made it be down more given the shift in the fleet age, blah, blah, blah?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, part of it is that and then also there's some timing there. It will be higher in the second quarter, but it's just timing of engine overhauls and aircraft overhauls in the first quarter. There were fewer there than there will be throughout the year.
componenttext: No, part of it is that and then also there's some timing there. It will be higher in the second quarter, but it's just timing of engine overhauls and aircraft overhauls in the first quarter. There were fewer there than there will be throughout the year.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Darryl Genovesi with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Darryl Genovesi with UBS.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a follow-up on some of the comments you made around what you think is investors' concern about your revenue perhaps decoupling from oil on the longer term. I guess, I just wonder how you sort of apply that logic to today, right? Because I mean, if
componenttext: So just a follow-up on some of the comments you made around what you think is investors' concern about your revenue perhaps decoupling from oil on the longer term. I guess, I just wonder how you sort of apply that logic to today, right? Because I mean, if we just were to think about, for instance, the domestic environment, in the second quarter, you saw about a 6.5% revenue decline domestically, and I appreciate that DPIJ is probably playing a role. But maybe you still have a mid-single-digit decline in your unit revenue in Q1. And that's on an industry capacity growth number that's adjusted for leap year and the domestic market of about 5%. And so if I to go back and look historically, domestic airline revenue has grown at something like U.S. nominal GDP. So if you have kind of a low to single digit -- low to mid-single-digit underlying revenue trend as a result of just general economic activity and you couple that with a 5% supply growth number, then I guess I would have expected something more like a low single-digit kind of RASM decline as opposed to a mid-single-digit RASM decline. So just, I guess, sorry for the long-winded question, but the -- I think, the worry here isn't so much that capacity decisions have decoupled from fuel. It's more that pricing seems to have decoupled from what's going on with capacity, and I think, we're all just struggling to understand that.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, I understand the concern. The first quarter, sort of, I guess, across the industry domestically was weaker than, I think, you would have thought fundamentals would suggest. For us, RASM -- consolidated domestic RASM was down 5.3%. I think you r
componenttext: Yes, look, I understand the concern. The first quarter, sort of, I guess, across the industry domestically was weaker than, I think, you would have thought fundamentals would suggest. For us, RASM -- consolidated domestic RASM was down 5.3%. I think you referred to the mainline number. But a 5% PRASM decline, even a couple of points of that is coming from DPIJ. I thought it was better. I really do think -- I think it was the first question on the call. I'd go back to, I think, there were 2 big things that caused the first quarter to be worse than it otherwise would have been. One was the temporary change in the pricing structure where Advantage Fares were gone and now they're back. And second was we had a drop in corporate travel demand mid-quarter that coincided with the decline in the stock market. And we've seen that happened before, and it comes back. That's the bad news. The good news is as we've moved into April, close-in demand -- as those 2 things have changed, close-in demand actually has picked up pretty well. So our fingers are crossed that we're going to be back to a more normal trend line of the relationship between supply and demand and revenue.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for that. And then, I guess, Doug, I know you don't have as much of a crystal ball as maybe we expect you to sometimes. But a couple of quarters ago on your Q3 call, oil was at kind of a similar level as it is today, maybe $1 or $2 a barrel c
componenttext: Okay, thanks for that. And then, I guess, Doug, I know you don't have as much of a crystal ball as maybe we expect you to sometimes. But a couple of quarters ago on your Q3 call, oil was at kind of a similar level as it is today, maybe $1 or $2 a barrel cheap -- sorry, $1 or $2 a barrel more expensive, but generally in the same ballpark. And at the time, you said you thought that there was a reasonable potential that margins would be down this year, but that you would expect pretty good opportunity for margin expansion in 2017. Just wondering if that's still the way you view the world.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Darryl, what I know I said, and I'm not arguing what -- the way you characterized it based on -- I don't want to get into the business of forecasting margins from year-to-year. At the time, what we were talking about was a real concern among -- on pe
componenttext: Yes, Darryl, what I know I said, and I'm not arguing what -- the way you characterized it based on -- I don't want to get into the business of forecasting margins from year-to-year. At the time, what we were talking about was a real concern among -- on people's part that indeed you might see declines in 2016 versus 2015, and at least articulated by some as a concern that we had peaked as an industry. And what I was trying to point out at that time was that's not -- that wasn't our view. Indeed, what I said -- what we believed and what I said, I'm pretty sure, was 2015 had this phenomenon of incredibly quickly falling fuel prices that fell so fast, that capacity couldn't catch it. And in a sense, the 2015 results, because of that, were higher than one would expect them to be in the long term. So while you might see, therefore, declines into 2016 and margins, you shouldn't view that as the industry had peaked rather you should view that as kind of a 1 term, onetime spike in margins in the industry and that they would normalize in '16 to a level higher than '14 which, by the way, it appears they're going to. And therefore, one shouldn't assume that they would continue to fall from '16 into '17. So I think all that's still true, but I'm not going to try and make a forecast on '17 for you because I don't know. But that's what I was trying to point out that 2015 -- the fact that 2016 was going to be lower than 2015, which it's turned out to be, I certainly wouldn't view as some sort of cyclical issue as opposed to rather than this kind of spike that we had in '15.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Savi Syth with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Savi Syth with Raymond James.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know you've provided a little bit of this color in parts, the Transatlantic and the domestic market. But I wonder if you could walk through a little bit about the potential progression or just the headwinds and the tailwinds by region assuming current d
componenttext: I know you've provided a little bit of this color in parts, the Transatlantic and the domestic market. But I wonder if you could walk through a little bit about the potential progression or just the headwinds and the tailwinds by region assuming current demands and other trends persist.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So expect the Transatlantic to get a little worse and actually all other regions to get a little better. So domestic, our forecast is for it to get better moving into the second quarter; same for Pacific, not a lot, but a little better; and same for
componenttext: Sure. So expect the Transatlantic to get a little worse and actually all other regions to get a little better. So domestic, our forecast is for it to get better moving into the second quarter; same for Pacific, not a lot, but a little better; and same for Atlantic -- or for Latin. Latin is really based on the comps are getting a lot easier. But all regions with the exception of the Atlantic getting modestly better in the second quarter than the first.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as you look to the second half?
componenttext: And as you look to the second half?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Second half, we don't have a precise forecast, but I think that the trend will continue, that all regions will get better into the second half. All 4 regions will continue to progress better because the capacity environment progresses better, I think, in
componenttext: Second half, we don't have a precise forecast, but I think that the trend will continue, that all regions will get better into the second half. All 4 regions will continue to progress better because the capacity environment progresses better, I think, in the third and fourth quarter. And as a result, I expect every one of those regions to continue to sequentially improve from the second to the third to the fourth quarter.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then if I might ask, I apologize if I missed this. But you've been making investments in improving operations, particularly in Dallas, I believe. I was just wondering if you could give an update on how that's progressing and maybe what more mi
componenttext: Got it. And then if I might ask, I apologize if I missed this. But you've been making investments in improving operations, particularly in Dallas, I believe. I was just wondering if you could give an update on how that's progressing and maybe what more might be needed?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Robert Isom. Yes, we've been making considerable investments and seeing payoff. And as Scott noted in his opening remarks, the best indication of that is operating performance in terms of departing and arriving on time and also baggage performance
componenttext: This is Robert Isom. Yes, we've been making considerable investments and seeing payoff. And as Scott noted in his opening remarks, the best indication of that is operating performance in terms of departing and arriving on time and also baggage performance as well. So the corresponding impact of that is, obviously, fewer misconnected passengers and misconnected -- and lost bags as well. Completion factors are higher. A lot of that is a result of investments that we've made that have been put in place in regard to ground equipment, process changes, people. And then as we look forward into the future, you're going to see some benefits from technology changes as well that will really help as we try to tackle issues when operational disruptions occur. So all positive on that front.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mike Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mike Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones here. Scott, I guess, Derek, in his opening remarks, talked about certain domestic markets seeing competitive pressures and driving lower revenue. You called out Dallas. What are some of the other hotspots in the market? And then just wi
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones here. Scott, I guess, Derek, in his opening remarks, talked about certain domestic markets seeing competitive pressures and driving lower revenue. You called out Dallas. What are some of the other hotspots in the market? And then just with respect to close-in demand in April, I know you said that it's a picking up. Is that more of a function of volumes? Or are you also seeing better close-in demand yields? Are we still seeing corporate travel demands under pressure?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, from a capacity perspective, Dallas is the only place that I would call out domestically, but it's also one of our best performing year-over-year hubs. I think it just would have been really, really good. Dallas economy, despite energy, is doi
componenttext: So I guess, from a capacity perspective, Dallas is the only place that I would call out domestically, but it's also one of our best performing year-over-year hubs. I think it just would have been really, really good. Dallas economy, despite energy, is doing well. And I think, it would have been really gangbuster had it not been for the large capacity growth here in DFW or in Dallas, actually mostly at Love Field, it wasn't at DFW. And what was the second part of the question, I forgot?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on -- you talked about close-in demand picking up in April. And the question is, is that really more volumes are picking up? Or are you seeing improvement in yield because our sense is that yields are under pressure because of waning corporate travel
componenttext: Just on -- you talked about close-in demand picking up in April. And the question is, is that really more volumes are picking up? Or are you seeing improvement in yield because our sense is that yields are under pressure because of waning corporate travel.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are not seeing a pickup in yield. It is improvement -- it's certainly improvement in volume, but it's -- the revenue environment, the booked revenues were also improving relative to where they were in February and March. In February and March, we
componenttext: Yes, we are not seeing a pickup in yield. It is improvement -- it's certainly improvement in volume, but it's -- the revenue environment, the booked revenues were also improving relative to where they were in February and March. In February and March, we had the same yield issue that we have right now. So that's really was no different, but we also had weak volumes. So we still have weak year-over-year yields, but unlike February and March where we had weak year-over-year yields and weak year-over-year volumes, at least, now we have higher year-over-year volumes.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, at this time, we would like to open up the floor for questions from the media. [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Andrea Ahles with Fort Worth Star Telegram.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, at this time, we would like to open up the floor for questions from the media. [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Andrea Ahles with Fort Worth Star Telegram.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I was wondering if you could actually elaborate a little bit more on what you're talking about with Dallas and the capacity that's gone on at Love Field. I mean, since September was sort of when you think it's going to stabilize, but can you talk a
componenttext: Scott, I was wondering if you could actually elaborate a little bit more on what you're talking about with Dallas and the capacity that's gone on at Love Field. I mean, since September was sort of when you think it's going to stabilize, but can you talk about if -- are your yields doing well at DFW? Or are you still seeing sort of what you were mentioning sort on the weak demand that you had in February and March in Dallas?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, fares are lower in Dallas than they were last year. And the growth at Love Field, the last big tranche of growth was September of last year. And so when we get to September of this year, we will have overlapped the big growth. But fares are lower in
componenttext: Yes, fares are lower in Dallas than they were last year. And the growth at Love Field, the last big tranche of growth was September of last year. And so when we get to September of this year, we will have overlapped the big growth. But fares are lower in Dallas. It's a great time if you're a traveler in Dallas, to get out and go somewhere. There's some really attractive places.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And with the Advantage Fares that you said were not in the market to customers, are they now back in the market, particularly, in the DFW area?
componenttext: And with the Advantage Fares that you said were not in the market to customers, are they now back in the market, particularly, in the DFW area?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: They are. They are.
componenttext: They are. They are.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Susan Carey with The Wall Street Journal.
componenttext: We'll go next to Susan Carey with The Wall Street Journal.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Advantage Fare thing, can I just -- can you remind me -- I thought that was like a proprietary thing that US Airways had, which was sort of a cheaper ticket for -- via a connection. But you're talking about it almost like it's a generic thing now.
componenttext: On the Advantage Fare thing, can I just -- can you remind me -- I thought that was like a proprietary thing that US Airways had, which was sort of a cheaper ticket for -- via a connection. But you're talking about it almost like it's a generic thing now. Could you explain that to me?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is a generic thing now. You described it correctly. It is when a connecting carrier offers a lower price than the nonstop carrier. The rationale being that an inferior product from a customer's perspective. A customer would rather fly nonstop. And so o
componenttext: It is a generic thing now. You described it correctly. It is when a connecting carrier offers a lower price than the nonstop carrier. The rationale being that an inferior product from a customer's perspective. A customer would rather fly nonstop. And so offering a lower price, that's something that US Airways uniquely did. We brought that to American Airlines after the merger. And when we did that, our large competitors copied us. So now it is -- you called it a generic thing, but it is really systematic and exists virtually everywhere that there's nonstop service in the U.S.

componenttext: Well, I have to be careful talking about the rationale, but we've had them in place for over a decade. We're in a world with lots of low fares and lots of other places. And we wanted to see what would happen -- we had lots of other low-fare alternatives. When we first started the program, we had fewer low-fare alternatives. There's lots of other low-fare alternatives in place today, so we wanted to see what would happen if we kind of did a reset. It looked like that the results were actually negative. But before we could pull the trigger on changing it, one of our competitors put it back in place ahead of us. So presumably, they saw something similar.

componenttext: Well, we hope to roll out basic economy this year. It will be towards the end of this year. I said second half. It will be towards the end of the year. But what I was saying on the call is the impact of that, the revenue impact of that will be a 2017 effect. So even if we rolled it out, even though we still plan to roll out basic economy this year, it really won't affect our revenues until 2017.

componenttext: Well, look, we at American are running a much better operation. We're investing in our product. We're investing in customer service. And I think, we're generally on a trend of from a customer perspective, things are getting better.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in relation to the industry, Ted, I mean, this is what we suggested would happen as we got to an industry that could serve customers better. As we got through the consolidation of U.S. carriers to still be an incredibly competitive business but one th
componenttext: And in relation to the industry, Ted, I mean, this is what we suggested would happen as we got to an industry that could serve customers better. As we got through the consolidation of U.S. carriers to still be an incredibly competitive business but one that could provide the utility customers wanted to take -- to have a series of airlines that could take customers everywhere they want to go. That's one that's much better utility for the customer and also puts us all in a position of competing much more on the inflight product and on reliability than simply on where we fly and others don't. So in a world where a number of us can take customers anywhere around the globe, what matters more than it used to is how you compete for high-value customers that can use any of those carriers. The product matters even more than it did before, and you're seeing investments in that.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last thing. If I were to write this story now, I would write that American Airlines seems to have so much money. It doesn't know what to do with it all. Is that fair that you're able to spend so much money? Is it fair to say that?
componenttext: Last thing. If I were to write this story now, I would write that American Airlines seems to have so much money. It doesn't know what to do with it all. Is that fair that you're able to spend so much money? Is it fair to say that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would be an incorrect headline, Ted. What I would say is the team at American Airlines is doing an excellent job of running the airline, getting 2 airlines integrated, taking care of their customers, and the result of that is they're profitable. And
componenttext: That would be an incorrect headline, Ted. What I would say is the team at American Airlines is doing an excellent job of running the airline, getting 2 airlines integrated, taking care of their customers, and the result of that is they're profitable. And the result of those profits is primarily being used to invest in its product and its team because its team is critical to its product, and those results are paying off. And the future of American looks really bright. As a result of that, the industry has been transformed, American Airlines has been transformed, and you should expect to see more of that in the future. But businesses are supposed to be profitable and ours is. And we expect to continue it to be. And to the extent we can generate profits and use those to continue to put in the product and take care of our team and then to the extent we have generate even more than that, that gets returned to shareholders. So it's what business is supposed to do, and we're happy to actually be in that position now versus where airlines have been in the past. It's a longer headline, I know, but it's the right one.
