componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We will take our first question from Mike Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, I think, Derek, you may have called this out, just competitive capacity growth as being an issue on the revenue performance. When -- where did you see -- like, where was that most egregious? Like, which markets, and maybe it's more domestic? And
componenttext: Actually, I think, Derek, you may have called this out, just competitive capacity growth as being an issue on the revenue performance. When -- where did you see -- like, where was that most egregious? Like, which markets, and maybe it's more domestic? And maybe this is actually more a question for Scott to answer. I know you did call it out, Derek. Which of your domestic markets maybe have seen the most egregious sort of conditions from a competitive capacity growth perspective?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, there's lots of capacity growth everywhere. It's not just domestically. While there's capacity growth across the Atlantic and Pacific in particular, a lot of capacity growth is actually in the Caribbean and Mexico. The one place, international
componenttext: Well, look, there's lots of capacity growth everywhere. It's not just domestically. While there's capacity growth across the Atlantic and Pacific in particular, a lot of capacity growth is actually in the Caribbean and Mexico. The one place, internationally at least, where we've finally started to see capacity start to rightsize to -- well, I don't know if rightsize is the right term -- start to at least adjust to the demand environment is South America, where Brazil actually saw declining capacity, and we continue to see declining capacity going forward. Domestically, I mean, it's mostly across the board. We still see higher growth in Dallas out of Love Field. The good news for us is that growth, as we get to September, we will overlap the last phase of Southwest growth. And so at least the head-to-head competitive environment for us relative to where it has been will improve in September. But really, there's been a lot of growth everywhere. Los Angeles has been a high-growth market. But I don't think, other than Dallas, I would single out any particular market for high growth. It's been across the board.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And just a quick follow-up to Derek. On the NOLs now, I mean, now you're booking taxes. But at what point -- do you have an estimate when you believe you'll be paying cash taxes? And I guess I would just presume that just based on current profitabi
componenttext: Right. And just a quick follow-up to Derek. On the NOLs now, I mean, now you're booking taxes. But at what point -- do you have an estimate when you believe you'll be paying cash taxes? And I guess I would just presume that just based on current profitability trends, is -- are cash taxes going to become a real thing in maybe, what, 2018, 2019? Any thoughts on that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're thinking right now 2019 or 2020. But it just depends on also aircraft purchases and other things like that. So I think we're looking at more '19 to '20 for cash taxes.
componenttext: Yes. We're thinking right now 2019 or 2020. But it just depends on also aircraft purchases and other things like that. So I think we're looking at more '19 to '20 for cash taxes.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Rajeev Lalwani with Morgan Stanley.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, just a question for you. We've heard a lot from other airlines as far as pressures on closing yields and that sort of thing. What are you seeing there and just thoughts going forward? That's the first one.
componenttext: Scott, just a question for you. We've heard a lot from other airlines as far as pressures on closing yields and that sort of thing. What are you seeing there and just thoughts going forward? That's the first one.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I guess we're seeing something a little different, and all of our competitors said it. Closing yields are still down year-over-year, they're still negative, but we certainly haven't seen another leg down. Actually, I would have said it's probably
componenttext: Okay. So I guess we're seeing something a little different, and all of our competitors said it. Closing yields are still down year-over-year, they're still negative, but we certainly haven't seen another leg down. Actually, I would have said it's probably quite the opposite, that things look marginally less that for us on closing yields. But some of that is probably because we do, I think, have a little bit different competitive environment on a year-over-year basis. We've had some huge headwinds from a competitive perspective. Dallas Love Field is one of those big headwinds domestically that drove a lot of, like, capacity growth in our market. And now we're starting to overlap that. And so we have what would be a more normal comparison with the rest of the industry looking forward. And so that probably means that we're looking -- we're seeing something perhaps that's a little different than our competitors on a year-over-year basis. Secondly, we've had, on a year-over-year basis, while we still probably have the most exposure to ultra low-cost carriers of any airline, they aren't going in our markets anymore, at least to a large degree. And so we have less of that incremental pressure, and they're adding capacity in other places. And when they do, that causes closing yields to decline in those markets. But we've already had that, and we're overlapping now on a year-over-year basis where they're effectively flat in our markets. And then third, we've been less involved in some of the pricing -- I don't think is the right word -- pricing issues going on between airlines. We've been involved on the periphery, but some others have been more involved in lowering fares in each of these markets than we have. As we've probably benefited from not being quite as involved in that.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Sorry, Doug, if I could ask you a quick question. As it relates to buybacks, you've obviously been pretty aggressive. Why not be even more aggressive where -- maybe taking the company private or something like that, just given your confidence in th
componenttext: Right. Sorry, Doug, if I could ask you a quick question. As it relates to buybacks, you've obviously been pretty aggressive. Why not be even more aggressive where -- maybe taking the company private or something like that, just given your confidence in the model?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're being adequately aggressive and properly aggressive. Our view, as we stated it many times, is after we go through and make sure we're investing in all the right things, our people, the airline, our customers, paying off high-cost debts, the
componenttext: I think we're being adequately aggressive and properly aggressive. Our view, as we stated it many times, is after we go through and make sure we're investing in all the right things, our people, the airline, our customers, paying off high-cost debts, the question then becomes of the cash we continue to generate in excess of that, what should we do with it? And certainly, with -- given our view of the future that we've described and where the market has the stock right now, it appears to us that the best use of that cash is to buy back our shares. And we're doing so in -- I think, in a reasonably aggressive way. But that's the current plan.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Helane Becker with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Helane Becker with Cowen and Company.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have a question about headcount. Do you think that there are extra people still on board -- I guess that's a bad way to phrase, but relative to the merger and the consolidation? And do you think that as you look out another couple of years, that nu
componenttext: I just have a question about headcount. Do you think that there are extra people still on board -- I guess that's a bad way to phrase, but relative to the merger and the consolidation? And do you think that as you look out another couple of years, that number starts to increase at a slower rate?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I -- Helane, I would say the answer to that is yes. Our #1 job is to get through the merger and complete the merger. So there are areas where we do have extra headcount to make sure that we get the operation running right, to make sure that we comple
componenttext: Yes. I -- Helane, I would say the answer to that is yes. Our #1 job is to get through the merger and complete the merger. So there are areas where we do have extra headcount to make sure that we get the operation running right, to make sure that we complete the integration. So yes, I believe over time, we will pull it back and become more efficient. But I think right now, we're doing the right things to make sure that we get everything running right and get the integration done. So I think, over time, it will come down, but over the next few years as we look forward.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just another process question. I couldn't find it in the 10-Q real quickly this morning, but the intangibles from the balance sheet decline, did you have to make any adjustments for slots at Newark or anywhere else?
componenttext: Okay. And then just another process question. I couldn't find it in the 10-Q real quickly this morning, but the intangibles from the balance sheet decline, did you have to make any adjustments for slots at Newark or anywhere else?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did, but it wasn't very big. It's in the $20 million range for us, but it was very small from the Newark perspective. But we did make an adjustment and wrote those down to 0.
componenttext: Yes, we did, but it wasn't very big. It's in the $20 million range for us, but it was very small from the Newark perspective. But we did make an adjustment and wrote those down to 0.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Hunter Keay with Wolfe Research.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, Scott, you said in the past that you guys expect to have the best margins in the industry amongst the legacy network peers, and that's probably looking a little bit less likely now. So if we were to sort of like start here and pick one financi
componenttext: So I think, Scott, you said in the past that you guys expect to have the best margins in the industry amongst the legacy network peers, and that's probably looking a little bit less likely now. So if we were to sort of like start here and pick one financial-oriented metric that you want American to lead the pack on over the next 12 months from today, what would it be?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I still want us to have the highest pretax margins amongst the network carriers. I still think we'll get there, and I think we're on a good path. We took a step back from, well, a few big things that disproportionately impacted American. And t
componenttext: Well, look, I still want us to have the highest pretax margins amongst the network carriers. I still think we'll get there, and I think we're on a good path. We took a step back from, well, a few big things that disproportionately impacted American. And these kind of things are cyclical, and they'll eventually come back. But you look at Venezuela first, which had RASM that was 4x our system average, and the country fell apart. And you had Brazil, which was 80-something percent above system average, and the country fell apart. Those were massive, massive headwinds that drove 3 to 4 points -- just those 2 issues, 3 to 4 of points of system PRASM and 3 to 4 points of margin decline. So the hell we had to overcome to get back on those things was bigger because those big macro exogenous events disproportionately impacted American. That said, it feels like we're -- those things are about to be in the rearview mirror. Brazil is no longer a negative. Venezuela is still a big negative. It's still -- RASM is going to be down 35% this coming quarter again, but it's coming off a much smaller base. And so now you have something to call out as a system-level impact because it's coming off a smaller base. So we've had some really big headwinds between that and Dallas Love Field growth. And those headwinds are now in the rearview mirror, and we have a more normalized, at least on a year-over-year basis, comparison to the rest of the industry. And I think you're starting to already see our -- as we look out, our RASM results start to reflect that. We've also been -- had at least one hand tied behind our backs in the last few years as you get through integration and you have all your resources, you have systems locked down that even when you know you want to make changes, you can't because you're in the middle of converting the systems. And our hands are getting untied now. We still have some of that work left to do, but there's more coming. We'd have had basic economy and premium economy, which I've said, I think, are worth -- I'll be disappointed if they're not $1 billion a year. We'd have those done by now if we hadn't been in the middle of an integration. But we have been in the middle of an integration, and we've had to get through that. So I think we're going to continue to knock those kinds of and many other smaller projects out along the way and that we're on a good path. We got our credit card deal done. Others get theirs done ahead of time. We get ours done. So I feel really good about the path that we're on, and ultimately, our goal is to have the highest pretax margins amongst the network carriers.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you mentioned some of the competitive headwinds shifting. Do you feel vindicated? I mean, I guess, what you said here is what we've learned is that it pays to kind of go nuclear when this stuff happens. So do you feel vindicated that this is happ
componenttext: Okay. So you mentioned some of the competitive headwinds shifting. Do you feel vindicated? I mean, I guess, what you said here is what we've learned is that it pays to kind of go nuclear when this stuff happens. So do you feel vindicated that this is happening now? Or do you -- now that this is sort of settling down, do you feel like, "Well, maybe there could have been like a little bit more of like a tactical way to do this without setting the house on fire, but we had to destroy the village to save it," type thing? Or is there any, like, lessons learned that you can extrapolate going forward about how to compete maybe more tactically? Or do you have no regrets?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't agree with any of the commentary about nuclear, house on fire, any of that. So I think there...
componenttext: I don't agree with any of the commentary about nuclear, house on fire, any of that. So I think there...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fine, whatever you want to say.
componenttext: Fine, whatever you want to say.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that there's absolutely no choice but to compete and to match pricing of nonstop competitors. There's just absolutely no choice. And it's not a matter of vindicated or any other of those words. It's what you have to do. And it's what we've done, a
componenttext: I think that there's absolutely no choice but to compete and to match pricing of nonstop competitors. There's just absolutely no choice. And it's not a matter of vindicated or any other of those words. It's what you have to do. And it's what we've done, and it's the right strategy.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm trying to figure out a way to avoid using the term nuclear in my question now, bazooka versus rifle or something like that. Listen, Scott, you've avoided fuel hedging in the past, believing that fuel prices and passenger demand would broadly move in c
componenttext: I'm trying to figure out a way to avoid using the term nuclear in my question now, bazooka versus rifle or something like that. Listen, Scott, you've avoided fuel hedging in the past, believing that fuel prices and passenger demand would broadly move in conjunction with one another. If you look at current revenue and GDP trends now, that time-held relationship has decoupled for the first time since the financial crisis or the advent of the Internet. And by the way, fuel and capacity have been volatile in the past, yet the revenue-to-GDP relationship was broadly unaffected. So I have 2 questions. First, what explains the disconnect? Is it secular or self-inflicted? And two, if the relationship is decoupling and continues to do so, then your primary argument against fuel hedging is no longer valid. Thoughts?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so I'll try on both of those. First, I think there still is a relationship between fuel price and revenues. It comes with a lag. I've historically said 4 to 6 months, one of our competitors said 9 months. It does come with a lag. And I think revenue
componenttext: Okay, so I'll try on both of those. First, I think there still is a relationship between fuel price and revenues. It comes with a lag. I've historically said 4 to 6 months, one of our competitors said 9 months. It does come with a lag. And I think revenues will be higher in the fourth quarter than they otherwise would have been if fuel was lower. Now fuel prices at whatever it was yesterday, $47 a barrel, while it took a very brief spike down to $35 a barrel, I doubt capacity ever adjusted all the way down to $35 a barrel, and you saw earnings improve dramatically as a result. So I'm not sure what the right comparison is, if it was $35 a barrel or $47 a barrel where people were planning capacity from, but I think there still is a link. Second, I think there has been another structural change in the industry, and that has been in particular the growth of ultra low-cost carriers. That is a structural change, a structural change that required a structural response. The structural response is twofold. It's, one, to compete with them, which we're doing, and the second one is product segmentation. It has been a structural change in the industry, where 20 years ago, we segmented customer demand based on fare rules. And if you're a business traveler, you're -- the higher the fares, the low fares, which were designed for leisure customers, required a Saturday night stay, you had to buy 21 days in advance. And that didn't work for business travelers. That kind of segmentation doesn't work in today's world anymore, and so we have to change the model. And changing the model is going to product segmentation, which is what basic economy and premium economy are all about. Now I wish we could have done that by snapping our fingers like we could make a change in the fare filing in this ultra low-cost carriers group that we could have immediately effected that change, but we couldn't. And so we had to compete first, and then we'll get to segmentation, starting with basic economy later this year and premium economy next year. And I think that's going to address the secular change from ultra low-cost carriers. But we probably -- we have taken a leg down because of that, and I think we'll recover it once we get those things in effect. As to the fuel hedging question, there's 2 reasons to not hedge fuel, and [indiscernible] tied to revenue is maybe the second one. The biggest reason to not hedge fuel is because it's rigged the game that's impossible to beat. Fuel prices most of the time are trading at contango. So while fuel is $47 a barrel today, if we try to buy fuel for -- a year from now, it's well north of that. In addition, we all realize the risk that you take if you just do countless callers. And so what most people do and the prudent view is that you should buy options. So if you want to buy an option for fuel a year from now, you're going to pay an $8 to $10 option premium. So fuel prices have to go up -- varies from time to time depending on how big a contango is and how high volatility is, but in the 30% to 50% range just to break even. And when you're playing a game that you have to have oil go up 30% to 50% to break even, it's impossible to win in the long term. It can be days that you win or it can be months that you win, but it is impossible to win in the long term.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we will take Dan McKenzie with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Next, we will take Dan McKenzie with Buckingham Research.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Scott. British Airways, they cut their earnings outlook following the Brexit vote. And I'm wondering if you can talk a little bit more about what Brexit might or might not mean for American as we look ahead. And then separately, I wonder what you can
componenttext: Hey, Scott. British Airways, they cut their earnings outlook following the Brexit vote. And I'm wondering if you can talk a little bit more about what Brexit might or might not mean for American as we look ahead. And then separately, I wonder what you can share about BA's willingness to work with you to optimize the transatlantic flying as we look ahead.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first, on Brexit, I think in the near term, and I'll define near term as being until the U.K. actually leaves the EU. So 2-plus years, depending on when they trigger Article 50. There's sort of I think of it as 3 effects. One is the currency effect, wh
componenttext: So first, on Brexit, I think in the near term, and I'll define near term as being until the U.K. actually leaves the EU. So 2-plus years, depending on when they trigger Article 50. There's sort of I think of it as 3 effects. One is the currency effect, which is a pretty clear negative. Actually, when we look by currency-by-currency, what has the biggest year-over-year impact, it's been the Brazilian real for a long time. It's now the U.K. pound because of the decline in currency. And by the way, we generated -- about 4% of our revenues are sold in British pounds. So currency decline is negative. The second point is that it will happen over the near to medium term. The indirect direct impact I actually think will be positive. And when I say direct impact, I mean the number of people having to fly back and forth across the North Atlantic, particularly business customers as there's a lot more consultants, lawyers, bankers that are likely to be flying back and forth, figuring out what the heck this means and what are we going to do. The third and most concerning thing that will be -- that has the potential to be negative is, in the near to medium term, is if it creates business confidence problems. We have seen historically that when there's business confidence, one of the thirst -- first things businesses do is cut the travel and entertainment budget. That's not something that would uniquely affect the U.K. or the EU, it will be a broader impact. I was gratified to see that while the market fell for 2 days after the Brexit vote, it has bounced back, and that's usually a pretty good indicator of confidence or highly correlated with confidence. And so I think it's unlikely that we're going to see a big change of confidence. So all of which means, I think, for the few years at least, there's not going to be much impact from Brexit when you sort of do those 3 items. Don't have tons of data. We have a month's worth of data so far, and our booked revenues have improved in the month since Brexit happened at least relative to the way they were before. So hard to see any evidence that it's a big problem. Longer term, the issue is going to be obviously what happens with the U.K. economy, what happens with the banking industry in particular because that is a big component of revenue across the North Atlantic and what happens from a regulatory framework. But near term, I don't anticipate an awful lot of issues.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I appreciate that. Derek, the reduced CapEx in cash tax perspective addresses key investor concerns that I've been getting. Just given the net debt coming down, does that also mean gross adjusted debt will start coming down in 2017? And then as you
componenttext: Well, I appreciate that. Derek, the reduced CapEx in cash tax perspective addresses key investor concerns that I've been getting. Just given the net debt coming down, does that also mean gross adjusted debt will start coming down in 2017? And then as you think about the longer term leverage targets, say, 3 years out, what could that look like?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that if we look at CapEx, we talked about it being at $4.4 billion this year, goes down to $4 billion next year and then down to $2.1 billion, $2.5 billion, $2.5 billion. So the significant reduction in the CapEx will help all those leverage r
componenttext: No, I think that if we look at CapEx, we talked about it being at $4.4 billion this year, goes down to $4 billion next year and then down to $2.1 billion, $2.5 billion, $2.5 billion. So the significant reduction in the CapEx will help all those leverage ratios out. So I think those will be benefited as well going out throughout the year. So I think, all of our metrics from a leverage basis get better as we go through '17, '18, '19, '20 as the aircraft CapEx gets reduced over the time period.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I wonder if you could put a finer point on RASM expectations for Europe or the U.K. specifically. What are you expecting in terms of year-to-year change in RASM to the U.K. in the September quarter versus, say, the second quarter?
componenttext: Scott, I wonder if you could put a finer point on RASM expectations for Europe or the U.K. specifically. What are you expecting in terms of year-to-year change in RASM to the U.K. in the September quarter versus, say, the second quarter?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, Europe is probably the only region in the world that, I think, is going to get sequentially worse from the second quarter to the third quarter. Pacific will be about the same on RASM. Domestic and Latin, as I said in my opening comments, going
componenttext: Well, look, Europe is probably the only region in the world that, I think, is going to get sequentially worse from the second quarter to the third quarter. Pacific will be about the same on RASM. Domestic and Latin, as I said in my opening comments, going to get better. We do expect Europe to get worse although it's really core Europe more than it is the U.K. Europe has several, almost, I guess, 3 strikes against it looking forward. It's one, there is more economic uncertainty. It's not just [indiscernible] Brexit, there's more economic uncertainty, and it's a challenging economic environment in Europe, so the macro is not good. You get accelerating capacity growth across the Atlantic, so it's a second strike for Europe. And third is currency. So the one impact of Brexit that actually isn't a identifiable negative is currency weakness. So those 3 things, I mean, that's the 1 region of the world that we think is actually going to sequentially get worse in the third quarter. But it's really not a U.K. issue. It's actually more core Europe than it is U.K. from our perspective.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. You wouldn't care to put a finer point on it of how much you expect RASM to be down next quarter?
componenttext: I appreciate that. You wouldn't care to put a finer point on it of how much you expect RASM to be down next quarter?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I said double digits in my opening comments. And I am not going to put a finer point on it than that.
componenttext: Well, I said double digits in my opening comments. And I am not going to put a finer point on it than that.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the comments on Latin are really interesting. Maybe you could help us put some context around Brazil. Could you remind us how much your capacity is down 3Q versus 2Q and what the shape of RASM your expecting? So for example, we've heard som
componenttext: Okay. And then the comments on Latin are really interesting. Maybe you could help us put some context around Brazil. Could you remind us how much your capacity is down 3Q versus 2Q and what the shape of RASM your expecting? So for example, we've heard some others that may be long-haul international to Brazil went from like down 35 to down 25, which is sequential improvement, but is still pretty weak for you. Your capacity cuts are much greater than that, so maybe revenues or maybe RASM's closer to flattish. Any help you can give us there would be appreciated.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've cut capacity, I don't know, 3Q versus 2Q. We started cutting capacity in 2015, and we could see these results clearly deteriorating. We were surprised actually in 2015. I think, every carrier that flies from Brazil to the United States not only
componenttext: Yes, we've cut capacity, I don't know, 3Q versus 2Q. We started cutting capacity in 2015, and we could see these results clearly deteriorating. We were surprised actually in 2015. I think, every carrier that flies from Brazil to the United States not only increased capacity, but increased capacity by double digits, except for American Airlines. So I think, we're probably down 35% to 40% from where we were back in '14 today. But in the second quarter for the first time, we actually saw industry capacity come down. It's going to come down even more in the third and fourth quarter. And as a result, Brazil, which was running down kind of 35% in the second quarter RASM, was down 13%. In the third quarter, we expect it to be positive. Now we're getting a boost in the third quarter from the Olympics, so I wouldn't necessarily expect the fourth quarter to remain positive. Although our guess is right now that the fourth quarter will remain positive. There's just been an awful lot of capacity come out, and you just got to such a low level, I mean, RASM will still be down. I don't know the number, 40%, 50% from where it was at the peak even if it turns positive in the third and fourth quarter. But it's certainly -- it feels like it's not getting worse anymore. It's not really on -- it's coming off a low base, it's not really on a rapid recovery, but it does feel like it's not getting worse anymore.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe RASM positive on capacity down double digits for you so [indiscernible]?
componenttext: So maybe RASM positive on capacity down double digits for you so [indiscernible]?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know what our capacity is right now. As I look at our overall longer-time horizon, over a longer-time horizon, we're down quite close to 40%. But I don't know what it is 3Q versus 2Q.
componenttext: I don't know what our capacity is right now. As I look at our overall longer-time horizon, over a longer-time horizon, we're down quite close to 40%. But I don't know what it is 3Q versus 2Q.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we will take Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Next, we will take Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Derek, one for you. On the CapEx decline in 2017 and 2018 starts to free up some free cash flow. What are your priorities? Are there additional opportunities to prepay debt? And is this meant to help with the pension funding requirement coming in 2019?
componenttext: Derek, one for you. On the CapEx decline in 2017 and 2018 starts to free up some free cash flow. What are your priorities? Are there additional opportunities to prepay debt? And is this meant to help with the pension funding requirement coming in 2019?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so 2 things. One it will be -- we're going to cash to complete the integration and continue to do all the projects that were -- we've got on the list. As Scott talked about, basic economy, premium economy, cash will definitely go to that first. As we
componenttext: Yes, so 2 things. One it will be -- we're going to cash to complete the integration and continue to do all the projects that were -- we've got on the list. As Scott talked about, basic economy, premium economy, cash will definitely go to that first. As we look at pension requirements, our first pension requirement payment is in '19. We have a small requirement in '18, but the biggest requirement is in '19. We do have the possibility to pre -- do that early on the pensions in '18 if we want to get 80% funded in the '18 time frame, so that's a possibility to do, but it's not required to do. Our requirement is in '19 to do that. So I think, the biggest uses are going to be making sure that we have enough CapEx. We have $1.2 billion this year in CapEx. We expect that to maintain, if not grow a little bit in '17 and '18 just due to all the projects and the backup demand that's there for everybody. So I think that's where we're more likely go than any early pension payments. The requirement and the pension is in '19.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, very helpful. And then Scott, one for you. From the last year, we've seen the weakness in -- from competitive actions is really contained. How much do you worry about that when you observe what's going on in other market with the other airlines that
componenttext: Okay, very helpful. And then Scott, one for you. From the last year, we've seen the weakness in -- from competitive actions is really contained. How much do you worry about that when you observe what's going on in other market with the other airlines that you mentioned?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, it's a really competitive environment, and it's still a yield and RASM-negative environment across the board, so we are impacted by that. I think, we get better at competing in environment. The more experience we get with it, we work -- learn
componenttext: Well, look, it's a really competitive environment, and it's still a yield and RASM-negative environment across the board, so we are impacted by that. I think, we get better at competing in environment. The more experience we get with it, we work -- learn things that work, learn things that we can do better. But the biggest thing we can do really is the structural response. And I know on these calls we typically focus on what's going to happen in the next quarter or the next 3 weeks and have a pretty short-term focus on it. But the biggest thing we can do is get the product segmentation right, not just for our investors, but for our customers, where we can give customers what they're looking for, whether they want a really cheap, low -- bare-bones low price or whether they want a product that has more amenities and is a higher-quality product. And it's taking us time to get that done, but that's really the right structural response. So look, we feel pretty good about where we are. We think that we're on a continuing trajectory. The expected derivative positive trajectory to get back to positive PRASM that happened this quarter, and we expect it to happen -- or in the second quarter, we expect it in the third quarter. And we think we're going to continue on that trend. So we wish it was -- PRASM was positive today, and we wish we had a benign competitive environment. But we have what we have, and we think we're making good progress.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Julie, this is Derek. Just one follow-up to that question. On a -- from a debt -- nonaircraft debt payments next year, it's only $100 million for us. Year after that, it's only $600 million. We do have an unsecured bond in '18, and we will -- if there
componenttext: And Julie, this is Derek. Just one follow-up to that question. On a -- from a debt -- nonaircraft debt payments next year, it's only $100 million for us. Year after that, it's only $600 million. We do have an unsecured bond in '18, and we will -- if there's any opportunities to prepay any high-cost debt, which we've done a significant amount of and will do at any point we can, we will use that cash to prepay any of that. We don't have any planned in '17 and '18, but if we find things that we can prepay early, we will use any cash to do that in '17 and '18.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, Scott..
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, Scott..

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Doug. Only because we have a lot of our employees who listen in to these calls, and you mentioned the pension, I just want to make sure that I explain to everybody kind of what's going on there. The issue is -- you may or may not [indiscernible] J
componenttext: This is Doug. Only because we have a lot of our employees who listen in to these calls, and you mentioned the pension, I just want to make sure that I explain to everybody kind of what's going on there. The issue is -- you may or may not [indiscernible] Julie, we are fully funded for per some airline pension funding rules, and more funded on that -- in that regard than our competitors on the pensions. We at American are required because of the way these -- because, frankly, the American didn't file a bankruptcy and Delta and Northwest did -- or Delta and United did. We're required to move off that funding plan into other funding plans sooner than they are, and as Derek said, I think that's '18 or '19 for us. So that will require us to move up to a higher level at that time. We could do it today if we wanted to. It's not a funding issue. It will never be a funding issue. It's just what's the right time to pay debt in recessions. And this is -- so we will pay that when -- we will fund that as we're required. We're fully funded now higher than our competitors and we'll be funded at a rate higher than them when we do this, but we don't think it's a -- we don't think -- none of us think it's in the best interest of the company to go fund it in advance or to be overfunded on something that doesn't have a return. So we'll keep doing until that. We are well aware it's there, it's not an issue whatsoever, and it's fully manageable. It can be funded now.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one last one for you, Scott, on corporate. It's been a pretty big topic on some of the other calls, and you guys haven't mentioned it. What -- can you give us an update on what trends you're seeing from a corporate perspective?
componenttext: Okay. And then just one last one for you, Scott, on corporate. It's been a pretty big topic on some of the other calls, and you guys haven't mentioned it. What -- can you give us an update on what trends you're seeing from a corporate perspective?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they continue as they have been. We had a corporate demand up, and we continue to win share. I think, corporate revenue was down 1% for us in the quarter, so obviously, it's outperforming the rest of the system. But, I think, it's much like it has b
componenttext: Well, they continue as they have been. We had a corporate demand up, and we continue to win share. I think, corporate revenue was down 1% for us in the quarter, so obviously, it's outperforming the rest of the system. But, I think, it's much like it has been. Corporate demand is strong, but we have a lot of low fares in the market, so they're getting the deal right now.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Darryl Genovesi with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Darryl Genovesi with UBS.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, maybe I'd like to follow up on Jamie's question to Scott with regard to some of the secular trends that we're perhaps witnessing you had called out, the growth of low-cost carriers. But one of the things that I've been thinking a little bit harder ab
componenttext: Hey, maybe I'd like to follow up on Jamie's question to Scott with regard to some of the secular trends that we're perhaps witnessing you had called out, the growth of low-cost carriers. But one of the things that I've been thinking a little bit harder about more recently is that we've also seen a lot of frequency consolidation here over the last few years, and I'm just wondering if maybe you thought perhaps the quality of the schedule having deteriorated a bit could have also driven some of the decoupling that we've seen in that historical relationship between airline revenue and GDP and just any thoughts around that.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. I mean, one of the things that is a close analogue to that probably is every airline has increased density on aircraft. And so we've done it, but all of our competitors have as well. And at least, as with regard to RASM, that we typicall
componenttext: I don't think so. I mean, one of the things that is a close analogue to that probably is every airline has increased density on aircraft. And so we've done it, but all of our competitors have as well. And at least, as with regard to RASM, that we typically think of those extra seats as coming in at 50% of system RASM. And so when we put another 12 seats on the 737-800, that 12 seats, a 6% of capacity, means that all those flights come in, RASM is 3% lower than it otherwise would have been, the profit-positive. But I think that is -- that is probably a change that has driven lower RASM, at least across the industry. It's had a corresponding benefit on the cost side, of course, that would drive lower RASM. But we still have high-quality schedules for business travelers. And I don't think business travelers are flying less because maybe you have 14 flights today in the market instead of 15 flights a day. I don't think you're really losing any business. But people are resigned to stay home because of that.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you had also mentioned that you thought the Olympics were going to be a positive. Down in Brazil, I remember 2 years ago when we had the World Cup down there, you saw some very close in revenue deterioration, bookings deterioration, which,
componenttext: Okay. And then you had also mentioned that you thought the Olympics were going to be a positive. Down in Brazil, I remember 2 years ago when we had the World Cup down there, you saw some very close in revenue deterioration, bookings deterioration, which, I think, was related to hotel availability. Do you think that, that's likely going to be an issue again this time?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, usually, the Olympics, World Cups, conventions are a negative for revenues because business travelers just stay away because they can't get hotels and worry about all -- the crowds and some business travel dries up, and we've seen that in all the ot
componenttext: Well, usually, the Olympics, World Cups, conventions are a negative for revenues because business travelers just stay away because they can't get hotels and worry about all -- the crowds and some business travel dries up, and we've seen that in all the other Olympics, we've seen that in the World Cup. In this case, Brazil is so bad that there is no business traffic or close to no business traffic. And so this year, I think that will be a positive just because Brazil had fallen so much before. Two years ago I would have thought the Olympics would be a negative, and it would have been 2 years ago. But today, because things have fallen so much, they're going to actually be a positive.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then if I could squeeze one last one, I just like a point of clarification for Derek. Derek, I think, you said CapEx was coming down by $500 million in '17 and $700 million in '18. Is that just aircraft CapEx or is that total CapEx? And I think
componenttext: Great. And then if I could squeeze one last one, I just like a point of clarification for Derek. Derek, I think, you said CapEx was coming down by $500 million in '17 and $700 million in '18. Is that just aircraft CapEx or is that total CapEx? And I think, you said there was also an offset on a nonaircraft line.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's just aircraft CapEx. Right now, we're showing $1.2 billion in '16 for nonaircraft CapEx. We think it will go up to $1.5 billion in '17 and then probably $1.5 billion. I just put $1.5 billion for both '17 and '18 as we finish off, and then we'll dro
componenttext: That's just aircraft CapEx. Right now, we're showing $1.2 billion in '16 for nonaircraft CapEx. We think it will go up to $1.5 billion in '17 and then probably $1.5 billion. I just put $1.5 billion for both '17 and '18 as we finish off, and then we'll drop off in '19 and '20. So I'm trying to get done with all the basic economy, premium economy, all the interior work that we're doing and all the completion of all the merger activity. We'll have higher nonaircraft CapEx in '17 and '18, but then get back to that $1.2 billion, $1 billion run rate in '19 and '20.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would you just provide the total gross CapEx as you see it today for those years?
componenttext: Would you just provide the total gross CapEx as you see it today for those years?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, great. And then just to switch on to the kind of nonfuel cost side. On a pre-profit-sharing basis, if I look at the full year guide, it seems that there's a lot of pressure here in 2016 and just wondering, what's driving that? And when we might
componenttext: All right, great. And then just to switch on to the kind of nonfuel cost side. On a pre-profit-sharing basis, if I look at the full year guide, it seems that there's a lot of pressure here in 2016 and just wondering, what's driving that? And when we might see some of the -- kind of the benefits from kind of merger or integration-related benefits benefiting the cost side. And maybe just some early thoughts on what we might see from headwinds and tailwinds in 2017.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the -- what's driving this year is primarily for a full year effect, it's salaries and benefits and adding back in the profit sharing. So that of a full year, we've guided right around 5, that's almost 4.5 of it. The third quarter change from
componenttext: Yes, I think the -- what's driving this year is primarily for a full year effect, it's salaries and benefits and adding back in the profit sharing. So that of a full year, we've guided right around 5, that's almost 4.5 of it. The third quarter change from the second quarter is really driven by maintenance timing. I think, we had 1.7% good guy in maintenance in the first quarter, 1% in the second quarter, and it's shifting almost exactly opposite in the third and fourth quarter with about a 1.6 headwind in the third and a 1.4 headwind in the fourth. So it's really a shift in the maintenance timing. Year-over-year, our maintenance is flat, it's up 0.1, so it's virtually flat. But if the timing of things moving from the -- this year in the third and fourth quarter more than last year being in the first and second quarter, so that's really the year-over-year timing. As we look forward, we don't -- we still have 1 contract to do that is not in our guidance, that we're still working hard to get our mechanics and our ramp contract done, and we want to get that done as soon as possible. That would be the biggest headwind going into next year from a CASM perspective. Other than that, we believe that we should be in the 0% to 2% range going forward, and there -- we don't see any major CASM headwinds looking out into '17 or '18.

componenttext: Correct. There's only -- from a delivery perspective, we only have about 12 aircraft of gauge coming in, in '17, so there'll be some effect from the '16. We had 42 aircraft coming in '16, so there'll be a little bit effect that next year. This year we had a gauge difference of about, from an ASM perspective, of about 3.3. Next year, it's probably about half of that, 1.5 to 2 points on the regional perspective.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Derek and Scott, I just want to talk about the capacity reductions you announced, I guess, it was last week. One of your peers has said that it's essentially too expensive for them to pull capacity starting in fourth quarter. So I just want to unders
componenttext: Hey, Derek and Scott, I just want to talk about the capacity reductions you announced, I guess, it was last week. One of your peers has said that it's essentially too expensive for them to pull capacity starting in fourth quarter. So I just want to understand, when you guys ran the numbers on pulling ASMs, was it dilutive to earnings and you were just willing to accept that to try and regain some pricing power? Or was it not?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we think it's the right thing to do. We think it's earnings-positive in that world. I mean, look, in a world were RASM is declining and/or fuel prices are going up, it just becomes mathematically true that everything across your system gets a little w
componenttext: No, we think it's the right thing to do. We think it's earnings-positive in that world. I mean, look, in a world were RASM is declining and/or fuel prices are going up, it just becomes mathematically true that everything across your system gets a little worse. And so the bottom 1% has a higher probability that it's no longer profitable. It is true that you can't get 100% of the cost out in the short term. That does drive CASM pressure for us. But we think that the capacity changes we made are both revenue- and earnings-positive beginning the fourth quarter, even though we can't get 100% of the cost out.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It should stay pretty stable where we have it right now, so our interest expense line in '16 is forecast to be right about at $1 billion, and we forecast it for the next -- depending on what we do, I think right in -- right now, we expect to finance a fai
componenttext: It should stay pretty stable where we have it right now, so our interest expense line in '16 is forecast to be right about at $1 billion, and we forecast it for the next -- depending on what we do, I think right in -- right now, we expect to finance a fair amount of those aircraft, so if we do that, we will reduce debt pretty much commensurate with what we bring on. So our interest expense should stay pretty flat over the next 5 years under that methodology. And we have reduced the cost of the debt from 5% down almost to 4% debt, which is as we have refinanced and financed these aircraft at really attractive rates, we've reduced our overall cost of debt down to around 4%.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just to go back to the revenue initiatives and cabin segmentation for a moment. I know the plan is to have basic economy by the end of the year. But can you give us a sense for when you would expect those initiatives to really start having some n
componenttext: I guess, just to go back to the revenue initiatives and cabin segmentation for a moment. I know the plan is to have basic economy by the end of the year. But can you give us a sense for when you would expect those initiatives to really start having some noticeable improvement on the P&L in terms of your RASM or PRASM?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So basic economy, I think, will start to have an impact probably on March of next year is what I'd say. And then premium economy, while we'll roll it out at some point in '17 because it will also be tied in that we're going to treat premium economy like a
componenttext: So basic economy, I think, will start to have an impact probably on March of next year is what I'd say. And then premium economy, while we'll roll it out at some point in '17 because it will also be tied in that we're going to treat premium economy like a separate cabin, essentially. So different than what other airlines might call premium economy today. More expansive, more what it looks like or more how it's treated internationally or how we're going to treat it internationally as a separate cabin. And because of that, it will have impact on the frequent flyer program, and so that will probably be for 2018 really because we need to tell our frequent flyers in advance how it impacts the frequent flyer program.

componenttext: Two probably for Scott. I think, Scott, at the outset, I understood you to say that your 3Q guidance for -- is going to be for RASM, down 3.5% to 5.5%, and I believe I understood you to say you were abandoning PRASM and you were going to be adopting the RASM model going forward. Am I getting that right?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I didn't say abandon, but yes, that's right. It's the better metric to look at more an increasing percentage of our revenues come in the other revenue line. The credit card deal is obviously a big component of that. But also as we move into a world
componenttext: Well, I didn't say abandon, but yes, that's right. It's the better metric to look at more an increasing percentage of our revenues come in the other revenue line. The credit card deal is obviously a big component of that. But also as we move into a world of basic economy and premium economy, there'll be a higher amount of revenues that come in other revenues, and that's really the most important metric. So we're going to guide -- be guiding to RASM on a go forward basis.

componenttext: Well, look, we have a great relationship with IAG, and we talk to them all the time about what the right amount of capacity is and will this continue in the normal course in that process, and we'll react as we see things happen in the market. componenttext: Well, we didn't specify and there really isn't because we have -- we still have to work through the plans on where we're going to fly with the existing fleet. It -- really, what this does is give us flexibility. All these aircraft are scheduled to be replacement aircraft for existing aircraft, and so we can extend some of the leases longer to keep the existing flying and/or growth plans in place or, given a weak international environment, we can keep some of those retirements in place as they were and pull back on what our growth plans otherwise would have been. So it really just gives us flexibility.

componenttext: I just wanted to understand why you're choosing to do the A350 deferrals now. You had the US Airways in American order books back in 2013, so why the decision to do this now versus a year ago or so?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in order to defer, you can't just unilaterally decide to defer aircraft and call Airbus or Boeing up and say, hey, we're going to defer aircrafts, and they say, okay. You have to work it out with them. And so we just needed to find a point in time w
componenttext: Well, in order to defer, you can't just unilaterally decide to defer aircraft and call Airbus or Boeing up and say, hey, we're going to defer aircrafts, and they say, okay. You have to work it out with them. And so we just needed to find a point in time where it was in Airbus's best interest to defer the orders and ours. And so the timing is really about when it works for both sets of partners.

componenttext: Edward, this is Doug. I mean, look. Anyway, first off, as you know, we came here with 2 rounds of 2 large fleet orders, and we've been trying to get them better coordinated. This helps. And on the Airbus front, you should talk to them, but it's been a very popular product as you know, and they've sold a lot of them, and they are trying to meet all their customers' needs, and this deferral, I think, was consistent with that.

componenttext: Yes. So it worked out fine -- it worked out well for us and presumably worked out well for Airbus, but we did not -- we certainly did not have to pay any penalties for it.

componenttext: Well, we don't have any way of knowing why bookings are lower or why revenue is weaker. Europe is the 1 area that [indiscernible] going to sequentially get worse in the third quarter than the second quarter. But whether it's that or whether it's the economic weakness or whether it's Brexit or whether it's just the currency impact or whether it's all the capacity growth, there's a lot of things that could be driving it, and it's probably all of the above.
