componenttext: Our next question comes from Jack Atkins with Stephens.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just to go back to the revenue initiatives and cabin segmentation for a moment. I know the plan is to have basic economy by the end of the year. But can you give us a sense for when you would expect those initiatives to really start having some n
componenttext: I guess, just to go back to the revenue initiatives and cabin segmentation for a moment. I know the plan is to have basic economy by the end of the year. But can you give us a sense for when you would expect those initiatives to really start having some noticeable improvement on the P&L in terms of your RASM or PRASM?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So basic economy, I think, will start to have an impact probably on March of next year is what I'd say. And then premium economy, while we'll roll it out at some point in '17 because it will also be tied into -- we're going to treat premium economy like a
componenttext: So basic economy, I think, will start to have an impact probably on March of next year is what I'd say. And then premium economy, while we'll roll it out at some point in '17 because it will also be tied into -- we're going to treat premium economy like a separate cabin, essentially. So different than what other airlines might call premium economy today. More expansive, more what it looks like or more how it's treated internationally or how we're going to treat it internationally as a separate cabin. And because of that, it will have impact on the frequent flyer program, and so that will probably be for 2018 really because we need to tell our frequent flyers in advance how it impacts the frequent flyer program.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two probably for Scott. I think, Scott, at the outset, I understood you to say that your 3Q guidance for -- is going to be for RASM, down 3.5% to 5.5%, and I believe I understood you to say you were abandoning PRASM and you were going to be adopting the R
componenttext: Two probably for Scott. I think, Scott, at the outset, I understood you to say that your 3Q guidance for -- is going to be for RASM, down 3.5% to 5.5%, and I believe I understood you to say you were abandoning PRASM and you were going to be adopting the RASM model going forward. Am I getting that right?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I didn't say abandon, but yes, that's right. It's the better metric to look at more an increasing percentage of our revenues come in the other revenue line. The credit card deal is obviously a big component of that. But also as we move into a world
componenttext: Well, I didn't say abandon, but yes, that's right. It's the better metric to look at more an increasing percentage of our revenues come in the other revenue line. The credit card deal is obviously a big component of that. But also as we move into a world of basic economy and premium economy, there'll be a higher amount of revenues that come in other revenues, and that's really the most important metric. So we're going to guide -- be guiding to RASM on a go forward basis.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And -- okay. So and the other question, I think an analyst asked it, you said there are -- Brexit is not really going have a big impact on you for the foreseeable future, except on the Forex front. But I think the guy asked, what are you going to do about
componenttext: And -- okay. So and the other question, I think an analyst asked it, you said there are -- Brexit is not really going have a big impact on you for the foreseeable future, except on the Forex front. But I think the guy asked, what are you going to do about coordinating with BA across the pond in case there has to be some kind of capacity adjustment? Is it premature to talk about that right now? Or is that something that's in your planning horizon?

componenttext: Well, look, we have a great relationship with IAG, and we talk to them all the time about what the right amount of capacity is and will this continue in the normal course in that process, and we'll react as we see things happen in the market. But there's nothing specific to talk about today.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Well, we didn't specify and there really isn't because we have -- we still have to work through the plans on where we're going to fly with the existing fleet. It -- really, what this does is give us flexibility. All these aircraft are scheduled to be replacement aircraft for existing aircraft, and so we can extend some of the leases longer to keep the existing flying and/or growth plans in place or, given a weak international environment, we can keep some of those retirements in place as they were and pull back on what our growth plans otherwise would have been. So it really just gives us flexibility.

componenttextpreview: I just wanted to understand why you're choosing to do the A350 deferrals now. You had the US Airways in American order books back in 2013, so why the decision to do this now versus a year ago or so?
componenttext: I just wanted to understand why you're choosing to do the A350 deferrals now. You had the US Airways in American order books back in 2013, so why the decision to do this now versus a year ago or so?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in order to defer, you can't just unilaterally decide to defer aircraft and call Airbus or Boeing up and say, hey, we're going to defer aircrafts, and they say, okay. You have to work it out with them. And so we just needed to find a point in time w
componenttext: Well, in order to defer, you can't just unilaterally decide to defer aircraft and call Airbus or Boeing up and say, hey, we're going to defer aircrafts, and they say, okay. You have to work it out with them. And so we just needed to find a point in time where it was in Airbus's best interest to defer the orders and ours. And so the timing is really about when it works for both sets of partners.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay. I mean, one of the things that comes up -- I think of is -- I mean, Airbus has already started cutting metal for first half's '17 deliveries at this point. So I mean, do you have any color on it? Were you penalized for doing a deferral now? Or but you said it was just in the best interest.

componenttext: Edward, this is Doug. I mean, look. Anyway, first off, as you know, we came here with 2 rounds of 2 large fleet orders, and we've been trying to get them better coordinated. This helps. And on the Airbus front, you should talk to them, but it's been a very popular product as you know, and they've sold a lot of them, and they are trying to meet all their customers' needs, and this deferral, I think, was consistent with that.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Well, we don't have any way of knowing why bookings are lower or why revenue is weaker. Europe is the one area that is going to sequentially get worse in the third quarter than the second quarter. But whether it's that or whether it's the economic weakness or whether it's Brexit or whether it's just the currency impact or whether it's all the capacity growth, there's a lot of things that could be driving it, and it's probably all of the above.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] And now I would like to turn the conference over to your moderator, Managing Director of Investor Rela
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] And now I would like to turn the conference over to your moderator, Managing Director of Investor Relations, Mr. Dan Cravens. Please go ahead.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us on the call today is Doug Parker, our Chairman and CEO; Robert Isom, our President and Derek Kerr, our Chief Financial
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. 
Joining us on the call today is Doug Parker, our Chairman and CEO; Robert Isom, our President and Derek Kerr, our Chief Financial Officer 
Also in the room for Q&A session is Elise, our EVP of People and Communications; Dave, our Chief Integration Officer; Maya Leibman, Chief Information Officer; Steve Johnson, our EVP of Corporate Affairs. And Don Casey, our Senior Vice President of Revenue management. 
As is our normal practice, we're going to start the call with Doug, and he will provide an overview of the third quarter financial results. Derek will then walk us through the details on the quarter and provide some additional information on our guidance for the remainder -- for the fourth quarter. Robert will then follow with commentary on the operational performance and revenue environment and after we hear from those comments, we'll open the call for analysts' questions and lastly, questions from the media. 
Before we begin, we must state that today's call does contain forward-looking statements, including statements concerning future revenues and costs, forecast or capacity, traffic, load factor, fleet plans and fuel prices. These statements represent our predictions and expectations as to future events, but numerous risks and uncertainties could cause actual results to differ from those projected. Information about some of those risks and uncertainties can the fund in our earnings press release issued this morning and our Form 10-Q for the quarter ended September 30, 2016. 
In addition, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures this morning, such as net profit and CASM, excluding unusual items. A reconciliation of those numbers to the GAAP financial measures is included in the earnings release, that can be found on our website. The webcast of this call will also be archived on our website. The information that we're giving you on the call is as of today's date, and we undertake no obligation to update the information subsequently. 
So thanks, again, for joining us this morning. And at this point, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chairman and CEO, Doug Parker.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. And thanks, everyone, for being on this morning's announcement. Our pretax earnings, excluding special items of $1.5 billion. It's down from last year's $1.9 billion. That's due both by declining unit revenues, our total -- our PRASM was down
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. And thanks, everyone, for being on this morning's announcement. Our pretax earnings, excluding special items of $1.5 billion. It's down from last year's $1.9 billion. That's due both by declining unit revenues, our total -- our PRASM was down 2.2% versus last year. And increasing year cost, driven primarily by investments in our team. 
But while they're down, their still second best third quarter in history in American Airlines behind only the third quarter 2015. 
Also because of our share repurchase activity, our adjusted EPS was actually up, even the earnings were down from $2.77 up to $2.80 in the quarter. 
So the results are doing fantastic team at American, done amazing job for our customers, they were extremely grateful for that they do. 
On the revenue front, Robert will provide a lot more detail, but we're encouraged by the trends. Our PRASM, as I said, was down 2.2% in the third quarter. That's better than we've seen in terms of the decline in recent quarters. It's better than our competitors are experiencing. 
In fact, the month of September PRASM was actually improved year-over-year, which was the first month of year-over-year PRASM improvement for American Airlines since November of 2014. Now, of course, September was helped by the calendar on a year-over-year basis, which is we at American would like to focus much on monthly unit revenue numbers, but the trend is good, and it appears to be continuing as Robert will discuss. 
Our unit costs grew in the quarter and Derek will provide more detail on that, but the primary driver of the unit cost increase is our decision to invest in seats. We have paid increases in profit sharing that are, by far, the largest drivers of the cost increase, and we're pleased to be able to provide those improvements to our team members. We now reached new agreements with all of our work groups, so the large increases are behind us. 
Furthermore, as we complete more of our integration in 2017, we'll be able to give eliminating some of the redundancies that still exist because of the 2 airlines, and that will help us reduce expenses in 2018 and beyond. 
As integration, we have enormous success early this month with the fall integration of our flight operating system across. This is extremely complicated system integration that's what operational disruptions in the airlines as they've gone through mergers and our team executed without a hitch. While we're doing all that, we continue to invest in our products, improve the product. We have 12 new aircraft-s as part of our unprecedented fleet renewal program report. Americans fleet is now more than 40% younger in our large network peers and that gap is widening. 
We had 10 new destinations to our network, including 5 in Cuba, a new service from LAX to Hong Kong and next month, we'll begin daily flights to Havana, strengthening our position as the largest carrier to Cuba. 
We continue to make enormous improvements to our clubs, including this quarter, the reopening of renovated Admirals Club in Rio de Janeiro and the refurbishment of our London Heathrow Arrivals Club, which now has 29 shower rooms in the business group. 
So in summary, this U.S. airline industry have been transformed and American Airlines is well positioned for success in the New World. We're producing record profits, near record profits. Despite a soft economic environment, and we're using those profits to improve customer service to important investments in both our products and our team. 
And we're returning the excess cash to shareholders through share repurchases. 
While there's much work ahead, the American team continues to improve their challenge. We're extremely pleased with where we are and very bullish on the future of American Airlines. 
So now, I'd like to turn it over to Derek who provide more details on the financial results. And then to our recently appointed President, Robert Isom, who will discuss operating performance and revenue environment. Derek?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everyone. We filed our 10-Q and earnings press release this morning and then that released our third quarter 2016 GAAP net profit was $737 million or $1.40 per diluted share. This compares to our third quarter 20
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everyone. We filed our 10-Q and earnings press release this morning and then that released our third quarter 2016 GAAP net profit was $737 million or $1.40 per diluted share. This compares to our third quarter 2015 GAAP net profit of $1.7 billion or $2.49 for diluted share and if we exclude special charges, we reported net profit of $933 million in the third quarter of 2016 or $1.76 per diluted share versus the third quarter net profit of $1.9 billion in 2015 or $2.77 per diluted share. 
Our GAAP third quarter pretax profit was $1.2 billion, equating to a pretax margin of 11.2%, excluding special charges, our third quarter pretax profit was $1.5 billion which resulted in a pretax margin of 14%. 
Excluding the effects of special charges and the noncash tax provision of $449 million, our third quarter 2016 adjusted fully diluted EPS was $2.80 per share compared to $2.77 in the third quarter of 2015, reflecting a 22% reduction in our fully diluted average share count during the quarter. 
We continue to see sequential improvement in the revenue environment during the quarter, which Robert will talk more about. For the quarter, total operating revenues were $10.6 billion, down 1.1% year-over-year. Passenger revenues were $9.1 billion, down 2.2%, driven by our 0.6% decline in yields. 
Cargo revenues were down 5.1% to $171 million due primarily to a decline in international and domestic yields. 
Other operating revenues were $1.3 billion, up 8.5% versus the same period last year due to the impact of the new credit card deals signed with Barclays U.S., Citi and MasterCard on July 12, 2016. 
Total GAAP operating expenses were $9.2 billion, up 5.2% versus the same period last year. This increase was driven by investments in our people through contractual increases and the introduction of profit sharing plan, investments in our product, investments which includes our fleet, as Doug talked about, and investments in our operation. These investments were offset in part by lower fuel costs. Our average mainline fuel price, including taxes for the third quarter of 2016 was down 12.4% year-over-year to $1.46 per gallon. 
Third quarter mainline cost per ASM was $0.1196, up 5.6% year-over-year. Excluding special charges and fuel, our mainline CASM was $0.0932, up 8.9% year-over-year. Regional operating cost per ASM in the third quarter was $0.1885, which was down 5.2% from the same quarter in 2015. 
Excluding special charges in fuel, regional CASM was $0.1508, a decrease of 4.4% due to continued shift to more efficient large regional jets. 
We entered the third quarter of 2016 with approximately $9.2 billion in total available liquidity comprised of cash and investments of $6.8 billion and $2.4 billion in undrawn revolver capacity well in the excess -- well in excess of $6.5 billion minimal liquidity we seek to maintain for the foreseeable future. 
The company also had $635 million classified as restricted cash during the quarter. 
We did generate $1.1 billion during the quarter of cash flow from operations and made $372 million in debt payments. We continue to believe it is important to retain liquidity levels higher than our network peers given our overall leverage and the fact that we have not yet completed our fleet renewal program, which will be substantially complete in 2017. 
During the quarter, the company took advantage of favorable market conditions, and completed several financing transactions, including a repricing of the company's 2014 term loan, collateralized by our London Heathrow slots, which reduced interest by 25 basis points and the issuance of $814 million EETC -- consisting of
[Audio Gap]
Shares withheld to cover taxes associated with employee equity awards and share of distributions and the cash extinguishment of convertible debt, our share count has dropped 31%, from 756 million at merger close in December 2013 to 519.2 million shares on September 30, 2016. 
At the end of the third quarter 2016, the company had approximately $565 million remaining on it current share repurchase authorization. 
Turning to our guidance for the remainder of 2016. We continue to monitor our capacity plans and in our IR update issued last week, we lowered full year 2016 system capacity guidance by 0.5 points and are forecasting it to be up approximately 1.5%. 
For the fourth quarter of 2016, we expect our mainline capacity to be 57.5 billion ASMs and our regional capacity to be 7.84 billion ASMs, so our consolidated capacity will be flat year-over-year in the fourth quarter. 
On the cost side, we're forecasting year-over-year mainline CASM excluding special items and fuel to be up approximately 5% to 7% while regional CASM excluding special items and fuel is projected to be down approximately 3% to 5%. 
For the fourth quarter of 2016, we expect our mainline CASM excluding fuel and special items to be up between 8% and 10%. This year-over-year increase is driven primarily by investment in our people of about 6 points, maintenance timing of 2 points and D&A from new aircraft and increased CapEx of 1 point. 
Regional CASM excluding special items and fuel is expected to be down by approximately 3% to 5% in the same period. 
As we look forward for the first time since mid-2014, year-over-year fuel prices are expected to be higher through the remainder of the year. Based on the forward curve as of October 17, our mainline fuel price forecast for the fourth quarter of 2016 is $1.59 to $1.64 per gallon while our regional fuel forecast for the fourth quarter is $1.65 to $1.70.  Despite these higher fuel prices, we expect the full year 2016 consolidated fuel expense to decreased by approximately $1.2 billion year-over-year. 
Using the midpoints of the guidance we just provided, along with the revenue guidance that Robert will give, we expect our fourth quarter pretax margin excluding special items to be between 4% and 6%. 
For our capital expenditures, we still expect total gross CapEx to be approximately $4.4 billion in 2016. We have 20 deliveries with approximately $1.1 billion, which will occur in the fourth quarter, and we expect to invest $300 million in non-aircraft CapEx in the quarter, which is $1.2 billion for the full year, which includes continued integration work and investments to improve our product and operations, some that Doug referred to his comments. 
Looking now to 2017, we are taking a disciplined approach to matching our plant capacity levels with anticipated levels of command. We're still in the process of developing our operating plan so our formal capacity guidance will come out when we report fourth quarter earnings. But we currently expect our year-over-year system capacity to be up approximately 1% in 2017. 
We expect full year 2017 domestic capacity to be flat while our international capacity is expected to be up approximately 3.5%. 
Our international growth is driven primarily by our Pacific entity as we annualized the new routes added in 2016. 
We'll also know more about 2017 unit cost projections after we complete our operating plan, but as Doug noted, we now have the bulk of our cost increases behind us. As we look to 2017, we expect the fully impact of our labor agreements with add approximately 2 points of CASM. But otherwise our core CASM growth should be around 2% on a very modest 1% growth in ASMs. 
And as Doug also noted with the integration nearing completion, we will be able to begin the process of eliminating some redundancies in 2017, which will help our unit cost in 2018 and beyond. 
So in conclusion, we couldn't be more proud of more than 100,000 team members who continue to deliver outstanding results. We continue to make great progress integrating our airlines most recently with our flight operating system cut over, and we've already seen some positive results. 
We're are also excited about the commercial initiatives our team is working on and looking forward to reporting on their continued success of future calls. 
Thanks, again, for your time this morning. And with that, I'll turn it over to Robert.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Derek. Good morning to everyone. Appreciate that you're joining us. I'd like to start out by thanking our 100,000 team members for their outstanding work during the quarter. And I'd characterized this quarter as being one of operational and comm
componenttext:
Thanks, Derek. Good morning to everyone. Appreciate that you're joining us. 
I'd like to start out by thanking our 100,000 team members for their outstanding work during the quarter. And I'd characterized this quarter as being one of operational and commercial challenges. But I would like to underscore positively that we have executed integration items exceptionally well. 
Now despite all these challenges, our team's commitment to taking care for customers and each other has never wavered. 
Some of our performance was challenging for both our employees and customers. The primary driver was inclement weather that seem to settle over a number of our hubs thought the summer most notably Dallas or DFW. 
In addition, we struggled operate our expanded Los Angeles schedule reliably, primarily due to airport and facility constraints. 
We're working with Wawa so that we will be better able to meet our customers demand to fly American from Los Angeles going forward. 
I'm happy to report that our reliability has rebounded to near record levels across our system in September as a result of a number of factors and those trends have continued well into October and we expect that they will continue. 
Again, I appreciate the efforts of our frontline think team to take care for customers throughout the summer and especially and most recently during Hurricane Matthew. 
We have successfully completed some major integration milestones over the past few months, including a single flight operating system for our pilots, dispatch and aircraft. 
And I so appreciative of our 15,000 pilots, the APA, our IT and flight off teams for their efforts to ensure a seamless cutover. 
We've also put new uniforms on all of our employees. We have interim agreements with our fleet service and mechanic workgroups, tentative agreements now with our flight crew training instructors and sim engineers and once these tentative agreements have been ratified, all American team members will be benefiting from pay increases that resulted from our merger. 
So much of what we're striving to accomplish going forward will be difficult to address without having the integration work completed and completed well. 
As we start to think about our plans for next year, there's good reason to believe that American will improve versus the industry and operations performance. We're taking a fresh look at how we schedule our aircraft reliability. Our 777-200 reconfigurations will be completed by December 2017. Our 787 fleet has reached a critical mass allowing for easier recovery from our schedule ops and with the single flight operating system, our aircraft and pilots can now be used interchangeably instead of being managed as separate entities. 
We're also making big investments in service recovery and customer notification tools for passengers and employees that will continue to rollout next year. 
On the revenue front, our third quarter PRASM was down 2.2% while the revenue environment is still challenging in certain areas of the world, we have absorbed improvements in many places. The third quarter was much better than the second quarter, so we continue to see improving trends. As Doug noted, in September, we had positive year-over-year CASM and PRASM, and that's the first time this has occurred since November of 2014. 
And we're seeing improving trends in cargo as well. September marked the first time since December 2014 that our monthly year-over-year cargo revenue has improved. 
Domestically, consolidated PRASM was down 1.8%. This was our best result since the first quarter of 2015. We saw strength across the board with all hubs having second derivative improvements.  Los Angeles and DCA were top performers year-over-year. 
Internationally, we have lapped the dollar strengthening last year as well as declining international surcharges. Latin was our first entity to turn positive with PRASM up 1.8% for the quarter, driven by a 25% year-over-year improvement in Brazil PRASM as capacity rationalize and the real strengthened. 
In addition, there was continued strength in Mexico. 
The Atlantic was our worst-performing international entity down 11.2%. The main drivers of performance are continued capacity increases, specifically from low-cost carriers, the devaluation of British pound as a result of the Brexit vote and lingering impact from recent terrorist attacks. 
Costa Pacific, PRASM was down 10.5% and capacity increases of 28.7% with continued weakness in China due to excess capacity and growing into our new services from Los Angeles to Hong Kong, Haneda, Sydney and Oakland. 
We're pleased to see corporate passenger demand holding up, driven by our domestic entity. In the third quarter, we saw increases in both absolutely revenue and revenue share, and we see similar trends is helping in the fourth quarter. 
Looking forward, we see some choppiness in the fourth quarter due to holiday shifts with September and January benefiting from traffic shifting from October and December. We expect November to be the strongest month in the quarter versus 2015. 
Regionally, the domestic fourth quarter looks about the same as the third quarter due to holidays shifts. 
In Latin America, we expect continued sequential improvements and low single digit increases in PRASM. We expect the Pacific and Atlantic to remain challenging with low double-digit year-over-year PRASM declines. And with that, we expect our fourth quarter RASM, not PRASM, but total RASM to be down 1% to 3% year-over-year. We expected our fourth quarter declined to be smaller than our third quarter decline despite a more difficult fourth quarter year-over-year comparison. 
As we look forward to 2017, we expect continued second derivative improvement in year-over-year PRASM performance and look forward to getting positive PRASM in the first half of the year. 
In conclusion, it's an exciting time to be at American Airlines. We made a tremendous amount of progress over this past year with respect to integration, operational improvement and getting back on positive PRASM. All of these important steps are critical to restoring American Airlines through its rightful industry-leading position. We have a lot of work left to do, but are confident that the right plans, the right team in place to execute, and we look forward to reporting back on future successes. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call back over to the operator and begin the question-and-answer session.

componenttextpreview: Well, I think as we've said, we can go down. Our minimum number is going to about 6.5. We do have some things coming up in 2018 with the pension payments, we have about $1.4 billion pension payment in '18 as we start going forward. So we need to look out
componenttext: Well, I think as we've said, we can go down. Our minimum number is going to about 6.5. We do have some things coming up in 2018 with the pension payments, we have about $1.4 billion pension payment in '18 as we start going forward. So we need to look out all the way through that time period to make sure that we have enough cash cap levels at this point, and we're very confident we're at today and the levels we're at today. So I think we can take it down a little bit from here. But I want to make sure that we get through all of the aircraft purchases next year and then I think it gets into the -- as we said 6.5 is our minimum that we feel we can go down to and we're significantly above that today. So we have opportunities to continue to return cash to our shareholders.

componenttext: And just add on, Derek, just set of minimum, it's [indiscernible] below that, it's a target that we like to keep that would take say that amount a little bit more than our competitors, that's what we do rather than in exchange for having some higher leverage, the way we protect ourselves making sure we have a lot more cash investments [indiscernible] so we have target cash balance of $6.5 billion, we're higher than that now and we're investing heavily in the airline and in our people, we'll  continue to do so because we're investing for the future. To that extent, we continue to be well above that number, that's we consider that excess cash which we returned to our shareholders.

And when we look at the Dallas performance right now, it's really in line with performance across the rest of the system.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. And then a little more on debt, Derek. Scott said you don't believe in artificial stock targets. Your stock has been doing nicely, your RASM is getting better. At a certain point here, people are going to start moving away from it if you're not, I t
componenttext: Good. And then a little more on debt, Derek. Scott said you don't believe in artificial stock targets. Your stock has been doing nicely, your RASM is getting better. At a certain point here, people are going to start moving away from it if you're not, I think, perceived to be taking a more sort of approach on your balance sheet, again, next 3, 6 months as RASM gets better, it's fine, but you're running a risk of people sort of transitioning to more quality stocks in the space, if you will, if you're not taking sort of approach on debt. So maybe talk about rather just liquidity, just talk about debt holistically. And is there any thoughts providing, making a slide that shows where you want to be on debt targets over the next 2, 3, 4 years. Because it works for Delta and I think some of the incremental that might be put off as everybody's RASM get better, midpoint to next year.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, let me start, this is Doug. So Derek can provide details. But first off, I would -- frankly, we don't  agree with the premise and shareholders can make their own decisions obviously based upon what we do, but our view is the best thing for our shareh
componenttext: Hey, let me start, this is Doug. So Derek can provide details. But first off, I would -- frankly, we don't  agree with the premise and shareholders can make their own decisions obviously based upon what we do, but our view is the best thing for our shareholders is to ensure that we have sufficient amount of liquidity to withstand any sort of downturn, but the cost of getting of worrying about credit ratings is in a business where we're borrowing against aircraft of 3% doesn't necessarily actually doesn't seem to be -- that goal in of itself doesn't seem to be in our shareholders' best interest. So somewhat, it's somewhat surprised with shareholder -- with people like you who push back on this because we think we're doing our best for our shareholders. And at the end of the day, we're producing -- we are producing profits at levels this industry has never seen before but gives us with other industries do. We're very bullish in our ability to continue doing that over time. As we do so, the first thing we do is invest back in our company. This company needs a good bit of investments. We're investing at levels that no airlines have ever invested before. The aircraft modernization I talked about has now -- that aircraft levels with their -- at age levels that are well below our competitors, something like around 10 years and falling for us in 16, 17 years and increasing for them. And then investing -- on top of that, something as Derek said, $1.5 billion next year on improvements in the airlines.  Those are good investments, and we're excited about that. And those will provide reassurance for our shareholders. Those are long-lived assets. We're not of spending on ancillary businesses or trying to do something we're not. We're doing what we think is right, and we feel very good about that. That investment now returns for shareholders. Once we do that, then we look to make sure we pay down any high-cost debt, we've done. Derek and his team have done a phenomenal job of getting to what we have larger amount of debt on the balance sheet than it appears. The cost of that debt is low. And as we look to each -- the incremental decision by the way, comes down to that, we're adding airplanes as we do modernization. Should we use all of our cash balance to pay for those aircrafts or should we avail ourselves of the 3% debt. And we think the best thing for our shareholders is to avail of the 3% debt. That leaves us with cash balances that are in excess of the target and we what we do with that is to return to our shareholders. But the way we protect ourselves is having a much higher liquidity balance than others. That's the cost of it, but it's a much less costly thing done paying -- than not availing yourself of low cost debt. I mean, the other point I make is, even if we did those things, even if we started paying cash for aircraft, we still have higher debt because we have better assets. When you have airplanes that are 9 years old versus someone else's 17 years, you're going to have higher debt because you have much better assets and they're going to be here for a long time. That's why we're doing this. So [indiscernible]. This is we believe in the right spot. We're very comfortable with our leverage. We're very comfortable with our balance sheet, and we're doing the right thing for shareholders.

componenttext: Yes, that's seasonal. They do [indiscernible] we do. Now is the answer, I expect what you'll see in '17 is us do better than our competitors in terms of certainly year-over-year margins. You're seeing it already in the RASM, and that will continue into '17. You'll see on the cost front, as Derek noted, the reason the margins declined even though we're having better RASM right now, of course, is our CASM is more. That's because we're going to taking care of our people faster and gotten ourselves to a point where we have in every work group less than 3 years since the merger we now have everyone on new pay scales that reflect the job they're doing for us, and that increased our cost level but [indiscernible] level off. We have to do that, we're happy we did that, our shareholders should be happy we did that, but it's behind us now. We have one of those that was done mid-year, which is the TWI as Derek talked about that if have year-over-year impact, but it's in the current cost structure. But beyond that, we have sort of other cost increase certainly over and above inflationary rates in the airline. So I think what you'll see as we go through '17 is better revenue per ASM improvement on year-over-year basis and better cost performance as well.

componenttext: Thanks, Jamie. So basic economy, as you know, we've been working on for some time, and we're on track. We're prepared to launch at the end of this year. This comes a little bit from my operations background, I want to avoid the holidays and disruption to our folks. And so we're on track and ready to go. But any details on that, we're going to have to wait until we roll out, and we're not at this time, making any projections on revenue performance associated with the product.

componenttext: For international Premium Economy, the great news is we're seeing it come out in our 787-900 deliveries, which is fantastic news. And if those ramp up, we'll have critical mass to start selling. Right now, you can buy into those seats, which is good news. And as we get to the point of being able to offer consistently next year, we'll be able to start selling Premium Economy cabin.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Mike, we are doing the modifications. We have to go through on all of our wide-body aircraft the ones that aren't delivered with it. The brunt -- the biggest portion of them will start coming in '18, so we'll have all of those aircraft going through Mod in '17, so we will monetize those seats through probably MCE, our Main Cabin Extra product that we have today until we get to the critical mass and then we'll be able to put out roll out the premiere economy. So I think it's more of an '18 impact than it is a '17 impact due to having to modify all of our wide-body aircraft for that product.

componenttext: Let's work through and give you the number overtime. I'm not sure we know that number yet. What we know is we do indeed have because we're still not fully integrated a number of areas around the company where we have not just more people, but more resources that we need in all sorts of areas so we will make sure we do it in a way that as quickly as we can and also in a way that's takes care of our employees, it's really important to us. So that's a big project for us through 2017. I wouldn't expect it would be able to yield major cost savings in 2017 because we're still [indiscernible] airlines for a good part of 2017, but that's a big focus of the team's efforts to move forward to be sure that we are in the endeavoring to make sure we don't get to everyone airline and still have the infrastructure of 2. So we'll work through it. As we know more we let you know. But I mean, it's not insignificant we wont talk about it. It's something that's going to be able to yield some nice cost improvement, and it should. Part of why our cost are where they are right now is because we're running 2 separate airlines in a lot of areas, and we'll work through that as we go through 2017.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just real, the other question I just had within the Atlantic and your joint venture with BA and Iberia and the other carriers. I mean, have you been able to sort of think through what the right level of capacity is given that huge increasing cap
componenttext: Okay. And just real, the other question I just had within the Atlantic and your joint venture with BA and Iberia and the other carriers. I mean, have you been able to sort of think through what the right level of capacity is given that huge increasing capacity from what I would call low-fare and other airlines on the North Atlantic this past summer and what is likely to be next summer? May be too far away, but I'm sure you're giving it some thoughts.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, [indiscernible] different mark, but I mean, we have to be careful of our [indiscernible] capacity of course, the capacity plans based on others. What we know is while there are other carriers having an impact, what we fly is incredibly important t
componenttext: I mean, [indiscernible] different mark, but I mean, we have to be careful of our [indiscernible] capacity of course, the capacity plans based on others. What we know is while there are other carriers having an impact, what we fly is incredibly important to American Airlines. And don't have no material plans to doing anything other than what we're doing right now and planning to continue to do so. It's a huge part of our network, important to our customers and relationship with PAs and [indiscernible] appears important ones. As others we work through those things, but I don't  expect you'll see us just decide to -- we're the ones who should be looking to have our capacity going. Don?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add in the upcoming winter season where actually we're reducing our capacity about 6%, so we are taking some actions. And those capacity reductions are focused to the market where we face structural challenges where we have partners we continue
componenttext: I'll just add in the upcoming winter season where actually we're reducing our capacity about 6%, so we are taking some actions. And those capacity reductions are focused to the market where we face structural challenges where we have partners we continue to maintain our capacity going forward.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: I just wanted to follow up to actually where Joe started the conversation on capacity. If we look at this year, I think you spreaded out about 3%, and we're finishing up about 140 basis points below that. Could you quantify how much of that was due to regional supply constraints? And I wonder if you would be willing to get specific on republics restructuring what were the aircraft you expected to be [indiscernible] in the original plan that went away?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Duane, I think it would be hard for us to break out right now, but our reductions are really a result of not only a little bit due to regional supportability due to pilot concerns, but also South American concerns and then just adjustment througho
componenttext: Yes, so Duane, I think it would be hard for us to break out right now, but our reductions are really a result of not only a little bit due to regional supportability due to pilot concerns, but also South American concerns and then just adjustment throughout the system. So I think that where we stand right now is where we need to be, and we've got a fleet and a wrap network that's meeting with the demand that we think that's out there.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the reductions, of course, we're still increasing -- it's not increasing a rate that, but one point in the future we forecast it would be. So it's not because of aircraft numbers, it's because of utilization of aircraft that we respond to demand. So t
componenttext: And the reductions, of course, we're still increasing -- it's not increasing a rate that, but one point in the future we forecast it would be. So it's not because of aircraft numbers, it's because of utilization of aircraft that we respond to demand. So that's really was going on here, Duane, for the most part, and we look out a few quarters and think where we may be based on the aircraft we have, and we have common. And then as we get closer and see what's happening with demand, we may make schedule changes, and that's what's happened here.

componenttext: And Joe, this is Derek. We did put in our Q that we have reached agreement with Republic on a go-forward plan, which did take out about 25 aircraft out of the contract, so we've reached that agreement with them obviously there's still have a process to go through to get out of bankruptcy, but our deal moving forward has reduced aircraft, and we're in pretty good shape with where we're at with the Republic.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. And then Robert, I wanted to ask a question kind of old structure versus new old structure. What were some of the less than optimal aspects of kind of getting a network plan from the other side of the house and then you having to deliv
componenttext: Okay. That's great. And then Robert, I wanted to ask a question kind of old structure versus new old structure. What were some of the less than optimal aspects of kind of getting a network plan from the other side of the house and then you having to deliver that from an operational perspective? And I guess, more importantly, what are the implications of an engineer, and I mean that in a very flattering way, of an engineer now owing both the network plan and ops?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, thanks. Look, our company has been so focused on integration, merger, huge initiatives that the adjustments that was made in terms of work structure really designed now that we're getting past some of the major integration milestones. To start look
componenttext: Duane, thanks. Look, our company has been so focused on integration, merger, huge initiatives that the adjustments that was made in terms of work structure really designed now that we're getting past some of the major integration milestones. To start looking at how we can really optimize the running the company day to day. And to do that, we know that we've got to collaborate, and we all have to be focused on the same goals. And I think we've gotten org structure and fantastic people running each of the operating groups and are committed to doing that. And so any difficulties that we've had, I think, we're just going to be more well-suited to collaborate, communicate and make sure that we're aligned going forward.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jack Atkins with Stephens.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jack Atkins with Stephens.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, just following up on that last question for a moment, Robert. Now that you're in your new role, has the strategy at all changed with -- as far as the competition with the ULC and markets? And then as you look at your network today are there an
componenttext: So I guess, just following up on that last question for a moment, Robert. Now that you're in your new role, has the strategy at all changed with -- as far as the competition with the ULC and markets? And then as you look at your network today are there any specific items or projects now that you're in your new role as you look to sort of undertake over the next 12 months?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thanks for the question. Hey, look, I've been part of this management team since the get go. So in terms of how we go to market and strategies that we're intending to pursue, I feel like I've been part of those. And the direction that we're having toda
componenttext: So thanks for the question. Hey, look, I've been part of this management team since the get go. So in terms of how we go to market and strategies that we're intending to pursue, I feel like I've been part of those. And the direction that we're having today isn't going to change. We're going to be incredibly competitive with all commerce, especially in our hubs. And so you won't see much of a change in terms of philosophy as we go to marketplace and compete. Yes, in terms of going forward, there's things we want to do, we want to certainly excel at. One of them is running a fantastic airline, one that is best in the business on all levels, and that's operational as well as revenue performance and certainly, from a perspective of meeting customer's expectations. That's going to require that we really engage all of our people in a way that we haven't before. And so I do believe going forward that one of the primary points of emphasis that we're going to make is involved in all of our people and making sure that they are in equipped and well trained and treated in a fashion where they help us outperform the industry. So from -- there's a lot of other things that we have going on. Certainly, we want to make sure that we have all of our forward-looking strategies, alliances, alliance partners, our network in the best fashion. But it all leads to the same place, which is having the best network, the best people and the best product for our customers.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jack, it's Doug, too. That's a great answer by Robert, but I also want to chime a little bit especially on the ULCC piece that you mentioned. As Robert said, there's absolutely no change. What we need we have to compete aggressively on price against
componenttext: Hey, Jack, it's Doug, too. That's a great answer by Robert, but I also want to chime a little bit especially on the ULCC piece that you mentioned. As Robert said, there's absolutely no change. What we need we have to compete aggressively on price against carriers like that and when they come -- when they add flights to our hubs, we actually have a competitive advantage because we have so much connecting activity. The one game-changer, maybe a big [indiscernible] certainly an improvement in how we can do that and still not -- and still be good for American Airlines as can be is basic economy. And so that product we have in play will allow us to do just that, but not have the same amount of dilution we have to American Airlines. So the impact to [indiscernible] frontiers will be the same, we aggressively mentioned the prices but since -- as we put that product in place it will have some attributes that some of customers would rather don't  care to purchase or want to purchase other attributes for more. And right now, as we match, we don't agree much, we're not able to do that. So that will allow us to do what we're doing today, continue to do what we're doing today which Robert says what we're going to do what also do it in a way that allows us to provide another, more utility to our customers and give them a product in addition to the one that they absolutely lowest fare.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I guess just as a follow-up question, it seems as though whether it's cabin segmentation or international revenue opportunities or reducing redundancies in the organization over the next couple of years, there's a huge revenue and cost op
componenttext: Okay, great. And I guess just as a follow-up question, it seems as though whether it's cabin segmentation or international revenue opportunities or reducing redundancies in the organization over the next couple of years, there's a huge revenue and cost opportunity at American which should drive significant profitability. I'm just sure of of curious as you guys think about how to communicate  that going forward, is there going to be maybe an opportunity for us to get from you guys detailed financial targets long term? Because I think that will be really helpful to understand the earnings barrier?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for the comment. We'll take it under advisement. I understand the value that could provide. Just know that I've been doing this way too long and I'm often reluctant to do -- depends on how we define the target. But what I don't like doing is
componenttext: Okay, thanks for the comment. We'll take it under advisement. I understand the value that could provide. Just know that I've been doing this way too long and I'm often reluctant to do -- depends on how we define the target. But what I don't like doing is suggesting that we can project the future in this business. It is incredibly volatile, it will be volatile. I think it will be profitable, I think it's dramatically changed. But the volatility hasn't changed. So we sometimes are less comfortable than others trying to set things like margins -- margin targets when we know that some things affect us margins are outside of our control primarily the economy and fuel prices. So I'll tell you this, we couldn't feel better about American Airlines' future and its financial future. And I also will tell you that based on what we think about the future, we're extremely bullish on the American stock, which is why we continue to purchase of the levels we do because as we look out, targets or non-targets, our projections even in difficult economic environments have this company being nice and profitable, and it doesn't feel like our stock reflects that. So we're happy to give you that guidance and let you do your own numbers. But what we do management company is make sure we're optimizing for the long term, and we're doing all these things. But we are remised to try and tell you that we, and we had those up looks like to us and therefore here's what we will produce because we know there's a lot of volatility in what we're able to produce and our job is to make sure we can manage around the volatility. We can, we're excited about that. We'll work to see what we can give you some our guidance we have in the past about longer term. But just understand that's our concern.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the opportunities on the cost side now that the integrations lushly behind it, which is structural cost-reduction programs a few years after the emerges and where do you think American could announce something similar? And where more sp
componenttext: Can you talk about the opportunities on the cost side now that the integrations lushly behind it, which is structural cost-reduction programs a few years after the emerges and where do you think American could announce something similar? And where more specifically are some of the opportunity?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as we talked about on the call, we're going to be going through '17 from a -- we have talked about having excess headcount in certain areas just duplication of work just because we're running 2 different airlines. That's the primary area tha
componenttext: Well, I think as we talked about on the call, we're going to be going through '17 from a -- we have talked about having excess headcount in certain areas just duplication of work just because we're running 2 different airlines. That's the primary area that we'll work on as we move forward. As we said in the call, I think are going to look at that stuff starting in '17, and it will start to affect us in '18. So I think what we want to do is, we're going to go through the budget in '17, we're going to see where everything is and then try to work with each one of the teams to figure out how we take that out over the time period into '18. But I think it's more -- as we talked about, an '18 issue than it is an '17 issue. Mostly it's inefficiencies of trying to run 2 different airlines all throughout the company. It's not just one point, it's all throughout the company as we've tried to get ourselves where we want to be from an airline and running the best airline we can.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just a question on capacity in Latin America. You guys have obviously taken a lot of capacity out and you're certainly seeing the benefits of that today. However, you think about presuming growth now that entity has turned and are you worried about latent capacity coming back in next year?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Julie, it's Robert. For us, it's a wait-and-see. We're pleased with the signs of some growth, and we're going to hold onto that for a while and see where things go.

componenttext: Okay. And one final one. Robert, when would you expect Atlantic PRASM to -- trends to flatten out?

componenttextpreview: It's Don, again. We do not see in in the foreseeable future. Capacity in the first quarter, industry capacity is going to be up 7%, and we don't see signs of that abating. And until that abates, i going to be hard to see a positive trajectory in the Atlan
componenttext: It's Don, again. We do not see in in the foreseeable future. Capacity in the first quarter, industry capacity is going to be up 7%, and we don't see signs of that abating. And until that abates, i going to be hard to see a positive trajectory in the Atlantic.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan McKenzie from Buckingham research.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: I guess, this would be for Robert or Don. Does the revenue guide factor and the potential loss of the codeshare with Alaska? And how material could that impact be if it's lost?

componenttext: The revenue guide does not and I don't think, if we did, it would change. So it wouldn't be materially impacting to the guidance.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, Doug or Derek, my question was on debt as well. So we all know absolutely debt levels are higher than they been historically. But with respect to the underlying business, I wonder if you could just help investors understand the le
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, Doug or Derek, my question was on debt as well. So we all know absolutely debt levels are higher than they been historically. But with respect to the underlying business, I wonder if you could just help investors understand the leverage metrics relative to where they've been historically. maybe on an American standalone basis. So leverage metrics today relative to some average over some period of time that makes sense. And as you look at those metrics and as you feel comfortable about those metrics, is it that you expect profits to continue growing faster than the debt? And wonder if you could just up us understand what are those metrics look like under your stress test?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And thanks for bringing it back because I know when I said it, we're comfortable. What I meant was we're comfortable where it is at this time because looking to the future, what we expect just those metrics continue to improve. I want to try to sugg
componenttext: Sure. And thanks for bringing it back because I know when I said it, we're comfortable. What I meant was we're comfortable where it is at this time because looking to the future, what we expect just those metrics continue to improve. I want to try to suggest we're comfortable of keeping them, although we may be. But the reason we're comfortable with them at this time is because of what you say, we have very good line of sight as to what our capital requirements are going forward. We have a very -- we have -- we feel good about our -- certainly even on a very -- in difficult economic times those, stress testing, I guess, even things like recession about what our earnings would do. As we go forward. So those -- that gives us comfort that we are in a good spot right now and when things come up like 3% interest, it seems to be an absolute no-brainer to us that the right thing to do is to take those debt on rather than using cash to pay airplanes and use that cash for [indiscernible]. So that's what we're comfortable about. What happens over time, I would expect and again, without giving the targets is you will see certainly that the metrics that are tied coverage ratios, for example, high earnings to debt levels, you see those get for overtime, and you get better as our earnings get better and the debt gets lower, we are also, I should note, while we're well ahead of everyone in terms of modernizing our fleet, there will come a time that we've got gotten that done in the future, and you will see the debt continue to come out at these levels. So as debt gets lower overtime and earnings continue -- EBITDA  or margin starts to stay where they are, you'll see those numbers get better. And that's what why we're comfortable where we are today. I think where we are today because of the reasons I said and believe we have the right structure in place. As insurance we carry a lot more cash than others, but we think that's the better way to do for our shareholders than to go and pay cash for airplanes rather taking a 3% data.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes Darryl Genovesi from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes Darryl Genovesi from UBS.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, just to follow up on some of your comments around aircraft age. I know you inherited a significant majority of your order book from your predecessor. But is the longer-term plan to maintain the same relative age advantage over your competitors that
componenttext: Doug, just to follow up on some of your comments around aircraft age. I know you inherited a significant majority of your order book from your predecessor. But is the longer-term plan to maintain the same relative age advantage over your competitors that you have today? Because I think doing so would imply a much different longer term CapEx profile than allowing the fleet age to revert?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, aircraft age is not a metric that we look at to measure versus our competitors. I'm just pointing out where it is. But we don't have a goal to say we need to be below others in aircraft age. But it's noteworthy, particularly when we get to conversati
componenttext: Yes, aircraft age is not a metric that we look at to measure versus our competitors. I'm just pointing out where it is. But we don't have a goal to say we need to be below others in aircraft age. But it's noteworthy, particularly when we get to conversations about relative debt levels to point out how much stronger our asset base is my only point. And the best way for me to communicate that to you is to point out how much younger our fleet is. Look, it is it's absolutely a customer advantage when you get one embarked new airplanes as one that is no doubt that it is a much better in-flight product, and you can tell the difference. So we feel good about that. But you're right, the orders were in place and are coming, and we're taking them. But the bigger point I'm trying to make here is these are, if you look in the very near term, you may say, oh my gosh, these guys -- they have all these debt. These are 25-year assets and those airlines have 17-year-old airplanes won't be able to have 42-year-old airplanes 25 years from now. So at some point, my point is we ahead of them and suggesting they need to go, spend enormous amount of capital in the very near term, but they will need to do something, and we won't have too at that point in time, that's way it works. So anyway our goal is to make sure we have the absolute [indiscernible] it's nice when you're in that position. But to the extent you want to look at relative debt levels, you need to look at the asset base, and our asset base is just tremendously more [indiscernible].

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I'll just ask you on -- or maybe Robert, whoever wants to comment, can you just give us some sense of how your view on hub is evolving given your recent emphasis on Los Angeles and the existing presence in Dallas?
componenttext: Great. And then I'll just ask you on -- or maybe Robert, whoever wants to comment, can you just give us some sense of how your view on hub is evolving given your recent emphasis on Los Angeles and the existing presence in Dallas?

componenttext: Thanks, I appreciate it. It seems does well for us. It serves the same purpose that we view over just the start of the merger, it's a great connecting hub, it's got a growing metro area, and it's serving our network very well.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And L.A. is different, it's largely international gateway that we feed and are looking to expand. But they're complementary, not competitive.
componenttext: And L.A. is different, it's largely international gateway that we feed and are looking to expand. But they're complementary, not competitive.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one question for Robert. I guess, when I look at your on time performance stats, they really start to lag both your network peers starting about 6-month ago or so. Is there a reason for this? Is anything going on with the integration that would have
componenttext: Just one question for Robert. I guess, when I look at your on time performance stats, they really start to lag both your network peers starting about 6-month ago or so. Is there a reason for this? Is anything going on with the integration that would have cost us? I can't imagine that it's all the L.A. issues that you mentioned in your prepared remarks. And I know you mentioned solid corporate share earlier, but have you heard anything from your corporate customers on this performance?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the answer in terms of corporate customers, the answer is no. We haven't heard anything. We are performing very well, as I said, in my remarks with our corporate business. So in terms of this summer and the fall, that's really where I look at things an
componenttext: So the answer in terms of corporate customers, the answer is no. We haven't heard anything. We are performing very well, as I said, in my remarks with our corporate business. So in terms of this summer and the fall, that's really where I look at things and its associated with schedule where I think quite frankly, we're pretty aggressive in terms of the schedule that we put out this summer. We had issues in Los Angeles. We definitely had, I think, an order of that amount weather issues associated with DFW and then Charlotte and Miami, and that was pragmatic. So seems like we're in a recovery phase a lot of during the summer. As I said before we have a lot of integration tools that we didn't have that we will have in the future and that is on building the airline back after disruption and making sure our customers and their baggage is taken care of. One of the things you'll note though is that we continue to be really strong in terms of our departing on time performance, the [indiscernible] performance. That is something that we'll continue to see and I think that they'll will translate into more competitive arrivals within 14 performance. And you'll see as well, that our completion factor as we move from operating 2 systems and really 3 systems in regard to our pilot down to one that we've got a chance to do much, much better. So I'm very optimistic of where we're headed and if you take a look at where we're at right now, schedule reduction associated with the fall season with changes to our Los Angeles operation, we're operating back at near record levels and that should continue and again, as I said before all efforts are focused on making sure that we work together to put out a schedule in 2017 that we can operate reliably and competitively with the best in the business.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: And that ends the analyst question. We will now take questions from the media. [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Andrea Ahles with Forth Worth Star-Telegram.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would like to follow up little bit on Helane's regarding the possibility on reducing headcount and how that might be done in 2017. Are you looking at actually doing sort of any layoffs or reduction enforced, particularly in headquarters where you may ha
componenttext: I would like to follow up little bit on Helane's regarding the possibility on reducing headcount and how that might be done in 2017. Are you looking at actually doing sort of any layoffs or reduction enforced, particularly in headquarters where you may have overlapping functions as you operate -- as you go from operating 2 down into 1? Can you give a little more color detail on that?

componenttext: Sure, absolutely. Glad you asked. You made it sound that way. We have pockets of the airline in different groups, we will have -- of course, we're running 2 airlines, where we have people we get that down to 1. But we will manage that over time through attrition, through -- if makes sense if it's a labor group early on, whatever works for our people to make sure we do that. We don't have any intention that we care to go describe we do this in a way that works for our team.

componenttext: Nothing we can talk about. Again, this is more of a beyond 2017 issue. We're going to do the work through 2017. The good news is this we have regular attrition rates. We have raised people to do look to retire early and we'll work through those things as it becomes an issue. Right now, we're just -- the reason we mentioned it is something important to the analyst maybe to understand that, that would be something that comes beyond 2017.

componenttext: Yes, as we sit here today [indiscernible] that is what I think is correct. [indiscernible] and I also want to say enormous number  [indiscernible] We have pockets of people throughout the organization, as I said and we'll make sure this works out for those who are either looking to leave on their own as we have natural attrition [indiscernible]. So this is nothing about furloughs and layoffs, it's all about the fact that as you move from 2 airlines to truly one airlines, we'll be able to get some cost efficiencies.

componenttext: So Edward, the premiere economy is going to go to A330-200 fleet, the 777-200s, 777-300s and then our 787 fleet. And then as we said the 78, 79s are starting now and as Don mentioned we should have for sale in terms of a different classic service next year. But the reconfigurations are going to take place over the course over the next really 18 months, 24 months, so we're not going to be ready along all those fleets until June of 2018.

componenttext: Yes, sure, there are 2 areas that are already driving the growth. One is Latin America. Latin America, Brazil, where we've seen 25% increase in your revenue year-over-year. Mexico is performing strongly. We got a positive revenue growth in Mexico and Venezuela is contributing to overall unit revenue growth as well. Domestic business, the trend there really has been positive. As I mentioned earlier, we've seen close in yield strength, will also seen a stabilize pricing environment that's been pretty tumultuous this year but as of late July, it kind of evened out. And when we look at domestic business from an R&D perspective, we seeing kind of the best and strongest kind of yield performance in connecting all markets in the domestic business which ties a little bit back to my earlier comments on pricing. And also we seeing the benefits now of the credit card you that we've did in the second quarter as well.

componenttext: I just had a couple of questions about Latin America, some just answered. But are these gains in Latin America, are they sustainable? componenttext: This is Don, again. So we think our performance in Latin America overall is going to continue to get [indiscernible] As for Cuba, I think everyone has struggled a little bit in terms of selling in Cuba. There are a lot of restrictions that they're still in place that made it difficult to sell. But I think charter -- Cuba is going to be a bit of a long route, I think.

componenttext: We're waiting for the long haul. I mean, this is not something we didn't expect, this is really a new market. And so anyway, we're excited to be the largest carrier there, and we're committed to Cuba in making it work, and we'll  work through the start-up to get it to the [indiscernible] where we all expect it will be.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: This is Doug. Thanks, everybody. Again, look, the story to this -- from my perspective listening to all these we -- the team when we did this merger less than 3 years ago, the biggest question we get on this call was concerns about our ability to manage the integration. And I can't be more pleased to the work the team has done to get through obviously things like PSS and just now past, so the delays sitting here manages through whole team effort, which is why it's so hard, it takes cross factional work where people trying to do their full job, too. So we are you related that, that concern we've been able to take off of your list of concerns, and that's important. But what it's more important about this it shows what a great team we have here and the things we can do and now with much of that work behind, not all of it, but much of it is behind us we're extremely excited about everything that we have going on particularly the investments we're making in our people, in our product that will accrue to our customers. And yes, that provides us, but we're in this for the long term. We're excited about the long term, and we appreciate your support. Thanks.
