headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] And now I would like to turn the conference over to your moderator, Managing Director of Investor Re
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
And now I would like to turn the conference over to your moderator, Managing Director of Investor Relations, Mr. Dan Cravens. Please go ahead.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us on the call today is Doug Parker, our Chairman and CEO; Robert Isom, our President and Derek Kerr, our Chief Financial O
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to the American Airlines Group Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Joining us on the call today is Doug Parker, our Chairman and CEO; Robert Isom, our President and Derek Kerr, our Chief Financial Officer. Also in the room for our question-and-answer session is Elise Eberwein, our EVP of People and Communications; Bev Goulet, our Chief Integration Officer; Maya Leibman, Chief Information Officer; Steve Johnson, our EVP of Corporate Affairs; and Don Casey, our Senior Vice President of Revenue Management. 
As is our normal practice, we're going to start the call with Doug and he will provide an overview of the third quarter financial results. Derek will then walk us through the details on the quarter and provide some additional information on our guidance for the remainder -- for the fourth quarter. Robert will then follow with commentary on the operational performance and revenue environment. And then after we hear from those comments, we'll open the call for analysts' questions and lastly, questions from the media. 
Before we begin, we must state that today's call does contain forward-looking statements, including statements concerning future revenues and costs, forecast of capacity, traffic, load factor, fleet plans and fuel prices. These statements represent our predictions and expectations as to future events, but numerous risks and uncertainties could cause actual results to differ from those projected. Information about some of those risks and uncertainties can be found in our earnings press release issued this morning and our Form 10-Q for the quarter ended September 30, 2016. 
In addition, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures this morning, such as net profit and CASM, excluding unusual items. A reconciliation of those numbers to the GAAP financial measures is included in the earnings press release that can be found on our website. A webcast of this call will also be archived on our website. The information that we're giving you on the call is as of today's date, and we undertake no obligation to update the information subsequently. 
So thanks, again, for joining us this morning. And at this point, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chairman and CEO, Doug Parker.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan. And thanks to everybody for being on. We released the earnings this morning, as Dan stated. Pretax earnings, excluding special items of $1.5 billion. It's down from last year's $1.9 billion. But that's due both by declining unit revenues, our
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan. And thanks to everybody for being on. We released the earnings this morning, as Dan stated. Pretax earnings, excluding special items of $1.5 billion. It's down from last year's $1.9 billion. But that's due both by declining unit revenues, our total -- our TRASM was down 2.2% versus last year. And increasing year cost, driven primarily by investments on our team. But while they're down, they're still the second best third quarter in history in American Airlines behind only the third quarter 2015. 
Also because of our share repurchase activity, our adjusted EPS was actually up, even though earnings were down from $2.77 up to $2.80 in the quarter. 
So these results are due to the fantastic team at American who've done an amazing job for our customers. We're extremely grateful for them and what they do. 
On the revenue front, Robert will provide a lot more detail, but we're encouraged by the trends. Our TRASM, as I said, was down 2.2% in the third quarter. But that's better than we've seen in terms of the decline in recent quarters. And it's better than our competitors are experiencing. In fact, our -- the month of September TRASM was actually improved year-over-year, which was the first month of year-over-year TRASM improvement for American Airlines since November of 2014. Now of course, September was helped by the calendar on a year-over-year basis, which is why we at American would like to focus much on monthly unit revenue numbers. But the trend is good and it appears to be continuing, as Robert will discuss. 
Our unit costs grew in the quarter and Derek will talk -- will provide more detail on that. But the primary driver of the unit cost increase is our decision to invest in our seats. We have pay increases and profit sharing that are, by far, the largest drivers of the cost increase. and we're pleased to be able to provide those improvements to our team members. We've now reached new agreements with all of our work groups, so the large increases are behind us. 
Furthermore, as we complete more of our integration in 2017, we'll be able to begin eliminating some of the redundancies that still exist because of the 2 airlines, and that'll help us reduce expenses in 2018 and beyond. 
As integration, we had an enormous success earlier this month with the flawless integration of our flight operating system across. This is an extremely complicated system integration that's led to operational disruptions with other airlines as they've gone through mergers. And our team executed it without it -- without a hitch. 
While we're doing all that, we continue to invest in our products and improve the product. We had 12 new aircraft as part of our unprecedented fleet renewal program in the [indiscernible]. American's fleet is now more than 40% younger than our large network peers and that gap is widening. 
We had 10 new destinations to our network, including 5 in Cuba, a new service to -- from LAX to Hong Kong. And next month, we'll begin daily flights to Havana, strengthening our position as the largest carrier to Cuba. 
We continue to make enormous improvements to our clubs, including in this quarter, the reopening of a renovated Admirals Club in Rio de Janeiro and the refurbishment of our London Heathrow Arrivals Club, which now has 29 shower rooms and a business center. 
So in summary, this -- the U.S. airline industry have been transformed and American Airlines is well positioned for success in the New World. We're producing record profits -- near record profits despite a soft economic environment, and we're using those profits to improve customer service through important investments in both our products and our team. And we're returning the excess cash to our shareholders through share repurchases. 
There's much work ahead, but the American team continues to improve [indiscernible] challenge. We're extremely pleased with where we are and very bullish on the future of American Airlines. 
So now, I'd like to turn it over to Derek, who will provide more details on the financial results. And then to our recently appointed President, Robert Isom, who will discuss operating performance and revenue environment. Derek?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everyone. We've filed our 10-Q and earnings press release this morning. And in that release, our third quarter 2016 GAAP net profit was $737 million or $1.40 per diluted share. This compares to our third quarter
componenttext:
All right. Thanks, Doug, and good morning, everyone. We've filed our 10-Q and earnings press release this morning. And in that release, our third quarter 2016 GAAP net profit was $737 million or $1.40 per diluted share. This compares to our third quarter 2015 GAAP net profit of $1.7 billion or $2.49 per diluted share. And if we exclude the special charges, we reported a net profit of $933 million in the third quarter of 2016 or $1.76 per diluted share versus the third quarter net profit of $1.9 billion in 2015 or $2.77 per diluted share. 
Our GAAP third quarter pretax profit was $1.2 billion, equating to a pretax margin of 11.2%. Excluding special charges, our third quarter pretax profit was $1.5 billion, which resulted in a pretax margin of 14%. Excluding the effects of special charges and the noncash tax provision of $449 million, our third quarter 2016 adjusted fully diluted EPS was $2.80 per share compared to $2.77 in the third quarter of 2015, reflecting a 22% reduction in our fully diluted average share count during the quarter. 
We continue to see sequential improvement in the revenue environment during the quarter, which Robert will talk more about. For the quarter, total operating revenues were $10.6 billion, down 1.1% year-over-year. Passenger revenues were $9.1 billion, down 2.2%, driven by a 0.6% decline in yields. Cargoes were -- cargo revenues were down 5.1% to $171 million due primarily to a decline in international and domestic yields. Other operating revenues were $1.3 billion, up 8.5% versus the same period last year due to the impact of the new credit card deal signed with Barclays U.S., Citi and MasterCard on July 12, 2016. 
Total GAAP operating expenses were $9.2 billion, up 5.2% versus the same period last year. This increase was driven by investments in our people through contractual increases and the introduction of profit sharing plan, investments in our product, investment, which includes our fleet, as Doug talked about, and investments in our operation. These investments were offset in part by lower fuel costs. Our average mainline fuel price, including taxes for the third quarter of 2016, was down 12.4% year-over-year to $1.46 per gallon. 
Third quarter mainline cost per ASM was $0.1196, up 5.6% year-over-year. Excluding special charges in fuel, our mainline CASM was $0.0932, up 8.9% year-over-year. Regional operating cost per ASM in the third quarter was $0.1885, which was down 5.2% from the third quarter in 2015. Excluding special charges in fuel, regional CASM was $0.1508, a decrease of 4.4% due to the continued shift to more efficient large regional jets. 
We entered the third quarter of 2016 with approximately $9.2 billion in total available liquidity comprised of cash and investments of $6.8 billion and $2.4 billion in an undrawn revolver capacity well in the excess -- well in excess of the $6.5 billion minimal liquidity we seek to maintain for this foreseeable future. The company also had $635 million classified as restricted cash during the quarter. 
We did generate $1.1 billion during the quarter of cash flow from operations and made $372 million in debt payments. We continue to believe it is important to retain liquidity levels higher than our network peers given our overall leverage and the fact that we have not yet completed our fleet renewal program, which will be substantially complete in 2017. 
During the quarter, the company took advantage of favorable market conditions and completed several financing transactions, including a repricing of the company's 2014 term loan collateralized by our London Heathrow slots, which reduced interest by 25 basis points and the issuance of $814 million EETC consisting of
[Audio Gap]
Shares withheld to cover taxes associated with employee equity awards and share of distributions and the cash extinguishment of convertible debt, our share count has dropped 31% from 756 million at merger close in December 2013 to 519.2 million shares on September 30, 2016. At the end of the third quarter 2016, the company had approximately $555 million remaining on its current share repurchase authorization. 
Turning to our guidance for the remainder of 2016. We continue to monitor our capacity plans. And in our IR update issued last week, we lowered full year 2016 system capacity guidance by 0.5 point and are forecasting it to be up approximately 1.5%. For the fourth quarter of 2016, we expect our mainline capacity to be 57.5 billion ASMs and our regional capacity to be 7.84 billion ASMs. So our consolidated capacity will be flat year-over-year in the fourth quarter. 
On the cost side, we're forecasting year-over-year mainline CASM, excluding special items and fuel, to be up approximately 5% to 7% while regional CASM, excluding special items and fuel, is projected to be down approximately 3% to 5%. For the fourth quarter of 2016, we expect our mainline CASM, excluding fuel and special items, to be up between 8% and 10%. This year-over-year increase is driven primarily by investment in our people of about 6 points, maintenance timing of 2 points and D&A from new aircraft and increased CapEx of 1 point. Regional CASM, excluding special items and fuel, is expected to be down by approximately 3% to 5% in the same period. 
As we look forward for the first time since mid-2014, year-over-year fuel prices are expected to be higher through the remainder of the year. Based on the forward curve as of October 17, our mainline fuel price forecast for the fourth quarter of 2016 is $1.59 to $1.64 per gallon, while our regional fuel forecast for the fourth quarter is $1.65 to $1.70. Despite these higher fuel prices, we expect the full year 2016 consolidated fuel expense to decrease by approximately $1.2 billion year-over-year. 
Using the midpoints of the guidance we just provided, along with the revenue guidance that Robert will give, we expect our fourth quarter pretax margin, excluding special items, to be between 4% and 6%. 
For capital expenditures, we still expect total gross CapEx to be approximately $4.4 billion in 2016. We have 20 deliveries worth approximately $1.1 billion, which will occur in the fourth quarter. And we expect to invest $300 million in non-aircraft CapEx in the quarter, which is $1.2 billion for the full year, which includes continued integration work and investments to improve our product and operations, some that Doug referred to in his comments. 
Looking now to 2017. We are taking a disciplined approach to matching our planned capacity levels with anticipated levels of demand. We are still in the process of developing our operating plan, so our formal capacity guidance will come out when we report fourth quarter earnings. But we currently expect our year-over-year system capacity to be up approximately 1% in 2017. We expect full year 2017 domestic capacity to be flat, while our international capacity is expected to be up approximately 3.5%. Our international growth is driven primarily by our Pacific entity as we annualize the new routes added in 2016. 
We'll also know more about our 2017 unit cost projections after we complete our operating plan, but as Doug noted, we now have the bulk of our cost increases behind us. As we look to 2017, we expect the full year impact of our labor agreements will add approximately 2 points of CASM. But otherwise, our core CASM growth should be around 2% on a very modest 1% growth in ASMs. And as Doug also noted, with the integration nearing completion, we will be able to begin the process of eliminating some redundancies in 2017, which will help our unit cost in 2018 and beyond. 
So in conclusion, we couldn't be more proud of more than 100,000 team members who continue to deliver outstanding results. We continue to make great progress integrating our airlines most recently with our flight operating system cut over, and we've already seen some positive results. We are also excited about the commercial initiatives our team is working on and looking forward to reporting on their continued success on future calls. 
Thanks again for your time this morning. And with that, I'll turn it over to Robert.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Derek. Good morning to everyone. Appreciate that you're joining us. I'd like to start out by thanking our 100,000 team members for their outstanding work during the quarter. And I'd characterized this quarter as being one of operational and commer
componenttext:
Thanks, Derek. Good morning to everyone. Appreciate that you're joining us. I'd like to start out by thanking our 100,000 team members for their outstanding work during the quarter. And I'd characterized this quarter as being one of operational and commercial challenges. But I would like to underscore positively that we have executed integration items exceptionally well. despite all these challenges, our team's commitment to taking care of our customers and each other has never wavered. 
Summer ops performance was challenging for both our employees and customers. The primary driver was inclement weather that seemed to settle over a number of our hubs throughout the summer, most notably Dallas, or DFW. in addition, we struggled to operate our expanded Los Angeles schedule reliably, primarily due to airport and facility constraints. We're working with LAWA, so that we will be better able to meet our customers' demands to fly American from Los Angeles going forward. 
I'm happy to report that our reliability has rebounded to near-record levels across our system in September as a result of a number of factors, and those trends have continued well into October. And we expect that they will continue. 
Again, I appreciate the efforts of our frontline team to take care for customers throughout the summer and especially, and most recently, during Hurricane Matthew. 
We have successfully completed some major integration milestones over the past few months, including a single-flight operating system for our pilots, dispatch and aircraft. And I'm so appreciative of our 15,000 pilots, the APA, our IT and flight ops teams for their efforts to ensure a seamless cutover. 
We've also put new uniforms on all of our employees. We have interim agreements with our fleet service and mechanic workgroups, tentative agreements now with our flight crew training instructors and SIM engineers. And once these tentative agreements have been ratified, all American team members will be benefiting from pay increases that resulted from our merger. So much of what we're striving to accomplish going forward would be difficult to address without having the integration work completed and completed well. 
As we start to think about our plans for next year, there's good reason to believe that American will improve versus the industry in operations performance. We're taking a fresh look at how we schedule our aircraft reliability. Our 777-200 reconfigurations will be completed by December 2017. Our 787 fleet has reached a critical mass, allowing for easier recovery from off-scheduled ops. And with the single-flight operating system, our aircraft and pilots can now be used interchangeably instead of being managed as separate entities. We're also making big investments in service recovery and customer notification tools for passengers and employees that will continue to rollout next year. 
On the revenue front, our third quarter TRASM was down 2.2%. While the revenue environment is still challenging in certain areas of the world, we have observed improvements in many places. Third -- the third quarter was much better than the second quarter, so we continue to see improving trends. As Doug noted, in September, we had positive year-over-year TRASM and PRASM, and that's the first time this has occurred since November of 2014. And we're seeing improving trends in cargo as well. September marked the first time since December 2014 that our monthly year-over-year cargo revenue has improved. 
Domestically, consolidated PRASM was down 1.8%. This was our best result since the first quarter of 2015. We saw strength across the board with all hubs having second derivative improvements.  Los Angeles and DCA were top performers year-over-year. 
Internationally, we have lapped the dollar strengthening last year as well as declining international surcharges. Lat-Am was our first entity to turn positive with PRASM up 1.8% for the quarter, driven by a 25% year-over-year improvement in Brazil PRASM as capacity rationalized and the real strengthened. In addition, there was continued strength in Mexico. 
The Atlantic was our worst-performing international entity, down 11.2%. The main drivers of performance are continued capacity increases, specifically from low-cost carriers, the devaluation of the British pound as a result of the Brexit vote and lingering impacts from recent terrorist attacks. 
Across the Pacific, PRASM was down 10.5% and capacity increases of 28.7% with continued weakness in China due to excess capacity and growing into our new services from Los Angeles to Hong Kong, Haneda, Sydney and Auckland. 
We're pleased to see corporate passenger demand holding up, driven by our domestic entity. In the third quarter, we saw increases in both absolute revenue and revenue share. And we see similar trends developing in the fourth quarter. 
Looking forward, we see some choppiness in the fourth quarter due to holiday shifts with September and January benefiting from traffic shifting from October and December. We expect November to be the strongest month in the quarter versus 2015. 
Regionally, the domestic fourth quarter looks about the same as the third quarter due to holidays shifts. 
In Latin America, we expect continued sequential improvement and low single digit increases in PRASM. We expect the Pacific and Atlantic to remain challenging with low double-digit year-over-year PRASM declines. With that, we expect our fourth quarter TRASM, not PRASM, but total RASM to be down 1% to 3% year-over-year. We expect that our fourth quarter decline to be smaller than our third quarter decline despite a more difficult fourth quarter year-over-year comparison. As we look forward to 2017, we expect continued second derivative improvement in year-over-year TRASM performance and look forward to getting to positive TRASM in the first half of the year. 
In conclusion, it's an exciting time to be at American Airlines. We've made a tremendous amount of progress over this past year with respect to integration, operational improvement and getting back on to positive TRASM. All of these important steps are critical to restoring American Airlines to its rightful industry-leading position. We have a lot of work left to do, but we're confident we have the right plans, the right team in place to execute, and we look forward to reporting back on future successes. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call back over to the operator and begin the question-and-answer session.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Derek, you mentioned, again, that you're carrying some excess liquidity as you get through this CapEx bubble that wraps up next year. What's normal liquidity for you guys look like once you get through that?
componenttext: Okay. And then Derek, you mentioned, again, that you're carrying some excess liquidity as you get through this CapEx bubble that wraps up next year. What's normal liquidity for you guys look like once you get through that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, as we've said, we can go down. Our minimum number is going to about $6.5 billion. We do have some things coming up in 2018 with the pension payments. We have about a $1.4 billion pension payment in '18 as we start going forward. So we need
componenttext: Well, I think, as we've said, we can go down. Our minimum number is going to about $6.5 billion. We do have some things coming up in 2018 with the pension payments. We have about a $1.4 billion pension payment in '18 as we start going forward. So we need to look out all the way through that time period to make sure that we have a cap cash levels at that point. And we're very confident where we're at today and where our levels are at today. So I think we can take it down a little bit from here. But I want to make sure that we get through all of the aircraft purchases next year. And then I think, it gets into the -- as we said, $6.5 billion is our minimum that we feel we can go down to and we're significantly above that today. So we have opportunities to continue to return cash to our shareholders.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to add on, Derek, just sort of minimum, it's -- I don't think we're below that. It's a target that we'd like to keep that we think is a safe amount, a good bit more than our competitors. That's what we do rather than what -- in exchange for havin
componenttext: And just to add on, Derek, just sort of minimum, it's -- I don't think we're below that. It's a target that we'd like to keep that we think is a safe amount, a good bit more than our competitors. That's what we do rather than what -- in exchange for having some higher leverage. The way we protect ourselves is making sure we have a lot more cash than everybody else does. So we have target cash balances of $6.5 billion. We're higher than that now. And as -- and we're investing heavily in the airline and in our people. We'll continue to do so because we're investing for the future. To the extent we continue to be well above that number, that's we consider that excess cash, which we can return to our shareholders.

Just talk about Dallas and overall domestic yields.

componenttext: Sure. On the domestic front, as we went through the quarter, we saw improving near-term yield. so yields start to improve across the domestic business starting in August. and from a RASM perspective, we saw improved near-end RASM build going back to April. As for Dallas, in particular, August was the last tranche of the Southwest expansion for Dallas. And when we look at the Dallas performance right now, it's really in line with performance across the rest of the system.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. And then a little more on debt, Derek. Scott said you don't believe in artificial debt targets. Your stock has been doing nicely. Your RASM is getting better. At a certain point here, people are going to start moving away from it if you're not, I th
componenttext: Good. And then a little more on debt, Derek. Scott said you don't believe in artificial debt targets. Your stock has been doing nicely. Your RASM is getting better. At a certain point here, people are going to start moving away from it if you're not, I think, perceived to be taking a more assertive approach on your balance sheet. Again, next 3, 6 months, as RASM gets better, it's fine. But you're running the risk of people sort of transitioning to more quality stocks in the space, if you will, if you're not taking a sort of approach on debt. So maybe talk about rather than just talking about liquidity. Let's talk about debt holistically. And is there any thoughts providing -- making a slide that shows where you want to be on debt targets over the next 2, 3, 4 years? Because it works for Delta and I think it's a nice story to tell for somebody [indiscernible] only? Is that might be a little putoff as everybody's RASM gets better, midpoint and next year?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just let me start. This is Doug. So -- and then Derek can provide details. But first off, I would just -- I -- frankly, we don't  agree with the premise and shareholders can make their own decisions obviously based upon what we do. But our view is the
componenttext: So just let me start. This is Doug. So -- and then Derek can provide details. But first off, I would just -- I -- frankly, we don't  agree with the premise and shareholders can make their own decisions obviously based upon what we do. But our view is the best thing for our shareholders, is to ensure that we have a sufficient amount of liquidity to withstand any sort of downturn. But the cost of getting to -- of worrying about credit ratings is in a business where we can -- we're borrowing against aircraft of 3%. It doesn't necessarily -- actually, it doesn't seem to be -- that goal, in and of itself, doesn't seem to be in our shareholders' best interest. So somewhat -- it's somewhat surprised with shareholder -- with people like you who'd push back on this [indiscernible] year's out because we think we're doing what's best for our shareholders. At the end of the day, we're producing -- we are producing profits at levels we've -- this industry has never seen before, but consistent with what other industries do. We're very bullish on our ability to continue doing that over time. As we do so, the first thing we do is invest back in our company. This company needs a good bit of investments. We're investing at levels that no airlines ever invested before. The aircraft modernization I talked about has now at aircraft levels that are  -- at age levels that are well below our competitors, something like around 10 years and falling for us in 16, 17 years and increasing for them. And then investing -- on top of that, it's something as Derek said, $1.5 billion next year on improvements in the airlines. That's -- those are good investments, and we're excited about those. And those will provide return shares to our shareholders. Those are long-lived assets. They're -- we're not off spending it on ancillary businesses or trying to do something we're not. We're doing what we think is right, and we feel very good about that. That investment now returns to shareholders. Once we do that, then we look to make sure we've paid down any high-end cost debt. We've done that. Derek and his team have done a phenomenal job of getting to while we have a larger amount of debt on the balance sheet than it appears. The cost of that debt is low. And as we look to each -- the incremental decision, by the way, comes down to that. We're adding airplanes as we do this modernization, should we use some of our cash balance to pay for those aircraft or should we avail ourselves of the 3% debt. And we think the best thing for our shareholders is to avail ourselves of the 3% debt. That leaves us with cash balances that are in excess of the target. And we think the right thing to do with that is to return to our shareholders. But the way we protect ourselves is having a much higher liquidity balance than others. That's the cost of it, but it's a much less costly thing than paying -- than not availing yourself a low-cost debt. I mean, the other point I want to make is, even if we did those things, even if we started paying cash for aircraft, we still have higher debt. It's because we have better assets. When you have airplanes that are 9 years old versus someone else's 17 years, you're going to have higher debt because you have much better assets. And they're going to be here for a long time. As are we -- and that's why we're doing this. So Saudi Arabia, this is -- we believe we're in the right spot. We're very comfortable with our leverage. We're very comfortable with our balance sheet. And we're doing the right thing for our shareholders.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's seasonal. They do better in third quarter than we do. Now is the answer, I expect what you'll see in '17 is us do better than our competitors in terms of, certainly, year-over-year margins. You're seeing it already in the RASM, and that will c
componenttext: Yes, that's seasonal. They do better in third quarter than we do. Now is the answer, I expect what you'll see in '17 is us do better than our competitors in terms of, certainly, year-over-year margins. You're seeing it already in the RASM, and that will continue into '17. You'll see on the cost front, as Derek noted, we -- the reason the margins declined even though we're having better RASM right now, of course, is because our CASM is up more. That's because we've gone in taking care of our people faster and gotten ourselves to a point where we have, in every work group, less than 3 years since the merger, we now have everyone on new pay scales that reflect the job they're doing for us, and that's increased our cost, but [indiscernible] they're well below. We had to do that. We're happy we did that. Our shareholders should be happy we did that. But it's behind us now. We have one of those that was done mid-year, which is the TWIM, as Derek talked about, so that will have a year-over-year impact, but it's in the current cost structure. And beyond that, we'll be able to see any sort of other cost increase certainly over and above kind of inflationary rates in the airline. So I think what you'll see, as we go through '17, is better revenue per ASM improvement on year-over-year basis and better cost performance as well.

componenttext: Thanks, Jamie. So with basic economy, we've been -- as you know, we've been working on for some time, and we're on track. We're prepared to launch at the end of this year. I want to avoid the holidays and disruption to our folks. And so we're on track and ready to go. But any details on that, you're going to have to wait until we roll out. And we're not, at this time, making any projections on revenue performance associated with the product.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then just my second question for Bob -- or Robert. We -- you've talked about basic economy and rolling that out in early 2017. headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: For international Premium Economy, the great news is that we're seeing it come out on our 787-900 deliveries, which is fantastic news. And as those ramp up, we'll have critical mass to start selling. Right now, you can buy into those seats, which is good
componenttext: For international Premium Economy, the great news is that we're seeing it come out on our 787-900 deliveries, which is fantastic news. And as those ramp up, we'll have critical mass to start selling. Right now, you can buy into those seats, which is good news. And as we get to the point of being able to offer it consistently next year, we'll be able to start selling the Premium Economy cabin.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, we are doing the modifications. We have to go through on all of our wide-body aircraft, the ones that aren't delivered with it. The brunt -- the biggest portion of them will start coming in '18, so we'll have all of those aircraft going through
componenttext: Yes, Mike, we are doing the modifications. We have to go through on all of our wide-body aircraft, the ones that aren't delivered with it. So we will monetize those seats through probably MCE, our Main Cabin Extra, product that we have today until we get to the critical mass and then we'll be able to put out -- roll out the Premium Economy. So I think that it's more of an '18 impact than it is a '17 impact due to having to modify all of our wide-body aircraft for that product.

componenttext: Perhaps, we don't know yet. If it is not material versus all the other stuff we have our IT group doing in terms of integration otherwise, so there may be something that that's not a large issue for us.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question is, when you think about your headcount, I know you guys have talked about it being overstaffed as you work through all the integration. So as we look ahead to maybe 2018 and there's -- I assume we're going to reduce thro
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question is, when you think about your headcount, I know you guys have talked about it being overstaffed as you work through all the integration. So as we look ahead to maybe 2018 and there's -- I assume we're going to reduce through attrition, what's like the normalized level we should be thinking about?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's work through and give you that numbers overtime. I'm not sure we know that number yet. What we know is, we do indeed have, because we're still not fully integrated, a number of areas around the company where we have not just more people, but more re
componenttext: Let's work through and give you that numbers overtime. I'm not sure we know that number yet. What we know is, we do indeed have, because we're still not fully integrated, a number of areas around the company where we have not just more people, but more resources that we need in all sorts of areas. So we will make sure we do it in a way that's as quickly as we can and also in a way that takes care of our employees, that's really important to us. So that's a big project for us through 2017. I wouldn't expect it would be able to yield major cost savings in 2017 because we'd still be running into airlines for a good part of 2017, but that's a big focus of the team's efforts to move forward us to be sure that we are indeed endeavoring to make sure we don't get to every one airline and still have the infrastructure of 2. So we'll work through it. As we know more, we'll let you know. But now that it's -- I mean, it's not insignificant that we wouldn't talk about it. It's something that's going to be able to yield some nice cost improvement, and it should. Part of why our costs are where they are right now is because we're running 2 separate airlines in a lot of areas, and we'll work through that as we go through 2017.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just real, the other question I just had with Atlantic and your joint venture with BA and Iberia and the other carriers. I mean, have you been able to sort of think through what the right level of capacity is, given that huge increasing cap
componenttext: Okay. And then just real, the other question I just had with Atlantic and your joint venture with BA and Iberia and the other carriers. I mean, have you been able to sort of think through what the right level of capacity is, given that huge increasing capacity from, what I would call, low-fare in other airlines on the North Atlantic this past summer and what is likely to be next summer? May be too far away, but I'm sure you're giving it some thought.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, I mean, Don again correct me if I am wrong, but I mean, we have to be careful of our [indiscernible] market capacity, of course, the capacity plans based on others. What we know is, while those other carriers are having an impact, what we fly is
componenttext: You know, I mean, Don again correct me if I am wrong, but I mean, we have to be careful of our [indiscernible] market capacity, of course, the capacity plans based on others. What we know is, while those other carriers are having an impact, what we fly is incredibly important to American Airlines. And we don't have no material plans to doing anything other than what we're doing right now, and we plan to continue to do so. It's a huge part of our network, and important part of our network, important to our customers and the relationship with BA, our BAs are very important ones. So the -- as capacity comes on from others, of course, be able to swallow, and we work through those things. But I don't expect you'll see us just decide that we're the ones who should be looking to impair our capacity going. Don?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add in the upcoming winter season where actually we're reducing our capacity by about 6%, and so we are taking some actions. And those capacity reductions are focused to the markets where we face with structural challenges. But where we have par
componenttext: I'll just add in the upcoming winter season where actually we're reducing our capacity by about 6%, and so we are taking some actions. And those capacity reductions are focused to the markets where we face with structural challenges. But where we have partners, we continue to maintain our capacity going forward.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up to actually where Joe started the conversation on capacity. If we look at this year, I think you spreaded out about 3%, and we're finishing up about 140 basis points below that. Could you quantify how much of that was due to reg
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up to actually where Joe started the conversation on capacity. If we look at this year, I think you spreaded out about 3%, and we're finishing up about 140 basis points below that. Could you quantify how much of that was due to regional supply constraints? And I wonder if you would be willing to get specific on republics restructuring, what were the aircraft you expected to be forming in the original plan that went away?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Duane, I think it would be hard for us to break that out right now, but it's -- our reductions are really a result of not only a little bit due to regional supportability due to pilot concerns, but also South American concerns and then just adjust
componenttext: Yes, so Duane, I think it would be hard for us to break that out right now, but it's -- our reductions are really a result of not only a little bit due to regional supportability due to pilot concerns, but also South American concerns and then just adjustment throughout the system. So I think that where we stand right now is where we need to be, and we've got a fleet and a wrap network that's meeting the demand that we think that's out there.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in our reductions, of course, we're still increasing -- it's not increasing the rate, but at one point in the future we forecast where we would be. So it's not because of aircraft numbers, it's because of utilization of aircraft that we respond to dem
componenttext: And in our reductions, of course, we're still increasing -- it's not increasing the rate, but at one point in the future we forecast where we would be. So it's not because of aircraft numbers, it's because of utilization of aircraft that we respond to demand. So that's really was going on here, Duane, for the most part. You know, we look out a few quarters and think where we may be based on the aircraft we have, and we have common. And then as we get closer and see what's happening with demand, we may make schedule changes, and that's what's happened here.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay, I may follow-up you on -- I thought you had mentioned some impact from Republic previously, but I can follow up you know to...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry.
componenttext: I'm sorry.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, this is overall of the short fall. About 1/3 of that comes from total regional issues. Some of that is, of course, Republic. Some of it is issues associated with pilots flight, other partner regionals and our wholly-owned as well.
componenttext: Duane, this is overall of the short fall. About 1/3 of that comes from total regional issues. Some of that is, of course, Republic. Some of it is issues associated with pilots flight, other partner regionals and our wholly-owned as well.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Joe, this is Derek. We did put in our Q that we have reached agreement with Republic on a go-forward plan, which did take out about 25 aircraft out of the contract, so we've reached that agreement with them. Obviously, they still have a process to go
componenttext: And Joe, this is Derek. We did put in our Q that we have reached agreement with Republic on a go-forward plan, which did take out about 25 aircraft out of the contract, so we've reached that agreement with them. Obviously, they still have a process to go through to get out of bankruptcy, but our deal moving forward has reduced aircraft, and we're in pretty good shape where we're at with the Republic.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. And then Robert, I wanted to ask a question kind of old order structure versus new order structure. What were some of the less than optimal aspects of kind of getting a network plan from the other side of the house and then you having
componenttext: Okay. That's great. And then Robert, I wanted to ask a question kind of old order structure versus new order structure. What were some of the less than optimal aspects of kind of getting a network plan from the other side of the house and then you having to deliver that from an operational perspective? And I guess, more importantly, what are the implications of an engineer, and I mean that in a very flattering way, of an engineer now ordering both the network plan and ops?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, thanks. Look, our company has been so focused on integration, merger, huge initiatives that the adjustments that we've made in terms of order structure are really designed now that we're getting past so many of the major integration milestones. To
componenttext: Duane, thanks. Look, our company has been so focused on integration, merger, huge initiatives that the adjustments that we've made in terms of order structure are really designed now that we're getting past so many of the major integration milestones. To start looking at how we can really optimize running the company day to day. And to do that, we know that we've got to collaborate, and we all have to be focused on the same goals. And I think we've gotten an order structure and fantastic people running each of the operating groups and they're committed to doing that. And so any difficulties that we've had, I think, we're just going to be more well-suited to collaborate, communicate and make sure that we're all aligned going forward.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jack Atkins with Stephens.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jack Atkins with Stephens.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, just following up on that last question for a moment, Robert. Now that you're in your new role, has the strategy at all changed with -- as far as the competition what the ULC sees in your markets? And then as you look at your network today, ar
componenttext: So I guess, just following up on that last question for a moment, Robert. Now that you're in your new role, has the strategy at all changed with -- as far as the competition what the ULC sees in your markets? And then as you look at your network today, are there any specific items or projects now that you're in your new role that you look to sort of undertake over the next 12 months?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thanks for the question. Hey, look, I've been part of this management team since the get go. So in terms of how we go-to-market and the strategies that we're intending to pursue, I feel like I've been part of those. And the direction that we're having
componenttext: So thanks for the question. Hey, look, I've been part of this management team since the get go. So in terms of how we go-to-market and the strategies that we're intending to pursue, I feel like I've been part of those. And the direction that we're having isn't going to change. We're going to be incredibly competitive with all comers, especially in our hubs. And so you won't see much of a change in terms of philosophy as we go to the marketplace and compete. Yes, in terms of going forward, there's things we want to do, we want to certainly excel at. One of them is running a fantastic airline, one that is best in the business on all levels, and that's operational as well as revenue performance and certainly, from a perspective of meeting customer's expectations. That's going to require that we really engage all of our people in a way that we haven't before. And so I do view going forward that one of the primary points of emphasis that we're going to make is involving all of our people and making sure that they are in equipped and well trained and treated in a fashion where they help us outperform the industry. So from -- there's a lot of other things that we have going on. Certainly, we want to make sure that we have all of our forward-looking strategies with alliances, alliance partners, our network in the best fashion. But it all leads to the same place, which is having the best network, the best people and the best product for our customers.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jack, it's Doug, too. That's a great answer by Robert, but also I just want to chime in a little bit, specifically, on the ULCC piece that you mentioned. As Robert said, there's absolutely no change. What we need we have to compete aggressively on pr
componenttext: Hey, Jack, it's Doug, too. That's a great answer by Robert, but also I just want to chime in a little bit, specifically, on the ULCC piece that you mentioned. As Robert said, there's absolutely no change. What we need we have to compete aggressively on price against carriers like that and when they come -- when they add flights to our hubs, we actually have a competitive advantage because we have so much connecting activity. The one game-changer, maybe a big stretch of the work, but actually, certainly an improvement in how we can do that and still not -- and still be as good for American Airlines as it can be is basic economy. And so that product we have in place will allow us to do just that, but not have the same amount of dilution we have to American Airlines. So the impact to the spheres and the frontiers would be the same, we would aggressively match their prices but since -- as we put that product in place, it will have some attributes that some of customers would rather don't  care to purchase or want to purchase other attributes for more. And right now, as we match, we don't agree much, we're not able to do that. So that will allow us to do what we're doing today, continue to do what we're doing today as Robert says what we're going to do, but also do it in a way that allows us to provide another -- more utility to our customers and give them a product in addition to the ones of the absolutely lowest fare.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I guess just a follow-up question. It seems as though whether it's cabin segmentation or international revenue opportunities or reducing redundancies in the organization over the next couple of years, there's a huge revenue and cost oppor
componenttext: Okay, great. And I guess just a follow-up question. It seems as though whether it's cabin segmentation or international revenue opportunities or reducing redundancies in the organization over the next couple of years, there's a huge revenue and cost opportunity at American, which should drive significant current profitability. And I'm just sort of curious as you guys think about how to communicate that going forward. Is there going to be, maybe, an opportunity for us to get from you guys detailed financial targets long-term? Because I think that way it would be really helpful to understand the earnings better here?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for the comment. We'll take it under advisement. I understand the value that it could provide, just know that I've been doing this way too long and I'm often reluctant to do -- depends on how we define the target. But what I don't like doing
componenttext: Okay, thanks for the comment. We'll take it under advisement. I understand the value that it could provide, just know that I've been doing this way too long and I'm often reluctant to do -- depends on how we define the target. But what I don't like doing is suggesting that we can project the future in this business. It is incredibly volatile, it will be volatile. I think it will be profitable, I think it's dramatically changed. But the volatility doesn't change. So we sometimes are less comfortable than others trying to set things like margins -- margin targets when we know that some things that affect those margins are outside of our control, primarily the economy and fuel prices. So I'll tell you this, we couldn't feel better about American Airlines' future and its financial future. And I also will tell you that based on what we think about the future, we're extremely bullish on the American stock, which is why we continue to purchase at the levels we do, because as we look out, targets are known targets, our projections even in difficult economic environments have this company be nice and profitable, and it doesn't feel like our stock reflects that. So we're happy to give you that guidance and let you do your own numbers. But what we do the way we manage the company is make sure we're optimizing for the long term, and we're doing all those things. But we are remised to try and tell you that when we add those up here little, it looks like to us and, therefore, here's what we will produce, because we know there's a lot of volatility in what we're able to produce and our job is just to make sure we can manage around that volatility. We can, we're excited about that. We'll work to see if we can give you some more guidance as we have in the past about longer term. But just understand that's our concern.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the opportunities on the cost side now that the integration is largely behind you. We've seen structural cost-reduction programs a few years after the other mergers. And when do you think American could announce something similar? And w
componenttext: Can you talk about the opportunities on the cost side now that the integration is largely behind you. We've seen structural cost-reduction programs a few years after the other mergers. And when do you think American could announce something similar? And where more specifically are some of the opportunities?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think as we talked about on the call, we're going to be going through '17 from a -- we have talked about having excess headcount in certain areas just duplication of work just because we're running 2 different airlines. That's the primary a
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think as we talked about on the call, we're going to be going through '17 from a -- we have talked about having excess headcount in certain areas just duplication of work just because we're running 2 different airlines. That's the primary area that we'll work on as we move forward. As we said in the call, I think we're going to look at that stuff starting in '17, and it will start to affect us in '18. So I think what we want to do is, we're going to go through the budget in '17, we're going to see where everything is and then try to work with each one of the teams to figure out how we take that out over the time period into '18. But I think it's more, as we've talked about, an '18 issue than it is a '17 issue. Mostly, it is just inefficiencies of trying to run 2 different airlines all throughout the company. It's not just one point, it's all throughout the company as we've tried to get ourselves where we want to be from an airline and running the best airline we can.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just a question on capacity in Latin America. You guys have, obviously, taken a lot of capacity out and you're certainly seeing the benefits of that today. How are you thinking about presuming growth, now that the entity has turned. And are you w
componenttext: And then just a question on capacity in Latin America. You guys have, obviously, taken a lot of capacity out and you're certainly seeing the benefits of that today. How are you thinking about presuming growth, now that the entity has turned. And are you worried about latent capacity coming back in next year?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julie, it's Robert. For us, it's a wait-and-see. We're pleased with the signs of some growth, and we're going to hold onto that for a while and see where things go.
componenttext: Julie, it's Robert. For us, it's a wait-and-see. We're pleased with the signs of some growth, and we're going to hold onto that for a while and see where things go.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one final one. Robert, when would you expect the transatlantic PRASM to -- trends to flatten out?
componenttext: Okay. And one final one. Robert, when would you expect the transatlantic PRASM to -- trends to flatten out?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Don, again. We do not see it in the foreseeable future. Capacity in the first quarter, industry capacity is going to be up 7%, and we don't see signs of that abating. And until that abates, it's going to be hard to see a positive trajectory in the At
componenttext: It's Don, again. We do not see it in the foreseeable future. Capacity in the first quarter, industry capacity is going to be up 7%, and we don't see signs of that abating. And until that abates, it's going to be hard to see a positive trajectory in the Atlantic.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan McKenzie from Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan McKenzie from Buckingham Research.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, this would be for Robert or Don. Does the revenue guide factor in the potential loss of the codeshare with Alaska? And how material could that impact be if it's lost?
componenttext: I guess, this would be for Robert or Don. Does the revenue guide factor in the potential loss of the codeshare with Alaska? And how material could that impact be if it's lost?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The revenue guide does not. And I don't think, if we did, it would change. So it wouldn't be materially impacting to the guidance.
componenttext: The revenue guide does not. And I don't think, if we did, it would change. So it wouldn't be materially impacting to the guidance.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, Doug or Derek, my question was on debt as well. So we all know absolute debt levels are higher than they've been historically. But with respect to the underlying business, I wonder if you could just help investors understand the l
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, Doug or Derek, my question was on debt as well. So we all know absolute debt levels are higher than they've been historically. But with respect to the underlying business, I wonder if you could just help investors understand the leverage metrics relative to where they've been historically, maybe on an American standalone basis. So leverage metrics today relative to some average over some period of time that makes sense. And as you look at those metrics and as you feel comfortable about those metrics, is it that you expect profits to continue growing faster than the debt? And I wonder if you could just up us understand what do those metrics look like under your stress test?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And thanks for bringing me back because I know when I said it, we're comfortable. What I meant was we're comfortable with where it is at this time, because looking to the future what we expect is you'll see those metrics continue to improve. I want
componenttext: Sure. And thanks for bringing me back because I know when I said it, we're comfortable. What I meant was we're comfortable with where it is at this time, because looking to the future what we expect is you'll see those metrics continue to improve. I want to try and suggest we're comfortable in keeping them exactly where they are, although we may be. But the reason we're comfortable with them at this time is because of what you say, we have very good line of sight as to what our capital requirements are going forward. We have a very -- we have -- we feel good about our -- certainly, even on a very -- in difficult economic times, stress testing, I guess, even things like recession about what our earnings would do as we go forward. So those -- that gives us comfort that we are in a good spot right now and when things come up like 3% interest, it seems to be an absolute no-brainer to us that the right thing to do is to take those debts on rather than using cash to pay airplanes and to use that cash for better purposes. So that's where we're comfortable about. What happens over time, I would expect and again, without giving the targets, is you will see, certainly, that the metrics that are tied, the coverage ratios, for example, tie earnings to debt levels, you'll see those get better over time, and the earnings get better. And as earnings get better and the debt gets lower, we are also, I should note, while we're well ahead of everyone in terms of modernizing our fleet, there will come a time that we've got gotten that done in the not too distant, and you won't see the debt continue to come out at these levels. So as debt gets lower overtime and earnings continue, and EBITDA or margins set or stay where they are, you'll see those numbers get better. And that's why we're comfortable with where we are today. We are comfortable where we are today because of the reasons I said and believe we have the right structure in place. As insurance, we carry a lot more cash than others. But we think that's the better way to do this for our shareholders than to go and pay cash for airplanes rather taking a 3% debt.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes Darryl Genovesi from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes Darryl Genovesi from UBS.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, just to follow up on some of your comments around aircraft age. I know you inherited a significant majority of your order book from your predecessor. But is it the longer-term plan to maintain the same relative age advantage over your competitors th
componenttext: Doug, just to follow up on some of your comments around aircraft age. I know you inherited a significant majority of your order book from your predecessor. But is it the longer-term plan to maintain the same relative age advantage over your competitors that you have today? Because I think doing so would imply a much different longer term CapEx profile than allowing the fleet age to mean revert?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, aircraft age is not a metric that we look at to measure versus our competitors. I'm just pointing out where it is. But we don't have a goal to say, we need to be below the others in aircraft age. But it's noteworthy, particularly when we get to conve
componenttext: Yes, aircraft age is not a metric that we look at to measure versus our competitors. I'm just pointing out where it is. But we don't have a goal to say, we need to be below the others in aircraft age. But it's noteworthy, particularly when we get to conversations about relative debt levels to point out how much stronger our asset base is my only point. And the best way for me to communicate that to you is to point out how much younger our fleet is. Look, it is absolutely a customer advantage, when you get one [indiscernible] new airplanes, there is one of of our other airplanes, there is no doubt that it is a much better in-flight product and you can tell the difference. So we feel good about that. But you're right, the orders were in place and they're coming, and we're taking them. But the bigger point I'm trying to make here is these are -- if you look in the very near term, you may say, oh my gosh, these guys -- they have all these debt. These are 25-year assets, and those airlines that have 17-year-old airplanes won't be able to have 42-year-old airplanes 25 years from now. So at some point -- my point is we're ahead of them, and I'm suggesting they need to go, spend enormous amount of capital in the very near term, but they will need to do something, and we won't have to at that point in time, that's way that works. So anyway our goal is to make sure we have the absolute youngest, it's nice when you're in that position. But to the extent you want to look at relative debt levels, you need to look at the asset base, and our asset base is just worth tremendously more than what theirs are.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, I guess, a way just to ask you on -- or maybe Robert, whoever wants to comment, can you just give us some sense of how your view on your Phoenix hub is evolving, given your recent, I'll say, emphasis on Los Angeles and the existing presen
componenttext: Great. And then, I guess, a way just to ask you on -- or maybe Robert, whoever wants to comment, can you just give us some sense of how your view on your Phoenix hub is evolving, given your recent, I'll say, emphasis on Los Angeles and the existing presence of Dallas?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, I appreciate it. Phoenix have does well for us. It serves the same purpose that we viewed it as over since the start of the merger, and it's a great connecting hub. It's got a growing metro area, and it's serving our network very well.
componenttext: Thanks, I appreciate it. Phoenix have does well for us. It serves the same purpose that we viewed it as over since the start of the merger, and it's a great connecting hub. It's got a growing metro area, and it's serving our network very well.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And L.A. is different, it's largely international gateway that we feed and are looking to expand. But they're complementary, not competitive.
componenttext: And L.A. is different, it's largely international gateway that we feed and are looking to expand. But they're complementary, not competitive.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one question for Robert. I guess, when I look at your on time performance stats, they really start to lag both your network peers starting about 6 months ago or so. Is there a reason for this? Is anything going on with the integration that would have
componenttext: Just one question for Robert. I guess, when I look at your on time performance stats, they really start to lag both your network peers starting about 6 months ago or so. Is there a reason for this? Is anything going on with the integration that would have caused this? I can't imagine that it's all the L.A. issues that you mentioned in your prepared remarks. And I know you mentioned solid corporate share earlier, but have you heard anything from your corporate customers on this performance?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the answer in terms of corporate customers, the answer is no. We haven't heard anything. We're performing very well, as I said, in my remarks with our corporate business. So in terms of this summer and the fall, that's really where I look at things and
componenttext: So the answer in terms of corporate customers, the answer is no. We haven't heard anything. We're performing very well, as I said, in my remarks with our corporate business. So in terms of this summer and the fall, that's really where I look at things and it is associated with the schedule where I think we -- just quite frankly, we're pretty aggressive in terms of the schedule that we put out this summer. We had issues in Los Angeles. We definitely had, I think, an inordinate amount of weather issues associated with DFW and then Charlotte and Miami, and that was problematic. So it seems like we're in a recovery phase a lot of during the summer. As I said before, we have a lot of integration tools that we didn't have, but we will have in the future and that is on building the airline back after disruption and making sure our customers and their baggage is taken care of. One of the things you'll note though is that we continue to be really strong in terms of our departing on time performance, the D0 performance. That's something that we'll continue to see. And I think that, that will translate into more competitive arrivals within 14 performance. And you'll see as well, that in our completion factor as we move from operating 2 systems and really 3 systems in regard to our pilots down to 1, that we've got a chance to do much, much better. So I'm very optimistic of where we're headed. And if you take a look at where we're at right now, schedule reduction associated with the fall season with changes to our Los Angeles operation, we're operating back at near record levels and that should continue. And again, as I said before all efforts are focused on making sure that we work together to put out a schedule in 2017 that we can operate reliably and competitively with the best in the business.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that ends the analysts' questions We will now take questions from the media. [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Andrea Ahles with Forth Worth Star-Telegram.
componenttext: And that ends the analysts' questions We will now take questions from the media. [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Andrea Ahles with Forth Worth Star-Telegram.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would like to follow-up a little bit on Helane Becker's question regarding the possibility on reducing headcount and how that might be done in 2017. Are you looking at actually doing sort of any layoffs or reductions enforced, particularly in headquarte
componenttext: I would like to follow-up a little bit on Helane Becker's question regarding the possibility on reducing headcount and how that might be done in 2017. Are you looking at actually doing sort of any layoffs or reductions enforced, particularly in headquarters where you may have overlapping functions as you operate -- as you go from operating 2 airlines down into 1? Can you give a little more color or detail on that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, absolutely not. Glad you asked, we made it sound that way. We have through pockets of the airline in different groups, we will have -- we have, because we're running 2 airlines, we have more people when we get that down to 1. But we will manage that
componenttext: Sure, absolutely not. Glad you asked, we made it sound that way. We have through pockets of the airline in different groups, we will have -- we have, because we're running 2 airlines, we have more people when we get that down to 1. But we will manage that over time through attrition, through -- if it makes sense, if it's a labor group early outs, whatever works for our people, I do make sure we do that. We're not -- we don't have any intention that we care to go through like you described, we'll do this in a way that works for our team.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Mary Schlangenstein with Bloomingburg News.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Mary Schlangenstein with Bloomingburg News.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to follow up on Andrew's question. Do you guys some sense of the number of positions that you're talking about that you have redundancy across your workforce?
componenttext: So I want to follow up on Andrew's question. Do you guys some sense of the number of positions that you're talking about that you have redundancy across your workforce?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing we can talk about. Again, this is more of a beyond 2017 issue. And we're going to do the work through 2017. We still do have 2 airlines with our customers we know, but we still have 2 fleets, we make it separate, we still have flights that are not
componenttext: Nothing we can talk about. Again, this is more of a beyond 2017 issue. And we're going to do the work through 2017. We still do have 2 airlines with our customers we know, but we still have 2 fleets, we make it separate, we still have flights that are not integrated. While we have that going on, we can't do any of this work what we endeavor through 2017 to figure out where it is. And as we know more, we'll let people know more. The good news in this is, we have regular attrition rates. We have raised people to look to retire early, and we'll work through those things as it becomes an issue. Right now, we're just -- the reason we mentioned it is something because it's important to the analyst community to understand it that will be something that comes beyond 2017.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So you will only consider things like early retirements, buyouts, and no involuntary furloughs is what you're saying?
componenttext: Right. So you will only consider things like early retirements, buyouts, and no involuntary furloughs is what you're saying?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we sit here today, Mary, that's what I think, it's correct. Your decisions can change, and also I want to make the sound like some enormous number of people. So we have pockets of people throughout the organization, as I said. And we'll work throu
componenttext: Yes, as we sit here today, Mary, that's what I think, it's correct. Your decisions can change, and also I want to make the sound like some enormous number of people. So we have pockets of people throughout the organization, as I said. And we'll work through and make sure this works out for those, who are either looking to leave or want to leave on their own as we have natural attrition at workplace. So this is nothing about furloughs and layoffs, all about the fact that as you move from 2 airlines to truly 1 airline, we'll be able to get some cost efficiencies.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Next, we have Edward Russell with Flightglobal.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a bit more about the Premium Economy rollout on the rest of the wide-body fleet. You outlined target of getting it done in 2017, yet I wanted to -- with the business class rollout, that ended up being delayed. I mean, how do you plan to ac
componenttext: I wanted to ask a bit more about the Premium Economy rollout on the rest of the wide-body fleet. You outlined target of getting it done in 2017, yet I wanted to -- with the business class rollout, that ended up being delayed. I mean, how do you plan to achieve the rollout into 2017?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Edward, the Premium Economy is, actually, going to go on our A330-200 fleet, the 777-200s, 777-300s and then our 787 fleet. And as we said 78, 79s are starting now and, as Don mentioned, we should have for sale in terms of a different class of service
componenttext: So Edward, the Premium Economy is, actually, going to go on our A330-200 fleet, the 777-200s, 777-300s and then our 787 fleet. And as we said 78, 79s are starting now and, as Don mentioned, we should have for sale in terms of a different class of service next year. But reconfigurations are going to take place over the course of the next really 18 months, 24 months, so we're not going to be ready along all those fleets until June of 2018.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay, got it. And how many -- roughly, how many do you forecast the reduction on the number of economy seats on these aircraft as you make the modifications? Or are they just an installation, is it going to be a neutral?

componenttext: I think we're talking about a road generally, and I think so that are very different aircraft types, but that should be the way how it rolls out.
