componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple here. On the credit card deal with the MasterCard exclusivity, Derek, I guess I missed that when the original press release came out. I just -- I know you had a really long-term relationship with Visa. So is there any sort of incremental ben
componenttext: Just a couple here. On the credit card deal with the MasterCard exclusivity, Derek, I guess I missed that when the original press release came out. I just -- I know you had a really long-term relationship with Visa. So is there any sort of incremental benefit? Or were the numbers that you gave us when that was announced, does that also include moving over to MasterCard from Visa?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That includes moving over to MasterCard.
componenttext: That includes moving over to MasterCard.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just my second question for Bob -- or Robert. We -- you talked about basic economy and rolling that out in early 2017. I guess, can you talk about the international Premium Economy, which, I believe, is actually rolling out this week
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just my second question for Bob -- or Robert. We -- you talked about basic economy and rolling that out in early 2017. I guess, can you talk about the international Premium Economy, which, I believe, is actually rolling out this week? How long is it going to take to ramp up across your international system? And what should we think about potential revenue upside from putting this product out across your fleet? And by the way, when do you get it fully up and running?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: For international Premium Economy, the great news is that we're seeing it come out on our 787-900 deliveries, which is fantastic news. And as those ramp up, we'll have critical mass to start selling. Right now, you can buy into those seats, which is good
componenttext: For international Premium Economy, the great news is that we're seeing it come out on our 787-900 deliveries, which is fantastic news. And as those ramp up, we'll have critical mass to start selling. Right now, you can buy into those seats, which is good news. And as we get to the point of being able to offer it consistently next year, we'll be able to start selling the Premium Economy cabin.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, we are doing the modifications. We have to go through on all of our wide-body aircraft, the ones that aren't delivered with it. The brunt -- the biggest portion of them will start coming in '18, so we'll have all of those aircraft going through
componenttext: Yes, Mike, we are doing the modifications. We have to go through on all of our wide-body aircraft, the ones that aren't delivered with it. The brunt -- the biggest portion of them will start coming in '18, so we'll have all of those aircraft going through Mod in '17. So we will monetize those seats through probably MCE, our Main Cabin Extra product that we have today until we get to the critical mass and then we'll be able to put out -- roll out the Premium Economy. So I think that it's more of an '18 impact than it is a '17 impact due to having to modify all of our wide-body aircraft for that product.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Don. I'll just add that we've also -- we have to actually create the infrastructure and saber to sell a fourth cabin. And that's a big IT project that's underway right now. And that is -- we're expected to have that completed in the early next yea
componenttext: This is Don. I'll just add that we've also -- we have to actually create the infrastructure and saber to sell a fourth cabin. And that's a big IT project that's underway right now. And that is -- we're expected to have that completed in the early next year. We'll start selling the fourth cab in mid-February for flights beginning the beginning of April.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we think about the magnitude kind of the run rate on this, is this like $0.5 billion, $750 million type program when it's up and running? Is that -- or am I just way out the ballpark on that?
componenttext: When we think about the magnitude kind of the run rate on this, is this like $0.5 billion, $750 million type program when it's up and running? Is that -- or am I just way out the ballpark on that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't know, Mike, that we've given those numbers, but, anyways, it hundreds of millions of dollars, I think we're quite comfortable saying that. And it's a great product for our customers. In addition, we've seen -- frankly, the way we saw this was
componenttext: Yes, I don't know, Mike, that we've given those numbers, but, anyways, it hundreds of millions of dollars, I think we're quite comfortable saying that. And it's a great product for our customers. In addition, we've seen -- frankly, the way we saw this was being able to look at our partners' information, BA doing similar flying as we were across the Atlantic and getting higher RASM because of this product, it helps in a number of ways. So we're excited about it. It certainly is -- it's a meaningful impact to our customers and to our revenues.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Helane Becker with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Helane Becker with Cowen and Company.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have just a couple of questions. The first is, do you have to make any changes in IT to accommodate the rule the DOT issued yesterday with respect to on-time performance, specifically?
componenttext: I have just a couple of questions. The first is, do you have to make any changes in IT to accommodate the rule the DOT issued yesterday with respect to on-time performance, specifically?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perhaps, we don't know yet. If it is, it's not material versus all the other stuff we have our IT group doing in terms of integration otherwise, so there may be something we need to do but that's not a large issue for us.
componenttext: Perhaps, we don't know yet. If it is, it's not material versus all the other stuff we have our IT group doing in terms of integration otherwise, so there may be something we need to do but that's not a large issue for us.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question is, when you think about your headcount, I know you guys have talked about it being overstaffed as you work through all the integration. So as we look ahead to maybe 2018 and there's -- I assume we're going to reduce thro
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question is, when you think about your headcount, I know you guys have talked about it being overstaffed as you work through all the integration. So as we look ahead to maybe 2018 and there's -- I assume we're going to reduce through attrition, what's like the normalized level we should be thinking about?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let us work through and give you the numbers over time. I'm not sure we know that number yet. What we know is, we do indeed have, because we're still not fully integrated, a number of areas around the company where we have not just more people, but more r
componenttext: Let us work through and give you the numbers over time. I'm not sure we know that number yet. What we know is, we do indeed have, because we're still not fully integrated, a number of areas around the company where we have not just more people, but more resources than we need in all sorts of areas. So we will make sure we do it in a way that's -- as quickly as we can and also in a way that takes care of our employees, that's really important to us. So that's a big project for us through 2017. I wouldn't expect it would be able to yield major cost savings in 2017 because we'd still be running 2 airlines for a good part of 2017, but that's a big focus of the team's efforts to move forward is to be sure that we are indeed endeavoring to make sure we don't get to have one airline and still have the infrastructure of 2. So we'll work through it. As we know more, we'll let you know. But know that it's -- I mean, it's not insignificant or we wouldn't talk about it. It's something that we think is going to be able to yield some nice cost improvement, and it should. Part of why our costs are where they are right now is because we're running 2 separate airlines in a lot of areas, and we'll work through that as we go through 2017.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just real, the other question I just had with the Atlantic and your joint venture with BA and Iberia and the other carriers. I mean, have you been able to sort of think through what the right level of capacity is, given that huge increasing
componenttext: Okay. And then just real, the other question I just had with the Atlantic and your joint venture with BA and Iberia and the other carriers. I mean, have you been able to sort of think through what the right level of capacity is, given that huge increasing capacity from what I would call low-fare and other airlines on the North Atlantic this past summer and what is likely to be next summer? Maybe too far away, but I'm sure you're giving it some thought.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, Don again, chime in if I am wrong, but I mean, we got to be careful of our market capacity, of course, the capacity plans based on others. What we know is, while those other carriers are having an impact, what we fly is incredibly important to Ame
componenttext: I mean, Don again, chime in if I am wrong, but I mean, we got to be careful of our market capacity, of course, the capacity plans based on others. What we know is, while those other carriers are having an impact, what we fly is incredibly important to American Airlines. And don't have any material plans to doing anything other than what we're doing right now, and plan to continue to do so. It's a huge part of our network, an important part of our network, important to our customers and the relationship with BA and Iberia's a very important one. So the -- as capacity comes on from others, of course, deals follow and we work through those things. But I don't expect you'll see us just decide that we're the ones who should be looking to have our capacity go away. Don?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add in the upcoming winter season where actually we're reducing our capacity by about 6%, and so we are taking some action. And those capacity reductions are focused on the markets where we're faced with structural challenges. But where we have
componenttext: I'll just add in the upcoming winter season where actually we're reducing our capacity by about 6%, and so we are taking some action. And those capacity reductions are focused on the markets where we're faced with structural challenges. But where we have partners, we continue to maintain our capacity going forward.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Evercore ISI.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up to actually where Joe started the conversation on capacity. If we look at this year, I think you spread it out about 3%, and we're finishing up about 140 basis points below that. Could you quantify how much of that was due to re
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up to actually where Joe started the conversation on capacity. If we look at this year, I think you spread it out about 3%, and we're finishing up about 140 basis points below that. Could you quantify how much of that was due to regional supply constraints? And I wonder if you would be willing to get specific on republics restructuring, what were the aircraft you expected to be forming in the original plan that went away?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Duane, I think it would be hard for us to break that out right now, but it's -- our reductions are really a result of not only a little bit due to regional supportability due to pilot concerns, but also South American concerns and then just adjust
componenttext: Yes, so Duane, I think it would be hard for us to break that out right now, but it's -- our reductions are really a result of not only a little bit due to regional supportability due to pilot concerns, but also South American concerns and then just adjustment throughout the system. So I think that where we stand right now is where we need to be, and we've got a fleet and a wrap network that's meeting the demand that we think that's out there.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, in our reductions, of course, we're still increasing -- it's not increasing a rate, but at one point in the future we forecast what it would be. So it's not because of aircraft numbers, it's because of utilization of aircraft that we respond to
componenttext: And again, in our reductions, of course, we're still increasing -- it's not increasing a rate, but at one point in the future we forecast what it would be. So it's not because of aircraft numbers, it's because of utilization of aircraft that we respond to demand. So that's really what's going on here, Duane, for the most part. We look out a few quarters and think where we may be based on the aircraft we have and what we have coming. And then as we get closer in and see what's happening with demand, we may make schedule changes, and that's what's happened here.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I may follow-up you on -- I thought you had mentioned some impact from Republic previously, but I can follow up to...
componenttext: Okay, I may follow-up you on -- I thought you had mentioned some impact from Republic previously, but I can follow up to...

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry.
componenttext: I'm sorry.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, this is just overall of the shortfall. About 1/3 of that comes from total regional issues. Some of that is, of course, Republic. Some of it is issues associated with pilots flight, other partner regionals and our wholly owneds as well.
componenttext: Duane, this is just overall of the shortfall. About 1/3 of that comes from total regional issues. Some of that is, of course, Republic. Some of it is issues associated with pilots flight, other partner regionals and our wholly owneds as well.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Joe, this is Derek. We did put in our Q that we have reached agreement with Republic on a go-forward plan, which did take out about 25 aircraft out of the contract, so we've reached that agreement with them. Obviously, they still have a process to go
componenttext: And Joe, this is Derek. We did put in our Q that we have reached agreement with Republic on a go-forward plan, which did take out about 25 aircraft out of the contract, so we've reached that agreement with them. Obviously, they still have a process to go through to get out of bankruptcy, but our deal moving forward has reduced aircraft, and we're in pretty good shape where we're at with Republic.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. And then Robert, I wanted to ask you a question kind of old work structure versus new work structure. What were some of the less than optimal aspects of kind of getting a network plan from the other side of the house and then you havin
componenttext: Okay. That's great. And then Robert, I wanted to ask you a question kind of old work structure versus new work structure. What were some of the less than optimal aspects of kind of getting a network plan from the other side of the house and then you having to deliver that from an operational perspective? And I guess, more importantly, what are the implications of an engineer, and I mean that in a very flattering way, of an engineer now owning both the network plan and ops?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duane, thanks. Look, our company has been so focused on integration, merger, huge initiatives that the adjustments that we've made in terms of work structure are really designed now that we're getting past so many of the major integration milestones to st
componenttext: Duane, thanks. Look, our company has been so focused on integration, merger, huge initiatives that the adjustments that we've made in terms of work structure are really designed now that we're getting past so many of the major integration milestones to start looking at how we can really optimize the running of the company day to day. And to do that, we know that we've got to collaborate, and we all have to be focused on the same goals. And I think we've gotten a work structure and fantastic people running each of the operating groups and they're committed to doing that. And so any difficulties that we've had, I think we're just going to be more well-suited to collaborate, communicate and make sure that we're all aligned going forward.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jack Atkins with Stephens.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jack Atkins with Stephens.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, just following up on that last question for a moment, Robert. Now that you're in your new role, has the strategy at all changed with -- as far as the competition with the ULCCs in your markets? And then as you look at your network today, are t
componenttext: So I guess, just following up on that last question for a moment, Robert. Now that you're in your new role, has the strategy at all changed with -- as far as the competition with the ULCCs in your markets? And then as you look at your network today, are there any specific items or projects now that you're in your new role that you look to sort of undertake over the next 12 months?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thanks for the question. Look, I've been part of this management team since the get-go. So in terms of how we go to market and the strategies that we're intending to pursue, I feel like I've been part of those. And the direction that we're headed isn't
componenttext: So thanks for the question. Look, I've been part of this management team since the get-go. So in terms of how we go to market and the strategies that we're intending to pursue, I feel like I've been part of those. And the direction that we're headed isn't going to change. We're going to be incredibly competitive with all comers, especially in our hubs. And so you won't see much of a change in terms of philosophy as we go to the marketplace and compete. Yes, in terms of going forward, there's things we want to do, we want to certainly excel at. One of them is running a fantastic airline, one that is best in the business on all levels, and that's operational as well as revenue performance and certainly, from a perspective of meeting customer's expectations. That's going to require that we really engage all of our people in a way that we haven't before. And so I do view going forward that one of the primary points of emphasis that we're going to make is involving all of our people and making sure that they are equipped and well trained and treated in a fashion where they help us outperform the industry. So from -- there's a lot of other things that we have going on. Certainly, we want to make sure that we have all of our forward-looking strategies with alliances, alliance partners, our network in the best fashion. But it all leads to the same place, which is having the best network, the best people and the best product for our customers.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jack, it's Doug, too. That's a great answer by Robert, but also I just want to chime in a little bit, specifically, on the ULCC piece you mentioned. As Robert said, there's absolutely no change. We need, we have to, compete aggressively on price against c
componenttext: Jack, it's Doug, too. That's a great answer by Robert, but also I just want to chime in a little bit, specifically, on the ULCC piece you mentioned. As Robert said, there's absolutely no change. We need, we have to, compete aggressively on price against carriers like that and when they come -- when they add flights to our hubs, we actually have a competitive advantage because we have so much connecting activity. The one game-changer, maybe a big stretch of the word, but actually, certainly an improvement in how we can do that and still not -- and still be as good for American Airlines as it can be is basic economy. And so that product we have in place will allow us to do just that, but not at the same amount of dilution we have to American Airlines. So the impact to the spheres and the frontiers would be the same, we would aggressively match their prices but since -- as we put that product in place, it will have some attributes that some of our customers would rather don't care to purchase or are willing to purchase other attributes for more. And right now, as we match, pretty much, we're not able to do that. So that will allow us to do what we're doing today, continue to do what we're doing today, which as Robert says what we're going to do, but also do it in a way that allows us to provide another -- more utility to our customers and give them a product in addition to the ones at the absolute lowest fare.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I guess just a follow-up question. It seems as though whether it's cabin segmentation or international revenue opportunities or reducing redundancies in the organization over the next couple of years, there's a huge revenue and cost oppor
componenttext: Okay, great. And I guess just a follow-up question. It seems as though whether it's cabin segmentation or international revenue opportunities or reducing redundancies in the organization over the next couple of years, there's a huge revenue and cost opportunity at American, which should drive significant profitability. And I'm just sort of curious as you guys think about how to communicate that going forward. Is there going to be, maybe, an opportunity for us to get from you guys detailed financial targets long-term? Because I think that way it would be really helpful to understand the earnings power here?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for the comment. We'll take it under advisement. I understand the value that it could provide, just know that I've been doing this way too long and I'm often reluctant to do -- it depends on how we define the target. But what I don't like doi
componenttext: Okay, thanks for the comment. We'll take it under advisement. I understand the value that it could provide, just know that I've been doing this way too long and I'm often reluctant to do -- it depends on how we define the target. But what I don't like doing is suggesting that we can project the future in this business. It is incredibly volatile; it will be volatile. I think it will be profitable, I think it's dramatically changed. But the volatility doesn't change. So we sometimes are less comfortable than others trying to set things like margins -- margin targets when we know that some things that affect those margins are outside of our control, primarily the economy and fuel prices. So I'll tell you this, we couldn't feel better about American Airlines' future and its financial future. And I also will tell you that based on what we think about the future, we're extremely bullish on the American stock, which is why we continue to purchase at the levels we do, because as we look out, targets or no targets, our projections even in difficult economic environments have this company being nice and profitable, and it doesn't feel like our stock reflects that. So we're happy to give you that guidance and let you do your own numbers. But what we do the way we manage the company is make sure we're optimizing for the long term, and we're doing all those things. But we are remiss to try and tell you that when we add those up here's what it looks like to us and, therefore, here's what we will produce, because we know there's a lot of volatility in what we're able to produce and our job is just to make sure we can manage around that volatility. We can, we're excited about that. We'll work to see if we can give you some more guidance than we have in the past about longer term. But just understand that's our concern.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Julie Yates with Crédit Suisse.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Derek, can you talk about the opportunities on the cost side now that the integration is largely behind you? We've seen structural cost-reduction programs a few years after the other mergers. And when do you think American could announce something similar
componenttext: Derek, can you talk about the opportunities on the cost side now that the integration is largely behind you? We've seen structural cost-reduction programs a few years after the other mergers. And when do you think American could announce something similar? And where more specifically are some of the opportunities?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think as we talked about on the call, we're going to be going through '17 from a -- we have talked about having excess headcount in certain areas, just duplication of work just because we're running 2 different airlines. That's the primary
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think as we talked about on the call, we're going to be going through '17 from a -- we have talked about having excess headcount in certain areas, just duplication of work just because we're running 2 different airlines. That's the primary area that we'll work on as we move forward. As we said in the call, I think we're going to look at that stuff starting in '17, and it will start to affect us in '18. So I think what we want to do is, we're going to go through the budget in '17, we're going to see where everything is and then try to work with each one of the teams to figure out how we take that out over the time period into '18. But I think it's more, as we've talked about, an '18 issue than it is a '17 issue. Mostly, in just inefficiencies of trying to run 2 different airlines all throughout the company. It's not just one point, it's all throughout the company as we've tried to get ourselves where we want to be from an airline and running the best airline we can.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just a question on capacity in Latin America. You guys have, obviously, taken a lot of capacity out and you're certainly seeing the benefits of that today. How are you thinking about presuming growth, now that the entity has turned? And are you w
componenttext: And then just a question on capacity in Latin America. You guys have, obviously, taken a lot of capacity out and you're certainly seeing the benefits of that today. How are you thinking about presuming growth, now that the entity has turned? And are you worried about latent capacity coming back in next year?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julie, it's Robert. For us, it's a wait-and-see. We're pleased with the signs of some growth, and we're going to hold onto that for a while and see where things go.
componenttext: Julie, it's Robert. For us, it's a wait-and-see. We're pleased with the signs of some growth, and we're going to hold onto that for a while and see where things go.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one final one. Robert, when would you expect the transatlantic PRASM to -- trends to flatten out?
componenttext: Okay. And one final one. Robert, when would you expect the transatlantic PRASM to -- trends to flatten out?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Don, again. We do not see it in the foreseeable future. Capacity in the first quarter, industry capacity is going to be up 7%, and we don't see signs of that abating. And until that abates, it's going to be hard to see a positive trajectory in the At
componenttext: It's Don, again. We do not see it in the foreseeable future. Capacity in the first quarter, industry capacity is going to be up 7%, and we don't see signs of that abating. And until that abates, it's going to be hard to see a positive trajectory in the Atlantic.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan McKenzie with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan McKenzie with Buckingham Research.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess this would be for Robert or Don. Does the revenue guide factor in the potential loss of a codeshare with Alaska? And how material could that impact be if it's lost?
componenttext: I guess this would be for Robert or Don. Does the revenue guide factor in the potential loss of a codeshare with Alaska? And how material could that impact be if it's lost?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The revenue guide does not. And I don't think, if we did, it would change. So it wouldn't be material impact to the guidance.
componenttext: The revenue guide does not. And I don't think, if we did, it would change. So it wouldn't be material impact to the guidance.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, Doug or Derek, my question was on debt as well. So we all know absolute debt levels are higher than they've been historically. But with respect to the underlying business, I wonder if you could just help investors understand the l
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, Doug or Derek, my question was on debt as well. So we all know absolute debt levels are higher than they've been historically. But with respect to the underlying business, I wonder if you could just help investors understand the leverage metrics relative to where they've been historically, maybe on an American standalone basis. So leverage metrics today relative to some average over some period of time that makes sense. And as you look at those metrics and as you feel comfortable about those metrics, is it that you expect profits to continue growing faster than the debt? And I wonder if you could just help us understand what do those metrics look like under your stress test?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And thanks for bringing me back to it because I know when I said it, we're comfortable. What I meant was we're comfortable with where it is at this time, because looking to the future what we expect is you'll see those metrics continue to improve. I
componenttext: Sure. And thanks for bringing me back to it because I know when I said it, we're comfortable. What I meant was we're comfortable with where it is at this time, because looking to the future what we expect is you'll see those metrics continue to improve. I wasn't trying to suggest we're comfortable in keeping them exactly where they are, although we may be. But the reason we're comfortable with them at this time is because of what you say, we have very good line of sight as to what our capital requirements are going forward. We have a very -- we have -- we feel good about our -- certainly, even on a very -- in difficult economic times, stress testing against even things like recession about what our earnings would do as we go forward. So those -- that gives us comfort that we are in a good spot right now and when things come up like 3% interest, it seems to be an absolute no-brainer to us that the right thing to do is to take those debts on rather than using cash to pay airplanes and to use that cash for better purposes. So that's where we're comfortable with that. What happens over time, I would expect, and again, without giving the targets, is you will see, certainly, that the metrics that are tied, the coverage ratios, for example, that tie earnings to debt levels, you would see those get better over time, the earnings continue to get better. And as earnings get better and the debt gets lower, we are also, I should note, while we're well ahead of everyone in terms of modernizing our fleet, there will come a time that we've gotten that done in the not too distant future, and you won't see the debt continue to come out at these levels. So as debt gets lower over time and earnings continue, and EBITDA or margins, etc., stay where they are, you'll see those numbers get better. And that's why we're comfortable with where we are today. We're comfortable where we are today because of the reasons I said and believe we have the right structure in place. As insurance, we carry a lot more cash than others. But we think that's the better way to do this for our shareholders than to go and pay cash for airplanes rather than taking 3% debt on.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes Darryl Genovesi with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes Darryl Genovesi with UBS.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, just to follow up on some of your comments around aircraft age. I know you inherited a significant majority of your order book from your predecessor. But is the longer-term plan to maintain the same relative age advantage over your competitors that
componenttext: Doug, just to follow up on some of your comments around aircraft age. I know you inherited a significant majority of your order book from your predecessor. But is the longer-term plan to maintain the same relative age advantage over your competitors that you have today? Because I think doing so would imply a much different longer term CapEx profile than allowing the fleet age to mean revert?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, aircraft age is not a metric that we look at to measure versus our competitors. I'm just pointing out where it is. But we don't have a goal to say, we need to be below the others in aircraft age. But it's noteworthy, particularly when we get to conve
componenttext: Yes, aircraft age is not a metric that we look at to measure versus our competitors. I'm just pointing out where it is. But we don't have a goal to say, we need to be below the others in aircraft age. But it's noteworthy, particularly when we get to conversations about relative debt levels, to point out how much stronger our asset base is my only point. And the best way for me to communicate that to you is to point out how much younger our fleet is. Look, it is absolutely a customer advantage, when you get one onboard new airplanes, there is one of our older airplanes, there is no doubt that it is a much better in-flight product and you can tell the difference. So we feel good about that. But you're right, the orders were in place and they're coming, and we're taking them. But the bigger point I'm trying to make here is these are -- if you look in the very near term, you may say, "Oh my gosh, these guys -- they have all this debt." These are 25-year assets, and those airlines that have 17-year-old airplanes won't be able to have 42-year-old airplanes 25 years from now. So at some point -- my point is we're ahead of them, and I'm not suggesting they need to go, spend enormous amount of capital in the very near term, but they will need to do something, and we won't have to at that point in time, that's the way this works. So at any rate, our goal isn't to make sure we have the absolute youngest, it's nice when you're in that position. But to the extent you want to look at relative debt levels, you need to look at the asset base, and our asset base is just worth tremendously more than theirs are.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, I guess, if I could just ask you on -- or maybe Robert, whoever wants to comment, can you just give us some sense of how your view on your Phoenix hub is evolving, given your recent, I'll say, emphasis on Los Angeles and the existing pres
componenttext: Great. And then, I guess, if I could just ask you on -- or maybe Robert, whoever wants to comment, can you just give us some sense of how your view on your Phoenix hub is evolving, given your recent, I'll say, emphasis on Los Angeles and the existing presence of Dallas?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, I appreciate it. The Phoenix hub does well for us. It serves the same purpose that we viewed it as over since the start of the merger, and it's a great connecting hub. It's got a growing metro area, and it's serving our network very well.
componenttext: Thanks, I appreciate it. The Phoenix hub does well for us. It serves the same purpose that we viewed it as over since the start of the merger, and it's a great connecting hub. It's got a growing metro area, and it's serving our network very well.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And L.A. is different; L.A. is largely international gateway that we feed and are looking to expand. But they are complementary, not competitive.
componenttext: And L.A. is different; L.A. is largely international gateway that we feed and are looking to expand. But they are complementary, not competitive.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Andrew Didora with Bank of America.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one question for Robert. I guess, when I look at your on-time performance stats, they really start to lag both your network peers starting about 6 months ago or so. Is there a reason for this? Is anything going on with the integration that would have
componenttext: Just one question for Robert. I guess, when I look at your on-time performance stats, they really start to lag both your network peers starting about 6 months ago or so. Is there a reason for this? Is anything going on with the integration that would have caused this? I can't imagine that it's all the L.A. issues that you mentioned in your prepared remarks. And I know you mentioned solid corporate share earlier, but have you heard anything from your corporate customers on this performance?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the answer in terms of corporate customers, the answer is no. We haven't heard anything. We're performing very well, as I said, in my remarks with our corporate business. So in terms of the summer and the falloff, and that's really where I look at thin
componenttext: So the answer in terms of corporate customers, the answer is no. We haven't heard anything. We're performing very well, as I said, in my remarks with our corporate business. So in terms of the summer and the falloff, and that's really where I look at things and it is associated with the schedule where I think we -- just quite frankly, we were pretty aggressive in terms of the schedule that we put out this summer. We had issues in Los Angeles. We definitely had, I think, an inordinate amount of weather issues associated with DFW and then Charlotte and Miami, and that was problematic. So it seems like we're in a recovery phase a lot of -- during the summer. As I said before, we have a lot of integration tools that we didn't have that we will have in the future and that is on building the airline back after disruption and making sure our customers and their baggage is taken care of. One of the things you'll note though is that we continue to be really strong in terms of our departing on time performance, the D0 performance. That's something that we'll continue to see. And I think that, that will translate into more competitive arrivals within 14 performance. And you'll see as well, that in our completion factor as we move from operating 2 systems and really 3 systems in regard to our pilots down to 1, that we've got a chance to do much, much better. So I'm very optimistic of where we're headed. And if you take a look at where we're at right now, schedule reduction associated with the fall season with changes to our Los Angeles operation, we're operating back at near record levels and that should continue. And again, as I said before, all efforts are focused on making sure that we work together to put out a schedule in 2017 that we can operate reliably and competitively with the best in the business.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that ends the analysts' questions. We will now take questions from the media. [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Andrea Ahles with Fort Worth Star-Telegram.
componenttext: And that ends the analysts' questions. We will now take questions from the media. [Operator Instructions] We'll take our next question from Andrea Ahles with Fort Worth Star-Telegram.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would like to follow-up a little bit on Helane Becker's question regarding the possibility of reducing headcount and how that might be done in 2017. Are you looking at actually doing sort of any layoffs or reductions in force, particularly at headquarte
componenttext: I would like to follow-up a little bit on Helane Becker's question regarding the possibility of reducing headcount and how that might be done in 2017. Are you looking at actually doing sort of any layoffs or reductions in force, particularly at headquarters where you may have overlapping functions as you operate -- as you go from operating 2 airlines down into 1? Can you give a little more color or detail on that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, absolutely not. Glad you asked, we made it sound that way. We have through pockets of the airline in different groups, we will have -- we have, because we're running 2 airlines, we have more people than we'll need when we get down to 1. But we will
componenttext: Sure, absolutely not. Glad you asked, we made it sound that way. We have through pockets of the airline in different groups, we will have -- we have, because we're running 2 airlines, we have more people than we'll need when we get down to 1. But we will manage that over time through attrition, through -- if it makes sense, if it's a labor group early outs, whatever works for our people, to make sure we do that. We're not -- we don't have any intention nor do we care to go through like you described. We'll do this in a way that works for our team.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Mary Schlangenstein with Bloomingburg (sic) [ Bloomberg ] News.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Mary Schlangenstein with Bloomingburg (sic) [ Bloomberg ] News.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Close. So I want to follow up on Andrea's question. Do you guys have some sense of the number of positions that you're talking about that you have redundancy across your workforce?
componenttext: Close. So I want to follow up on Andrea's question. Do you guys have some sense of the number of positions that you're talking about that you have redundancy across your workforce?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing we can talk about. Again, this is more of a beyond 2017 issue. And we're going to do the work through 2017. We still do have 2 airlines. Doesn't look like it with our customers, we know, but we still have 2 fleets we need to keep separate, we stil
componenttext: Nothing we can talk about. Again, this is more of a beyond 2017 issue. And we're going to do the work through 2017. We still do have 2 airlines. Doesn't look like it with our customers, we know, but we still have 2 fleets we need to keep separate, we still have flights that are not integrated. While we have that going on, we can't do any of this work. We'll endeavor through 2017 to figure out where it is. And as we know more, we'll let people know more. But the good news in this is, we have regular attrition rates. We have ways to -- people to look to retire early, and we'll work through those things as it becomes an issue. Right now, we're just -- the reason we mentioned it is simply because it's important to the analyst community to understand it that will be something that comes beyond 2017.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So you will only consider things like early retirements, buyouts, and no involuntary furloughs is what you're saying?
componenttext: Right. So you will only consider things like early retirements, buyouts, and no involuntary furloughs is what you're saying?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we sit here today, Mary, that's what I think is correct. Decisions can change, and also I don't want to make this sound like some enormous number of people. So we have pockets of people throughout the organization, as I said. And we'll work throug
componenttext: Yes, as we sit here today, Mary, that's what I think is correct. Decisions can change, and also I don't want to make this sound like some enormous number of people. So we have pockets of people throughout the organization, as I said. And we'll work through to make sure this works out for those who are either looking to leave or want to leave on their own. As we have natural attrition, we just won't replace them. So this is nothing about furloughs and layoffs, all about the fact that as you move from 2 airlines to truly 1 airline, we'll be able to get some cost efficiencies.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Edward Russell with Flightglobal.
componenttext: Next, we have Edward Russell with Flightglobal.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a bit more about the Premium Economy rollout on the rest of the wide-body fleet. You outlined target of getting it done in 2017, yet I wanted to -- with the business class rollout, that ended up being delayed. I mean, how do you plan to ac
componenttext: I wanted to ask a bit more about the Premium Economy rollout on the rest of the wide-body fleet. You outlined target of getting it done in 2017, yet I wanted to -- with the business class rollout, that ended up being delayed. I mean, how do you plan to achieve the rollout in 2017?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Edward, the Premium Economy is eventually going to go on our A330-200 fleet, the 777-200s, 777-300s and then our 787 fleet. And as we said 78, 79s are starting now and, as Don mentioned, we should have for sale in terms of a different class of service
componenttext: So Edward, the Premium Economy is eventually going to go on our A330-200 fleet, the 777-200s, 777-300s and then our 787 fleet. And as we said 78, 79s are starting now and, as Don mentioned, we should have for sale in terms of a different class of service next year. But reconfigurations are going to take place over the course of the next really 18 months, 24 months, so we're not going to be ready along all those fleets until June 2018.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And how many -- roughly, how many do you forecast the reduction on the number of economy seats on these aircraft as you make the modifications? Or are they just an install issue? And is it going to be a neutral?
componenttext: Okay, got it. And how many -- roughly, how many do you forecast the reduction on the number of economy seats on these aircraft as you make the modifications? Or are they just an install issue? And is it going to be a neutral?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're talking about a road generally, I think, so that will vary on different aircraft types, but that should be about the way it rolls out.
componenttext: I think we're talking about a road generally, I think, so that will vary on different aircraft types, but that should be about the way it rolls out.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Conor Shine with Dallas Morning News.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Conor Shine with Dallas Morning News.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wonder if you could talk a little bit more about the improving TRASM trend? What are the kind of factors that are driving that improvement? Is it just kind of reduction in capacity growth going forward? Or are there other elements to that?
componenttext: I just wonder if you could talk a little bit more about the improving TRASM trend? What are the kind of factors that are driving that improvement? Is it just kind of reduction in capacity growth going forward? Or are there other elements to that?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Don, do you want to take?
componenttext: Yes, Don, do you want to take?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, there are 2 areas that are already driving the growth. One is Latin America. Latin America with Brazil, where we've seen 25% increase in your revenue year-over-year. Mexico is performing strongly. We got positive revenue growth in Mexico. And V
componenttext: Yes, sure, there are 2 areas that are already driving the growth. One is Latin America. Latin America with Brazil, where we've seen 25% increase in your revenue year-over-year. Mexico is performing strongly. We got positive revenue growth in Mexico. And Venezuela is contributing to overall unit revenue growth as well. Domestic business, the trend there really has been positive. As I mentioned earlier, we've seen close in yields strength, we've also seen a stabilized pricing environment that's been pretty tumultuous this year, but as of the late July, it kind of evened out. And when we look at the domestic business from an O&D perspective, we seeing kind of the best and strongest kind of yield performance in connecting and slow markets in the domestic business, which ties a little bit back to my earlier comments on pricing. And also we're seeing the benefits now of the credit card deal that we did in the second quarter as well.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Ted Reed with The Street.
componenttext: Our last question comes from Ted Reed with The Street.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a couple of questions about Latin America, some just answered. But are these gains in Latin America, are they sustainable? How much of an edge do they give you over your competitors with less presence in Latin America? And also when are you goi
componenttext: I just had a couple of questions about Latin America, some just answered. But are these gains in Latin America, are they sustainable? How much of an edge do they give you over your competitors with less presence in Latin America? And also when are you going to be able to make money in Cuba and will this be a factor in improving PRASM in Latin America or will be -- will it be less valuable there?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Don, again. When we look at kind of the trends in Latin America, we would expect -- Brazil was a big factor, obviously, in the overall result, and we're expecting our performance in Brazil in the fourth quarter to be better, materially better than
componenttext: This is Don, again. When we look at kind of the trends in Latin America, we would expect -- Brazil was a big factor, obviously, in the overall result, and we're expecting our performance in Brazil in the fourth quarter to be better, materially better than the performance in the third quarter. So we think our performance in Latin America overall is going to continue to get better. And as for Cuba, I think everyone is struggling a little bit in terms of selling in Cuba. There are a lot of restrictions that are still in place that have made it difficult to sell. Right now, we're seeing the greatest strength in terms of forward booking, in the Havana markets where we've had a long presence with our charter operations. But I think charter -- Cuba is going to be a bit of a long route, I think.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're in it for the long haul. I mean, this is not something we didn't expect, this is really a new market. And so at any rate, we're excited to be the largest carrier there. We're committed to Cuba and making it work, and we'll work through the start-up
componenttext: We're in it for the long haul. I mean, this is not something we didn't expect, this is really a new market. And so at any rate, we're excited to be the largest carrier there. We're committed to Cuba and making it work, and we'll work through the start-up to get it to the point where eventually we all expect it will be.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excited about the startup of Havana on November 30.
componenttext: Excited about the startup of Havana on November 30.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quickly, I assume the vast majority of sales are in the U.S., in Miami?
componenttext: Quickly, I assume the vast majority of sales are in the U.S., in Miami?

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they are.
componenttext: Yes, they are.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that concludes today's question-and-answer session. At this time, I will turn the conference back over to Mr. Dan Cravens for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: And that concludes today's question-and-answer session. At this time, I will turn the conference back over to Mr. Dan Cravens for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Doug. Thanks, everybody. Again, look, the story to this -- from my perspective listening to all this is -- we -- this team when we did this merger less than 3 years ago, the biggest questions we get on this call was concerns about our ability to m
componenttext: This is Doug. Thanks, everybody. Again, look, the story to this -- from my perspective listening to all this is -- we -- this team when we did this merger less than 3 years ago, the biggest questions we get on this call was concerns about our ability to manage the integration. And I couldn't be more pleased with the work the team has done to get through, flawlessly, things like PSS and just now FOS, so the waves hitting here has helped us -- manages through us. But this is a full team effort, which is why it's so hard, it takes cross-functional work while people are trying actually do their full jobs, too. So we are elated that, that concern we've been able to take off your list of concerns, and that's important. But what it's more important about is it shows what a great team we have here and the things we can do and now with much of that work behind us, not all of it, but much of it behind us, we're extremely excited about everything that we have going on, particularly the investments we're making in our people, in our product that will accrue to our customers. And the upside that, that provides us, but we're in this for the long term. We're excited about the long term, and we appreciate your support. Thanks.

headline: American Airlines Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that concludes today's presentation. We thank you all for your participation, and you may now disconnect.
componenttext: And that concludes today's presentation. We thank you all for your participation, and you may now disconnect.
